speaker: Anna
text: Hi Daniel, thanks for joining. Can you hear me okay?

speaker: Daniel
text: Yeah, hi Anna. I can hear you. Can you hear me?

speaker: Anna
text: Yes, I can. Great. Before we start, just a couple of quick things.

speaker: Anna
text: This is an interview about your experiences with career support, including human coaching and AI tools for career questions. It’s voluntary, you can skip any question, and you can stop anytime. With your permission, Im recording it to record audio for transcription.

speaker: Anna
text: Is that okay?

speaker: Daniel
text: Yeah, that’s okay. As long as it’s anonymous, right?

speaker: Anna
text: Yes, exactly. We’ll anonymize everything and use a pseudonym like “Daniel,” and remove identifying details. Are there any topics you’d prefer not to discuss?

speaker: Daniel
text: I think it’s fine. Just… not too much family stuff. Career stuff is okay.

speaker: Anna
text: Totally. We’ll keep it to career-related experiences. If anything feels too personal, tell me and we’ll move on.

speaker: Anna
text: I’m starting the recording now.

speaker: Daniel
text: Okay. 2) Participant context & career situation

speaker: Anna
text: To start, where are you currently in your career, and what career decisions or questions are you dealing with right now?

speaker: Daniel
text: Okay, um… I’m 24, I’m a UX/UI designer. I’m in Germany now, in Berlin. I moved here almost three years ago.

speaker: Daniel
text: And right now I’m kind of stuck in this loop of short projects and freelance gigs like three weeks here  two months there. I can’t land stable work.

speaker: Anna
text: When you say stable, what does that mean for you?

speaker: Daniel
text: Like a proper contract. Not just we’ll pay you as a freelancer, good luck. I mean full-time, or at least part-time but long-term.

speaker: Daniel
text: And honestly, stability also means health insurance not being this constant anxiety. Here it’s… a whole universe. And I’m tired of always applying, always proving myself, always rewriting case studies.

speaker: Anna
text: What’s been the most significant decision or moment for you in the last 6 to12 months?

speaker: Daniel
text: Honestly… whether I should stay in UX or pivot to something differentt. Like product, or maybe UI-only, or even something outside design. Because the junior UX market feels saturated, and also the German language requirement blocks me a lot.

speaker: Anna
text: How often do you see German required in roles you look at?

speaker: Daniel
text: A lot. Like more than half. Even if the job description is in English, they write German is a plus, but then in interviews they ask, Can you work with stakeholders in German?

speaker: Daniel
text: And I’m like… ich kann ein bisschen. But not enough for workshops.

speaker: Anna
text: How would you describe your German level?

speaker: Daniel
text: Maybe B1-ish, but not a clean B1. I can do appointments, Anmeldung, doctor stuff. But professionally, I freeze.

speaker: Daniel
text: English is fine.

speaker: Anna
text: And you moved from another country? Where from?

speaker: Daniel
text: Serbia originally. I studied there and then moved here for career and life reasons. I also had a girlfriend here at the time, but that ended.

speaker: Daniel
text: I stayed anyway.

speaker: Anna
text: Does your residency situation affect the job search?

speaker: Daniel
text: Yes and no. I have a legal residence permit tied to work, but it’s not super fragile right now. Still, employers sometimes ask, and you can feel hesitation.

speaker: Daniel
text: Even when I say, “No sponsorship,” they still look unsure. It’s just extra friction. And for me it adds pressure because I want a contract not only for money, but also for paperwork stability.

speaker: Anna
text: What kind of work have you been doing in your projects?

speaker: Daniel
text: Mostly early-stage startups. One was fintech, like a dashboard redesign. Another was e-commerce, improving checkout.

speaker: Daniel
text: And then a meditation app where it was more UI polish. Sometimes I do end-to-end research planning, interviews, journey maps, wireframes, prototyping in Figma, handoff. But in small projects it’s often like we need UI by next Friday, so you don’t do proper research, you just guess.

speaker: Daniel
text: And that bothers me.

speaker: Anna
text: What bothers you about it?

speaker: Daniel
text: Because I want to be a real UX designer, not just someone making pretty screens. I want to justify decisions, test, measure. But the projects I get are more like survival mode.

speaker: Anna
text: How do you usually search for work?

speaker: Daniel
text: LinkedIn mainly. Also company career pages. Sometimes Wellfound.

speaker: Daniel
text: In Germany I tried StepStone, but it’s very German. And I go to some meetups—UX meetups, design systems meetups. I tried portfolio reviews too.

speaker: Anna
text: What has networking been like for you here?

speaker: Daniel
text: Mixed. People are friendly at meetups, but it’s hard to convert to referrals. You talk, you connect, and then… nothing.

speaker: Daniel
text: And I’m not super outgoing. I can talk, but it costs energy.

speaker: Anna
text: What kind of support do you feel you need most right now?

speaker: Daniel
text: Clarity and strategy. Like, am I applying to the right roles? Is my portfolio wrong?

speaker: Daniel
text: Am I too generalist? Should I specialize? And also confidence.

speaker: Daniel
text: After many rejections, I start thinking I’m the problem. But I also know the market is tough. So it’s both.

speaker: Daniel
text: 3) Career support in general

speaker: Anna
text: When you need career support like practical or emotional then who or what do you usually turn to?

speaker: Daniel
text: Friends first. I have one friend who’s a developer. He’s good for keep going, but he doesn’t understand design hiring.

speaker: Daniel
text: I talk to my sister back home sometimes, but she’s like, Just get any job, which isn’t helpful hahaha.

speaker: Anna
text: Yeah, my mother does the same hahaha. I understand. What about more formal support like career services, mentors, coaches?

speaker: Daniel
text: I tried a career service once, like an integration center thing. They helped with German CV format. Lebensrough?

speaker: Daniel
text: Basic stuff. It felt generic and more for traditional roles. And then I used ADPList, which is more design-specific.

speaker: Anna
text: Any other resources?

speaker: Daniel
text: YouTube, honestly. Portfolio tips, case study tips. Medium articles too, but it’s too much content.

speaker: Daniel
text: And sometimes I use ChatGPT for rewriting bullet points or prepping for interviews.

speaker: Anna
text: What tends to feel genuinely helpful?

speaker: Daniel
text: Something actionable. Like, change this section of your case study, or your headline is unclear, or here are keywords you’re missing.If it’s concrete, I can do it. If it’s motivational talk, it feels nice for a moment, but then I still don’t know what to do.

speaker: Anna
text: And what feels unhelpful?

speaker: Daniel
text: Advice that ignores context. Like, just network more, without understanding language barriers or how drained I am. Or just do a personal project, when I already did three and I also need money.

speaker: Daniel
text: Context-blind advice. 4) Human coaching: experience & trust

speaker: Anna
text: You mentioned ADPList. Can you walk me through your experience? How many sessions did you did, what you expected, and how it went overall?

speaker: Daniel
text: I used ADPList maybe six sessions over about a year, with different mentors. I expected portfolio feedback, career direction, maybe interview prep.

speaker: Anna
text: What was the experience like in most sessions?

speaker: Daniel
text: Most were okay. Not horrible. But not a wow.

speaker: Daniel
text: A lot were surface-level. Like they glance at the portfolio and say looks good, and then they talk about their own career a lot. And I’m sitting there thinking, okay, but what do I do tomorrow?

speaker: Daniel
text: You know?

speaker: Anna
text: Can you describe one session that felt neutral or disappointing what happened?

speaker: Daniel
text: Yeah. One mentor was a senior designer at a huge tech company. I booked him because I thought he’d know about hiring.

speaker: Daniel
text: He was clearly smart, but he was rushing. He kept checking another screen. And he kept saying, where is your impact?

speaker: Daniel
text: Where are your metrics? And I said, i was freelance, I don’t have metrics. And he was like, then create metrics.

speaker: Daniel
text: And I was like… how? I can’t invent numbers. And he said, you can approximate.That triggered a trust issue for me.

speaker: Daniel
text: I don’t want to lie.

speaker: Anna
text: What did that do to your trust in him?

speaker: Daniel
text: It dropped. I trusted his competence in big-tech storytelling, but I didn’t trust his alignment with me, and I didn’t trust the ethics of what he was suggesting. Also he didn’t ask questions about my situation, Germany, language, anything.

speaker: Daniel
text: It was like a template advice.

speaker: Anna
text: Was there anything about safety or confidentiality that mattered in that moment?

speaker: Daniel
text: Yeah, because it’s a stranger. You’re already a bit vulnerable. And when someone is distracted, you don’t feel safe to open up.

speaker: Daniel
text: So you keep it superficial.

speaker: Anna
text: And you said one session felt truly helpful. Can you describe that one?

speaker: Daniel
text: That was with a mentor who worked at a mid-size German company. She was also an immigrant, from Brazil. And I think it mattered because she understood the stress.

speaker: Daniel
text: She started by asking questions: my story, what I tried, what I want, constraints. She asked about my German level, and how I present myself in interviews. She also asked what stability means for me like contract, team, insurance.

speaker: Daniel
text: It felt structured.

speaker: Anna
text: What did she do that built trust for you?

speaker: Daniel
text: She was fully present. She took notes and told me she’s taking notes. She shared her screen and made a little structure, goal constraints strengths, gaps, actions.

speaker: Daniel
text: Then she gave feedback in a gentle way. She said my portfolio is visually strong, but the case studies read like a story without decisions. And she gave me a framework: problem, role, options considered, decision, result, reflection.

speaker: Daniel
text: Then she told me to pick two projects and rewrite them using that.

speaker: Anna
text: Did anything change after that session?

speaker: Daniel
text: Yes. I rewrote one case study. I changed my LinkedIn headline.

speaker: Daniel
text: She suggested I apply to “Product Designer” roles instead of “UX/UI Designer,” because in Germany the naming is different. She also told me to add a line like Deutsch B1 working on it instead of hiding it. That felt honest.

speaker: Anna
text: If you think about trust in human mentors, what are your personal trust triggers?

speaker: Daniel
text: Competence, empathy, structure. And humility. If someone says, i don’t know that’s fine.

speaker: Daniel
text: If they pretend, I hate it. And being fully present matters a lot.

speaker: Anna
text: And what makes you distrust?

speaker: Daniel
text: Overconfidence, generic advice, distraction. Also when mentors push their own path like it’s universal. And sometimes the power imbalance, like they treat take-home tasks as nothing, but for me it’s unpaid time I can’t afford.

speaker: Daniel
text: 5) AI tools: experience & trust

speaker: Anna
text: Now let’s talk about AI tools like ChatGPT. How do you use them for career-related questions?

speaker: Daniel
text: Mostly for rewriting. I paste bullet points and ask it to make them more concise or more impact-oriented. Sometimes I ask for keyword ideas from job descriptions.

speaker: Daniel
text: It’s like a writing assistant.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you give a concrete example where it helped?

speaker: Daniel
text: I had a bullet like designed onboarding screens for fintech app. Very flat. ChatGPT suggested stronger phrasing like redesigned onboarding flow by simplifying steps and improving clarity.

speaker: Daniel
text: It also gave me versions without fake metrics, if I ask it not to invent numbers. That helped me upgrade the tone.

speaker: Anna
text: And a moment where it failed or felt untrustworthy?

speaker: Daniel
text: One time I asked how to answer Why did you move to Germany? and it gave me this super polished, fake-sounding story about german innovation culture, and it didn’t sound like me. It also assumed a visa type incorrectly, like it just made an assumption.

speaker: Daniel
text: That reminded me that I don't know my life.

speaker: Anna
text: Do you have privacy concerns when using it?

speaker: Daniel
text: Yes. I don’t paste sensitive info. I remove company names sometimes, or I generalize.

speaker: Daniel
text: I’m cautious.

speaker: Anna
text: When you think about “trust” in AI, what does trust mean for you?

speaker: Daniel
text: Accuracy and boundaries. It should be able to say it’s unsure, but it rarely does. It always gives an answer.

speaker: Daniel
text: And I trust it more when it explains the changes, like why a sentence is stronger.

speaker: Anna
text: Do you ever use it for emotional support during the job search?

speaker: Daniel
text: Sometimes. When I get rejected I ask how to cope. It’s comforting in a shallow way because it doesn’t judge me.

speaker: Daniel
text: But it doesn’t replace a friend. 6) Human vs AI comparison via tasks

speaker: Anna
text: I’m going to name a few tasks, and for each one tell me whether you’d prefer a human coach, AI, or both, and why. For improving CV or LinkedIn wording?

speaker: Daniel
text: AI first. It’s fast, cheap, and I can iterate without feeling embarrassed. Then maybe a human to check if it sounds authentic and aligned.

speaker: Anna
text: For deciding what roles to apply for UX, product designer, something else?

speaker: Daniel
text: Human or hybrid. AI gives generic lists. A human can ask about my preferences and constraints, and also understand Germany context.

speaker: Daniel
text: But it has to be a good match.

speaker: Anna
text: For interview preparation?

speaker: Daniel
text: Hybrid. AI for practicing phrasing and structure, human for feedback on how I come across, tone, confidence, if my story lands.

speaker: Anna
text: For values clarification, figuring out what you really want?

speaker: Daniel
text: Human. AI gets cliche there. A human can hold silence and challenge me in a useful way.

speaker: Anna
text: For handling rejection and motivation?

speaker: Daniel
text: Honestly, friends. But if it’s between AI and coach, then human. AI can help at 2 a.m.

speaker: Daniel
text: with calming words, but it’s limited.

speaker: Anna
text: I want to add a quick rating moment. From 0 to 10, how would you rate your trust in human career coaches or mentors for your situation?

speaker: Daniel
text: I’d say 6.

speaker: Anna
text: Why 6?

speaker: Daniel
text: Because humans can be great, and I experienced that. But it’s inconsistent. So I trust the concept, not automatically the person.

speaker: Anna
text: And your trust in AI tools like ChatGPT, 0 to 10?

speaker: Daniel
text: Maybe 5.

speaker: Anna
text: Why 5?

speaker: Daniel
text: It’s useful, but it can hallucinate and miss context. I trust it for writing support, not for truth.

speaker: Anna
text: Now effectiveness. How effective has human coaching been for your situation overall, 0 to 10?

speaker: Daniel
text: Effectiveness… maybe 4.

speaker: Anna
text: Why 4?

speaker: Daniel
text: Because only one session really changed things. The rest felt like noise. And I still don’t have stable work, so overall impact is low.

speaker: Anna
text: And effectiveness of AI tools for your situation, 0 to 10?

speaker: Daniel
text: Maybe 6.

speaker: Anna
text: Why higher?

speaker: Daniel
text: Because it actually improved the output my CV language, cover letters, and speed. I got more replies when my documents were clearer. It doesn’t solve direction, but it helps a lot with production.

speaker: Anna
text: In your experience, how do trust and effectiveness connect? Do you have examples where you trusted someone but it wasn’t effective, or where something was effective but you didn’t really trust it?

speaker: Daniel
text: Yeah, both. Trusted but not effective: I had a mentor who was very kind and validating. I felt safe, I trusted her as a person.

speaker: Daniel
text: But she didn’t give concrete actions. I left feeling warm, but nothing changed.

speaker: Anna
text: And effective but not trusted?

speaker: Daniel
text: The big tech mentor. His advice had useful parts impact, decision-making story, stronger narrative. But I didn’t trust him because he seemed okay with exaggerating and he was distracted.

speaker: Daniel
text: I still took some tips, but it cost energy. If you don’t trust, you second-guess everything, so it’s harder to act.

speaker: Anna
text: So distrust creates friction?

speaker: Daniel
text: Exactly. Trust makes implementation faster. Distrust makes me overthink.

speaker: Daniel
text: Trust is like a multiplier.

speaker: Anna
text: And with AI, do you see the same pattern?

speaker: Daniel
text: Yeah. AI can be effective but not trusted, like it writes something good but I don’t trust it’s authentic or accurate. And trusted but not effective is like emotional comfort—safe, but not changing anything long-term.

speaker: Daniel
text: 8) Preferences & hybrid model reaction

speaker: Anna
text: Imagine a hybrid model where AI helps you prepare and organize things, and a human coach steps in for deeper conversations and decision points. What’s your reaction?

speaker: Daniel
text: That sounds good. AI can handle the annoying part—rewriting, templates, checklists. And the human can do the meaning part and also verify reality.

speaker: Anna
text: Verify what?

speaker: Daniel
text: Context. Like what companies actually require German, what roles are truly junior-friendly, what hiring expectations look like here. AI might list companies, but a human in Germany can reality-check.

speaker: Anna
text: What would make you trust a hybrid system like that?

speaker: Daniel
text: Transparency about what AI does and doesn’t do. Privacy. And quality of matching for the human part.

speaker: Daniel
text: If the human part is random like ADPList sometimes, hybrid doesn’t solve it.

speaker: Anna
text: Matching seems central for you.

speaker: Daniel
text: Yeah. My one good mentor worked because she understood the Germany market and immigrant stress. If a system matches me with someone who gets those constraints, trust goes up.

speaker: Anna
text: Any concerns about hybrid models?

speaker: Daniel
text: That AI becomes too central and flattens nuance. Or the human just repeats what AI says, then why pay. And also I worry about incentives, like upselling or pushing me into a path that benefits the platform.

speaker: Anna
text: What would reduce that concern?

speaker: Daniel
text: Clear boundaries, maybe evidence like testimonials, and making it easy to switch mentors without shame. If switching is normalized, it’s easier to find a real fit.

speaker: Anna
text: How does that compare to your experience with ADPList?

speaker: Daniel
text: ADPList feels like speed dating. Profiles are vague, quality varies. Also I spent the first ten minutes explaining my context every time.

speaker: Daniel
text: That repetition is exhausting and it affects trust. 9) Closing

speaker: Anna
text: We’re almost at the end. If you could tell people designing career support tools what they should understand about someone in your situation, what would you say?

speaker: Daniel
text: Don’t underestimate admin stress or insurance, contracts, Anmeldung. It affects risk. People say take a risk, but here risk is tied to paperwork.

speaker: Daniel
text: And junior designers need very specific feedback, not like your portfolio is good also I want to not feel judged for language or being foreign. When someone acknowledges it’s harder, I trust them more, but then they also need to help me act.

speaker: Anna
text: If you could design the perfect support session for yourself next week, what would it look like?

speaker: Daniel
text: AI first i upload my CV and two job descriptions, it gives adjustments and a checklist. Then human: 45 minutes to decide my positioning and narrative, and to commit to a plan. And maybe a short follow-up with next steps for accountability.

speaker: Anna
text: What would make you walk away thinking, this was effective?

speaker: Daniel
text: If I have a plan I actually believe in, and I feel less scattered. Ideally it leads to interviews, but even without that, effectiveness is knowing what to do and why.

speaker: Anna
text: Anything you want to add before we stop?

speaker: Daniel
text: Not really. I’m curious what patterns you’ll find, but yeah. That’s it.

speaker: Anna
text: Thanks, Daniel. I’m stopping the recording now. And just to reiterate, everything will be anonymized.

speaker: Anna
text: Thanks again for your time.

speaker: Daniel
text: Thank you. Bye.

speaker: Anna
text: Bye.

speaker: Anna
text: Hi Simon, can you hear me well?

speaker: Simon
text: Yes, I can hear you. Can you hear me too?

speaker: Anna
text: Yes, perfectly. Thanks for joining. Before we start, I want to quickly go through consent.

speaker: Anna
text: Is it okay if I m recording the audio of this interview? The recording is only for transcription, it will be anonymized, and you can skip any question or stop at any time.

speaker: Simon
text: Yes, that is okay. You can record.

speaker: Anna
text: Great, thanks. Just to confirm, we will use a pseudonym for you, and anything identifying like company name or specific people, we will keep generic. If I ask something that feels too specific, you can just say pass.

speaker: Simon
text: Yeah alright

speaker: Anna
text: also the topic is trust and perceived effectiveness in AI based career coaching versus human career coaching. There are no right answers. I am interested in your experience and your thinking.

speaker: Anna
text: Does that sound okay?

speaker: Simon
text: Yes, totally.

speaker: Anna
text: Perfect. I will start the recording now. Okay, recording is on.

speaker: Anna
text: To warm up, how are you doing today?

speaker: Simon
text: Um, fine. A bit tired because I was debugging something since morning, but yeah, okay hahahah

speaker: Anna
text: Sounds very on brand for a machine learning engineer. hahaha . Okay, let us start.

speaker: Anna
text: 2) Participant context and career situation

speaker: Anna
text: To begin, where are you currently in your career, and what career decisions or questions are you facing right now or have recently faced?

speaker: Simon
text: Okay. So i  am 24, and i am finishing my Master degree in Germany. I have a physics background, like my Bachelor was physics, and then I moved into more data science and machine learning during my Master.

speaker: Simon
text: Right now I work in a Munich startup in a student role. The title is something like AI product engineer, but it is basically a mix of ML engineering and product work. And the main career thing is that I already signed a full-time offer with the same startup.

speaker: Simon
text: So, in about two months after graduation I start full time, and it also has a Blue Card pathway. So in that sense the big decision is kind of done, but I still have like smaller questions: what direction do I want long term, how do I build toward product management, and how do I handle the German bureaucracy without losing my mind hahaha.

speaker: Anna
text: Oh, German bureaucracy is crazy right. When you say the big decision is done, can you tell me what made that decision significant for you?

speaker: Simon
text: It is like, it locks in the next chapter. I moved here from Brazil two years ago for the Master. So the decision is not only job, it is also, do I stay in Germany, do I build a life here, do I commit to the visa path, all those things.

speaker: Simon
text: Munich is expensive, rent is crazy, and at the same time career wise it is a good place for tech, at least for what I do. So the offer is not just money, it is stability, residence permit, being able to plan. Also it confirms that my pivot from physics into ML actually worked.

speaker: Simon
text: That felt big.

speaker: Anna
text: What was most difficult about it, in the last months? Was it uncertainty, lack of information, pressure, fear of mistakes, something else?

speaker: Simon
text: A mix. Uncertainty about the market, because everyone talks about layoffs, and also in Germany there is like this vibe of, you need to be very qualified, very formal, like your CV must be perfect. Also pressure from timeline.

speaker: Simon
text: My student residence permit is tied to finishing studies, and then you have this job-seeking period, and you have to do paperwork, and the Ausländerbehörde appointments are… yeah. So I had a time pressure, like if I do not get an offer fast enough, it becomes messy. And fear of mistakes, yes.

speaker: Simon
text: Like, if I accept the wrong role, maybe I get stuck writing code forever, and I already know I want to move more toward product. So I wanted a role that gives me credibility technically but also lets me touch product.

speaker: Anna
text: What kind of support did you feel you needed during that time?

speaker: Simon
text: Practical and emotional, both. Practical as in how do I position myself, how do I explain the physics background, how do I write a CV that fits the German style, how do I prepare for ML interviews, and also how do I negotiate, like salary, contract terms, and Blue Card stuff. Emotional support is more like am I making a mistake moving countries, what if I fail, what if I do not fit in.

speaker: Simon
text: But I am a bit self-directed, so I mostly tried to build my own structure. Still, I used tools and people.

speaker: Anna
text: When you say self-directed, what does that look like for you in practice?

speaker: Simon
text: I set my own milestones. Like, I created a spreadsheet with companies, roles, deadlines, status. I decided, okay, every week I apply to X roles, every weekend I work on portfolio projects, and I go to meetups to get referrals.

speaker: Simon
text: Also I have a clear picture of what I want next. Like, short term I am okay doing hands-on ML. Mid term I want to be closer to product decisions, user needs, and strategy.

speaker: Simon
text: I do not want to be coding all day forever. And because I know that, I choose activities that push me there, like I ask to join product meetings, or I do user story writing sometimes, even if my job is technical.

speaker: Anna
text: That is helpful. Can you describe the startup a bit, in a generic way, and what you do there day to day?

speaker: Simon
text: Sure. It is a B2B startup, Munich-based, around industrial IT and predictive maintenance. So we have sensor data from machines, and we build models to predict failures or optimize maintenance schedules.

speaker: Simon
text: My tasks are mixed. Some days I do data pipelines, like cleaning time series, feature engineering. Some days I train models and evaluate them, and make them production-ready, like monitoring, drift checks, that stuff.

speaker: Simon
text: And because we are small, I also do product things, like talking to the product manager, translating client pain points into model requirements, writing internal docs, and sometimes presenting results to clients. It is very fast. Like, you ship fast, then you fix.

speaker: Simon
text: Not always perfect.

speaker: Anna
text: What was your path into that role? How did you find it and what did the hiring process look like?

speaker: Simon
text: I found it through LinkedIn plus a meetup connection. I went to a machine learning meetup in Munich, like one of those evening events with pizza, and I talked to someone who later became my internal referral. Then I applied on LinkedIn, and the process was: first a recruiter screen, then a technical interview with an ML engineer, then a take-home assignment.

speaker: Simon
text: The assignment was like, here is a dataset, build a small model, explain your choices, and write a short report. Then I had a final interview with the CTO plus product manager, more like system design and product sense: how would you deploy this, how would you handle feedback from customers, how do you prioritize. And also some behavioral questions.

speaker: Anna
text: How did you feel in those steps? Any part particularly challenging?

speaker: Simon
text: The take-home was time-consuming. Also the product sense questions, because I came from physics and like pure engineering mindset. In physics you are trained to be correct, not necessarily to be pragmatic.

speaker: Simon
text: In startup you need to say, okay, we cannot be perfect, we need something that works and creates value. So I had to learn to talk in that language. Also speaking English is fine for me, but sometimes German comes in, like documents or bureaucracy, and then you feel less confident.

speaker: Anna
text: What languages do you use day to day?

speaker: Simon
text: At work mostly English. Some colleagues speak German in side conversations, but meetings are English because we have international people. My German is like B1-ish, maybe.

speaker: Simon
text: I can do basics like Anmeldung, or at the doctor, but professional German, no. And outside work, in Munich, you can survive in English, but for bureaucracy you need German or someone who helps.

speaker: Anna
text: What was your relocation story, briefly? What brought you to Germany?

speaker: Simon
text: I wanted a strong Master program in data and AI, and Germany was attractive because tuition is low compared to like the US or UK. Also I liked the idea of being in Europe, like more stability. I applied to programs, got into one in Munich, moved here in 2024.

speaker: Simon
text: The first months were intense: finding a room, Anmeldung, opening bank account, health insurance, like Krankenkasse, all that. And then adapting to winter. Hahaha.

speaker: Simon
text: Brazil to Munich winter is… yeah.

speaker: Anna
text: Hahaha. Yes. And you said you have a full-time offer starting in two months after graduation.

speaker: Anna
text: What does the Blue Card pathway mean to you personally?

speaker: Simon
text: It means I can stop being stressed all the time. Because the visa situation affects everything. Like, you cannot sign a long rent contract if you are unsure.

speaker: Simon
text: You cannot plan travel easily. You always think, what if the appointment is late. So Blue Card is like a feeling of legitimacy.

speaker: Simon
text: Also it is a signal that my salary and contract are in a good range. But it is also paperwork, and it depends on rules, and rules can change. So it is not pure comfort, but it is better than being on student status.

speaker: Anna
text: Okay. That gives me a good overview. Let us move to how you usually get career support.

speaker: Anna
text: When you need career support, who or what do you usually turn to?

speaker: Simon
text: Um, first myself  like, I read a lot, I do research. Then I talk to a few people: friends who are also in tech, some classmates, and one mentor I have informally. Not like official mentoring, but a guy I met at university who works as a data scientist, maybe 5 years older, and we talk sometimes.

speaker: Simon
text: I also used the university career center once, like they had a CV check. And then honestly I use AI tools a lot, mainly ChatGPT, for writing and structuring.

speaker: Anna
text: What tends to actually help you, and what tends to feel unhelpful or frustrating?

speaker: Simon
text: Helpful is concrete feedback. Like, if someone reads my CV and says, this line is unclear, this is too long, this does not show impact. Or if they tell me, for this role you need to emphasize A and B.

speaker: Simon
text: Also helpful is reality checks about the market, like, do not apply to only big tech, also look at middlestrandt or look at startups. Unhelpful is generic advice like, follow your passion, or network more, or just be confident. Like, yeah, okay, but what do I do tomorrow.

speaker: Simon
text: Also unhelpful is when people give advice that does not fit my context as an immigrant in Germany. Like, someone might say, just walk in and talk to the manager, but in Germany that is weird

speaker: Anna
text: If you think about the support you got during your job search, what were the top channels for you?

speaker: Simon
text: LinkedIn for sure, because it is easy and you see roles. Referrals through meetups helped a lot. GitHub and portfolio also mattered, because in ML, having projects that show you can do end-to-end is important.

speaker: Simon
text: And also my university network, like professors or labs, not super strong but some.

speaker: Anna
text: Did you use any other resources, like online communities, forums, or events?

speaker: Simon
text: Yes, meetups, like Munich ML meetup or something like that i dont remember the name of it , had a very funny one actually , also some AI product events. And I read blogs, like on interview prep, and watched YouTube videos for system design. But you need to filter because a lot of content is US market focused.

speaker: Simon
text: In Germany interviews are sometimes different. But the ML fundamentals are universal.

speaker: Anna
text: When you evaluate career advice in general, what makes you take it seriously?

speaker: Simon
text: Two things. One is competence, like does the person actually know what they are talking about, have they done it. The other is fit, like do they understand my goals and constraints.

speaker: Simon
text: If advice is competent but not fitting, it can still be interesting, but I might not follow it. And I also value honesty about uncertainty. Like, if someone says, it depends, and then explains what it depends on, I trust that more than someone being very sure.

speaker: Anna
text: That is a nice transition into trust. Next I will ask specifically about human coaching, but you mentioned you have not had offline coaching. So we will talk about expectations.

speaker: Anna
text: 4) Human coaching experience and trust

speaker: Anna
text: Have you ever had an offline or online career coaching session with a professional coach, like a paid coach or a structured program?

speaker: Simon
text: No, not in the classic sense. I never paid a coach or went to a private career coach. I only used the university career center, but that was more like a service, not coaching.

speaker: Simon
text: It was like, here are tips, fixed appointment, very practical.

speaker: Anna
text: Okay. So if you imagine a human career coach, what do you expect they would do with you? What would you want from them, given your situation?

speaker: Simon
text: I would want them to help me with strategy and positioning. Like, how do I present myself as someone who is technical but wants to move toward product. Also I would want them to help me identify gaps: what skills do I need, what experiences do I need.

speaker: Simon
text: And maybe accountability, like, if I say I will do X, then they check. Also maybe help with negotiation and career planning. And honestly, emotional support too, like someone who can listen and reflect back, because moving countries and building a career is stressful.

speaker: Anna
text: What would make you trust a human coach?

speaker: Simon
text: Hhm let me think… Competence i guess. Like, they should have experience with tech careers. If it is a general coach who only coached like marketing people, I would worry.

speaker: Simon
text: Also kindness or empathy,or  like when they should listen properly, not rush not judge and confidentiality. Because career topics can be sensitive, like visa status, salary, insecurities. I need to feel safe that they do not share it or use it in a weird way.

speaker: Simon
text: Thats all i think. No  structure also. Structure yes.

speaker: Simon
text: Like, I like a plan. I do not want just a conversation, I want some framework, goals, follow-ups. And also feeling seen, like they understand my background and my specific context.

speaker: Anna
text: When you say feeling seen, how would you notice that in a session?

speaker: Simon
text: The questions they ask. If they ask generic questions like, what are your strengths, and then they give a generic summary, I would not feel seen. But if they pick up on details, like, you said you liked bridging technical and business, tell me more, and then they connect it to a plan, then I feel they actually listened.

speaker: Simon
text: Also if they remember what I said last time, like small details.

speaker: Anna
text: What would be red flags for you with a human coach?

speaker: Simon
text: Sales vibe. Like if in the first 10 minutes they push their package, or they say, you need 10 sessions, pay now, I would not like that. Also false certainty, like, I guarantee you will get a job in 2 weeks.

speaker: Simon
text: That is unrealistic. Another red flag is if they do not understand tech context and still act like they do. Like mixing up basic concepts, or giving advice that is clearly not relevant.

speaker: Simon
text: Also confidentiality doubts, like if they talk about other clients in too much detail. And also if they are too moralizing, like judging your choices.

speaker: Anna
text: If you think about your own attitude, you said you generally trust career coaches and believe they often help. Where does that belief come from, if you have not used one yourself?

speaker: Simon
text: From observing friends and also from the idea that talking to an experienced person can help you see blind spots. Like, coaching is basically structured reflection plus expertise. I have seen friends who had coaches for job changes, and they got clarity and made decisions faster.

speaker: Simon
text: Also, I guess I am open to the concept. I do not think coaches are magic, but I think they can help if they are good and if the client is engaged. I would consider it in the future, maybe when I want to make a bigger transition, like from engineering to product management.

speaker: Anna
text: You also mentioned you have considered becoming a career coach later for technical specialists. Can you tell me what you mean by that?

speaker: Simon
text: Yeah. Like, in tech, a lot of people struggle with interviews, or with presenting themselves, or with deciding between paths like research, engineering, product, management. And someone who has been through it could help, especially if they know how to prepare for coding interviews, ML interviews, system design, and also how to communicate impact.

speaker: Simon
text: I could imagine doing that later, as a side thing, like helping people with CVs, interview prep, career strategy in tech. But not now. Now I need to build my own career first.

speaker: Anna
text: Makes sense. If you were to choose a coach, what would you look for in their background or credentials?

speaker: Simon
text: I would look for someone who has worked in tech, ideally in Germany or Europe, because context matters. Maybe someone who has been an engineer and then moved to product, because that is my goal. Also I would look for testimonials, but carefully, because testimonials can be marketing.

speaker: Simon
text: I would look for a first session that feels like value, not just sales. And maybe some proof of methodology, like how they work, what is the process. And I would prefer someone who can speak English, obviously, and maybe some German knowledge could help with local context.

speaker: Anna
text: Okay. Let us switch to AI tools, where you do have experience.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you tell me about your experience using AI tools for career-related questions? What have you used, and for what?

speaker: Simon
text: Mainly ChatGPT. I also tried Claude once, but mostly сhat because it is convenient and I already have a routine. I used it for rewriting my CV, rewriting bullet points, translating things into a more professional English.

speaker: Simon
text: Also for LinkedIn summary, like how to position myself. And for interview prep: generating likely questions, practicing answers, and also explaining ML concepts in a way that is interview-friendly. Like, if I know the math, but I need to explain it clearly.

speaker: Simon
text: It helped a lot, honestly.

speaker: Anna
text: You said it helped you get the job by rewriting your CV. Can you walk me through that episode? What exactly did you do and what changed?

speaker: Simon
text: Yes. So initially my CV was very academic. Physics style.

speaker: Simon
text: Like, lots of theory, not enough impact. And also the language was not good, because I wrote in a kind of formal, but not business-friendly way. I took my CV text, removed personal details, and pasted bullet points into сhat.

speaker: Simon
text: I asked something like: rewrite these bullets for an AI product engineer role in a German startup, emphasize impact, use action verbs, keep it concise, quantify where possible. And it gave me a version that was much more readable.

speaker: Anna
text: What was different in the rewritten version?

speaker: Simon
text: It was more outcome focused. Like, instead of saying, implemented a neural network, it would say, built a predictive model that reduced error by X, or improved detection of anomalies. It also suggested a structure: first a summary, then skills, then experience, then projects.

speaker: Simon
text: And it helped me translate academic projects into product language. Like, I did a thesis project on time series forecasting, and chat helped me frame it as, developed forecasting pipeline for industrial sensor data, evaluated models, deployed prototype. That kind of framing.

speaker: Anna
text: How did you decide what to keep and what to change?

speaker: Simon
text: I did not just copy paste. I compared it with job descriptions and with other CV examples. I took the good parts, and I edited.

speaker: Simon
text: Also I checked for accuracy, because sometimes it invents metrics. Like it will say, improved performance by 30 percent, but I did not measure that. So I had to be careful.

speaker: Simon
text: I used it like a draft generator, not as truth.

speaker: Anna
text: Did you notice any emotional impact from that process? Like confidence, stress level?

speaker: Simon
text: Yes, it reduced stress, because the blank page problem is real. Like, you know you did stuff, but writing it in a good way is hard. When chat gave me a draft, I felt, okay, I can work with this.

speaker: Simon
text: It also made me more confident to apply, because I felt my CV was not embarrassing hahaha. And I did get more interview invitations after improving it, so that reinforced it.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you share a moment where ChatGPT truly helped beyond writing? Something like a decision, or preparation, or clarity?

speaker: Simon
text: Interview prep. There was one interview where they asked product sense questions. Like, how do you decide what model to deploy, how do you trade off accuracy versus latency, how do you communicate uncertainty to a client.

speaker: Simon
text: I practiced with chat by giving it the context and asking it to act like an interviewer. And then I responded, and it gave feedback, like, you focused too much on technical details, mention business impact, mention monitoring, mention user trust. That helped me.

speaker: Simon
text: In the actual interview, I was more structured. And I think that contributed to the offer.

speaker: Anna
text: Do you remember a specific piece of feedback that stuck?

speaker: Simon
text: Yes. It said something like, always connect model decisions to stakeholder needs. Like, if the client needs reliability, talk about robustness and monitoring, not just metrics.

speaker: Simon
text: And also, do not oversell, be clear about limitations. That is aligned with how Germans like things, I think, like realistic. So I used that.

speaker: Anna
text: And can you share a moment when ChatGPT failed you or felt unhelpful?

speaker: Simon
text: Definitely. Sometimes it gives generic output. Like, you ask, how do I move from ML engineer to product manager, and it gives the same list: learn business, talk to stakeholders, build roadmap.

speaker: Simon
text: It is true but too generic. Another failure was hallucination. I asked it about Blue Card requirements and timelines, and it confidently gave wrong information.

speaker: Simon
text: Like it mixed up salary thresholds and said something about documents that was not correct for my case. I noticed because I cross-checked with official sources and with my company HR. So that was a big reminder: do not trust it for legal specifics.

speaker: Anna
text: How did that affect your trust?

speaker: Simon
text: It lowered it for that domain. Like, I trust it for writing and brainstorming, but for legal or visa stuff, I treat it as a rough starting point at most. If it speaks with too much certainty in areas where rules change, I get suspicious.

speaker: Anna
text: Any other concerns?

speaker: Simon
text: Privacy. Like, CV contains personal info. I tried to remove name, address, company names, but still, you share your career story.

speaker: Simon
text: So I am careful. I do not paste full contracts or visa letters. Also sometimes it makes assumptions about my background, like it will assume I am a software engineer with 5 years experience, because the prompt is vague.

speaker: Simon
text: Then the answer is not tailored.

speaker: Anna
text: How do you verify AI outputs in general?

speaker: Simon
text: I do a few things. For factual claims, I ask for sources or I cross-check with credible websites. For writing, I check for tone, and I make sure it is truthful.

speaker: Simon
text: For interview prep, I compare with real interview guides and with feedback from humans. Also I sometimes run the same question with a different phrasing, to see if the answer is consistent. If it changes drastically, I know it is shaky.

speaker: Anna
text: What makes it feel trustworthy to you, like in the moment?

speaker: Simon
text: When it reflects my context correctly. Like, when I give it details and it uses them. Also when it shows nuance, like, it does not just say do X, but says, here are options, here are trade-offs.

speaker: Simon
text: And when it admits uncertainty, like, I am not sure, or it depends. That increases trust. If it is too confident, I trust less.

speaker: Anna
text: That is a good point. Let us move into comparison.

speaker: Anna
text: I want to compare human coaching and AI tools via specific career tasks. I will name a task, and I would like you to tell me which you would prefer for that task and why. Does that work?

speaker: Simon
text: Yes.

speaker: Anna
text: First task: rewriting a CV and LinkedIn profile for a specific role in Germany. What would you prefer, human coach or AI tool?

speaker: Simon
text: For first draft and iteration, AI tool. It is fast and you can do many versions. But for final polish, especially if it is high-stakes, I would like a human review, ideally someone who knows the market.

speaker: Simon
text: Because AI can make it sound good, but maybe it misses local expectations, like German CV style, or it can create too much fluff. So I would do AI first, then human second.

speaker: Anna
text: What is the advantage of AI there, in your experience?

speaker: Simon
text: Speed. You can ask 20 times, rewrite this bullet, shorten, make it more impact-focused, tailor to job description. A human would get tired, or it would be expensive.

speaker: Simon
text: Also AI is non-judgmental, you can ask stupid questions hahaha

speaker: Anna
text: Agreed. And what is the advantage of a human there?

speaker: Simon
text: Context and honesty. A human can say, this claim sounds unrealistic, or this project is not relevant, remove it. Also humans can pick up subtle things, like this sounds arrogant, or this is too humble.

speaker: Simon
text: And they can ask you follow-up questions to get more detail.

speaker: Anna
text: Second task: choosing between two offers, like startup versus corporate, or Germany versus another country. Who would you prefer?

speaker: Simon
text: Human. Because that is more values and trade offs. AI can help list pros and cons, but a human can challenge you, like, you say you want stability but you choose startup, why.

speaker: Simon
text: A human can also understand emotions, like fear, identity. AI is more mechanical.

speaker: Anna
text: Third task: interview preparation, technical and behavioral. What would you prefer?

speaker: Simon
text: Hybrid. AI for drilling questions and structuring answers, human for realistic feedback and for understanding how an interviewer in that company thinks. Like, a human who has done ML interviews can say, your answer is too theoretical, or you missed the point.

speaker: Anna
text: Fourth task: dealing with German bureaucracy and visa stress, like residence permit, Blue Card steps. What would you prefer?

speaker: Simon
text: Human, or official sources, not AI. Hahaha. AI is too risky there.

speaker: Simon
text: It can give outdated info. A human like HR or a relocation consultant or someone who went through it is better. AI can maybe help translate a letter or explain vocabulary, like what does this title?

speaker: Simon
text: Auf title? I dont remember hahaha what does it mean, but not advice.

speaker: Anna
text: Okay. I will now embed a quick micro-poll. I will ask you to rate some things from 0 to 10, where 0 is no trust or not effective at all, and 10 is complete trust or extremely effective.

speaker: Anna
text: There is no correct number. I care about why. Is that okay?

speaker: Simon
text: Yes.

speaker: Anna
text: First rating: trust in human career coaches, even though you have not used one. Based on your expectations. What number from 0 to 10?

speaker: Simon
text: I would say 7.

speaker: Anna
text: Why 7 and not lower?

speaker: Simon
text: Because I think many coaches genuinely want to help and have experience. The human element, empathy, confidentiality, that creates trust for me. Also if someone has a reputation and credentials, I would trust them.

speaker: Simon
text: So baseline is positive.

speaker: Anna
text: Why not higher than 7?

speaker: Simon
text: Because variability. Some coaches are great, some are not. And without personal experience, I cannot say 9 or 10.

speaker: Simon
text: Also, there is always the risk of generic advice or misfit. And sometimes coaching can be more about motivation than real strategy. For me, I want substance.

speaker: Simon
text: So 7 feels like, I am open and generally trusting, but not naive.

speaker: Anna
text: Second rating: trust in AI tools for career support, like ChatGPT, for your use. 0 to 10.

speaker: Simon
text: For trust, maybe 6.

speaker: Anna
text: Why 6?

speaker: Simon
text: Because it is useful and often accurate in writing and general guidance, but it can be delulu and it lacks true understanding of my life. So I trust it conditionally. I trust it as a tool, not as an authority.

speaker: Simon
text: Also privacy concerns reduce trust a bit.

speaker: Anna
text: What would make it a 7 or 8 for you?

speaker: Simon
text: Better transparency about sources, like if it shows where it got info, and if it has strong guardrails like, for legal topics it refuses or says it is uncertain. Also if there was a mode that guarantees not storing data, or a clear privacy contract, that would increase trust.

speaker: Anna
text: Third rating: perceived effectiveness of human coaching for your situation, expected effectiveness. 0 to 10.

speaker: Simon
text: I would say 7 again.

speaker: Anna
text: What does effectiveness mean to you here?

speaker: Simon
text: Effectiveness is outcomes. Like, does it help me make decisions, create action steps, build confidence, actually improve results like interviews passed or better offers. For human coaching, I expect it can be effective if the coach is good and fits my goals.

speaker: Simon
text: They can help with strategy and accountability. So 7.

speaker: Anna
text: Why not 9?

speaker: Simon
text: Because it is not magic. Also I am already quite structured. A coach might not add huge value for me in basic things.

speaker: Simon
text: It would be more effective in specific transitions, like moving to product. But in general, I think it is helpful, not transformational always.

speaker: Anna
text: Fourth rating: perceived effectiveness of AI tools for your situation, based on your experience. 0 to 10.

speaker: Simon
text: For effectiveness, I would say 8.

speaker: Anna
text: Why 8?

speaker: Simon
text: Because it actually produced concrete outcomes for me. It improved my CV, it helped me prepare, and I got the job. Also it saves time every day.

speaker: Simon
text: So in effectiveness terms, it is high. Even if I do not fully trust it, it is effective for certain tasks.

speaker: Anna
text: Why not 10?

speaker: Simon
text: Because it fails in areas like legal specifics, and it can be generic. And it cannot replace a human for deep reflection or accountability. Also, sometimes it makes me overthink.

speaker: Simon
text: Like, you ask too many questions and you get too many options.

speaker: Anna
text: That is very clear. Thank you. Let us go deeper into trust and effectiveness as separate things, because you already started to distinguish them.

speaker: Anna
text: When you think about trust, what does it mean for you in this context? And separately, what does effectiveness mean? You started defining effectiveness, but I want to hear it in your own words.

speaker: Simon
text: Okay. Trust is like, do I believe the source is competent, and do I feel safe using it. Competence means it gives good guidance, it understands context, it does not mislead.

speaker: Simon
text: Safe means confidentiality, not being judged, not being exploited, like not being manipulated. Also trust includes empathy for humans, like feeling understood. For AI, empathy is not real, but you can still feel comfortable if it is respectful and consistent.

speaker: Anna
text: How do trust and effectiveness connect for you? For example, if you trust something more, does it automatically become more effective?

speaker: Simon
text: Not automatically, but it changes how I use it. If I trust a coach, I will share more details, and then they can tailor better, so it becomes more effective. If I do not trust, I hold back, and then the advice is generic, so less effective.

speaker: Simon
text: But there is also the opposite: something can be effective even if I do not fully trust it, like AI. I do not fully trust it, but it still helps, because I use it in a limited way.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you give an example of low trust but some effectiveness, from your experience?

speaker: Simon
text: Yes. When I used chat to generate interview questions for the startup, I did not trust it fully because it might not know the company. But it still produced a structured list: ML fundamentals, system design, product questions, behavioral.

speaker: Simon
text: Even if some questions were not exactly asked, the structure helped me prepare. So effectiveness was there, but trust was moderate.

speaker: Anna
text: And can you give an example of high trust but low effectiveness, even hypothetically?

speaker: Simon
text: Hypothetically, yes. Imagine a human coach who is very empathetic, very supportive, you feel safe, you trust them personally. But they do not have tech context and they give advice like, just show your passion, or network more, or do a generic resume template.

speaker: Simon
text: Then you might feel good emotionally, high trust, but outcomes are not improved. So low effectiveness for my goals.

speaker: Anna
text: That is a strong distinction. Can the opposite happen, high effectiveness but low trust?

speaker: Simon
text: Yes, similar to AI. Or even with a human. Like, you could have a very direct reviewer, maybe a hiring manager, who is harsh, you do not feel emotionally safe, but they give very precise feedback that improves your CV.

speaker: Simon
text: So you do not trust them as a person, but the advice is effective. That can happen.

speaker: Anna
text: What about trust in terms of confidentiality. How important is that in career conversations?

speaker: Simon
text: Very important. Especially as an immigrant. Visa status, salary, insecurity about language, these are vulnerable topics.

speaker: Simon
text: With a human coach, I would need a clear confidentiality agreement. With AI, confidentiality is more like data privacy. If I think my data could be stored or used, I will limit what I share.

speaker: Simon
text: And then effectiveness goes down because it lacks context.

speaker: Anna
text: That is interesting. So your trust influences how much context you provide, and that influences effectiveness.

speaker: Simon
text: Exactly.

speaker: Anna
text: Are there any moments where you felt you had to choose between trust and convenience?

speaker: Simon
text: Yes. Convenience is AI. You can do it anytime, late night, quick.

speaker: Simon
text: Trust is more human, but it costs time and money. Sometimes I choose convenience. Like, at 1 am, I am not going to call a coach.

speaker: Simon
text: I will ask chat. Even if trust is lower, it is available.

speaker: Anna
text: In those moments, do you notice any boundaries you set with the AI?

speaker: Simon
text: Yes, I keep it at the level of content, not personal secrets. Like, I talk about how to phrase things, how to structure, but I do not paste personal documents. Also I remind myself that it can be wrong, so I treat it as suggestions.

speaker: Simon
text: I think that boundary helps maintain both trust and effectiveness in the limited domain.

speaker: Anna
text: What would make you stop using an AI tool for career support?

speaker: Simon
text: If it repeatedly gives wrong info in a way that harms me. Like, if I follow advice and it leads to a bad outcome. Also if there was a data scandal, like my data is leaked.

speaker: Simon
text: Or if it becomes too manipulative, like it pushes certain services. Basically if the risk becomes high.

speaker: Anna
text: And what would make you stop using a human coach, hypothetically?

speaker: Simon
text: Same vibe i guess  if they break confidentiality, if they push sales, if they do not listen, if they give generic advice, if they pretend certainty, or if they do not respect my autonomy. I do not want someone to tell me what to do, I want someone to support my decision-making.

speaker: Anna
text: Great. Now I want to explore your preferences and the idea of hybrid models.

speaker: Anna
text: Imagine a hybrid model where AI helps with preparation, structuring, and follow-up, and a human coach helps with deep reflection, accountability, and high-stakes decisions. What is your initial reaction?

speaker: Simon
text: That sounds like the best combination, in theory. Because it uses AI where it is strong: repetitive tasks, drafts, brainstorming, 24/7. And it uses humans where they are strong: understanding context, emotions, and making you commit to actions.

speaker: Simon
text: I think hybrid can also reduce cost, because you do not need a human for every small thing.

speaker: Anna
text: What parts of that hybrid idea feel attractive to you personally?

speaker: Simon
text: The workflow. Like, I could use AI to prepare before a session: write my thoughts, clarify my questions, generate options. Then in the human session, we go deeper, and we decide.

speaker: Simon
text: After that, AI could help me execute: write emails, update CV, plan steps, reminders. That would be very efficient.

speaker: Anna
text: What parts feel risky or unclear?

speaker: Simon
text: Data flow. Like, does the human coach see what I wrote to AI. How is it stored.

speaker: Simon
text: Who owns the data. Also accountability. If AI gives a plan and the human gives another plan, what is the source of truth.

speaker: Simon
text: Also quality control: if the AI output is wrong, does the human correct it, or do you end up trusting wrong stuff. And the boundary of roles: when do you escalate to human, when do you stay with AI.

speaker: Anna
text: If you could design the hybrid model for someone like you, what would be the rules for when AI leads versus when a human leads?

speaker: Simon
text: AI leads when tasks are low emotional and more technical: rewriting text, summarizing job descriptions, preparing interview question lists, generating templates, translating. Human leads when tasks involve values, identity, long-term decisions, or sensitive topics like negotiation, visa strategy, or conflict at work. Also human leads when I feel stuck emotionally, like anxiety or self-doubt, because AI can be supportive but it is not real empathy.

speaker: Anna
text: What would make you trust a hybrid platform more?

speaker: Simon
text: Transparency. Like, clear explanation of what AI does, what human does, how data is handled, how matching works if there is matching. Also clear limitations: do not promise guarantees.

speaker: Simon
text: And quality of humans: vetted coaches with relevant backgrounds. Also, I would like the AI part to show sources when it claims facts, and to separate facts from suggestions.

speaker: Anna
text: Would you personally pay for such a hybrid service?

speaker: Simon
text: Maybe, yes, if I am at a transition point. Right now I already have a job offer, so I do not urgently need it. But for the move to product management, I might pay, because that is strategic and it is harder.

speaker: Simon
text: If the hybrid service can provide a coach who actually did that path, plus AI to support execution, that is valuable.

speaker: Anna
text: What would be a deal-breaker?

speaker: Simon
text: If it feels like a funnel to sell courses, or if it is too generic. Also if privacy is unclear. And if the coaches are not credible.

speaker: Simon
text: Like, if they are generalists, it would not fit. I need someone who understands technical roles.

speaker: Anna
text: How would you want the coach to interact with you, style-wise?

speaker: Simon
text: Calm, structured, not too motivational. I prefer someone who asks good questions and also gives concrete feedback. Like, a mix of coaching and consulting.

speaker: Simon
text: Some coaches are purely reflective, but I also like directness.

speaker: Anna
text: If the platform offered AI-only, human-only, and hybrid, what would you choose for different situations?

speaker: Simon
text: AI-only for quick tasks like cover letter drafts, bullet rewrites, interview question practice. Human-only for big decisions and personal topics. Hybrid for structured career planning over time, where you want both reflection and execution support.

speaker: Anna
text: Great. We are close to closing. I want to ask one more thing: looking back, what do you think was the most effective support you used in your job search, and why?

speaker: Simon
text: Most effective was actually a combination: chat for writing and prep, plus human input from my referral and from my manager. Like, the referral helped me understand what the startup needed, what to emphasize. Chat helped me produce materials fast and practice.

speaker: Simon
text: So effectiveness came from combining resources. The AI tool gave me speed, but humans gave me credibility.

speaker: Anna
text: If you had to describe in one sentence what trust means for you in this topic, what would you say?

speaker: Simon
text: Trust means I feel safe sharing enough context, and I believe the guidance is competent and honest not like manipulative to get money out of me hahaha.

speaker: Anna
text: And one sentence for effectiveness?

speaker: Simon
text: Effectiveness means it leads to concrete progress

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you. Is there anything you expected me to ask but I did not, or anything you want to add?

speaker: Simon
text: Maybe just that for early-career people in tech, the barrier is often not knowledge, it is communication. Like, you can be good, but you cannot present it. AI helps with that a lot.

speaker: Simon
text: But humans help with confidence and with navigating systems. So both matter.

speaker: Anna
text: That is a valuable point. Thank you. Just to close formally, do you have any questions for me about the study or what happens next?

speaker: Simon
text: No, I think it is clear. You will anonymize and use it for research.

speaker: Anna
text: Exactly. We will transcribe, remove identifying details, and use it as part of thematic analysis. If later you want to withdraw, you can message me.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you for your time and for being so thoughtful!

speaker: Simon
text: Sure. Thank you. It was interesting.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you so much i will stop the recording now.

speaker: Anna
text: Hi Lisa, thanks for joining. Before we start, i am recording this meet do I have your permission to record this conversation for research purposes?

speaker: Lisa
text: Yes, you have my permission to record.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you. Just to reiterate: everything is anonymous, I will use a pseudonym, and you can skip any question or stop at any time. Does that feel okay?

speaker: Lisa
text: Yes, that is fine.

speaker: Anna
text: Great. Also, if anything feels too personal, just tell me and we move on.

speaker: Lisa
text: Okay.

speaker: Anna
text: Perfect. How is your day going so far?

speaker: Lisa
text: Busy, as always. I had two long  calls already, and then I was like, okay, now Zoom number three. But it is okay, I have coffee.

speaker: Anna
text: Great. Then let us start. 2) Participant context and career situation

speaker: Anna
text: To begin, where are you currently in your career, and what career decisions or questions are you facing right now?

speaker: Lisa
text: Okay. So, I am 28. I studied marketing in Germany, like classic, Bachelor and then Master.

speaker: Lisa
text: I started in a smaller agency first, then I moved to BCG. I am in marketing at BCG, not consulting. So, I am internal.

speaker: Lisa
text: I work on go to market and brand, and also campaign stuff, and some content, and internal stakeholder management. And right now my big question is: I want to transition from marketing into product management, or like a bridge, product marketing into PM. Because I want to build products, not only meaning or messaging.

speaker: Lisa
text: And that is, eehm, not a small shift, especially inside BCG.

speaker: Anna
text: When you say build products, what do you mean by product in your head?

speaker: Lisa
text: Good question. Because in consulting, people say product and it can mean many things. For me it means something that is used, like a tool, a digital product, maybe a platform, maybe internal product, maybe client facing, but with an actual user, an interface, a roadmap, prioritization, discovery, metrics.

speaker: Lisa
text: Not just, okay, we have an offer and we market it nicely. It is like owning the problem, and iterating. I want to be closer to that.

speaker: Anna
text: And what is pushing that now, in this last period?

speaker: Lisa
text: There was a trigger, yes. In the last, I would say, six to nine months, I was staffed on a project, not as a consultant but kind of supporting with marketing, for a digital product BCG was building internally for a client team. It was like a prototype, and we had a product owner from the consulting side, and designers, and some engineers.

speaker: Lisa
text: And I was invited because they needed positioning and messaging, yes, but then I ended up doing more. Like, I was the person who translated user feedback into changes in the onboarding flow. I wrote the first version of the user stories.

speaker: Lisa
text: I ran a workshop with internal users. And I felt, um, it sounds dramatic, but I felt alive. Like, this is the thing.

speaker: Lisa
text: And then I went back to my usual marketing cycle, where it is like, we polish a deck, we align on wording for two weeks, and I was like, why does this feel empty now?

speaker: Anna
text: So there was a comparison experience.

speaker: Lisa
text: Exactly. And also, I had a moment with a senior stakeholder, like a partner, who said something like, you are so good at making this sound great, but what is the actual thing? And it was not mean.

speaker: Lisa
text: But it hit me. Because I was like, yes, I can make things sound great, but I also want to influence what the thing is. Not just the story.

speaker: Lisa
text: And then I started reading about PM, talking to people, and then coaching.

speaker: Anna
text: What made the decision difficult?

speaker: Lisa
text: Several things. One is credibility. In Germany, the job market for PM can be picky, like they want experience.

speaker: Lisa
text: Titles matter a bit. Also language expectations. Some PM roles say English is fine, but then you see, okay, German required.

speaker: Lisa
text: And inside BCG, there is internal politics. Like, internal mobility is possible, but it is not like you click a button and suddenly you are a PM. There are product roles in BCG X, in Platinion, in digital ventures, and also in internal knowledge teams, but you need sponsorship, and you need to show evidence.

speaker: Lisa
text: People will ask, have you shipped? Have you owned a backlog? Have you done discovery?

speaker: Lisa
text: And my CV says marketing. So that is the problem.

speaker: Anna
text: What kind of support did you feel you needed?

speaker: Lisa
text: Structure. And honesty. And someone to, eehm, challenge me, but also not make me feel stupid.

speaker: Lisa
text: Because inside BCG, the environment is high pace and feedback culture is direct. It is polished, but it is also intense. You get feedback like, this is not sharp, this is not client ready.

speaker: Lisa
text: And I can handle that at work, but for my career, I needed someone who can hold the uncertainty with me. Like, am I making a mistake? Is this a fantasy?

speaker: Lisa
text: And then also practical support: CV, LinkedIn, target roles, experiments, interviews.

speaker: Anna
text: When you say uncertainty, what was the emotional part for you?

speaker: Lisa
text: The fear of losing status. And also, fear of disappointing myself. Like, I worked hard to get into BCG.

speaker: Lisa
text: It sounds silly because I am not even a consultant, but still, it is a known brand. And then to say, I want to switch, it is like, okay, am I ungrateful? And also fear of being rejected.

speaker: Lisa
text: Because PM interviews can be brutal, and I do not have the typical story. So, anxiety, yes.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you.And are you considering switching internally, externally, or both?

speaker: Lisa
text: Both. Internally, because it is easier in some ways, like you already have the brand and network. But also harder because people know you as marketing Lisa.

speaker: Lisa
text: Externally, because Berlin ecosystem has many product roles, Munich too but different, more enterprise, more automotive, more B2B. And I am based in Munich. So, I am exploring both.

speaker: Lisa
text: 3) Career support in general

speaker: Anna
text: When you need career support in general, who or what do you usually turn to?

speaker: Lisa
text: Um, friends, definitely. I have two friends who are product managers. One is in a startup in Berlin, one is in a big corporate in Munich.

speaker: Lisa
text: I also talk to my boyfriend, but he is in finance, so he is supportive but not super helpful on the content. And then at BCG, there are mentors, like informal, not official. I asked one woman in BCG  for a coffee chat.

speaker: Lisa
text: And I used online resources, like articles, some podcasts, and AI tools, yes. And then human coaching, which is the main thing for me.

speaker: Anna
text: What has actually helped, and what felt unhelpful?

speaker: Lisa
text: Helpful is when people give examples practical. Like, not just, follow your passion, but like, okay, here is how I moved from function A to function B. Here is the story I told.

speaker: Lisa
text: Here is how I positioned my experience. That helps. Unhelpful is generic advice.

speaker: Lisa
text: Like, network more. Okay, yes, but how? And also, some advice was too confident.

speaker: Lisa
text: Like, just apply to PM roles, it will work out. And I was like, hmm, no, you do not see my actual profile and the market.

speaker: Anna
text: And within BCG, how is it to ask for career support?

speaker: Lisa
text: It depends. People are nice, but everyone is busy. Staffing cycles are fast, projects change, priorities change.

speaker: Lisa
text: And there is a culture of being composed. So, you can say, I am thinking about development, but to say, I feel lost, is harder. Also, there is sometimes a fear that if you say you want to leave your function, your manager will think you are not committed.

speaker: Lisa
text: So you have to navigate that. It is like, you share selectively.

speaker: Anna
text: Aha. And you mentioned AI tools as part of your support mix. We will come to that later.

speaker: Lisa
text: Yes. 4) Human coaching experience and trust

speaker: Anna
text: You said you do human coaching. Can you tell me how you started, and what that process looks like?

speaker: Lisa
text: Yes. So, I found my coach via LinkedIn, through a friend recommendation. A friend of mine worked with her, and she said, this woman is good, she is structured, she understands corporate, and she is not, um, like a motivational speaker type.

speaker: Lisa
text: And I was like, okay, that sounds like what I need. I checked her LinkedIn, she had experience in tech and some consulting background, and she had coached people into product roles. So I booked a first call.

speaker: Anna
text: What was the first call like?

speaker: Lisa
text: It was like a chemistry check. She asked about my situation, my goal, what I tried already. She was calm, very direct, and she did not promise magic.

speaker: Lisa
text: She said, we can work together, but it will be work, and we will measure progress. And that already created trust for me because it felt honest. Not like, you will be PM in six weeks.

speaker: Anna
text: And what is the format now?

speaker: Lisa
text: We meet every two weeks, like therapy in cadence and depth. It is on video call, usually 60 minutes. And we have a process.

speaker: Lisa
text: Every session starts with a project audit. She asks, what did you do in the last two weeks? What projects at work?

speaker: Lisa
text: What side tasks? What decisions? And then she helps me identify product-like tasks inside my projects.

speaker: Lisa
text: Like, if I ran a stakeholder workshop, that is facilitation and discovery. If I defined a campaign KPI and tracked it, that is metrics. If I created a content journey based on user segments, that is user thinking.

speaker: Lisa
text: We translate.

speaker: Anna
text: So she is reframing your work through a product lens.

speaker: Lisa
text: Exactly. And then we rewrite my CV and LinkedIn around that. Not lying, but translating.

speaker: Lisa
text: And then we run job search as experiments. That is her style. We create hypotheses and test by response rates and callbacks.

speaker: Lisa
text: It is very, um, scientific.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you give a concrete example of one of these experiments?

speaker: Lisa
text: Yes. We did two CV variants. Variant A was more marketing heavy but with product adjacent language.

speaker: Lisa
text: Variant B was more aggressive, like product orientation, highlighting workshops, requirements, roadmap contributions, even if small. And then we targeted different roles. For A, we applied to product marketing roles, like PMM.

speaker: Lisa
text: For B, we applied to junior PM roles or associate PM roles, and also internal product roles. We tracked response rates in a spreadsheet. Like, how many applications, how many callbacks, how many recruiter screens, how many rejections, and why.

speaker: Anna
text: Do you remember any numbers, roughly?

speaker: Lisa
text: Um, yes, roughly. Variant A got like, maybe 20 to 25 percent callback for PMM, like recruiter replies. Variant B for PM roles got like 5 to 10 percent, which is not amazing, but it was not zero.

speaker: Lisa
text: And then we adjusted keywords. Like, we realized I used marketing language that PM recruiters ignore. We added words like discovery, backlog, stakeholder alignment, experimentation, prioritization.

speaker: Lisa
text: And we tailored the top summary. And then the response rate improved slightly, like from 5 percent to maybe 12 percent for some roles. Not huge, but enough to say, okay, it is possible.

speaker: Anna
text: How did that feel, emotionally, to treat job search like experiments?

speaker: Lisa
text: It helped my anxiety a lot. Because instead of, I got rejected, I am not good enough, it becomes, okay, hypothesis failed, adjust variables. It is less personal.

speaker: Lisa
text: It also fits my brain because at BCG we love frameworks. So it gave me something to hold onto.

speaker: Anna
text: You mentioned coaching is expensive but effective for you. Can you talk about that?

speaker: Lisa
text: Yes. It is expensive. I pay, um, I will not say exact number, but it is a significant amount per session.

speaker: Lisa
text: For Germany, it is not cheap. And I hesitated. I was like, should I spend this money?

speaker: Lisa
text: But I see it as investment. And I already feel outcomes. Like, clarity, reduced anxiety, better narrative, and also tangible things like more interviews.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you share a moment from coaching that increased your trust, something memorable?

speaker: Lisa
text: Yes. There was a session where I talked about internal politics. I was scared to say it, because it can be sensitive.

speaker: Lisa
text: Like, I told her about a situation where a senior person kind of blocked me from joining a product initiative. Not officially, but by saying, we need you in marketing now, stay in your lane. And I felt small and angry and also ashamed.

speaker: Lisa
text: And in the session, she did two things. First, she explicitly stated confidentiality. She said, I want you to know, this stays here, I do not work with your company, I do not know these people, and I will not share anything.

speaker: Lisa
text: And it was not like legal talk, it was calm. And I felt, okay, safe.

speaker: Anna
text: And the second thing?

speaker: Lisa
text: Second, she showed competence. She did not go into drama. She asked me to map stakeholders like a product launch.

speaker: Lisa
text: Who has power, who has interest, who could sponsor, what is the incentive. She was like, this is not personal, this is system. And then she gave me a script, like an exact wording for a conversation with my manager.

speaker: Lisa
text: In German, actually. Like, she said, you can say, Mir ist wichtig, meine Entwicklung Richtung Produkt zu gestalten, und ich moechte konkrete Schritte vereinbaren. Something like that.
