speaker: Lisa
text: And it worked. I used a version of it, and my manager responded better than I expected. That session made me trust her deeply, because she held my vulnerability and turned it into action.

speaker: Anna
text: What was vulnerable about it for you?

speaker: Lisa
text: I felt I was whining. In consulting culture, you are supposed to be solution oriented. So admitting I felt blocked felt weak.

speaker: Lisa
text: And also, there is fear of being naive. Like, maybe I misunderstand. She helped me see it clearly without making me feel stupid.

speaker: Anna
text: Was there a moment where you felt stuck and the coach helped you reframe?

speaker: Lisa
text: Yes. I remember one session where I said, I do not know if I am even allowed to want this. It sounds crazy, but I was like, who am I to think I can be a PM?

speaker: Lisa
text: And she stopped me. She said, okay, pause. Where did you learn that you need permission?

speaker: Lisa
text: And I was like, eehm, maybe family, school, German culture, like do not be too ambitious. And she reframed it as: you are already doing parts of product work, you just do not have the title. She asked me to list evidence.

speaker: Lisa
text: Like, concrete things I did. And then she said, your job is not to be chosen by the market, your job is to present evidence and learn. It sounds simple, but it hit me.

speaker: Anna
text: How did you feel after that session?

speaker: Lisa
text: Lighter. Also more confident. Not like, I am the best, but like, okay, I can try.

speaker: Lisa
text: It reduced anxiety.

speaker: Anna
text: Have you ever had an experience where you trusted the coach, but it was not effective in that moment?

speaker: Lisa
text: Yes, actually. Early on. In the first or second session, she wanted to go very deep into values, like what do you want in life, and I was in panic mode.

speaker: Lisa
text: I needed tactical help. I trusted her as a person, she was kind and smart, but I left the session thinking, okay, this was nice but I still do not know what to do next week. So it was trusted but not effective for my immediate needs.

speaker: Lisa
text: Then I told her, and she adjusted. She said, okay, we balance depth and action. That also increased trust, because she adapted.

speaker: Anna
text: That is a useful distinction. And on the other side, have you had something effective but not fully trusted? We will also talk about AI later, but within human coaching first.

speaker: Lisa
text: Within human coaching, maybe in the beginning I was like, is she really the right person? Like, she gave me a template for a networking message. It was effective, because people responded.

speaker: Lisa
text: But I still did not fully trust the method yet, because I was like, maybe this is too salesy. So I used it, it worked, but trust was still building. Now it is different.

speaker: Anna
text: What helps trust build over time for you?

speaker: Lisa
text: Consistency. She shows up. She remembers details.

speaker: Lisa
text: She tracks my progress. Also empathy without being fuzzy. Like, she can say, that sounds hard, and also, here is what we do.

speaker: Lisa
text: And confidentiality. And competence, yes.

speaker: Anna
text: And effectiveness, how do you evaluate that for your situation?

speaker: Lisa
text: Effectiveness is like, do I have more clarity? Did I make decisions? Did I take concrete actions?

speaker: Lisa
text: Do I get interviews? Do I feel less anxious? Do I have a narrative that feels true and strong?

speaker: Lisa
text: Also, at work, I see results. Like, I present myself differently in stakeholder meetings now, more like product thinking, and people respond. That is effectiveness too.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you. 5) AI tools experience and trust

speaker: Anna
text: Now I want to shift to AI tools. What AI tools do you use for career related things, and how?

speaker: Lisa
text: I use, um, mostly ChatGPT. And sometimes a tool like Notion AI for structuring notes. Also Grammarly, but that is more writing.

speaker: Lisa
text: For career, it is mostly ChatGPT. I use it for project audits and structure. Like, after a week, I dump what I did, and I ask it to categorize my tasks into product-like competencies.

speaker: Lisa
text: I also ask it to rewrite bullet points, or to generate a structure for a case story. But deep work is only with a human.

speaker: Anna
text: When you say deep work, what does that mean?

speaker: Lisa
text: Deep work is like, what am I actually afraid of? What is my real decision? Also, very tailored narrative.

speaker: Lisa
text: Like, how do I combine my BCG marketing story with product? AI can give generic, but it does not know my context fully. And also, I have privacy boundaries.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you give an example of a moment AI helped with project audit or restructuring accomplishments?

speaker: Lisa
text: Yes. There was a time I had to update my CV and I was overwhelmed. I had like, 12 projects, and BCG marketing projects are messy, like many stakeholders, and you do a bit of everything.

speaker: Lisa
text: I wrote a raw list of tasks, very unstructured. I put it into ChatGPT and asked: group these into themes, and suggest strong action verbs, and propose metrics placeholders. And it returned a neat structure.

speaker: Lisa
text: It was not perfect, but it helped me see patterns. Like, I realized I do a lot of experimentation, A B testing in campaigns, and also stakeholder workshops. And then I could bring that to my coach.

speaker: Lisa
text: So AI was effective as a first pass.

speaker: Anna
text: What made it effective there?

speaker: Lisa
text: Time. I mean speed of it. Seconds?

speaker: Lisa
text: And structure. It reduced cognitive load. It was like, okay, here is a draft.

speaker: Lisa
text: And then I can edit.

speaker: Anna
text: And can you describe a moment AI failed for you?

speaker: Lisa
text: Oh yes. Hahaha&. Many.

speaker: Lisa
text: One specific: I asked it to help me craft a story for why I want PM. I gave it my background, and it produced a very bland narrative, like, I am passionate about products and I want to leverage my marketing skills. It sounded like everyone.

speaker: Lisa
text: And it also assumed I had direct product ownership, like it wrote, led cross functional team to deliver product roadmap, which is not true. So I was like, no, that is dangerous. Also, it missed nuance.

speaker: Lisa
text: Like, my reason is partly emotional, partly about impact, partly about identity. It cannot capture that without a lot of back and forth.

speaker: Anna
text: Was there any privacy boundary moment?

speaker: Lisa
text: Yes and no at the same time. I hesitate to paste internal information. BCG has strict confidentiality.

speaker: Lisa
text: Even if I anonymize, I feel uneasy. So I keep it generic. And that makes the output more generic.

speaker: Lisa
text: But when I talk about myself i dont care.

speaker: Anna
text: How does that affect your trust in AI tools?

speaker: Lisa
text: It can lower it but depends on the task. Like, I trust it for structure,t for deep personal or confidential context sometimes but not like super strongly. Also, I sometimes worry about wrong assumptions.

speaker: Lisa
text: It can sound confident while being wrong. So I try to always verify.

speaker: Anna
text: Do you ever use AI during the coaching process?

speaker: Lisa
text: Yes, between sessions. Like, after a coaching call, I use AI to summarize my action items, or to draft an email to a mentor, or to brainstorm interview questions. But I do not replace the coach with AI.

speaker: Anna
text: What would make you trust AI more in this domain?

speaker: Lisa
text: Clear boundaries. Like, if it says, I cannot know your context, here are options. Also, better personalization without needing me to share sensitive data.

speaker: Lisa
text: And, eehm, maybe transparency, like why it suggests something. But honestly, performance matters most. If it consistently gives me useful outputs, I trust more.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you. 6) Human vs AI comparison via specific tasks

speaker: Anna
text: I want to compare human and AI through specific tasks. Let us take project audit first. If you had to choose, who is better for that, AI or your coach?

speaker: Lisa
text: AI is good for the first layer. Like, I dump tasks, it categorizes, it gives a structure. But my coach is better for meaning.

speaker: Lisa
text: She asks questions like, what did you decide, where did you influence, what was the impact. AI cannot ask the right follow ups in the same way, unless you prompt it very carefully. So, for project audit, I do both.

speaker: Lisa
text: AI for structure, human for interpretation.

speaker: Anna
text: What about rewriting CV and LinkedIn?

speaker: Lisa
text: AI can help with wording and variants. Like, give me three bullet options. That is helpful.

speaker: Lisa
text: But the coach is better for strategy. Like, what story do we want? What evidence do we highlight?

speaker: Lisa
text: How do we avoid overclaiming? She also knows market patterns. AI sometimes produces inflated language.

speaker: Lisa
text: In Germany, too much hype is a red flag. My coach catches that. She is like, do not sound like American sales.

speaker: Anna
text: And job search strategy, like selecting roles, companies, and testing hypotheses?

speaker: Lisa
text: Coach. Because she helps me decide what to test first, and how to interpret results. AI can suggest a list of companies, but it does not know internal constraints, like which BCG unit is realistic for me, or which hiring manager values what.

speaker: Lisa
text: Also, in Munich, the product ecosystem is different from Berlin. AI can say, apply to startups, but my coach asks, do you want startup risk? What is your visa situation?

speaker: Lisa
text: What salary floor? Things like that.

speaker: Anna
text: And emotional support, confidence, dealing with anxiety?

speaker: Lisa
text: Human. No question. AI can say supportive words, but it does not feel real to me.

speaker: Lisa
text: I mean, no wait, let me rephrase. It can be comforting for a minute, like journaling. But trust is different.

speaker: Lisa
text: With my coach, I feel seen. And AI can be like it is processing me? Scanning my words?

speaker: Lisa
text: I dont know

speaker: Anna
text: Can you explain what feeling processed means?

speaker: Lisa
text: Like, I input text, output comes. It is transactional. And sometimes it mirrors you, but you know it is a pattern.

speaker: Lisa
text: With my coach, she notices when I avoid something. She says, you laughed, why? She can sit with silence.

speaker: Lisa
text: AI fills silence with text.

speaker: Anna
text: Any tasks where AI is clearly better?

speaker: Lisa
text: Brainstorming quickly. Like, give me 20 interview questions, or a checklist for product case interviews, or a structure for a portfolio. Also language polishing.

speaker: Lisa
text: And sometimes, it is effective because it is available at night. Like, at 23:00, when I am spiraling, I can dump thoughts. Not ideal, but it is there.

speaker: Anna
text: And any tasks where the coach is clearly better beyond emotional support?

speaker: Lisa
text: Negotiating identity. Like, the shift from marketing to product is not just tasks, it is who I am. Also politics.

speaker: Lisa
text: And accountability. I tell her I will do something, and then two weeks later she asks, did you do it? AI does not hold me accountable unless I set it up.

speaker: Anna
text: So there is a relational accountability?

speaker: Lisa
text: Yes.

speaker: Anna
text: If you think about a very concrete moment, can you describe a time you tried AI for something and it did not work, and then you brought it to the coach and it did work?

speaker: Lisa
text: Yes. I tried AI to craft a message to a senior person at BCG  to ask about internal transfer. AI gave me a very formal message, polite but generic.

speaker: Lisa
text: I sent something similar once and I got no reply. Then I told my coach, and she asked, what is your relationship, what is the context, what do you want exactly, what is in it for them. And then we crafted a message that was short, specific, and referenced a concrete shared project.

speaker: Lisa
text: And I got a reply within one day. So AI was ineffective because it lacked relational nuance. Coach was effective because she coached me on social dynamics.

speaker: Anna
text: That is helpful.

speaker: Anna
text: I want to do a quick short rating part, just to capture your current perceptions. It will take about a minute. On a scale from 0 to 10, where 0 is no trust at all and 10 is complete trust, how would you rate your trust in human career coaches, in general?

speaker: Lisa
text: In general, I would say 8.

speaker: Anna
text: What makes it an 8 and not a 10?

speaker: Lisa
text: Because coaches vary. There are many on the market, and some are not good, or they overpromise. So general trust is not 10.

speaker: Lisa
text: But I believe a good human coach can be trustworthy because of empathy, confidentiality, and experience. That is why it is high.

speaker: Anna
text: And trust in AI tools for career support, 0 to 10?

speaker: Lisa
text: Maybe 5.

speaker: Anna
text: Why 5?

speaker: Lisa
text: Because I trust it for structure and drafts, but I do not trust it for nuance, confidentiality, and sometimes accuracy. It can hallucinate, like assume things. So it is mid.

speaker: Anna
text: Perceived effectiveness of human coaching for your situation, 0 to 10?

speaker: Lisa
text: For my situation, I would say 9.

speaker: Anna
text: Why 9?

speaker: Lisa
text: Because it actually moves me forward. I have actions, I have interviews, I have confidence. The only reason it is not 10 is because it is expensive, and also because not every session is a breakthrough.

speaker: Lisa
text: Sometimes it is maintenance.

speaker: Anna
text: And perceived effectiveness of AI tools for your situation, 0 to 10?

speaker: Anna
text: Why 6?

speaker: Lisa
text: It helps a lot with speed and structure. It is effective for certain tasks. But it cannot replace the human work, so sex.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you, that is very clear. 7) Trust-effectiveness link

speaker: Anna
text: Now I want to explore the link between trust and effectiveness in your experience. When you think about human coaching, how does trust affect whether it is effective?

speaker: Lisa
text: Trust is like the door. If I do not trust the coach, I will not share the real problem. And then they cannot help.

speaker: Lisa
text: Like, if I hide the messy parts, like insecurity, politics, fear, then the coach can only work on surface things, like CV wording. So trust enables depth. And depth makes it effective.

speaker: Anna
text: What are the main drivers of trust for you in a human coach?

speaker: Lisa
text: Competence. Like, do they understand my context, corporate, consulting pace, German market. Empathy, but not pity.

speaker: Lisa
text: Confidentiality, explicitly stated and felt. Structure, like a process. And feeling seen, like she remembers details, she catches patterns.

speaker: Anna
text: And what are your indicators that coaching is effective?

speaker: Lisa
text: Clarity, decisions, action. Like, I decide, okay, I will target PMM roles for two months and build a portfolio, then reassess. Or I decide to have a conversation with my manager.

speaker: Lisa
text: Also external indicators, like callbacks, interviews, response rates. And internal indicators, like less anxiety, more confidence, better narrative. And even at work, like I take more ownership, I speak in a different way, and stakeholders respond.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you think of a moment when trust was present but effectiveness was low, besides the early values session you mentioned?

speaker: Lisa
text: Yes. There was a session recently where I was very tired. BCG had a big push, and I was burned out.

speaker: Lisa
text: I trusted her, but I could not implement anything. So the session felt like, okay, we talked, but nothing moved. And then she noticed and said, maybe the effective thing now is rest.

speaker: Lisa
text: So the definition of effectiveness changed. But in the moment, I was like, not effective.

speaker: Anna
text: That is interesting, effectiveness depends on capacity.

speaker: Lisa
text: Exactly.

speaker: Anna
text: And can you think of a moment where something was effective but you did not fully trust it?

speaker: Lisa
text: That is mostly AI. Like, AI gave me a very good structure for a portfolio outline. It was effective because it saved time and it looked professional.

speaker: Lisa
text: But I did not fully trust it because I was like, is this actually the right thing for German PM interviews? Or is it generic i dont know silicon valley stuff. So I used it, but I needed validation from my coach.

speaker: Anna
text: So you can separate usefulness from trust?

speaker: Lisa
text: Yes. Usefulness can be high even when trust is not high. It is like, I can take the output as a draft, but I do not let it decide for me.

speaker: Anna
text: In your experience, does trust always lead to effectiveness?

speaker: Lisa
text: Not always. It increases the chance. Like, if I trust my coach, I will do the work and I will share more.

speaker: Lisa
text: But effectiveness also depends on timing and method. Like if I am burned out, even the best coach will not create miracles.

speaker: Anna
text: And can something be effective without trust, or with low trust?

speaker: Lisa
text: Yes, for small tasks. Like, if a person gives me a good template, I can use it. But for big decisions, I need trust.

speaker: Lisa
text: Otherwise I resist. I either do not follow through or I keep it superficial.

speaker: Anna
text: How do you notice in yourself that trust is missing?

speaker: Lisa
text: I become performative. Like I speak in polished phrases. Very BCG.

speaker: Lisa
text: ] I present a story instead of the truth. And I do not mention the parts that feel messy. That is when I know trust is not there.

speaker: Anna
text: aha and in human coaching, what did your coach do that made you not feel you had to be performative?

speaker: Lisa
text: She normalizes. She says, it is okay to not know. And she also uses silence.

speaker: Lisa
text: Like, if I say something and then I laugh, she waits and says, what is behind the laugh. That is uncomfortable but it makes it real. And also she shares structure.

speaker: Lisa
text: Like, okay, today we do audit, then we do narrative, then we do next steps. So I feel held.

speaker: Anna
text: Does confidentiality come up explicitly in your coaching relationship?

speaker: Lisa
text: Yes. In the first session she explained how she handles notes, what she stores, that she does not share anything. And then later, when I brought up sensitive internal stuff, she repeated it in a natural way.

speaker: Lisa
text: Not like legal text, but like, this is your safe space, I do not work with BCG, nothing leaves here. That matters.

speaker: Anna
text: Is there anything that could break trust quickly for you?

speaker: Lisa
text: Hm i guess if she would judge me. Like, if she says, why are you complaining, or you should just be grateful. That would break it.

speaker: Lisa
text: Also if she would push me into a decision that benefits her, like keeping me as a client, or if she would promise unrealistic outcomes. And if she would share even a small detail that makes me feel exposed. But that has not happened.

speaker: Anna
text: When you think of AI tools, do you have trust drivers there too, or is it different?

speaker: Lisa
text: It is different. AI trust drivers are more like, does it give consistent output, does it respect constraints, does it avoid inventing. And also, does it keep my data safe, but I cannot really verify that.

speaker: Lisa
text: So I rely on my own boundary.

speaker: Anna
text: So you manage trust by controlling what you input?

speaker: Lisa
text: Exactly. Like i do not paste internal numbers. I do not paste names.

speaker: Lisa
text: I keep it general. And then I accept that the output is general.

speaker: Anna
text: That if you had to describe the trust effectiveness link in one sentence for your situation, how would you say it?

speaker: Lisa
text: Trust allows me to be honest, and honesty makes the coaching effective. For AI, usefulness is separate from trust, because it can be useful without being relationally trustworthy.

speaker: Anna
text: alright. Let us move to comparing human and AI directly via tasks. 8) Preferences and hybrid model reaction

speaker: Anna
text: Imagine you have three tasks this week like one doing a project audit of your last two weeks, two, rewriting a LinkedIn section to be more product oriented, and three, preparing for a tough career conversation with your manager. For each task, which support would you choose and why?

speaker: Lisa
text: Okay. Project audit, I would start with AI. Because I can dump everything and get structure fast.

speaker: Lisa
text: Then I bring it to my coach for refinement.

speaker: Anna
text: Why not directly with the coach?

speaker: Lisa
text: Because coach time is expensive and limited. And also, AI can do the messy first pass without me feeling judged. Then I come to the coach with something more organized.

speaker: Anna
text: And rewriting LinkedIn?

speaker: Lisa
text: Both. AI for options, like three versions, different tones. But the coach for strategy, like what positioning is credible for me in Germany and within BCG context.

speaker: Lisa
text: Also she catches when it sounds too inflated.

speaker: Anna
text: And the career conversation with your manager?

speaker: Lisa
text: Only human. I would not use AI for that beyond maybe drafting the email follow up. But the core conversation prep needs a human.

speaker: Lisa
text: Because it is emotional, political, and I need to anticipate reactions. AI can give generic scripts, but it cannot read the relationship dynamics.

speaker: Anna
text: What makes you say relationship dynamics is crucial?

speaker: Lisa
text: Because my manager is supportive but also under pressure. If I push too hard, she might shut down. If I am too vague, nothing changes.

speaker: Lisa
text: My coach helps me find the right balance. She asks, what does your manager care about, what can you offer, what is a small ask. That is nuanced.

speaker: Anna
text: If you think about hybrid models, some providers imagine AI as a coach that chats with you daily, and then a human coach occasionally. How do you react to that?

speaker: Lisa
text: My first reaction is, hmm, no. Daily AI coaching feels like noise. I would use it like a journal, but I would not call it coaching.

speaker: Lisa
text: Coaching for me is depth, not frequency.

speaker: Anna
text: What would be your ideal hybrid setup?

speaker: Lisa
text: AI as a preparation and follow up assistant, like collecting my data, making a summary, tracking my experiment metrics, reminding me of action steps. Then human sessions every two weeks for deep work, decisions, and accountability. That is ideal.

speaker: Anna
text: What would you want AI to do specifically between sessions?

speaker: Lisa
text: It could help me do a weekly audit. Like, what did you do, what are outcomes, what are blockers, what is next. And it could generate drafts: networking messages, CV bullet variants, interview question lists.

speaker: Lisa
text: Also maybe a small tracker: which roles I applied to, response rates, and patterns. Like, if PM roles at certain companies respond more, that is data.

speaker: Anna
text: And what do you not want AI to do?

speaker: Lisa
text: Interpret my emotions. Or give me therapy style responses. And I do not want it to pretend it understands my life.

speaker: Lisa
text: I want clear boundaries. Also I do not want it to store sensitive data. If it has memory, I would be cautious.

speaker: Anna
text: If we take a step further: imagine a system where AI suggests a career decision, like you should choose internal transfer over external. Would you accept that?

speaker: Lisa
text: No, I would not accept it as decision. I might accept it as a set of options. Like, here are pros and cons.

speaker: Lisa
text: But the decision has to be mine, and ideally discussed with a human, because it involves values and risk.

speaker: Anna
text: What kind of risk?

speaker: Lisa
text: Financial, because coaching and job search take time. Also identity risk. Like leaving BCG brand.

speaker: Lisa
text: And in Germany, job changes are sometimes judged. Not always, but there is still a cultural thing of stability. Also practical things like location.

speaker: Lisa
text: Berlin is exciting but chaotic, Munich is stable but maybe less startup. So it is not a pure optimization problem.

speaker: Anna
text: That is interesting. If you imagine AI tools becoming much better at personalization and context, would that change your preference?

speaker: Lisa
text: It would change it partially. If AI could truly understand my context without me sharing sensitive data, and if it could challenge me like a good coach, then maybe. But I still think human presence matters.

speaker: Lisa
text: Like, when I am stuck, I need a person to look at me and say, I see you, and I believe you can do it, and also, you are avoiding the real issue. AI can imitate that, but it will not feel real to me. So I think I will always want some human element.

speaker: Anna
text: What if the human element was a group format, like group coaching, and AI handles individual prep?

speaker: Lisa
text: That could work. Group coaching can be cheaper. And hearing other people also reduces shame.

speaker: Lisa
text: Like, you realize everyone is struggling. And AI could handle the repetitive parts. But I would still want at least some one to one time for my specific situation, because internal BCG politics are very specific.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you. That covers hybrid preferences nicely. Let us go to the last blocks.

speaker: Anna
text: We already discussed trust and effectiveness as separate, but I want to ask you to reflect on the link more directly for AI versus human, and then we close. 9) Closing

speaker: Anna
text: As we wrap up, if you think about your own journey from marketing toward product, what do you think has changed most due to human coaching, and what has changed due to AI tools?

speaker: Lisa
text: Human coaching changed my identity narrative. Like, I stopped seeing myself as only marketing. I started seeing product thinking inside what I do.

speaker: Lisa
text: It also changed my behavior. I take more ownership, I speak differently. And it reduced my anxiety.

speaker: Lisa
text: AI tools changed my execution speed. Like i can create drafts faster, I can structure my thoughts, I can get unstuck on small tasks.

speaker: Anna
text: If you had to give one advice to someone similar to you, early career in Germany, wanting to switch into product, what would you say about trust and effectiveness in the support they choose?

speaker: Lisa
text: I would say, choose support that you trust enough to be honest. Because if you hide, you will not get the help you need. And effectiveness is not just motivation, it is concrete actions and feedback loops.

speaker: Lisa
text: If a coach or tool does not lead to actions, you will stay stuck.

speaker: Anna
text: Anything you would like to add that we did not cover?

speaker: Lisa
text: No

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you, Lisa. I will stop the recording now.

speaker: Anna
text: Hi Laura, thanks for joining. Before we start, I want to check a few things. Is it okay for you that I am recording this interview for transcription purposes?

speaker: Anna
text: I wont share the recording, only the transcript, everything will be anonymized.

speaker: Laura
text: Yes, this is fine.

speaker: Anna
text: Great. And just to confirm, you can skip any question, and you can stop the interview at any time, no explanation needed. Okay?

speaker: Laura
text: Yes, sounds good.

speaker: Anna
text: Perfect. Also, for context, I am interested in how early career people experience trust and perceived effectiveness in different kinds of career support, including AI tools and human coaching. There are no right or wrong answers.

speaker: Anna
text: I may ask follow up questions, just to understand your perspective. Any questions before we begin?

speaker: Laura
text: No

speaker: Anna
text: Great. Can you briefly introduce yourself in the way you would if someone asked you at a networking event? Just whatever feels natural.

speaker: Laura
text: Um, okay. I am Laura, I am 25, I live in Munich. I did my Bachelor in Aerospace, finished two years ago.

speaker: Laura
text: I started a Master after that, and eehm, I am kind of in the middle of a pivot. I am trying to get into something like cloud engineering, platform stuff, ideally in a startup.I was born in Spain, but I moved to Germany when I was seven, so I grew up here.

speaker: Anna
text: Thanks. We will go step by step. Let us move to your current situation.

speaker: Anna
text: Where are you currently in your career, and what career decisions or questions are you facing right now?

speaker: Laura
text: Eehm, so right now I am in a Master program at TUM. I started it because I thought I wanted research, like the classic path, you know, Bachelor, then Master, then maybe PhD, maybe a research institute. That was like the plan in my head.

speaker: Laura
text: But then I started and I was like, no. Like, no wait, let me rephrase. Not that the topic is bad, but the environment and the daily life of research, it felt so slow and kind of isolated.

speaker: Anna
text: Aha, i understand. When you say slow and isolated, what do you mean by that?

speaker: Laura
text: Like, weeks of reading papers, meetings where everyone speaks in very careful language, a lot of, um, how to say ehm i dont remember the word nevermind. I realized I get energy from shipping something, from seeing impact, from being in a team that builds and moves. Research can have impact, obviously, but it felt like I was always preparing for impact.

speaker: Anna
text: So what is the decision you are facing now?

speaker: Laura
text: The main decision is basically do I finish the Master as it is, or do I kind of reframe it to support the pivot. I am attracted to startups, but I also see the risk, like stability, visa stuff does not apply to me because I have German citizenship, but still, rent in Munich is not funny. And also language expectations.

speaker: Laura
text: Like my German is fluent, but in tech jobs a lot is English, and then some companies still want German for internal stuff. It is like, okay, where do I fit best.

speaker: Anna
text: If you think about the last 6 to 12 months, what was the most significant moment or turning point in your thinking?

speaker: Laura
text: There was one moment, yes. I was doing a research project, like a lab project, at a chair that works with simulations. It was not even a bad chair, the people were fine.

speaker: Laura
text: But we had this meeting, and I presented some results, and the professor was like, yes, interesting, but now you need to validate it with more literature, and then maybe in three months we can think about a workshop paper. And I remember walking out and feeling physically heavy. I was like, is this my life.

speaker: Laura
text: Another three months for a workshop paper that maybe five people read. And then, in the same week, I went to an event at Unternehmer TUM, and it was so different. People spoke about actual products, customers, costs, scaling.

speaker: Laura
text: And I was like, oh. This is where my brain feels something good.

speaker: Anna
text: Tell me about that UnternehmerTUM event. What kind of event was it, and what did you take away?

speaker: Laura
text: It was at the Unternehmertum building, like this startup hub vibe. I think it was a talk plus networking. The topic was something like platform strategy or infrastructure, maybe not exactly those words, but it was about building reliable systems for growth.

speaker: Laura
text: There was someone from a Munich startup, not like a huge сompany, more like Series A or something, and they explained how they migrated from a messy setup to a more structured platform approach. They talked about things like monitoring, incident response, and how that affects customer trust. And I was like, wow, this is engineering that sits directly next to business outcomes.

speaker: Laura
text: Like, if you do it well, the company can move faster, and customers are happy, and you avoid downtime.

speaker: Anna
text: Did something specific stick in your mind from that talk?

speaker: Laura
text: Yes. They said something like, platform engineering is not about tools, it is about enabling teams. Like internal customers.

speaker: Laura
text: And they described building a self service platform where dev teams can deploy without waiting for permission. And I was like, that is basically reducing friction, like a product, but interna. And I think that connected to me because I like systems.

speaker: Laura
text: Aerospace is also systems, but in aerospace it is often slow with heavy compliance, long cycles. Here it is faster.

speaker: Anna
text: So after that, what did you do? Did you take concrete steps?

speaker: Laura
text: I did. i started exploring what roles exist, like cloud engineer, DevOps, SRE, platform engineer. I realized the titles are messy.

speaker: Laura
text: And also  started learning more practically. I did a basic cloud certification prep, like AWS Cloud Practitioner first, and then I started looking at Solutions Architect Associate, but that one is heavy. And then I also tried some labs with Terraform and Docker.

speaker: Laura
text: Not super advanced, but enough to see if I like it.

speaker: Anna
text: And where are you now with the Master? You said you are in the middle of a pivot.

speaker: Laura
text: I am still enrolled. I have finished most core modules. I chose some electives that are more software or systems oriented.

speaker: Laura
text: I also took one entrepreneurship or management course, because I want to be closer to business. For the thesis, I am trying to find a topic that is not purely aerospace research, maybe something like cloud infrastructure for simulation pipelines, or reliability in engineering tools, something bridging.I am also applying for internships in startups, but it is competitive.

speaker: Anna
text: What makes it difficult right now for you?

speaker: Laura
text: Hm, uncertainty? Identity issues too. Like, my CV says aerospace.

speaker: Laura
text: People assume I want aerospace. And then I say, no, I want platform engineering, and they are like, why. And sometimes I feel like I am betraying my past self, you know.

speaker: Laura
text: But also I think it is normal to change. Also the job descriptions are crazy. Entry level but they want three years of Kubernetes, and then also German, and then also on call experience.

speaker: Laura
text: I am like, okay, sure hahaha.

speaker: Anna
text: What kind of support did you feel you needed during this period?

speaker: Laura
text: I dont know

speaker: Anna
text: Like what did you want someone experienced to tell you?

speaker: Laura
text: Ah, okay, like maybe what is the path, what are the steps, how do I present the story. Also accountability maybe. But I hate the idea of someone telling me who I am.

speaker: Laura
text: I need support but also that does not mean i am lost.

speaker: Anna
text: You mean you want to be in charge?

speaker: Laura
text: Yes.

speaker: Anna
text: Understood. Let us move to career support in general.

speaker: Anna
text: When you need career support, who or what do you usually turn to?

speaker: Laura
text: To myself, like journaling. Can use AI, like ChatGPT, for structured reflection. Then sometimes I talk to friends who work in tech.

speaker: Laura
text: I also talk to my boyfriend, but he is not in tech, so it is more emotional support. And I sometimes ask professors for practical things, but not career coaching, more like, can you recommend a course, can you connect me to someone. And also I go to events, like meetups, UnternehmerTUM, sometimes TUM career events, to just hear what exists.

speaker: Anna
text: When you talk to friends, what do you ask them?

speaker: Laura
text: Very concrete questions. Like, what do you actually do as a platform engineer. What skills do you use daily.

speaker: Laura
text: How did you get your first job. How do interviews look. And I trust that more because it is grounded.

speaker: Laura
text: Not like, follow your passion, and the universe will deliver. That kind of stuff makes me angry hahaha.

speaker: Anna
text: What has actually helped, and what felt unhelpful or frustrating?

speaker: Laura
text: Helpful is when someone gives me a mental model or a concrete step. Like, do one certification, build one small project, write about it, apply to these roles, tailor CV like this. Also helpful is when someone says, this is hard, but normal.

speaker: Laura
text: Unhelpful is vague advice or commodified empathy. Like, people who sell feelings. Also, anything that feels like influencer culture, like, buy my product, I will tell you your purpose.

speaker: Laura
text: That is, um, no.

speaker: Anna
text: You mentioned professors. Have you had any mentoring type relationship?

speaker: Laura
text: In a way, yes. I had one lecturer who was very honest about industry. He worked in Airbus before academia.

speaker: Laura
text: When I said I am thinking about leaving research, he did not judge, he said, okay, then you need to optimize for learning speed, go where you can do stuff. That felt like mentoring. But it was not a paid coach situation.

speaker: Anna
text: If you had to list what you need most from any form of support, what are the top two or three things?

speaker: Laura
text: Structure, realism, and maybe a mirror. Like reflecting my own thoughts back so I can see them.

speaker: Anna
text: A mirror? interesting. We will come back to that.

speaker: Anna
text: Now I want to focus specifically on human career coaching, even if you have not used it. 4) Human coaching experience and trust

speaker: Anna
text: Have you ever used human career coaching consultations, for example university career services or private coaching?

speaker: Laura
text: No. And I do not want to. I know that sounds harsh.

speaker: Laura
text: But I have a strong negative view.

speaker: Anna
text: That is okay. Can you tell me what your expectations are, and why you feel negative about it?

speaker: Laura
text: Eehm. I think coaching as an industry is full of nonsense. Like, people who have no real skills, but they learned how to talk, and they package common sense as a product.

speaker: Laura
text: And in Germany especially, there is this thing where people use titles and certifications to sound serious. But then they tell you very generic things. And they charge like 150 euros per hour for talking.

speaker: Laura
text: And I have seen friends being manipulated. Like, someone tells them, your fear is blocking you, invest in yourself, and then they buy more sessions. It feels like a scam ecosystem.

speaker: Anna
text: When you say manipulated, what happened to your friends?

speaker: Laura
text: One friend from my Bachelor, she was very anxious about jobs. She went to a coach she found on Better Go or something like that . The coach told her that she has limiting beliefs and she needs to commit to a package of three sessions, otherwise she will not change.

speaker: Laura
text: And my friend paid, and after three sessions she felt worse, because she felt like she is failing the coaching too. And the advice was like, visualize your future, write affirmations. That is not what she needed.

speaker: Laura
text: She needed interview prep and a plan. So I watched that and I was like, nope.

speaker: Anna
text: That sounds like a specific style of coaching. Do you make a difference between that and, for example, a coach provided by a university career center? Like a sound career coach, not just a coach?

speaker: Laura
text: Hmm. Maybe. I know TUM has career services, and those people are probably more grounded.

speaker: Laura
text: I still have skepticism, but I can imagine they might help with CV formatting or general guidance. But I think the private coaching market ruined the concept for me. Also, I do not like the power dynamic.

speaker: Laura
text: Like, I sit there and someone pretends to know my life better than me.

speaker: Anna
text: What do you think a human career coach would do in a session, if you imagine it?

speaker: Laura
text: They would ask me about my values, my strengths, maybe some tests. Then they would tell me I can do anything.

speaker: Anna
text: Jokes aside there can be like this sometimes yes.

speaker: Laura
text: Yes. And then maybe they would help with LinkedIn. But I think for complex situations, they do not have the context.

speaker: Laura
text: Like, they do not know the technical landscape, they do not know what a platform engineer actually does. Unless they are specialized.

speaker: Anna
text: What would make you trust a human career coach, hypothetically? If you think of trust drivers.

speaker: Laura
text: Competence, obviously. Like proven experience in the domain. Not just talking.

speaker: Laura
text: Also honesty about limits. If someone says, I do not know, that increases trust. Also not pushing packages.

speaker: Laura
text: And maybe references. Like if someone I respect recommends them. But in general, my baseline is low.

speaker: Anna
text: What about affective aspects, like empathy, feeling understood?

speaker: Laura
text: I do not want empathy from a stranger that I pay. It feels fake. Like, I know they are being nice because it is their job.

speaker: Laura
text: Maybe that is unfair, but that is how it feels. I prefer empathy from friends. For career decisions, I prefer competence and a plan.

speaker: Anna
text: You said earlier you need a mirror. Some people see a coach as a mirror. What makes that different for you?

speaker: Laura
text: Because the coach mirror comes with interpretation. And I do not trust their interpretation. If I want a mirror, I want something that reflects my words and helps me structure, but does not impose a narrative.

speaker: Laura
text: That is actually why I like AI, because it is basically me and my answers and model of thinking.

speaker: Anna
text: You said baseline trust is low. Can you give a number? I will ask you a few quick ratings later, but we can start here.

speaker: Anna
text: On a scale from 0 to 10, where 0 is no trust at all and 10 is complete trust, what is your trust in human career coaches, in general?

speaker: Laura
text: For private career coaches, maybe 1. For something like university career services, maybe 3. But if you ask one number, overall, I would say 2.

speaker: Anna
text: And why 2, not 0?

speaker: Laura
text: Because I know there are probably some good people. And also sometimes even generic advice can trigger something. Like, you hear something obvious and you finally do it.

speaker: Laura
text: So not zero. But yeah, very low.

speaker: Anna
text: aha cool thank you. We will revisit effectiveness separately. For now, I want to move to AI tools, where you said you have real experience.

speaker: Anna
text: Which AI based tools have you used for career related questions, and what was your experience?

speaker: Laura
text: Mostly ChatGPT. Also sometimes Perplexity for searching, but the main is ChatGPT because it is conversational. I use it like a thinking partner.

speaker: Laura
text: Like self coaching. I open it and I basically talk to it like I talk to myself, but it responds with structure.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you walk me through a concrete situation where you used it?

speaker: Laura
text: Yes. When I realized I might not want research, I was confused. I felt guilty, like I wasted time.

speaker: Laura
text: So I wrote a long message describing my situation, what I liked, what I hated, what I feared. And I asked it to help me map options. Not like telling me what to do, but like making a decision framework.

speaker: Laura
text: It responded with categories, like values, constraints, experiments. It suggested doing small experiments, like attending events, doing a small cloud project, talking to people. And that actually helped me because it made it actionable instead of emotional chaos.

speaker: Anna
text: What does trust mean for you when it comes to ChatGPT?

speaker: Laura
text: Trust is different. I do not trust it as truth. I trust it as a tool for reflection.

speaker: Laura
text: So I trust that it will give me a structured response and not judge me. And I trust that it will be available and consistent. I do not trust that it is always accurate about facts.

speaker: Laura
text: And I do not trust it with personal data, like very sensitive details. I keep some boundaries.

speaker: Anna
text: What boundaries for example?

speaker: Laura
text: I do not tell it names of companies I am applying to, or personal details about family, or things that could identify me. I keep it more abstract. And if I paste something like my CV, I remove contact data.

speaker: Laura
text: And I do not tell it like private conflicts. Maybe some, but not too deep.

speaker: Anna
text: You said you use it for self coaching. How exactly do you do that? Is it like daily, weekly?

speaker: Laura
text: It depends. In intense phases, I use it almost daily. Like when I am applying for jobs, I use it to rewrite bullet points, to prepare for interviews, to draft messages, to simulate questions.

speaker: Laura
text: In calmer phases, maybe once a week, like check in.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you give an example of a prompt, without quoting it directly, just describing what you asked?

speaker: Laura
text: Sure. I asked something like: here is my background in aerospace, here is why I want platform engineering, help me craft a narrative that does not sound random, and give me three versions, one for a startup recruiter, one for a corporate, and one for networking. And also highlight gaps and how to address them.

speaker: Laura
text: That kind of thing.

speaker: Anna
text: And what did it produce that was useful?

speaker: Laura
text: It gave me a structure: past, pivot trigger, present actions, future goal. It also suggested specific phrases to connect aerospace systems thinking with platform reliability. That was helpful.

speaker: Laura
text: It also listed gaps like lack of production experience, and suggested ways to compensate, like personal projects, open source contributions, internships.

speaker: Anna
text: What do you see as the main reasons you trust it more than a human coach?

speaker: Laura
text: It is not trying to sell me anything.I am already paying for premium though hahaha. At least it feels like that. It  is consistent and fast also it does not judge.

speaker: Laura
text: And what i like specifically is that it can adapt to my style. Like, if I say, be more direct, it does it. A human coach might be like, hmm, let us explore your childhood.

speaker: Laura
text: No thanks.

speaker: Anna
text: And what makes you distrust it, or trust it conditionally?

speaker: Laura
text: It can write complete cringe. Like, it can confidently say wrong things. That is a problem.

speaker: Laura
text: Also it can be basic. Sometimes it gives advice that is like the same that the selling coach gives like, network more, learn skills, be confident. And I am like, okay, thanks.

speaker: Laura
text: Also privacy. And also it sometimes assumes things about me.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you describe a specific moment where it failed in a way that mattered?

speaker: Laura
text: Yes. I asked about a specific certification path and job requirements in Germany. It recommended a certain certification that is more US focused, and it also said some companies require it, but when I checked, it was not true.

speaker: Laura
text: It sounded plausible, but it was not accurate for startups in DACH. And also once I asked about salary ranges, and it gave numbers that felt inflated i think.

speaker: Anna
text: Did that reduce your trust?

speaker: Laura
text: It reduced trust overall but i already knew it is not to be trusted. So yes but no in the reflection function. Like, I still trust it to help me think, but I do not trust it to be a source of truth.

speaker: Anna
text: If we do a quick rating: on 0 to 10, what is your trust in AI tools like ChatGPT for your career related needs?

speaker: Laura
text: Hmm. I would say 7.

speaker: Anna
text: Why 7, not 9?

speaker: Laura
text: Because of hallucinations and privacy. And because it lacks real world accountability. Like, it can say anything, and nothing happens to it.

speaker: Laura
text: So I keep it at 7.

speaker: Anna
text: Why 7, not 4?

speaker: Laura
text: Because it is actually useful and consistent. It has helped me a lot. So it earned trust through experience.

speaker: Anna
text: Great. Now I want to compare human and AI via tasks, because your thesis topic is about differences across tasks.

speaker: Anna
text: If you think about specific career tasks, which ones would you prefer AI for, and which ones would you prefer a human for, and why?

speaker: Laura
text: AI for brainstorming options, structuring plans, rewriting CV bullet points, cover letters, preparing interview answers, explaining concepts, giving learning roadmaps. Also for practicing, like mock interview questions. Human for specific mentoring, like someone who actually works as a platform engineer telling me what matters.

speaker: Laura
text: Also maybe emotional support, but not from a coach, more from friends. And maybe for negotiation or reading a room?

speaker: Anna
text: Let us pick one task. Clarifying options. If you were deciding between staying in research and going to business, how would AI and humans differ?

speaker: Laura
text: AI helped me create a matrix. Like, criteria and scoring. Humans often give opinions.

speaker: Laura
text: Like, do what makes you happy. Or they project their own fears. AI felt more neutral.

speaker: Laura
text: But it can miss context, like cultural stuff, family expectations.

speaker: Anna
text: Family expectations, can you tell me a bit about that?

speaker: Laura
text: My parents are Spanish, but they live here. They are hardworking, and they value stable careers. Aerospace sounds prestigious to them.

speaker: Laura
text: Research sounds prestigious too. Startup cloud engineer sounds like, what is that. So there is this pressure to not waste the degree.

speaker: Laura
text: They are not controlling, but they worry. And also in Spanish culture there is a bit of, you have difficulties, you do not jump around too much. So part of me is like, I should just finish and go to Airbus.

speaker: Laura
text: And part of me is like, no, I want something else. AI cannot fully understand that emotional layer, but it can help me articulate it.

speaker: Anna
text: And decision making? Do you think AI can support decisions effectively?

speaker: Laura
text: It can support the process but I don't think it can decide. But it can break down the decision. It can suggest experiments.

speaker: Laura
text: A human can also do that, but again, depends on the person.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you give an example where AI gave you a plan you actually followed?

speaker: Laura
text: Hm. Yes. I asked for a 12 week learning plan for some role, assuming I have 10 hours per week, and I want to be ready for internships.

speaker: Laura
text: It gave me weeks, topics, small projects. I followed it partly. Like not perfectly, but it made me start.

speaker: Laura
text: Without that, I would just be overwhelmed and would look for info in websites? I dont know even how people did that before chat GPT

speaker: Anna
text: What about CV and applications?

speaker: Laura
text: AI is great there. Like, you paste a bullet point, it makes it stronger. But you need to check truthfulness, because it sometimes exaggerates.

speaker: Laura
text: It can add things like led cross functional team, and I am like, no. So you need to control it.

speaker: Anna
text: You said human mentoring could be valuable. That is interesting given your strong rejection of coaching. Can you clarify the difference for you?

speaker: Laura
text: Yes. Mentoring is anchored in real experience. Like, a senior engineer telling me what they do.

speaker: Laura
text: Coaching feels like someone selling a method. Mentoring is not trying to transform your soul. It is like, here is reality.

speaker: Laura
text: And I respect that.

speaker: Anna
text: If you imagine a human career coach who is actually specialized, like someone who used to be a platform engineer and now coaches people into that field, would that change anything?

speaker: Laura
text: Maybe. It would increase competence trust. But I still dislike the vibe of coaching.

speaker: Laura
text: I would rather just talk to an engineer. But, okay, I can imagine for some people it helps to have a structured human guiding them, especially if they lack self discipline.

speaker: Anna
text: So there is a thing. For you, if i understood correctly, the label coaching is the problem, and the market practices?

speaker: Laura
text: I guess yes.

speaker: Anna
text: Now I want to ask explicitly about trust and effectiveness as separate concepts. Sometimes people say, I trust something but it does not help, or I do not trust it but it still helps. Do you have examples of that?

speaker: Laura
text: Yes. I think low trust but usefulI once attended a career talk, not at TUM, like a general career seminar. I did not trust the speaker because they were very salesy.

speaker: Laura
text: But they shared one framework for telling your story in interviews, like situation, task, action, result. That was useful. Even though I disliked them, I took the framework and used it.

speaker: Laura
text: So effectiveness can exist without trust.

speaker: Anna
text: Aha. Thank you. And high trust but limited effectiveness?

speaker: Laura
text: Probably also yes with AI  i trust ChatGPT to brainstorm and not judge me. But it cannot fully capture emotions. Like, sometimes I ask, why do I feel stuck, and it gives a reasonable answer, but it does not feel like being seen by a human.

speaker: Laura
text: It is like cognitive empathy, not real. So I trust it to be supportive, but it does not always change how I feel. It helps me think, but not always feel better.

speaker: Anna
text: So in your mind, trust and effectiveness are linked but not identical.

speaker: Laura
text: Seems to me like so yes. But like  if I do not trust something, I might not use it. But sometimes you still use it because it is convenient.

speaker: Laura
text: Like, I do not trust social media influencers, but sometimes I still watch a clip and get that blush from a tiktok shop you know. And effectiveness is about what came after. Like outcome or end goal was reached or not.

speaker: Anna
text: If you think about the way trust affects effectiveness for you, what is the mechanism?

speaker: Laura
text: If I trust the source, I invest more attention, I follow through. If I distrust, I keep distance, I might still take small pieces. So trust affects depth of engagement.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you. Now I want to do the short micro poll ratings, just to anchor the conversation. We already did two, but we will do all four clearly.

speaker: Anna
text: I will ask, and you give a number and a short explanation.

speaker: Laura
text: Okay.

speaker: Anna
text: On a scale from 0 to 10, your trust in human career coaches.

speaker: Laura
text: 2. Because I associate it with a market of vague advice and sales tactics. I think some are okay, but I start skeptical.

speaker: Anna
text: On a scale from 0 to 10, your trust in AI tools like ChatGPT for career support.

speaker: Laura
text: 7. Because it is consistent and helpful for structure, but it can hallucinate and there are privacy limits.

speaker: Anna
text: Perceived effectiveness of human career coaching for your situation, hypothetical, 0 to 10.

speaker: Laura
text: For me personally, maybe 3. It could help with generic things like CV review, but I do not think it would help with my real pivot decisions. Unless the person is very specialized.

speaker: Anna
text: Why 3, not 6?

speaker: Laura
text: Because I would resist it. I would sit there and internally argue. So even if it is good, it would not work on me.

speaker: Laura
text: Also cost. I would feel annoyed paying for it.

speaker: Anna
text: Fourth: Perceived effectiveness of AI tools for your situation, based on your experience, 0 to 10.

speaker: Anna
text: Why 8, not 10?

speaker: Laura
text: Because of factual unreliability and because it cannot replace real world mentorship and emotional depth. But it is very effective for planning, preparation, and clarity.

speaker: Anna
text: You mentioned earlier that you believe everyone should find their own path through difficulty? Can you explain that belief a bit?

speaker: Laura
text: Eehm, yes. I think struggle is part of building a real identity. If someone tells you what to do, you borrow their certainty.

speaker: Laura
text: But it is not yours. And then when it gets hard, you collapse. Whereas if you fight through confusion, you build internal trust.

speaker: Laura
text: That sounds dramatic. But I feel it. Like, I moved countries as a kid, I learned languages, I had to adapt.

speaker: Laura
text: That taught me that discomfort is normal. So when I see coaching that promises easy clarity, I distrust it. Life is messy.

speaker: Anna
text: Wow that is cool. Is there any scenario where you would accept paid human support?

speaker: Laura
text: If it is technical mentorship, like paying for a session with a senior cloud engineer to review my project or my approach. That is basically consulting. I would pay for expertise.

speaker: Anna
text: So it is not the money itself, it is what you pay for.

speaker: Laura
text: Exactly.

speaker: Anna
text: Imagine a hybrid model that combines AI for structured reflection and preparation, and then human experts for targeted sessions, for example to validate your plan, give industry context, or help with a key decision. How do you react to that idea?

speaker: Laura
text: That sounds more reasonable. Because AI can do the repetitive stuff, and human time is used for high value expertise. But I would want the human to be an insider, like actually working in the field, not a generic coach.

speaker: Anna
text: What would make you trust such a hybrid service?

speaker: Laura
text: Transparency about who the human is. Like their real job, background also clear boundaries what AI does, what human does. And no emotional manipulation.

speaker: Laura
text: Like, do not tell me, invest in yourself or you are blocked.Also pricing that feels fair. Like pay per session, not a package trap.

speaker: Anna
text: What would make you not use it?

speaker: Laura
text: If it feels like coaching culture. Or if the AI part collects too much data. Or if the matching feels random.

speaker: Laura
text: Like, if you match me to someone who is not relevant, I will lose trust immediately.

speaker: Anna
text: Would you want AI to be involved during the human session, like summarizing, creating action steps?

speaker: Laura
text: That could be helpful. Like after the session, AI could turn notes into a plan. But I would want control.

speaker: Laura
text: And I would want to know what data is stored.

speaker: Anna
text: If you think about tasks, which tasks would you assign to AI and which to the human in this hybrid?

speaker: Laura
text: pre work, self reflection, draft CV, draft interview answers, learning plan, tracking applications to ai probably. To human: reality check, feedback on my narrative, technical roadmap validation, maybe mock interview with real feedback, and advice about market, like which startups or companies are good.

speaker: Anna
text: In such a model, where would trust matter most?

speaker: Laura
text: Trust matters most with the human, because they can influence my decisions and they are a real person with incentives. AI is more like a tool. I need trust in the system to not harm me, but it is different.

speaker: Anna
text: And effectiveness?

speaker: Laura
text: Effectiveness depends on whether it produces action and outcomes. Like, do I get interviews, do I feel clearer, do I build skills. AI already helps with that.

speaker: Laura
text: Human could increase it if they are truly relevant.

speaker: Anna
text: If you had to design the perfect support experience for yourself, what would it look like in one paragraph?

speaker: Laura
text: I would have a space to think, like AI conversation, where I can dump thoughts and get structure. Then maybe once a month a session with a real platform engineer who reviews my progress and gives me realistic feedback. And maybe a community or meetup for networking, but not forced.

speaker: Laura
text: Like optional.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you. Before we close, I want to check if there is anything we missed about your experience with AI that feels important, especially around trust.

speaker: Laura
text: No

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you. Great. Laura this is  the end of the interview.

speaker: Anna
text: After this, I will stop the recording. If you have any questions later, you can message me in insta or whatsapp i give you

speaker: Anna
text: Hi Oleg. Thanks for joining today. Before we start, do I have your permission to record this interview?

speaker: Oleg
text: Yes, you have my permission.

speaker: Anna
text: Great. Just to repeat the basics: everything is anonymous, you can skip any question, and you can stop at any time. Does that feel okay?

speaker: Oleg
text: Yes, that is fine.

speaker: Anna
text: Good. And one more thing: I will ask about your experiences with human career support and also AI tools. There is no right answer.

speaker: Anna
text: I am interested in your honest experience. Any topics you would prefer not to discuss today?

speaker: Oleg
text: I don’t want to say the exact company name. But otherwise it is fine.

speaker: Anna
text: Perfect. We will keep it general and if something feels too specific, we can just rephrase. This interview will take about 45 minutes is it fine?

speaker: Oleg
text: Yes, yes. I am at home.

speaker: Anna
text: Great. Then I will start with some context questions.

speaker: Anna
text: Where are you currently in your career, and what career decisions or questions are you facing, or recently faced?

speaker: Oleg
text: So I am 25, I live in Germany now, for four years. I finished my Master two years ago, here in Germany. I work as a data analyst in a big transportation company.

speaker: Oleg
text: Like, buses, trains, logistics, mobility, that kind of thing. And I like data analytics a lot. I like when you take messy data and make something useful.

speaker: Oleg
text: But eehm, recently, I feel a bit lost about the next step.

speaker: Anna
text: When you say lost, what do you mean exactly?

speaker: Oleg
text: Like, I know I am good as an individual contributor. I can do all IT stuff, dashboards, stakeholder requests. But I want to develop towards management.

speaker: Oleg
text: I want to lead a team eventually, maybe manage an analytics unit. And I do not know i see some people become team leads, but it feels like договорняк как бы. Also there is German corporate culture, and you know.

speaker: Anna
text: Yes i know. What makes it feel like that договорняк you mentioned?

speaker: Oleg
text: There are like official career steps, job levels, all these frameworks. But in reality, you need sponsors, you need someone to say, okay, Oleg can lead. And I don’t know what exactly they look for.

speaker: Oleg
text: Sometimes I think, maybe I should switch to product analytics somewhere else, or maybe consulting, but I do not know. So I feel stuck between wanting leadership and not knowing how to move.

speaker: Anna
text: What is your current role like day to day?

speaker: Oleg
text: I am in a corporate analytics unit, like central reporting. We support different business areas, operations, punctuality, customer experience, finance controlling. So a typical week, I have stakeholder meetings, they want some KPI, some report for a board update, or for a performance review cycle.

speaker: Oleg
text: I work with data pipelines, but we also have data engineers. I mostly do analysis and dashboards. We use Power BI mainly, sometimes Tableau in some legacy teams, and I do Python for deep dives.

speaker: Oleg
text: And SQL daily, yes. A lot of SQL.

speaker: Anna
text: And what does leadership mean to you in this environment?

speaker: Oleg
text: Um, it is not only having people reporting to you. It is like owning a domain. Saying no to stakeholders.

speaker: Oleg
text: Helping juniors. Translating business questions into analytics. And also, eehm, protecting the team from chaos?

speaker: Oleg
text: Because in big company, everyone wants something yesterday.

speaker: Anna
text: What is the most significant career decision you have made in the last 6 to 12 months?

speaker: Oleg
text: Hmm. I think the biggest was whether to apply for an internal team lead position in another department. There was an opening, not in my team, but in a business unit analytics team.

speaker: Oleg
text: A colleague sent me the link and said, you should try. And I was like, wow, okay, but I am young, and also not native German speaker. And it was a leadership role.

speaker: Oleg
text: I was not sure if I am ready.

speaker: Anna
text: What did you do in the end?

speaker: Oleg
text: I did not apply. And I feel mixed about it. On one hand, maybe it was not the right role.

speaker: Oleg
text: It was very stakeholder heavy, and the team was under pressure. On the other hand, I think I blocked myself. Like страх, fear.

speaker: Oleg
text: And then I started to think, okay, how do I prepare for leadership if I always wait until I feel 100 percent ready.

speaker: Anna
text: What made it difficult to decide?

speaker: Oleg
text: Everything? Fear again. Like, I did not know how they evaluate candidates.

speaker: Oleg
text: Also I didn’t know if my current manager would support me, because it would mean leaving. And I was afraid, if I apply and fail, it will look bad. Eehm, also I had a permanent contract recently, so I felt, okay, stability, but then taking a risk.

speaker: Oleg
text: I can't go back to Russia hahaha.

speaker: Anna
text: What kind of support did you feel you needed at that time?

speaker: Oleg
text: I needed someone to help me see the realistic plan. Like, what are the steps not just motivation. I needed plan and feedback whether i have that material no whether i am a  leadership material, what is missing.

speaker: Oleg
text: And also maybe emotional support, because I overthink a lot.

speaker: Anna
text: Okay. Thank you. Let us talk more generally now about career support.

speaker: Anna
text: When you need career support, who or what do you usually turn to?

speaker: Oleg
text: Usually people. I talk to friends, some are also in corporate. I also talk to my mentor sometimes.

speaker: Oleg
text: And sometimes I talk to my manager, but it depends, because manager is not always neutral. And I also use online resources, like articles sometimes forums but eehm, I filter a lot.

speaker: Anna
text: What tends to actually help?

speaker: Oleg
text: Practical stuff. Like, someone telling me, in this company, you need to do this to get promoted. Or, talk to this person.

speaker: Oleg
text: Or, write your internal profile like this. Also, mock interviews helped. Also, sometimes just talking and hearing myself.

speaker: Oleg
text: Like, when you speak, you realize what you want.

speaker: Anna
text: And what feels unhelpful or frustrating?

speaker: Oleg
text: инфоцыганство hahaha.

speaker: Anna
text: hahaha.

speaker: Oleg
text: A Like, follow your dreams be confident. I mean its neat but doesn’t help.

speaker: Anna
text: Yes. Do you use any tools, like structured exercises, career tests, anything like that?

speaker: Oleg
text: I tried once some career test  like personality, but it felt very hmm поверхностно. It gave me results like analytical, introvert, whatever, and I was like, yes, I know. So no.

speaker: Oleg
text: I prefer conversations.

speaker: Anna
text: You mentioned a mentor. Can you tell me how that started?

speaker: Oleg
text: Yes. So, I came to Germany for Master. I studied Data Science did internships, but I was not sure how to enter a big company.

speaker: Oleg
text: A friend from Russian community introduced me to a guy, older, like 35 maybe, who worked in the company where I am now. He was in analytics, but more senior. We had a call, like an informational interview.

speaker: Oleg
text: And he was very open, explained the hiring process, what they look for. And then later, when there was an opening, he said, send me your CV, I can refer you. So that became mentoring, I guess.

speaker: Anna
text: How often did you meet?

speaker: Oleg
text: At the beginning, maybe once per month, then less. Sometimes every two or three months. It was not formal coaching, more like mentoring and career consultation.

speaker: Anna
text: And you experienced it overall as positive, you said.

speaker: Oleg
text: Yes, overall positive. Without him, I think I would not get this job. Or it would be much harder.

speaker: Oleg
text: So I value it a lot.

speaker: Anna
text: Okay. Lets go deeper into that experience, especially around trust.

speaker: Anna
text: Thinking about your experience with mentoring or career consultations, can you describe one specific moment that increased your trust in that mentor?

speaker: Oleg
text: Hmm. There was a moment early, when I asked him about salary expectations. I was afraid to ask because it is a sensitive topic.

speaker: Oleg
text: And he said, okay, listen, this is confidential. He literally said, whatever you say, stays between us. And then he opened the internal salary range, like not exact numbers, but he explained what is realistic for a junior analyst, what is too low, what is too high.

speaker: Oleg
text: And he also said, do not undersell yourself just because you are new in Germany. That made a hell lot of trust for him. Because he showed he understands the context and he is on my side.

speaker: Anna
text: What did he do that made it feel confidential, beyond just saying it?

speaker: Oleg
text: He did not share details with other people. Like, later I met someone from his team, and they did not know my situation. He would say, do not mention my name when you talk to HR, just say you heard it from internal sources.

speaker: Oleg
text: He protected himself and me. That felt professional.

speaker: Anna
text: So confidentiality and professionalism.

speaker: Oleg
text: Yes. And also competence. He knew the process.

speaker: Oleg
text: Like, he said, you will have HR screening, then technical interview, then business case, then final with hiring manager. He described what questions they ask. And it was super accurate.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you share an example where mentoring helped you concretely?

speaker: Oleg
text: Yes. So, first, he reviewed my CV. He changed it a lot.

speaker: Oleg
text: He said, German corporate CV is different. You need structure, bullet points, not too creative. He also said, quantify impact.

speaker: Oleg
text: So we added numbers from my internship. Like, reduced processing time, improved report accuracy, whatever. Then he helped with interview prep.

speaker: Oleg
text: We did a mock interview on Zoom. He asked me typical questions, and he stopped me when I was too long. He said, be concise, answer with this and that method.

speaker: Oleg
text: And then he referred me internally. He submitted my CV in the internal system. That gave me interview faster, because in big company, HR gets thousands.

speaker: Anna
text: That is a very nice mentoring i say.

speaker: Oleg
text: Yes.

speaker: Anna
text: When you think about trust in that relationship, what were the main drivers for you?

speaker: Oleg
text: Competence is number one. Like, do they know what they talk about. Then shared context.

speaker: Oleg
text: He worked in the same company, so it is not abstract. Then honesty about limits. Sometimes I asked, should I negotiate hard, and he said, I do not know your hiring manager, I cannot promise, but generally this works.

speaker: Oleg
text: So he was not pretending. And also feeling seen, like he remembered my background, that I moved from Russia, my Master, my anxiety. He would ask, how are you doing with German, are you okay in the team.

speaker: Oleg
text: That creates trust.

speaker: Anna
text: Did you ever experience something like trusted but not effective, with a human coach or mentor?

speaker: Oleg
text: Yes, actually. I had one session with a university career counselor during Master. She was very kind.

speaker: Oleg
text: Like, очень добрая, very warm. I trusted her in the sense she was not harmful. But it was not effective.

speaker: Oleg
text: She did not understand data roles in German market. She gave me generic advice like apply more, tailor your cover letter, go to job fairs. It did not move me forward.

speaker: Oleg
text: So I trusted her intentions, but it did not lead to progress.

speaker: Anna
text: Aha. You trusted her as a person, but the outcome was limited.

speaker: Oleg
text: Aha.

speaker: Anna
text: Did you ever have the opposite, where something was effective but you did not fully trust the person?

speaker: Oleg
text: Hmm. With humans, less. Maybe with a senior colleague once.

speaker: Oleg
text: He gave me a very good tip for stakeholder management. Like, always confirm requirements in writing, and document assumptions. It was effective.

speaker: Oleg
text: But I did not fully trust him personally, because he is political you know. He is nice, but he has certain you know

speaker: Anna
text: Yes i know aha

speaker: Oleg
text: So I took the advice, but I did not share my real doubts. So effective advice, but low trust on deeper level.

speaker: Anna
text: So you can act on something even without deep trust, if it is useful and low risk.

speaker: Oleg
text: Yes, if it is low risk and verifiable. But for personal questions, I need more trust.

speaker: Anna
text: What makes you distrust a human coach or mentor?

speaker: Oleg
text: If they are too confident without evidence. If they push their agenda. Or if they share stories about other clients in a way that feels not confidential.

speaker: Oleg
text: Also if they do not listen and just follow a script.

speaker: Anna
text: In your current company, do you have any formal career development support?

speaker: Oleg
text: We have HR programs, like trainings, leadership academy, mentoring program. But it is bureaucratic. You apply, you wait.

speaker: Oleg
text: And sometimes it feels like checkbox. Also we have performance review once per year, and mid year check. There is a works council and rules, so some things are structured.

speaker: Oleg
text: But the real development is through manager support and projects.

speaker: Anna
text: How do you experience that system, as someone aiming for leadership?

speaker: Oleg
text: It is okay, but slow. Like German corporates are slow. Decisions take time.

speaker: Oleg
text: And for leadership, they like stability. They want you to prove yourself. Which is fine.

speaker: Oleg
text: But for me, I want clarity and steps.

speaker: Anna
text: Okay. Let us shift to AI now. You said you use AI a lot for work, but not for self reflection.

speaker: Anna
text: What AI tools do you use at work, and what for?

speaker: Oleg
text: I use ChatGPT sometimes, and also internal company tools. We have an internal AI assistant in the Microsoft environment. It can summarize meetings, draft emails, help with Excel formulas.

speaker: Oleg
text: I use it mainly for productivity. Also for code. Like, I write SQL queries, and I ask it to optimize, or to generate a quick Python snippet for a data transformation.

speaker: Oleg
text: And sometimes I use it to write narrative for dashboards, like executive summary.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you give a concrete example of a moment where AI helped you a lot at work?

speaker: Oleg
text: Yes. There was a project about punctuality KPIs. We had to calculate delays, but the data source had weird logic.

speaker: Oleg
text: Some trains are cancelled, some are partial, some are replaced by buses. The stakeholder wanted a simple KPI for monthly report. I had to join multiple tables, handle edge cases.

speaker: Oleg
text: I wrote SQL, but it was messy. I asked AI to help me structure the query. I described the tables and logic without sensitive identifiers, just generic names.

speaker: Oleg
text: It suggested using CTEs, separate steps, and it reminded me about handling nulls and duplicates. It saved me maybe, I do not know, two hours. And it also explained why.

speaker: Oleg
text: That was very helpful.

speaker: Anna
text: And what made you comfortable using it in that case?

speaker: Oleg
text: Speed and I could verify. I run the query, check results, compare with baseline. So trust is not blind.

speaker: Oleg
text: It is like, assistant.

speaker: Anna
text: Have you had a moment where AI failed or felt risky?

speaker: Oleg
text: Oh yes. Many. One time it hallucinated.

speaker: Oleg
text: I asked for a Python snippet to do time series decomposition. It gave me code with a library that was not installed, and also wrong function name. I copied, it failed.

speaker: Oleg
text: Not dangerous, but annoying. Another time, more risky, I asked something about our internal policy, like, can we use certain customer data for analysis. It gave a confident answer, but it was wrong.

speaker: Oleg
text: And that can be serious. Because compliance, GDPR, Germany is strict. So I learned: do not trust AI for policies.

speaker: Oleg
text: You need official documents.

speaker: Anna
text: So you calibrate trust depending on the domain.

speaker: Oleg
text: Exactly. For code, okay. For compliance, no.

speaker: Oleg
text: Also privacy boundaries. I never paste sensitive data. I never paste customer information.

speaker: Oleg
text: We have rules. Sometimes people do it, but I do not. It feels risky.

speaker: Oleg
text: Also company has guidelines: do not upload confidential data to external AI.

speaker: Anna
text: What are your trust drivers for AI tools, compared to humans?

speaker: Oleg
text: For AI, trust is more like i can verify and stuff. Transparency helps, like if it shows sources, or explains steps and i can see if it makes things up or not i just need to be careful.

speaker: Anna
text: And with human coaches? Is it the same?

speaker: Oleg
text: Yes, but with AI it is even more important. Because it can sound very confident but be wrong.

speaker: Anna
text: Do you ever use AI for career related tasks, like CV writing, job search, or decision support?

speaker: Oleg
