text: I used it a little for CV wording. Like, I wrote bullet points and asked it to make them more concise. But I did not use it for big decisions.

speaker: Oleg
text: For job search, not really.

speaker: Anna
text: Why not?

speaker: Oleg
text: I don’t really know how i mean it feels artificial for self reflection. Like, I do not want to talk about my doubts with a chatbot. Also privacy.

speaker: Oleg
text: Even if they say it is safe, I do not know. And also, I prefer human feedback. When I process thoughts, I need a real person reacting, maybe challenging me.

speaker: Oleg
text: AI can simulate, but it does not feel the same.

speaker: Anna
text: What is missing exactly, for you?

speaker: Oleg
text: Emotional safety. Like, with a person, you have relationship, you see they care, they remember you. With AI, it is like talking to a wall that answers nicely.

speaker: Oleg
text: Also accountability. If a mentor says, do this, and next time asks, did you do it, that pushes. AI can remind, but it is not the same social pressure.

speaker: Oleg
text: And also, I worry it will give generic answers. Like career is messy. AI does not know the internal politics, my manager, my environment.

speaker: Anna
text: Do you think it is mainly about empathy, or about context knowledge?

speaker: Oleg
text: Both. Context and empathy. For work tasks, AI is great because the context is the prompt.

speaker: Oleg
text: For life, the context is huge.

speaker: Anna
text: Okay. Now I want to ask you to compare human and AI in specific career support tasks.

speaker: Anna
text: If you think about different career tasks, like clarifying options, making decisions, planning strategy, preparing for interviews, or writing a CV, where would you prefer a human, where would you prefer AI, and why?

speaker: Oleg
text: For CV formatting and wording, AI can help a lot. It is fast. Like, rewrite bullet points, adjust tone.

speaker: Oleg
text: But I still check, because sometimes it makes claims too strong, like 200 percent improvement, nonsense. So effective, but not fully trusted. I treat it as draft generator.

speaker: Anna
text: And for interview preparation?

speaker: Oleg
text: Mixed.

speaker: Anna
text: And for clarifying options, like whether to pursue leadership or switch track?

speaker: Oleg
text: Human. Definitely.

speaker: Anna
text: What about planning concrete steps towards leadership in your company?

speaker: Oleg
text: Human plus some AI support. Like, human mentor can tell me: talk to these stakeholders, join this project, volunteer to mentor juniors. AI can help me write an email to a senior manager, or prepare a 1 page plan.

speaker: Oleg
text: But the strategy and other stuff, human.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you think of a recent concrete career task where you used AI, and what happened?

speaker: Oleg
text: Yes. Recently I prepared for a performance review. We have annual review, and you need to write self evaluation.

speaker: Oleg
text: I used AI to structure it. I wrote my achievements, and asked it to make it more clear, and align to competencies. It gave me a nice structure.

speaker: Oleg
text: That was helpful. But I did not put sensitive numbers. I wrote general.

speaker: Oleg
text: And still, I did not fully trust it, because it can exaggerate. I edited.

speaker: Anna
text: So in that case, it was effective as a structuring tool.

speaker: Oleg
text: Yes, very effective for structure and wording.

speaker: Anna
text: And a human, did you involve anyone in that review preparation?

speaker: Oleg
text: I talked to my mentor a bit. He said, focus on impact and visibility. And he told me, ask your manager for a development plan.

speaker: Oleg
text: That was more strategic. So both contributed.

speaker: Anna
text: If you imagine a tool that is explicitly designed as a career coach chatbot, would that change anything?

speaker: Oleg
text: Maybe a little. If it is designed well, with boundaries, and if it is maybe integrated with German job market data. But still, for deep questions, I would want human.

speaker: Anna
text: What would make you consider using it for deeper questions?

speaker: Oleg
text: If I could be sure about privacy. If it is certified, maybe. And if it can show why it recommends something.

speaker: Oleg
text: Like evidence. And maybe if it is connected to a human coach, like hybrid. Then I can use AI for preparation and reflection, but human for decision.

speaker: Anna
text: That leads nicely to the trust and effectiveness link. But before that, I want to ask a short micro poll. These are 0 to 10 ratings.

speaker: Anna
text: It is quick, and then I will ask why.

speaker: Anna
text: On a scale from 0 to 10, where 0 is no trust at all and 10 is complete trust, how would you rate your trust in human career coaches or mentors, in general?

speaker: Oleg
text: In general, hmm, maybe 7.

speaker: Anna
text: Why 7, and not higher or lower?

speaker: Oleg
text: Because I think humans can be very helpful, and I trust the right person. But not all coaches are competent. Some are generic.

speaker: Oleg
text: Also humans can have bias. So I do not give 10. But I trust more than AI for personal topics.

speaker: Oleg
text: So 7.

speaker: Anna
text: Same scale, trust in AI tools for career support specifically.

speaker: Oleg
text: For career support, maybe 4.

speaker: Anna
text: What drives that 4?

speaker: Oleg
text: Because AI can be useful, but I do not trust it with high stakes decisions. Also privacy and AI can be wrong. For technical tasks, my trust would be higher, like 7 or 8.

speaker: Oleg
text: But for career, 4.

speaker: Anna
text: Now perceived effectiveness. For your personal situation, how effective is human coaching or mentoring, 0 to 10?

speaker: Oleg
text: I would say 8.

speaker: Anna
text: Why 8?

speaker: Oleg
text: Because my mentor actually helped me get the job, and also helped with internal understanding. It led to concrete actions. It increased my confidence.

speaker: Oleg
text: So it is effective. Not 10 because sometimes even mentor cannot solve the system. Like, internal promotion is still uncertain.

speaker: Oleg
text: And sometimes advice is limited.

speaker: Anna
text: And perceived effectiveness of AI tools for your personal situation, 0 to 10?

speaker: Oleg
text: For my situation, maybe 5.

speaker: Anna
text: Why 5?

speaker: Oleg
text: Because it can help with tasks like writing, structuring, generating options. That is effective. But it does not replace human for leadership decisions.

speaker: Oleg
text: So it is medium.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you. Now I want to explore the link between trust and effectiveness more directly. When you think about your experience, how does trust affect whether something feels effective?

speaker: Oleg
text: Trust is like, um, the entry point. If I do not trust, I do not use it deeply. Like with AI, even if it gives good advice, I might not act.

speaker: Oleg
text: Or I will double check so much that it loses value. With human, if I trust, I share more real information, like my fears, my doubts. Then the advice is better, more tailored.

speaker: Oleg
text: So trust enables depth, and depth enables effectiveness.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you give a specific example where trust increased effectiveness with your mentor?

speaker: Oleg
text: Yes. When I was preparing salary negotiation, I told him my real number, and my fear that they will reject me because I am foreign, and I needed visa stability. If I did not trust him, I would hide that.

speaker: Oleg
text: But because I shared it, he gave specific advice: focus on value, but also understand my risk tolerance. He said, okay, aim for X, but if they offer Y, it is still okay because you need entry. That was tailored.

speaker: Oleg
text: It was effective because it fit my real constraints.

speaker: Anna
text: And can you think of a case where you trusted but it was not effective, we touched one with the university counselor. Anything else?

speaker: Oleg
text: Another example: I had a friendly senior colleague, like a buddy. He listened, he was supportive, I trusted him emotionally. But when I asked about leadership track, he said, just wait, it will happen.

speaker: Oleg
text: And I was like, okay, but what should I do. He had no concrete steps. So trust, but low effectiveness.

speaker: Anna
text: And effective but not fully trusted, you mentioned AI for CV bullet points. Can you expand on that?

speaker: Oleg
text: Yes. AI can produce good bullet points quickly. That is effective.

speaker: Oleg
text: But I do not trust it fully because it can invent achievements. So I always verify. I treat it like speed, not authority.

speaker: Oleg
text: So it is effective, but trust is partial.

speaker: Anna
text: So effectiveness can exist without full trust if you can verify and the stakes are low.

speaker: Oleg
text: Yes

speaker: Anna
text: Aha. If we break down trust drivers, for humans you mentioned competence, confidentiality, feeling seen, shared context, honesty about limits. For AI you mentioned reliability, verifiability, transparency, boundaries.

speaker: Anna
text: Anything else?

speaker: Oleg
text: For AI, also consistency. Like, if it gives stable quality. And maybe integration.

speaker: Oleg
text: If it uses real data sources. For example, if it can cite German labor market, or internal job profiles.

speaker: Anna
text: For humans, anything else?

speaker: Oleg
text: For humans, also values alignment. Like, if a coach values stability and I value growth, there is mismatch. And also, the ability to challenge me without being rude.

speaker: Oleg
text: Like, constructive.

speaker: Anna
text: When you think about effectiveness indicators, what tells you that a career support interaction was effective?

speaker: Oleg
text: For me, effectiveness is when I get my head cleared. Like, I decide something. Not just thinking.

speaker: Oleg
text: Also when I take action. Like, I schedule a meeting with my manager, I apply, I join a leadership training, I ask for a project. Also when I see outcomes: interview invitations, internal opportunities, better performance review, more confidence.

speaker: Oleg
text: Not only feeling good, but steps.

speaker: Anna
text: Do you think trust always leads to effectiveness?

speaker: Oleg
text: No. You can trust someone and still not get results, like we said. And you can get results without deep trust if it is technical.

speaker: Oleg
text: So trust helps, but it is not enough. Competence is key.

speaker: Anna
text: Does effectiveness build trust?

speaker: Oleg
text: Yes, definitely. If AI helps me reliably with code, I trust it more in that area. And if a mentor gives good advice, trust increases.

speaker: Oleg
text: But if one time it fails badly, trust drops quickly, especially for AI. For humans, maybe you forgive more if relationship is strong. But it depends.

speaker: Anna
text: That is interesting. Why do you forgive humans more?

speaker: Oleg
text: Because you assume good intentions. And you see they are limited. With AI, it is just output.

speaker: Oleg
text: If it is wrong, you feel, okay, it is unreliable.

speaker: Anna
text: Okay. Now I want to ask about your preferences and reaction to hybrid models.

speaker: Anna
text: Imagine a hybrid career coaching model where you have AI support for preparation, reflection prompts, structuring options, and follow up, and you also have access to human mentors or coaches for deeper conversations and key decisions. What is your first reaction?

speaker: Oleg
text: I mean sounds good i mean It sounds like the best combination. Because I do not want to spend human time on small tasks like rewriting text. That can be AI.

speaker: Oleg
text: But for leadership path, I want human.

speaker: Anna
text: What would make you adopt such a hybrid model?

speaker: Oleg
text: Quality of the human part. Like, who are the mentors. Are they real professionals.

speaker: Oleg
text: Also trust and privacy for the AI part .And prices matter. I am early career, I can’t pay a lot. .

speaker: Anna
text: In such a model, where would you want AI to lead, and where would you want a human to lead?

speaker: Oleg
text: I don’t really care the main is the result.

speaker: Anna
text: Okay. If the AI part asks you reflective questions, like what do you value, what do you fear, would you use it?

speaker: Oleg
text: Maybe a bit, but I would be cautious. It depends on how it is framed. If it is like journaling prompts, okay.

speaker: Oleg
text: But if it tries to interpret me, like you are this type, then no. I do not want психологический анализ from AI. I want a person.

speaker: Anna
text: What about if the AI part was designed to be very transparent, like it always says, I am not a therapist, I am a tool, and it shows you how it builds suggestions.

speaker: Oleg
text: Doesn’t matter how you frame it it is still same.

speaker: Anna
text: How would you want the human coach to work with the AI output?

speaker: Oleg
text: It could be useful if I can bring a summary to the human. Like, AI helps me prepare: here are my goals, constraints, options. Then the human can go deeper.

speaker: Oleg
text: That saves time.

speaker: Anna
text: Would there be any red flags that would make you avoid a hybrid model?

speaker: Oleg
text: If it feels like the AI is replacing the human. Or if they push me to use AI only. Also if they collect too much data.

speaker: Oleg
text: Like, if they ask for my company name, salary, visa status, and store it. That would feel risky. Germany is sensitive about data I am now too hahaha.

speaker: Anna
text: And what if the model matches you to a mentor based on your profile and goals?

speaker: Oleg
text: That is good, but I would want to understand the logic. Like, why this person. If it is a black box, I trust less.

speaker: Oleg
text: If it shows criteria, I trust more.

speaker: Anna
text: Do you think you would trust a mentor from your own company more, or an external one?

speaker: Oleg
text: Mixed. From my company, they have context, very useful. But also risk, because internal politics.

speaker: Anna
text: If you had a human coach, what would you want them to help you with specifically, in the next three months?

speaker: Oleg
text: I want a plan steps to leadership. Like, identify skills gap. Identify projects to take.

speaker: Oleg
text: How to influence without authority. How to mentor juniors. And also how to talk to my manager about development.

speaker: Oleg
text: And maybe practice those conversations, because I get nervous about money talks.

speaker: Anna
text: If you had AI support, what would you want it to help with, in the next three months?

speaker: Oleg
text: Help me draft emails, structure my development plan, prepare for meetings, summarize feedback, and maybe simulate scenarios. Like, what if my manager says no. How to respond.

speaker: Oleg
text: But again, I would check.

speaker: Anna
text: Okay. We are close to the end. I want to ask a final closing block.

speaker: Anna
text: If you look back at everything we discussed, what feels like the biggest difference between trusting a human and trusting AI in this domain?

speaker: Oleg
text: So different types of trust. For me, human trust is like, do I feel safe, do I feel understood, is this person competent and confidential. AI trust is like tool trust does it work, can I verify.

speaker: Anna
text: And the biggest difference in effectiveness?

speaker: Oleg
text: Human is effective for deep, messy problems and decisions. AI is effective for structure, speed, and low stakes tasks.

speaker: Anna
text: Is there anything you wish I asked but did not?

speaker: Oleg
text: No.

speaker: Anna
text: Anything else you want to add?

speaker: Oleg
text: No.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you. I will stop the recording now.

speaker: Anna
text: Yes, perfectly. Thanks for joining today. Before we start, do I have your permission to record?

speaker: Anna
text: Everything is anonymous, you can skip any question, and you can stop at any time.

speaker: Lena
text: Yes, you can record.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you. Just to confirm, I will use a pseudonym and remove identifying details like company names. Is there anything you prefer not to discuss today?

speaker: Lena
text: Um, I think it is okay. Maybe not super detailed about internal company stuff, like specific metrics, because I do not want to say something wrong. But overall, it is fine.

speaker: Anna
text: Alright.. We can keep company details out.

speaker: Lena
text: Okay.

speaker: Anna
text: Great. And also, this is not a test. I am interested in your perspective so all answers are good.

speaker: Lena
text: Okay, sounds good.

speaker: Anna
text: Alright. Let us start.

speaker: Anna
text: Where are you currently in your career, and what career decisions or questions are you facing right now, or recently faced?

speaker: Lena
text: Eehm, so I am finishing my Bachelor in Media Informatics. I am in Berlin now, but I am from Mainz originally. I moved here for the university and also for work, kind of both.

speaker: Lena
text: And I work part time as a junior UX researcher, like Werkstudentin, at a mid size SaaS company. So I do research tasks, mostly around product discovery, usability tests, interviews. And the big question for me is like, what is my path after the Bachelor.

speaker: Lena
text: Like, do I continue with UX research, do I go more into UX design, or do I go into product, like PM, product discovery, something like that. And also the question of where, like stay in Berlin, or maybe go back to Mainz area, or maybe somewhere else. Or masters.

speaker: Lena
text: I don’t know yet. But Berlin is kind of the obvious place for UX, I think.

speaker: Anna
text: When you say the big question is the path, what makes it difficult?

speaker: Lena
text: Um. Ehem. I think I have multiple things.

speaker: Lena
text: One is, I like research a lot when I do it. Like the actual interviews, synthesis, finding patterns, it feels like my brain is good at that. But I also see that UX research roles are competitive and sometimes unclear.

speaker: Lena
text: Like in Berlin, every startup says they want a UXR, but then they want someone who is also a designer and also a PM and also a data analyst. And I am like, okay, what are you actually hiring for. So that makes it stressful.

speaker: Anna
text: Aha, I was the same.

speaker: Lena
text: Yes. And I don’t feel confident in selling myself. Like, I am okay in the work context, but in applications, I am really insecure.

speaker: Lena
text: My German is great, I  mean am I German hahaha, my professional English is also great. But interviews, especially when you have to talk about impact, I freeze. And I see other people who are louder, and they can tell a story, and I am like, I did good work, but I cannot present it as a shiny story.

speaker: Anna
text: So it is not that you doubt your ability to do the work, but you doubt the packaging of it.

speaker: Lena
text: Yes, exactly. Like, I can do the research. But then, Bewerbungen, portfolio, case studies, interviews, I feel like I am weak.

speaker: Lena
text: And I hate exaggerating, I hate the feeling of bragging.

speaker: Anna
text: What would you say was the most significant career decision in the last 6 to 12 months?

speaker: Lena
text: Hmm. I think the biggest one was whether to keep the job I have now, or switch to a different internship, like a bigger brand company. Because I had an offer from a startup, very early stage, and they said, you can do UX and product, like everything, and it sounded exciting.

speaker: Lena
text: But it was also chaotic. And my current company is more structured. So I decided to stay.

speaker: Lena
text: Also because I needed stability, like rent in Berlin is insane. And I have my thesis coming.

speaker: Anna
text: I see. What made that decision difficult?

speaker: Lena
text: The fear of missing out, honestly. Like, the startup sounded like, wow, you can build everything, you can do huge impact. And in my current company, I am part time, and I do research, but I do not own the whole product.

speaker: Lena
text: So I thought maybe I should go to the startup to have a stronger portfolio story. But also I was like, do I want to be in chaos while finishing my Bachelor. Probably not.

speaker: Lena
text: And also the startup offered less money.

speaker: Anna
text: If you think about what kind of support you needed during that decision, what was it?

speaker: Lena
text: I needed someone to help me evaluate conflicting sides, like not only salary, but learning, mentorship, portfolio, mental health. And also someone who understands the Berlin market, like what matters for UX roles here. I talked to friends, but they are also students, so they guess.

speaker: Lena
text: I wanted someone who knows how hiring works.

speaker: Anna
text: And now looking forward, what is the next decision that feels most pressing?

speaker: Lena
text: The thesis and the first full time step. Like, do I write my thesis with my company, or at university only. My company offered that I can do a thesis project related to their product, like research around onboarding or something.

speaker: Lena
text: But then I worry about confidentiality and also scope creep. And if I do it at university only, I have more freedom but maybe less practical connection.

speaker: Anna
text: What would be the ideal outcome of the next, let us say, 3 to 4 months?

speaker: Lena
text: Ideally, I finish the thesis without panic hahaha. And I have clarity, like, okay, I want to apply for UXR roles, and I have a portfolio that makes sense. Or if it is product, then I know what entry roles to target.

speaker: Lena
text: Because right now, it is like a fog. I know what I like, but I do not know what to choose.

speaker: Anna
text: When you need career support, who or what do you usually turn to?

speaker: Lena
text: Eehm. Friends, sometimes. My boyfriend a little bit, but he is in software engineering, so he is like, just apply as fast and as much as you can.

speaker: Lena
text: My parents, but they are supportive emotionally, not really informed about UX. And then online resources, like articles, LinkedIn posts, sometimes YouTube, like career advice. And I used the university career service once.

speaker: Lena
text: And I use AI tools for some things, like summarizing notes, rewriting CV bullets, especially in English.

speaker: Anna
text: What has actually helped you, and what has felt unhelpful or frustrating?

speaker: Lena
text: Helpful is talking to people who are actually in the field. Like I had one informal coffee chat with a UXR from another company, a friend of a friend, and she explained what she does, how she got hired, what her case study looked like. That was nice.

speaker: Lena
text: Unhelpful is like show your motivation, be confident. It is like, yes, but how.

speaker: Anna
text: When you say nice, what kind of nice?

speaker: Lena
text: Like, examples. Like, in your portfolio, structure your case study like this, problem, method, insight, impact, stakeholder. And also, what hiring managers actually look for.

speaker: Lena
text: For example, she told me, for junior UXR, they do not expect you to have huge business impact, but they want to see your thinking, and that you can communicate. That was nice.

speaker: Anna
text: How do you decide whether a source of support is worth listening to?

speaker: Lena
text: I think, if they understand my context. Like Germany, Berlin, junior roles, UX. And if they do not just project their own path.

speaker: Lena
text: Also tone matters. If someone is like, you are behind, you should do more, it makes me shut down. If they are calm, and they ask questions, then I listen more.

speaker: Anna
text: Listen more you mean trust?

speaker: Lena
text: Yes.

speaker: Anna
text: Aha. Thank you.

speaker: Anna
text: Do you have any mentors inside the company?

speaker: Lena
text: Not officially. There is a senior researcher, she is nice, and she reviews my discussion guide sometimes. But she is very busy.

speaker: Lena
text: And our PM sometimes gives feedback on my readouts, like, what is actionable. But it is not a formal mentorship.

speaker: Anna
text: And what about peers, like fellow students in your program?

speaker: Lena
text: Mixed. Some are supportive, but sometimes it becomes comparison. Like, someone says, I got invited to interviews at three startups, and I am like, okay, I am doing something wrong.

speaker: Lena
text: So it is not always helpful.

speaker: Anna
text: You mentioned you had one session with the university career service. Can you walk me through that session, like what triggered  you to book it, and what happened?

speaker: Lena
text: Yes. So, I booked it around, I think, May last year. Because I was starting to think about applications for internships and also like, what after Bachelor.

speaker: Lena
text: And I felt stuck with my CV. In UX, it is weird because CV is one thing but portfolio is another. So I booked a slot, it was like 30 minutes, online, with a career advisor from the university.

speaker: Anna
text: What did you expect going into it?

speaker: Lena
text: I expected they would understand at least basics of UX roles, like difference between UX design and UX research and product. And I wanted feedback on my CV, and also maybe direction, like, what titles to search for. I wanted someone to look at my experience and say, okay, this is your narrative.

speaker: Anna
text: And what happened in the session?

speaker: Lena
text: It felt very template. Like, she opened my CV, she said, okay, you should use this standard template, like Europass style, or like their uni template. And she said, put your skills here, put your education here, and keep it one page.

speaker: Lena
text: And I was like, okay, yes, but I am already doing that. And then I said, I am working as junior UX researcher, and she asked, so are you more like marketing research. And I was like, no, product research.

speaker: Lena
text: And she was like, ah okay. Then she gave advice like, use action verbs, quantify achievements, mention tools. Which is fine, but it was like reading a checklist.

speaker: Anna
text: Was there anything that felt personalized at all?

speaker: Lena
text: Not really. She did not ask about what kind of role I want, or what kind of company, or what my strengths are. She did not ask for my portfolio at all.

speaker: Lena
text: I was like, should I show it, and she said, we do not have time, but generally include a link. And it felt rushed. And no follow up, like, if you change it, send it again, nothing.

speaker: Anna
text: What emotions did you have during or after?

speaker: Lena
text: During, I was like, okay, maybe I was expecting too much but i felt very sad afterwards. Because I paid with my time, and I got basically nothing. But, to be fair, one thing was helpful.

speaker: Anna
text: What was helpful?

speaker: Lena
text: She said, for Germany, sometimes companies like to see a short profile summary at the top, like a 3 line thing, and that I can frame it as, media informatics student with UX research experience in SaaS, skilled in qualitative interviews and synthesis, seeking junior roles in product research. And that actually helped me because I had no summary before. So that was one useful tip.

speaker: Anna
text: Aha. Anything else?

speaker: Lena
text: Like, it was useful, but the overall feeling was not trust. It was more like, okay, this is a service, they do generic stuff.

speaker: Anna
text: When you think about trust in a human career supporter, what are the main drivers for you?

speaker: Lena
text: Understanding. Like they actually listen and remember details. Also domain like they know UX, hiring, what a portfolio is, what a case study is, what stakeholders are.

speaker: Lena
text: Confidentiality also structure, like a process. And non judgmental tone, like not making you feel stupid.

speaker: Anna
text: If you imagine an ideal real coach, what would you want them to do with you?

speaker: Lena
text: Hmm. I would want them to ask me questions first, like what motivates you, what kind of tasks give you energy, what you hate, what environment. Then help me map roles, like UXR, UX designer, product, and what skills overlap, what gaps.

speaker: Lena
text: Then help me build a narrative for applications. Like, not lie, but show my value. And maybe do mock interviews, because that is my weakness.

speaker: Anna
text: What would make you distrust a human coach?

speaker: Lena
text: If they push their own agenda, like, you should do this because it worked for me. Or if they do not understand the field, but still act confident. Or if they are judgmental.

speaker: Lena
text: Also if it feels like they are selling something, like upselling packages.

speaker: Anna
text: Have you ever trusted a friend a lot, but it was not effective?

speaker: Lena
text: Yes, actually. My best friend from Mainz, I trust her completely, like emotionally. She listens, she is kind.

speaker: Lena
text: But she is studying psychology, not UX. So she says things like, follow your heart, you will figure it out. And it helps emotionally, it reduces anxiety, but it does not give me concrete action.

speaker: Lena
text: So high trust, limited effectiveness for career decisions.

speaker: Anna
text: Got it, thank you. For you, effectiveness is what exactly, like how do you know support is effective?

speaker: Lena
text: Effective means I know what to do after, like I can decide something. Or I have a concrete plan, like, apply to these roles, change these portfolio parts, talk to this person. Maybe confidence also, like I feel less small.

speaker: Lena
text: Or measurable results like interview invites. But not only that, because sometimes you do everything and still no invites in this economy. But at least I feel my narrative is stronger and I can act.

speaker: Anna
text: So for you effectiveness includes clarity, confidence, concrete actions, and sometimes outcomes like interview invites?

speaker: Lena
text: Yes.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you. Now I want to talk about AI tools. You mentioned you use AI for summarizing notes and rewriting CV bullets, but you avoid using it for deeper self reflection because it feels too impersonal.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you tell me about your experience, what tools you use and for what?

speaker: Lena
text: I mostly use ChatGPT, like the normal one. And sometimes the built in AI in Notion for summarizing. But mainly ChatGPT.

speaker: Lena
text: I use it after user interviews, but not with raw transcripts, more like my notes. I write messy notes during interviews, and then after, I paste them and say, can you structure this into themes, pain points, quotes, and possible insights. And it helps me to get a first draft.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you give me a specific example of when it helped?

speaker: Lena
text: Yes. Two months ago, we did interviews about onboarding for a feature. We spoke with like six users, small sample, but still.

speaker: Lena
text: And my notes were messy, because I was facilitating and note taking. After, I had like pages of bullet points. I put them in AI and asked it to cluster into themes and also highlight contradictions.

speaker: Lena
text: And it gave me a structured summary. And I was like, yes, that is exactly it. It saved me time.

speaker: Lena
text: Then I refined it myself.

speaker: Anna
text: So it helped with speed and structure?

speaker: Lena
text: Yes, and also with wording. Sometimes I have the insight in my head, but I cannot phrase it professionally or just don’t want to do it and it helps me write a sentence that sounds clear.

speaker: Anna
text: And in CV bullets, how do you use it?

speaker: Lena
text: I write a bullet like, conducted interviews and made report. And then I ask AI to rewrite it into impact focused bullet points, like, led 6 user interviews to identify onboarding friction, resulting in prioritized recommendations for product team. Stuff like that.

speaker: Lena
text: HR love KPI.

speaker: Anna
text: And now the other side. Can you describe a moment where AI failed, or felt risky, or made you uncomfortable?

speaker: Lena
text: Not really. I mean yes sometimes it outputs something that is obviously fake. Like, increased conversion by 30 percent, or improved user satisfaction significantly.

speaker: Lena
text: And I am like, I did not measure that. So it pushes you to exaggerate. And if you do not pay attention, you might include lies.

speaker: Lena
text: But it’s common knowledge and one must pay attention to it themselves. I mean always recheck or read what it got you.

speaker: Anna
text: Aha. Anything else?

speaker: Lena
text: Privacy. At work, we have user data. We do interviews.

speaker: Lena
text: I cannot paste raw transcripts because there are identifying details. So I am careful. I only paste my own abstracted notes.

speaker: Lena
text: But still, sometimes I feel uneasy, like, am I allowed to do this. Even if it is anonymized, it is still internal. So I keep it low stakes.

speaker: Lena
text: Also, AI sometimes makes assumptions about roles. Like, it will say, as a UX designer you should do this, and I am like, I am a researcher. It confuses me.

speaker: Lena
text: So I do not trust it fully, but that's okay for me.

speaker: Anna
text: So you have usefulness, but not full trust?

speaker: Lena
text: Yes

speaker: Anna
text: I understand thank you. When you think about trust in AI tools, what drives trust for you?

speaker: Lena
text: Verifiability. Like, I can check. If it summarizes my notes, I can see if it matches.

speaker: Lena
text: Consistency, like it always gives a structured output. Controllability, like I can prompt it, I can say shorter, more formal, include this. And low stakes.

speaker: Lena
text: If it is a draft, it is fine. I do not trust it for decisions about my life, but I trust it for drafts.

speaker: Anna
text: What would reduce trust?

speaker: Lena
text: When it is too confident and wrong. Or when it gives advice that is generic but sounds authoritative. Or when it uses data it cannot know.

speaker: Lena
text: Also, if it feels like it is making me into a generic person, like, here is your career path, and it is not me.

speaker: Anna
text: You said it feels too impersonal for deeper self reflection. Can you unpack that?

speaker: Lena
text: Um. It is like, if I talk about insecurity, I want a human reaction. Like, a person who actually knows me, who can say, you are not crazy, or who can challenge me.

speaker: Lena
text: AI can respond kindly, but it feels like a script. And also I do not want to dump my emotional stuff into a tool. It feels weird.

speaker: Lena
text: Like, is this real, is someone reading it, I do not know. So I avoid.

speaker: Anna
text: So that is a mix of emotional need and privacy uncertainty?

speaker: Lena
text: Yes.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you. I want to compare human support and AI support through specific tasks. I will name a task, and you tell me what you would use, and why.

speaker: Anna
text: First task is clarifying options, like mapping UX research versus product versus design. What would you use?

speaker: Lena
text: For mapping options, I would maybe start with AI because it is fast. It gives a broad overview. But then for actually choosing, I would want a human, like someone who knows me and can ask questions, because AI can list options but cannot feel what fits.

speaker: Anna
text: What about rewriting CV bullets or cover letters?

speaker: Lena
text: AI, definitely, for the first draft. But I would want a human to review for tone and truth, and to make sure it sounds like me, not like AI. But if I do not have a human, I still use AI.

speaker: Anna
text: Next task is preparing for interviews, like telling your story, answering questions.

speaker: Lena
text: Human would be better, I think. Because interview is social. You need feedback on how you speak, and confidence.

speaker: Lena
text: AI can simulate questions, but it cannot really see you. But maybe AI could help generate question lists.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you. Managing anxiety about applying, like procrastination, imposter feelings.

speaker: Lena
text: Human. Or like friend, therapist, someone. AI is not good for that, for me.

speaker: Lena
text: It can give coping tips, but it is not the same.

speaker: Anna
text: Structuring your thesis decision, like thesis with company versus university.

speaker: Lena
text: Hmm. I would use both. AI for a pros and cons list, like a framework.

speaker: Lena
text: Human for the emotional part and context, like what my supervisor expects, what the company might do, what the risk is.

speaker: Anna
text: You mentioned earlier that the university career service did not look at your portfolio due to time. For portfolio strategy, who would you trust more, AI or human?

speaker: Lena
text: Human, if they understand UX hiring. Because portfolio is nuanced. AI can suggest a structure, but a human can say, this is convincing, this is not.

speaker: Lena
text: Also they know what looks junior, what looks senior.

speaker: Anna
text: Let us go into a specific work episode. Can you describe a moment at work where you felt strong and competent?

speaker: Lena
text: Yes. There was one meeting, like, I think in October. We had done usability testing on a new flow for setting up integrations.

speaker: Lena
text: And the PM and the designer were convinced that the flow was fine, like minimal issues. But in testing, users got stuck at a step because of terminology. They thought integration means something else.

speaker: Lena
text: I had clips, like short quotes, and I synthesized it into a clear insight: the mental model mismatch. In the readout, I presented it and I was like, this is not a small UI issue, it is conceptual. And the PM actually changed priority.

speaker: Lena
text: He was like, okay, we need to adjust the copy and add guidance. And later he told me, good catch, we would have shipped confusion.

speaker: Anna
text: What did you do in that moment that made it successful?

speaker: Lena
text: I mean I was prepared. I had evidence, like quotes, patterns, not just friction. I also explained the why, like mental model, not just, users are confused.

speaker: Lena
text: I could answer questions like, how many users, what scenarios, is it edge case. And I felt like, okay, I can influence.

speaker: Anna
text: And a moment where you felt insecure, especially around selling yourself?

speaker: Lena
text: Job applications, always. But also even inside the company, sometimes. Like, when we have a meeting with leadership, and they ask, what is the impact of research, and I am like, I do not have numbers.

speaker: Lena
text: And I see senior people speak confidently. And I feel small. And then I think, in interviews, it will be worse.

speaker: Lena
text: Because you have to say, I am great, hire me. And I just cannot.

speaker: Anna
text: What is the inner dialogue in those moments?

speaker: Lena
text: It is like, you are just a student, you are not real. Like, you only did small projects. Others have real impact.

speaker: Lena
text: And then I compare myself. Especially in Berlin, there are many people with shiny portfolios.

speaker: Anna
text: When you say shiny portfolios, what do you mean?

speaker: Lena
text: Like, beautiful case study websites, perfect storytelling, big brand logos. And they write like, drove strategic decisions, delivered measurable outcomes. And I am like, maybe they also exaggerate, but it still affects me.

speaker: Anna
text: Does AI play any role in that insecurity, like making it worse or better?

speaker: Lena
text: Better in the sense that it helps me write. Like, when I feel blocked, it gives me words. Worse in the sense that it can produce those shiny lines, and then I feel like, do I have to sound like that to be hired.

speaker: Lena
text: It pushes the standard higher. 7) Trust–effectiveness link

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you. Now I want to explore the link between trust and effectiveness in your experience. When you think about human support, how does trust affect whether it is effective?

speaker: Lena
text: Trust is like a gate. If I do not trust the person, I will not share the real problem. Like, I will keep it superficial.

speaker: Lena
text: Then the advice is superficial. In the career service session, I did not trust she understood UX, so I did not talk about deeper confusion. I just asked about CV.

speaker: Lena
text: So it limited what could be effective.

speaker: Anna
text: And when you do trust, what changes?

speaker: Lena
text: I can say, I am scared, I feel like an imposter, I do not know what to choose. And then a person can help with that. But if I do not trust, I stay in safe topics.

speaker: Anna
text: How about AI, does trust work the same way?

speaker: Lena
text: Similar but different. With AI, if I do not trust it, I still might use it for drafts, because it is easy. Like, I can use it pragmatically.

speaker: Lena
text: So trust is not necessary for some usefulness. But for high stakes, like, should I choose product or research, trust matters because otherwise I will not act on it.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you give an example where AI was useful but you did not fully trust it?

speaker: Lena
text: As I said before CV bullets. It gives me a good wording, but I do not trust that the bullet is truthful or appropriate. So I check and edit.

speaker: Lena
text: It is useful, but not trusted as final.

speaker: Anna
text: And can you give an example where a human was trusted but not effective?

speaker: Lena
text: My friend, like I said. She is very trustworthy as a person. But the advice is like, you will be fine, choose what feels right.

speaker: Lena
text: It helps emotionally, but it does not create action. So I trust her, but the career problem remains.

speaker: Anna
text: If we zoom out, what makes you say something is effective, independent of trust?

speaker: Lena
text: I think effectiveness is outcome, like does it move me forward. But trust influences whether I can engage deeply enough to get that outcome. In low trust, you can still get a small tip, like the summary paragraph in the CV.

speaker: Lena
text: That was effective in a small way. But the bigger questions need trust.

speaker: Anna
text: And for AI, could something be effective even if trust is low?

speaker: Lena
text: Yes like summarizing notes. Even if I do not trust it emotionally, it can still do the structure. But I would not let it decide.

speaker: Anna
text: I want to ask you now some quick ratings, like a micro poll. It is 0 to 10, where 0 is no trust at all, 10 is full trust. First, trust in human career coaches, in general, like your expectation, including your experience with the university career service.

speaker: Anna
text: What number would you give?

speaker: Lena
text: Hmm. Maybe a 6.

speaker: Anna
text: Why a 6?

speaker: Lena
text: Because I think humans can be very good if they understand the domain and if they care. I believe that. But my only official experience was generic, and I know there are also bad coaches.

speaker: Lena
text: So it is not like automatic trust. It depends. So 6 is like, open but cautious.

speaker: Anna
text: And trust in AI tools for career related tasks, 0 to 10?

speaker: Lena
text: For career tasks, maybe 7 for small tasks, but overall, I would say 5.

speaker: Anna
text: Can I ask you to please stick with one number for overall, and then explain.

speaker: Lena
text: Okay, overall 5.

speaker: Anna
text: Why 5?

speaker: Lena
text: Because I trust it to help with drafts, structure, brainstorming. But I do not trust it with personal context and decision making. Also privacy concerns.

speaker: Lena
text: So it is like half.

speaker: Anna
text: Next, perceived effectiveness of human coaching for your situation, 0 to 10.

speaker: Lena
text: Effectiveness, I would say 6 again.

speaker: Anna
text: Why 6?

speaker: Lena
text: Because I can imagine it being very effective if it is the right coach. But the career service was not very effective. It gave one good tip, but not clarity.

speaker: Lena
text: So I rate it moderate.

speaker: Anna
text: Perceived effectiveness of AI tools for your situation, 0 to 10.

speaker: Lena
text: For my situation, maybe 6.

speaker: Anna
text: Aha so you have AI effectiveness similar to human.

speaker: Lena
text: Yes, because for practical stuff, AI helps a lot, like saving time. But for the big decision, it does not help. So overall it is moderate.

speaker: Anna
text: If we separate trust and effectiveness, can you see cases where trust is higher than effectiveness, or effectiveness higher than trust?

speaker: Lena
text: Yes. With my friend, trust higher than effectiveness. With AI, effectiveness sometimes higher than trust, like it can produce a good structure even if I do not trust it fully.

speaker: Anna
text: Great. Now I want to introduce a concept of a hybrid model. Imagine a service where you have an AI that helps you prepare, like clarifying your situation, structuring your thoughts, drafting CV bullets, and collecting your experiences into a narrative.

speaker: Anna
text: Then you have access to a human coach or mentor for key moments, like decision making, mock interviews, and emotional support. How does that sound to you?

speaker: Lena
text: That sounds ideal, honestly. Because I do not want to pay a human for everything. Like, if I have to pay 100 euros per hour for someone to rewrite my bullet points, it feels wasteful.

speaker: Lena
text: But I would pay for someone to help me with strategy and confidence.

speaker: Anna
text: What would you want the AI part to do, specifically?

speaker: Lena
text: I would want it to help me prepare. Like, ask me questions, extract my experiences, help me build a portfolio outline, help me write drafts. Also maybe track applications, like reminders, but that is more tool.

speaker: Lena
text: And also give me prompts for reflection that are not too therapy. Like, what tasks energize you, what environment, but in a structured way. Maybe I would do that if it feels like a guided worksheet, not like emotional chat.

speaker: Anna
text: And what would you want the human part to do?

speaker: Lena
text: Validate, challenge, and personalize. Like, look at my portfolio and say, this is strong, this is weak, and why. Do mock interviews and give feedback on how I present.

speaker: Lena
text: And also help me decide between paths. And if I cry, they do not freak out hahaha.

speaker: Anna
text: What would make you skeptical about the hybrid model?

speaker: Lena
text: Data privacy and how the AI uses my information. Like, who owns it, where it goes. Also, if the AI gives generic outputs, it would annoy me.

speaker: Lena
text: And also the quality of the human. Like, if it is just random mentors, not trained, then it could be risky.

speaker: Anna
text: If you had to choose, would you prefer one consistent human person, or rotating mentors?

speaker: Lena
text: Consistent. Because trust needs continuity. If I have to explain my story again, it is exhausting.

speaker: Anna
text: And would you be open to AI being present during a human session, like summarizing, or suggesting questions?

speaker: Lena
text: Maybe, if it is transparent. Like, if the AI is only taking notes and I can see the notes, and it is not like spying. It could be helpful.

speaker: Lena
text: Because then I can focus on talking, and later I have a summary.

speaker: Anna
text: What kind of boundaries would you want clearly stated?

speaker: Lena
text: Like, AI is not making decisions for you. It is not therapy. It does not store sensitive data unless you choose.

speaker: Lena
text: It does not use your data to train something without consent. And the human is bound by confidentiality. Like, clear.

speaker: Anna
text: If you think about your reluctance to do deep self reflection with AI, could a hybrid model change that?

speaker: Lena
text: Maybe. Because if I know a human will see it later, then it feels less like talking into the void. Like, the AI could collect my thoughts, and then the human can discuss.

speaker: Lena
text: That feels less impersonal. But I still would not want to write very emotional stuff to AI.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you.

speaker: Anna
text: We are almost at the end. If you think about someone like you, early career in Berlin, UX leaning, what is one thing you wish career support services understood better?

speaker: Lena
text: That UX is not just a normal job application process. It is portfolio, storytelling, and ambiguity. And also that juniors need help translating real work into a narrative, without exaggerating.

speaker: Lena
text: And that confidence issues are real, like introverts exist hello.

speaker: Anna
text: If you could design your perfect support journey in one sentence, what would it be?

speaker: Lena
text: A structured process that helps me turn my experience into a clear story, with practical steps, and a human who understands UX and makes me feel safe.

speaker: Anna
text: Anything else you want to add that we did not cover?

speaker: Lena
text: No.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you, Lena. This was very helpful.

speaker: Lena
text: Okay. Thank you. It was actually nice to talk about it.

speaker: Anna
text: It was a pleasure interviewing you. Have a good evening.

speaker: Lena
text: You too. Bye.

speaker: Anna
text: Hi Mehmet. Thanks for joining. Before we start, do I have your permission to record?

speaker: Anna
text: Everything is anonymous, you can skip any question, and you can stop anytime.

speaker: Mehmet
text: Yes, you can record. It is okay.

speaker: Anna
text: Great. And just to confirm, you are comfortable with the topic, it is about your experiences with career support, human coaching, and AI tools.

speaker: Mehmet
text: Yes, totally.

speaker: Anna
text: Is there anything you prefer not to discuss today?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Hmm. Not really. Maybe not the exact company name, because, you know, Germany and Munich is small world.

speaker: Mehmet
text: But otherwise okay.

speaker: Anna
text: Perfect. We will keep it anonymous. If any detail feels too specific, just tell me and we can generalize it.

speaker: Anna
text: And one more thing, I may ask follow-up questions to understand your experience better, but there are no right answers.

speaker: Mehmet
text: Yes, okay.

speaker: Anna
text: Great. Let us start.

speaker: Anna
text: Where are you currently in your career, and what career decisions or questions are you facing right now, or recently faced?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Okay. So, eehm, I am 26. I am from Turkey.

speaker: Mehmet
text: I came to Germany, Munich, six years ago. I did my Master’s in Mechanical Engineering here in Munich. After graduation I started working as a project engineer.

speaker: Mehmet
text: I am in automotive supply chain, like Tier 1 supplier side, but we are very close to OEM, so we deliver modules and we are always under OEM pressure, you know.

speaker: Anna
text: Mm-hm.

speaker: Mehmet
text: And my question now is, I feel stuck. Like I am doing execution, execution, execution. Deadlines, quality topics, meeting after meeting.

speaker: Mehmet
text: And I want to move into, I would say, product management or operations strategy. Something where I am not only firefighting, but also shaping how we do things. But I struggle with language, like corporate German, and also framing.

speaker: Mehmet
text: Because in engineering, you do a lot, but you cannot always explain it as impact.

speaker: Anna
text: When you say stuck, what does that look like day to day?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Day to day is, eehm, I have my project plan, I track open points, I coordinate with production, quality, logistics. There is always some issue. Like a supplier is late, or a component has a deviation, or OEM changes requirement, and we need to react.

speaker: Mehmet
text: I am basically the person that pushes and aligns. In German they like to say Abstimmung, alignment. So I am like the ash.

speaker: Anna
text: Okay. And what feels missing?

speaker: Mehmet
text: The missing is, I do not own the why. I own the how. Like, okay we need to deliver this variant, we need to meet SOP date, we need to reduce scrap, okay.

speaker: Mehmet
text: But I am not in the discussion of, should we change the process, should we change supplier strategy, should we change product roadmap for the module. That is more like product or operations strategy. And I see those people, they speak differently.

speaker: Mehmet
text: They speak with, you know, business words, and in meetings they are confident.

speaker: Anna
text: What do product management and operations strategy mean to you, concretely?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Product management for me means, you decide what features, what variants, you prioritize, you talk with customer, you build business case. It is not only technical requirement list. And operations strategy is more like, how do we run the factory or supply chain in a smarter way.

speaker: Mehmet
text: Like standardization, make or buy, supplier development, risk management, maybe digitalization. Not just reacting, but planning.

speaker: Anna
text: Have you had a significant career decision in the last six to twelve months?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Yes. Actually the biggest decision was, do I stay in automotive at all. Because automotive in Germany is like, eehm, stress, and also now all this transformation, e-mobility, cost pressure, layoffs, hiring freezes.

speaker: Mehmet
text: In my company it is stable, but you always hear rumors.

speaker: Anna
text: Mm.

speaker: Mehmet
text: So I had an offer from a smaller company, not automotive, like industrial machinery. But it was more technical. And my manager also offered me to take a new project, more critical, more visibility.

speaker: Mehmet
text: I had to decide, do I take this and maybe get promoted in the same path, or do I pivot.

speaker: Anna
text: And what did you decide?

speaker: Mehmet
text: I stayed. I took the project. Because I thought, okay, if I want to move into product or ops, I need credibility and visibility.

speaker: Mehmet
text: But also, honestly, visa situation. I am on Blue Card now. I got it after I started full-time.

speaker: Mehmet
text: So stability matters. Munich rent is crazy.

speaker: Anna
text: So stability and building credibility. What made it difficult?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Difficult is, I do not trust that doing more execution will lead to strategy roles. Sometimes it feels like you become good at firefighting and they keep you there. And also language.

speaker: Mehmet
text: Like, my English is fine. German is, I would say B1-B2, but corporate German is another world. When people speak in meetings, it is like, eehm, they speak politely but they are pushing.

speaker: Mehmet
text: I struggle to do that.

speaker: Anna
text: What kind of support did you feel you needed around that decision and around the current situation?

speaker: Mehmet
text: I needed someone to tell me, okay, what is the path, how to translate your experience. How to speak. How to position myself internally.

speaker: Mehmet
text: Also maybe which certificates or steps make sense. And also, eehm, confidence. Because sometimes I feel like outsider.

speaker: Mehmet
text: Turkish, accent, not perfect German, and in Munich corporate culture it is very, I do not know, polished. 3) Career support in general

speaker: Anna
text: When you need career support, who or what do you usually turn to?

speaker: Mehmet
text: I talk with my friends, mostly other internationals. Also my girlfriend, she is German, she helps with language and also she understands the culture. I sometimes talk to my manager, but I am careful, because you do not want to look like you are leaving.

speaker: Anna
text: Right.

speaker: Mehmet
text: I use online resources, LinkedIn, YouTube, sometimes those German career channels. And I use AI a lot, like daily. For emails, meeting prep, translation.

speaker: Mehmet
text: And also for career conversations, like how to craft CV, how to answer interview questions. And I did human coaching, like a paid package.

speaker: Anna
text: What has actually helped so far, and what has felt unhelpful?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Helpful is AI for language, 100 percent. It makes me faster and more confident. Also, informational interviews helped, like I reached out to one person in my company who moved from project engineering to operations excellence.

speaker: Mehmet
text: We had coffee. That was helpful because he gave realistic steps.

speaker: Anna
text: And unhelpful?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Unhelpful is generic advice. Like, network more, tailor your CV, show leadership. Okay, but how, you know.

speaker: Mehmet
text: And sometimes human coach gave me that. Also, some German content online is too general, and it assumes you are German native, so they do not address the language barrier.

speaker: Anna
text: When you say you reached out internally, how did you do it?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Eehm, I wrote on Teams. Very polite. I used AI to write it in German.

speaker: Mehmet
text: Like, Hallo Herr so-and-so, ich interessiere mich fuer Ihren Werdegang, koennten wir uns 20 Minuten austauschen. Something like that.

speaker: Anna
text: And how did that go?

speaker: Mehmet
text: It went good. He was friendly. We met in the cafeteria.

speaker: Mehmet
text: He told me, you need to show impact, not tasks. And you need to volunteer for cross-functional initiatives. And he said German is important for leadership roles, but not perfect, just confident.

speaker: Mehmet
text: 4) Human coaching: experience and trust

speaker: Anna
text: You mentioned you did a paid career coaching package. Can you tell me about it? What did the package include?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Yes. So I found it on Instagram, actually. The coach was German, she had like, eehm, HR background and coaching certificate.

speaker: Mehmet
text: The package was six sessions, one hour each, over two months. And there was homework. She gave templates, like values exercise, strengths, and a CV template, and a story template, like STAR method but also German version.

speaker: Mehmet
text: And she had accountability, like you need to send your homework before next session.

speaker: Anna
text: What did you like about it?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Structure. Because I am engineer, I like structure. It was like, session one clarify goals, session two strengths and achievements, session three target roles, session four CV and LinkedIn, session five interview prep, session six action plan.

speaker: Mehmet
text: So I knew what is coming. Also the homework forced me to think, not only talk.

speaker: Anna
text: And what did not work?

speaker: Mehmet
text: The coach did not understand engineering reality. Like she would say, just highlight leadership, like leading projects. And I said, in my role, leadership is not official, it is informal, and also we have strict processes.

speaker: Mehmet
text: She suggested things like, you should propose a new product idea to the OEM. And I am like, eehm, I cannot just propose product idea. We are supplier.

speaker: Mehmet
text: There are contracts. There are change requests, it is very formal. Also she mapped roles in a too simple way.

speaker: Mehmet
text: Like, she said, project engineer can go to product manager easily. But in automotive, product management is sometimes technical product management, sometimes it is commercial. And they want German, customer communication.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you recall a specific moment that was memorable, where you felt that mismatch?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Yes. One session she asked me to write my biggest achievement. I wrote about solving a quality escalation.

speaker: Mehmet
text: We had a part issue from a sub-supplier, and OEM found it in incoming inspection, and they threatened to stop line, like line stop is huge. I coordinated a containment action, 24 hours, we did sorting, we negotiated with supplier, we updated OEM with daily status, and we avoided line stop. It was stressful but we succeeded.

speaker: Anna
text: That is quite an example.

speaker: Mehmet
text: Yes. And she said, okay, nice, but you should not talk about firefighting, you should talk about strategy. And I said, but that is the reality, this is what I did.

speaker: Mehmet
text: And she tried to rewrite it like, I led strategic quality initiative. And I was like, no, it was not strategic, it was urgent. But it still shows skills.

speaker: Mehmet
text: She did not see that.

speaker: Anna
text: So she wanted to force it into a strategy narrative that did not feel true.

speaker: Mehmet
text: Exactly. And then I started to feel, she is nice, and I trust she wants to help, but she does not understand my world. So I cannot fully use her advice.

speaker: Anna
text: When you say trust, what makes you trust a human coach, in general?

speaker: Mehmet
text: For me, trust is competence first. Like, they should understand engineering and corporate environment. Not necessarily mechanical engineering, but at least how projects work, constraints, stakeholders, timelines.

speaker: Mehmet
text: Second is structure, like process. Third is accountability, like they follow up. And empathy without fluff.

speaker: Mehmet
text: Like I do not want too much motivational talk. I want practical.

speaker: Anna
text: Mm-hm. Anything else?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Concrete examples. If coach says, I helped someone move from project engineer to product, and they can explain steps, then I trust more.

speaker: Anna
text: Did you feel any of that with your coach?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Structure yes. Accountability yes. Empathy yes, she was kind.

speaker: Mehmet
text: But competence in engineering reality, not enough. So I would say, I trusted her as a person, but not fully trusted her advice. Anna Thank you.

speaker: Mehmet
text: So trusted, but not effective?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Yes, exactly. I liked her, I felt safe, I could talk, but the output was not so effective for my situation.

speaker: Anna
text: When you say safe, what created that feeling?

speaker: Mehmet
text: She was not judging, she listened, she kept confidentiality, she did not share anything. And she was professional, like on time, prepared. That creates trust.

speaker: Anna
text: Did you ever hold back anything because of trust issues?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Not really. I am not very private. I can tell.

speaker: Anna
text: We will come back to privacy later.

speaker: Mehmet
text: Okay. 5) AI tools: experience and trust

speaker: Anna
text: Let us talk about AI tools. You said you use AI daily. What tools do you use, and for what?

speaker: Mehmet
text: I use ChatGPT and also sometimes DeepL for translation. But ChatGPT is more flexible. I use it for writing emails in German, like to be polite but also clear.

speaker: Mehmet
text: I use it to prepare for meetings, like I put agenda and notes and ask, what questions will they ask, what risks. I use it to summarize long Teams chat or notes. And for career, I use it for CV bullet points, cover letter, interview questions, and also to practice German corporate phrases.

speaker: Mehmet
text: Like, how to say I disagree politely. Claude code, Cursor, n8n and all other stuff.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you give me an example where AI clearly helped at work?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Yes. Last month we had a supplier delay, and we needed to inform OEM program manager. In German you cannot say, you are wrong, or we are late, like direct.

speaker: Mehmet
text: You say, eehm, there is a deviation, and we are working on mitigation, and we propose next steps. I wrote a draft and it sounded too blunt. I asked AI, rewrite in German corporate tone, like with those phrases, wir moechten Sie informieren, wir bitten um Verstaendnis, wir sind im engen Austausch.

speaker: Mehmet
text: And it created a very good email. My boss even said, good wording.

speaker: Anna
text: What was the risk in that situation?

speaker: Mehmet
text: The risk is, if the email is too direct, they escalate. If too soft, they think you are hiding. So you need balance.

speaker: Mehmet
text: AI helped with that.

speaker: Anna
text: And can you share an example where AI failed or caused a risk?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Yes. I once asked AI to draft an email to HR about internal mobility, like I want to explore opportunities in product management. And AI wrote something too strong, like I am unhappy in my current role and I want to change quickly.

speaker: Mehmet
text: And that is dangerous. Because in Germany HR is, eehm, they document things. So I did not send.

speaker: Mehmet
text: But I realized, okay, AI does not know internal politics. Also sometimes it hallucinates, like it adds policies that do not exist. It wrote something like, according to company guideline 4.3, you can apply after 12 months.

speaker: Mehmet
text: I was like, what guideline, hahahah.

speaker: Anna
text: How did you catch that?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Because I know there is no guideline 4.3. And also it sounded too confident. So I checked our intranet.

speaker: Mehmet
text: And it was different.

speaker: Anna
text: How do you generally verify AI output?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Depends. For translation and tone, I do quick check. I read it and if it sounds okay, I use it.

speaker: Mehmet
text: For technical content, I verify more. Like if it summarizes technical discussion, I check key numbers, tolerances, deadlines. For HR or sensitive topics, I verify a lot, and I ask my girlfriend or colleague.

speaker: Anna
text: So verification level depends on stakes.

speaker: Mehmet
text: Exactly.

speaker: Anna
text: What makes you trust AI in these tasks?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Speed, first. It is immediate. Second, repeatability.

speaker: Mehmet
text: I can ask again, change tone, shorter, more formal. Third, no judgment. I can ask stupid questions, like what does this German phrase mean, and it will answer.

speaker: Mehmet
text: Fourth, convenience, 24/7. Sometimes at 23:00 I prepare something for morning meeting.

speaker: Anna
text: And what reduces your trust?

speaker: Mehmet
text: When it gives wrong facts, or when tone is off. Like too formal, or too American, you know. Or it creates something that looks real but is not.

speaker: Mehmet
text: That is dangerous.

speaker: Anna
text: You also mentioned privacy. You said you know privacy is weak but you do not care much. Can you say that in your own words?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Yes. Eehm, honestly, I think privacy is kind of an illusion now. Like, everyone already has your data.

speaker: Mehmet
text: Google, WhatsApp, company systems. People share everything on Instagram. So I feel like, what am I protecting?

speaker: Mehmet
text: I am not a celebrity. I am not doing illegal things. So I do not care much.

speaker: Mehmet
text: I assume everyone already knows everything. So I have nothing to lose.

speaker: Anna
text: Does that affect whether you trust AI?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Yes, because I do not worry. I just use it. I do not overthink.

speaker: Mehmet
text: If I was very privacy person, maybe I would not paste emails or details. But I do.

speaker: Anna
text: Do you ever paste confidential company information?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Hmm. I try not to paste, like, very confidential numbers. But I paste context.

speaker: Mehmet
text: Like, schedule, topics, general. But yes, I share a lot.

speaker: Anna
text: And you feel okay with that.

speaker: Mehmet
text: Yes. In my mind, if company wants to be safe, they should provide their own tool. If they do not, then, eehm, people will use what exists.

speaker: Anna
text: Interesting. If I push a bit, do you see any scenario where privacy would matter for you?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Maybe if it is about health, or like family. But career topics, I do not mind. And emails, I mean, they are already in systems.

speaker: Anna
text: So for you, privacy is not a strong component of trust.

speaker: Mehmet
text: Exactly. Trust for AI is more about, will it help me and not create problems.

speaker: Anna
text: Okay. 6) Human vs AI comparison via specific tasks

speaker: Anna
text: I want to compare human and AI through specific tasks. Let us take one task like translating your execution experience into a product management narrative. If you had to do that tomorrow, what would you use, human coach or AI, and why?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Eehm. I would start with AI. Because AI can help me write bullet points and give me structure.

speaker: Mehmet
text: Like, it can take my messy notes and make it into achievements. And also it helps with German phrasing. But I would want a human, ideally someone who understands engineering, to validate if the story is credible and if it matches PM expectations.

speaker: Anna
text: So AI for draft, human for reality check.

speaker: Mehmet
text: Yes. Because AI sometimes makes it too polished and not realistic.

speaker: Anna
text: Another task.Preparing for an internal meeting where you need to influence stakeholders, like quality manager, production, maybe purchasing. What do you use?

speaker: Mehmet
text: AI helps to prepare agenda and questions. Like, what arguments, what risks, what data. But human helps with politics.

speaker: Mehmet
text: Like, who is sensitive, who needs to feel respected, what to say in the room. AI cannot know that.

speaker: Anna
text: And another task. Deciding whether to invest heavily in German language or instead focus on technical certifications for a pivot. How would you handle that?

speaker: Mehmet
text: That is more human. Because it is personal and also depends on my life. But I still use AI to brainstorm pros and cons.

speaker: Mehmet
text: But decision is, eehm, I need someone to challenge me, to ask why. AI can ask, but it is not the same.

speaker: Anna
text: Why not the same?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Because with human, you feel accountable. Like if I tell someone, I will do German course, then next session they ask, did you do it. AI does not care.

speaker: Anna
text: What about CV rewriting, cover letters?

speaker: Mehmet
text: AI is very good, very effective. Human coach also can help, but AI is faster and cheaper. And I can iterate many times.

speaker: Anna
text: Interview practice?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Mixed. AI can simulate questions, but human can read my vibe, my confidence, and also tell me if my story makes sense. And especially in Germany, cultural style matters.

speaker: Mehmet
text: Like not overselling, but also not under-selling. That is hard. 7) Trust–effectiveness link

speaker: Anna
text: Now I want to explore the link between trust and effectiveness. In your experience, how does trust affect whether a coaching method is effective?

speaker: Mehmet
text: For human, trust is necessary. If I do not trust the coach, I will not tell the real issues. Like, maybe I am insecure, or maybe I have conflict with manager, or maybe I feel discrimination.

speaker: Mehmet
text: If I do not trust, I will say only surface. Then coaching is not effective. So trust is like, access to truth.

speaker: Anna
text: And for AI?

speaker: Mehmet
text: For AI, trust is different. Because I can still use it even if I do not fully trust. Like, I can ask it to write an email.

speaker: Mehmet
text: It can be effective, even if I do not trust it fully, because I will check it. So effectiveness can happen with partial trust.

speaker: Anna
text: That is an important distinction. Can you give an example of effective but not trusted?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Yes. Sometimes AI writes a perfect email, like very diplomatic. It is effective because stakeholder reacts well.

speaker: Mehmet
text: But I do not trust that it is correct, so I read it carefully. I think, is this too much, is this wrong. So I use it but I have doubt.

speaker: Anna
text: And trusted but not effective, you already mentioned with the coach.

speaker: Mehmet
text: Exactly. I trusted her as person, but advice did not fit engineering reality. So not effective.

speaker: Anna
text: What counts as effectiveness for you, in this career support context?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Effectiveness is, I get clearer narrative about my work. Like, I can explain myself in interviews or internally. Second, I get interview invites or internal conversations.

speaker: Mehmet
text: Third, I can take steps for internal mobility, like apply, talk to people, join initiative. Fourth, in meetings I feel more confident and I can influence better. Like, not just follow.

speaker: Anna
text: So effectiveness is not only feelings, but concrete outcomes.

speaker: Mehmet
text: Yes. Feelings are part, but I want outcomes.

speaker: Anna
text: Do you think trust always leads to effectiveness?

speaker: Mehmet
text: No. You can trust someone and still they cannot help. Like my coach.

speaker: Mehmet
text: Or you can trust a human who is kind but not competent. And then you waste time. So trust is not enough.

speaker: Mehmet
text: Competence and fit is needed.

speaker: Anna
text: And can effectiveness build trust over time?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Yes. If AI helps me many times, I trust more. Even if I know it can be wrong, I rely more.

speaker: Mehmet
text: For human also, if coach gives me one good insight, I trust more.

speaker: Anna
text: You mentioned earlier you are not very concerned about privacy. Some people connect privacy with trust, especially for AI. In your case, do you see any downside in not caring?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Hmm. Maybe I am naive. But, eehm, I think if something bad happens, like data leak, then I will care.

speaker: Mehmet
text: But until then, I do not. It is pragmatic.

speaker: Anna
text: Does that pragmatism affect your willingness to use AI for deeper career reflection?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Yes. I use it for deeper reflection too. Like, I ask, what are my strengths, what are possible career paths.

speaker: Mehmet
text: I tell it my situation. I do not feel blocked.

speaker: Anna
text: Okay. Micro-poll ratings

speaker: Anna
text: I want to include a quick micro-poll, just to structure the comparison. On a scale from 0 to 10, where 0 is no trust at all and 10 is full trust, how much do you currently trust human career coaches?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Hmm. I would say 6.

speaker: Anna
text: Why 6?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Because I think humans can be helpful, and they can understand emotions and context. But many coaches are generic. And I do not know how to find a good one.

speaker: Mehmet
text: So I cannot give 8 or 9.

speaker: Anna
text: Same scale, trust in AI tools for career-related support?

speaker: Mehmet
text: I would say 7.5.

speaker: Anna
text: Why higher?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Because I use it daily, and it helps. I trust it for language and structure. But I do not trust it for facts always, so not 9.

speaker: Anna
text: Now perceived effectiveness for your situation. Effectiveness of human coaching you experienced, 0 to 10.

speaker: Mehmet
text: For my situation, maybe 5.

speaker: Anna
text: Why 5?

speaker: Mehmet
text: It gave me structure and some clarity, but it did not move me closer to product roles. It did not change outcomes yet.

speaker: Anna
text: And perceived effectiveness of AI tools for your situation, 0 to 10.

speaker: Mehmet
text: That is higher, maybe 8.

speaker: Anna
text: Why 8?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Because it improves my daily work and communication, and it helps me prepare career documents fast. It is very practical.

speaker: Anna
text: Great, thank you. 8) Preferences and hybrid model reaction

speaker: Anna
text: If you imagine an ideal setup, what would you prefer: only human coaching, only AI support, or a hybrid model?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Hybrid. Definitely.

speaker: Anna
text: What does hybrid mean for you?

speaker: Mehmet
text: AI for preparation, drafts, language. Human for big decisions, for accountability, and for industry reality check. And also for networking maybe.

speaker: Mehmet
text: Like a human can connect you, or tell you where to look.

speaker: Anna
text: If I describe a model where you have an AI assistant that helps you clarify goals, prepare materials, and then you can book sessions with experienced insiders in your target field, how do you react?

speaker: Mehmet
text: That sounds good. Because my problem is, I do not know where to find a good coach. If it is insider, like someone who did product in automotive or operations, then I would trust more.

speaker: Mehmet
text: And AI can help me not waste human time with basic things.

speaker: Anna
text: What would you be cautious about in such a model?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Quality control. Like, who are these insiders, are they really good. And also cost.

speaker: Mehmet
text: In Munich everything is expensive. And maybe, eehm, matching. Like, if you match me with someone from marketing, it will not help.

speaker: Anna
text: So domain fit is key.

speaker: Mehmet
text: Yes. And also language. If insider speaks English, I can do it.

speaker: Mehmet
text: But if they only speak German, it is hard. But maybe that is also training.

speaker: Anna
text: Would you want the insider to be very empathetic, or more direct and practical?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Practical and direct. Empathy is good, but not too much. Like, do not tell me, you are amazing, believe in yourself.

speaker: Mehmet
text: Tell me, do this, do that, and why.

speaker: Anna
text: If you could design the first session with such an insider, what would you want to achieve by the end?

speaker: Mehmet
text: I want a realistic path. Like, in my company or in Munich market, what are the roles, what skills, what steps. And I want to know, should I focus on German, on certifications, on internal projects.

speaker: Mehmet
text: And I want feedback on my story, like how to position my quality escalation example as leadership.

speaker: Anna
text: And what would AI do before that session?

speaker: Mehmet
text: AI would help me write my achievements, translate, and prepare questions. Also summarize my situation so insider can read and not spend time on basics.

speaker: Anna
text: You mentioned earlier you are not overly excited about human coaches, but still want to try a good one. Can you say more about that?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Yes. I think human coaches are fine, but many are like, eehm, same. They sell packages, they have nice websites, but I do not know if they can help an engineer.

speaker: Mehmet
text: I am not against it. I just do not feel, wow, coaching will change my life. But if I find a coach who is credible, then I am interested.

speaker: Anna
text: How would you try to find that credible person?

speaker: Mehmet
text: That is the problem. I do not know. Maybe through recommendation.

speaker: Mehmet
text: Or LinkedIn. Or platforms. But it is hard to evaluate before paying.

speaker: Anna
text: So trust formation is hard upfront.

speaker: Mehmet
text: Yes. You need signals. Like background, client stories, but those can be marketing.

speaker: Anna
text: In your experience, did AI play any role in helping you evaluate coaches?

speaker: Mehmet
