text: Yes, I asked AI, what questions should I ask a coach before buying. It suggested to ask about experience, methodology, success examples. That was useful.

speaker: Mehmet
text: But I did not do it strongly, because I am polite. 9) Closing

speaker: Anna
text: We are close to the end. Is there anything we did not cover that feels important about your experience with human coaching and AI for career support?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Maybe one thing. AI helps me with German corporate language, but it also makes me dependent. Like, sometimes I think, can I write without it.

speaker: Mehmet
text: And also, if everyone uses it, then the standard becomes higher. So you need it to keep up.

speaker: Anna
text: That is interesting. Like an arms race.

speaker: Mehmet
text: Yes, exactly. And for human coaching, I think it can be good, but it must be tailored to reality. For engineering, we need someone who understands constraints.

speaker: Anna
text: If you could give one advice to a human coach working with someone like you, what would it be?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Learn the engineering context. Ask about real projects and constraints. Do not force strategy words that are not true.

speaker: Mehmet
text: Help translate reality into impact, not invent.

speaker: Anna
text: And one advice to an AI tool designer for career support?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Make it understand German corporate culture better. Like tone, indirect phrasing, and also industry context. And maybe include warnings when content is risky, like HR emails.

speaker: Mehmet
text: Because sometimes AI is too confident.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you. Final question, how are you feeling about your next step right now, like today?

speaker: Mehmet
text: Today I feel, eehm, more hopeful than six months ago. Because I see options. I started German course again, and I did two informational coffees.

speaker: Mehmet
text: Small steps. But still, I feel stuck sometimes.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you for being open, Mehmet. If you have any questions for me about the study, you can ask now.

speaker: Mehmet
text: No, all good. It was interesting to reflect.

speaker: Anna
text: Great. Then we stop here. Thank you again.

speaker: Anna
text: Hi Sofia, thanks for joining. Before we start, do I have your permission to record? Everything will be anonymised, and you can skip any question.

speaker: Sofia
text: Hi Anna. Yes, you can record. That is okay.

speaker: Anna
text: Great. Just to double check, if anything feels uncomfortable, you can pause me or say you want to skip. Sound okay?

speaker: Sofia
text: Yes. Sounds good. I am a bit nervous but, um, okay hahaha.

speaker: Anna
text: Totally normal. We can take it slow. Also, I will ask about experiences with human mentoring or coaching and also AI tools for career support.

speaker: Anna
text: There are no right answers, just your experience. Ready?

speaker: Sofia
text: Yes. Ready. 2) Participant context and career situation

speaker: Anna
text: To start, where are you currently in your career, and what career decisions or questions are you facing right now, or recently faced?

speaker: Sofia
text: Eehm, so I am 27. I moved to Hamburg three years ago from Spain for my Master’s in Business Analytics. I finished last year.

speaker: Sofia
text: And now I work in e-commerce as a data specialist. In my company the title is Data Specialist, but it is basically marketing analytics, like growth marketing analytics.

speaker: Anna
text: Aha.

speaker: Sofia
text: And, um, I like the analysis part a lot. Like, I genuinely enjoy when there is messy data and you have to make it make sense. But I am not super comfortable with the, how to say, the storytelling to stakeholders.

speaker: Sofia
text: Like presenting to product managers or marketing leads, or leadership, that makes me anxious.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you say a bit more about what kind of situations trigger that anxiety?

speaker: Sofia
text: Yeah. So, we have weekly KPI meetings. It is fast paced, like every week is campaigns, promotions, seasonality, and everyone wants answers fast.

speaker: Sofia
text: And I have dashboards and analysis, and sometimes I am asked to, like, explain why conversion dropped in a certain segment, or why CAC changed, or why ROAS is not meeting target. And I know the analysis, but when I have to explain it in front of people who are very confident and very quick, I get, um, in my head.

speaker: Anna
text: What goes through your head in those moments?

speaker: Sofia
text: Like, I am thinking, okay, do I sound naive? Do I sound like I do not understand business? Also language.

speaker: Sofia
text: I speak English at work mostly, but there is always some German words and some jokes and, like, these small nuances. My German is, eehm, B1 maybe, like I can handle daily life, but in meetings I do not jump in German. So sometimes I feel behind.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you. What is a career decision you faced in the last, say, six to twelve months?

speaker: Sofia
text: Yes. So, around, maybe, September or October last year, I had this decision. I was doing mainly reporting and campaign performance, like weekly dashboards, and I felt I was becoming, um, a dashboard person.

speaker: Sofia
text: And I wanted to grow into a bridge role, like someone who can translate analytics to business decisions. Like analytics translator, analytics PM, strategy ops with data. But I was not sure how to move there from my current role.

speaker: Anna
text: So what did you consider doing?

speaker: Sofia
text: I considered applying internally to product analytics, because product analytics is closer to feature decisions. But then I was like, wait, I will still have to present to stakeholders, maybe even more. And then I considered asking my manager to give me more exposure, like not just sending slides, but presenting, leading parts of the meeting.

speaker: Sofia
text: That felt scary.

speaker: Anna
text: What did you end up doing?

speaker: Sofia
text: I did a bit of both. I did not apply internally yet. I had a conversation with my manager, and I asked for more stakeholder exposure, like I said, I want to own one KPI narrative end to end.

speaker: Sofia
text: Like not just numbers, but the story. And she said yes, but then I had to do it.

speaker: Anna
text: How did that go?

speaker: Sofia
text: The first time was bad in my head, but it was okay in reality. Like I prepared too much. I wrote a script almost.

speaker: Sofia
text: And then in the meeting, the Head of Marketing, he is German, very direct, he interrupted me and asked, so what do we do now? Like, he wanted action. And I froze for one second.

speaker: Sofia
text: And then I said, okay, we test creative A versus B, we adjust bid strategy, and we check attribution window. But my voice, I could hear it shaking.

speaker: Anna
text: What did you take away from that moment?

speaker: Sofia
text: That analysis depth is not enough. People want decision speed. They want, like, a recommendation, even if it is imperfect.

speaker: Sofia
text: And I can do that, but I need confidence. And also I need to feel safe. Like if someone interrupts and it feels aggressive, I interpret it as I failed.

speaker: Anna
text: When you say safe, what would create that safety for you?

speaker: Sofia
text: Um, if someone signals, it is okay to think, it is okay to not know everything. Like, if my manager says, we are exploring, not defending. But in those meetings it feels like defending.

speaker: Sofia
text: 3) Career support in general

speaker: Anna
text: When you need career support, who or what do you usually turn to?

speaker: Sofia
text: Eehm, friends. I have two close friends in Hamburg, one is also in tech. And I call my mom.

speaker: Sofia
text: My mom is in Spain, in Valencia region, like near Alicante, and she is very supportive. She is like, Sofia, you are capable, you moved countries, you did a Master’s, you can do this. She is very, how to say, ground?

speaker: Anna
text: What kind of support does your mom give you, practically?

speaker: Sofia
text: She gives emotional reassurance. Like she listens. And she also gives like, values advice.

speaker: Sofia
text: Like, she asks, what kind of life do you want? Do you want stability, do you want growth, do you want people around you? She is not in analytics, so she cannot give specific career tips, but she makes me calmer.

speaker: Anna
text: Anything else besides friends and your mom?

speaker: Sofia
text: Sometimes online resources, like LinkedIn posts, but honestly it overwhelms me. Everyone is like, you must do this, you must do that. So I avoid.

speaker: Sofia
text: And then, yes, I have used AI sometimes, like ChatGPT, and now I use Cursor a lot for vibe coding, building small agents. But that is more for work and also, like, for career brainstorming when I am overwhelmed.

speaker: Anna
text: Before we go to AI, tell me about human support. Have you used any mentoring or coaching?

speaker: Sofia
text: Yes. I tried mentoring via a women-in-tech network in Hamburg. It was like a programme, they matched you with a mentor.

speaker: Sofia
text: 4) Human coaching: experience and trust

speaker: Anna
text: Tell me about that mentoring. What was the setup, and what were you hoping to get?

speaker: Sofia
text: It was supposed to be, like, six months. One call per month, plus maybe messages in between. I wanted guidance on how to grow from data specialist into a more business bridging role.

speaker: Sofia
text: And also confidence, like how to speak up, how to present. Like, not therapy, but more, um, career mentoring.

speaker: Anna
text: What happened in the beginning?

speaker: Sofia
text: In the beginning it was great. I got matched with a mentor, she worked in a bigger company, like a marketplace, in analytics leadership. She was also Spanish, actually, which was, like, wow, instant connection.

speaker: Sofia
text: We spoke Spanglish sometimes. And she was very warm. She asked me questions, she remembered details.

speaker: Sofia
text: That made me trust her fast.

speaker: Anna
text: What specifically made you trust her?

speaker: Sofia
text: Feeling seen. Like she did not treat me like a generic mentee. She asked about my team, the meeting culture, my language situation.

speaker: Sofia
text: And she was credible, like she had done the path. Also confidentiality. She explicitly said, what we talk about stays here.

speaker: Sofia
text: That made me relax.

speaker: Anna
text: Was it effective?

speaker: Sofia
text: Um, partly. It was motivating. After the first call I felt, like, I can do it.

speaker: Sofia
text: She gave me some frameworks, like, prepare three bullets: insight, impact, action. And she suggested I ask my manager for more exposure. That was actually useful.

speaker: Anna
text: And then you said it became inconsistent.

speaker: Sofia
text: Yes. So after maybe two calls, it became messy. She started cancelling.

speaker: Sofia
text: Like, one time she cancelled 30 minutes before because she had a leadership meeting. And I understand, but then we rescheduled and she cancelled again. And then the programme coordinators said, okay, you can switch mentor if needed.

speaker: Anna
text: How did that affect you?

speaker: Sofia
text: It broke the trust in reliability. Like I still liked her as a person. So, this is interesting, I trusted her in the sense I felt safe and I thought she is a good person.

speaker: Sofia
text: But it was not effective anymore because there was no follow through. Like no accountability, no continuity.

speaker: Anna
text: Did you switch mentors?

speaker: Sofia
text: Yes. They switched me to another mentor. She was German, very direct, very structured.

speaker: Sofia
text: She was like, okay, what is your goal, what is your plan, send me your CV, we will review. That was, um, in some way effective, because she pushed me. But I did not trust her emotionally.

speaker: Anna
text: What made it hard to trust her?

speaker: Sofia
text: She felt judgemental, maybe not intentionally. Like she would say, why did you not do this already? And I was like, eehm, because I am scared?

speaker: Sofia
text: Hahaha. But I did not want to say that. Also she did not remember details.

speaker: Sofia
text: It felt transactional.

speaker: Anna
text: So would you say that mentor was effective but not trusted?

speaker: Sofia
text: Yes, exactly. Like, she gave concrete tasks. She told me to write a stakeholder update email in a certain format.

speaker: Sofia
text: And it worked. My manager liked it. So effective.

speaker: Sofia
text: But I did not feel warm. I did not feel safe. So I did not share the deeper anxiety.

speaker: Anna
text: And the first mentor, trusted but not effective, at least later on?

speaker: Sofia
text: Yes. Trusted, but not effective because no continuity. I still think she is great, but it did not help my career problem in the end.

speaker: Anna
text: Did you have any other human support, like a paid coach, university career services?

speaker: Sofia
text: I used the university career service once in the Master’s. It was okay, but very generic. Like, they gave me CV tips, but not specific to analytics in Germany.

speaker: Sofia
text: And also, I did not fully trust them because it felt like they do it for everyone.

speaker: Anna
text: Did it help anyway?

speaker: Sofia
text: A little. Like, they helped me format the CV and explain German CV conventions. That was useful, even if I did not trust them deeply.

speaker: Sofia
text: So, maybe that is human help that is effective despite low trust. It was effective for the task, but I did not feel a relationship.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you that is good for distinction. 5) AI tools: experience and trust

speaker: Anna
text: Now let’s talk about AI tools for career support. What have you used, and in what situations?

speaker: Sofia
text: Mostly ChatGPT, and also I use Cursor a lot. But for career support specifically, ChatGPT. When I am overwhelmed, like I have too many options and I cannot think.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you give me a concrete moment when AI helped?

speaker: Sofia
text: Yes. In November, I had a week where I felt, like, I am stuck. I was comparing roles like analytics PM, strategy and ops, product analyst, and I was like, I do not know what fits me.

speaker: Sofia
text: And I was also tired from work. So I opened ChatGPT and I wrote, I am a data specialist in e-commerce in Hamburg, I like analysis but fear presentations, I want a bridge role, what options exist and what steps to test them.

speaker: Anna
text: And what did it do?

speaker: Sofia
text: It gave structure. Like, it made a table. It suggested informational interviews, internal projects, asking to shadow product meetings, building a small portfolio, like case studies.

speaker: Sofia
text: And it suggested a weekly plan, like week 1 identify roles, week 2 talk to manager, week 3 update CV, etc. That calmed me.

speaker: Anna
text: Did you act on it?

speaker: Sofia
text: Yes, partially. I used it to draft a message to my manager, like a Slack message. I was like, can I take ownership of the KPI narrative for retention next month, and can we define success.

speaker: Sofia
text: It drafted something that sounded confident.

speaker: Anna
text: How did you feel sending that?

speaker: Sofia
text: Nervous but it helped. And then I double checked with my friend and my mom. My mom was like, it sounds professional, but make it more you, like not too robotic.

speaker: Anna
text: So you use AI but validate with humans.

speaker: Sofia
text: Yes. For important decisions, I need human validation. Even if AI is helpful, I do not fully trust it.

speaker: Anna
text: What makes you not fully trust it?

speaker: Sofia
text: Context and accuracy. Like, sometimes it assumes US style, or it assumes I can just switch jobs easily. Or it suggests things that do not fit German culture, like being super assertive in a way that can be seen as arrogant here.

speaker: Sofia
text: Also it can sound too polished. And then I worry, if I speak like that, people will think it is fake.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you describe a moment AI failed for you?

speaker: Sofia
text: Yes. I asked it once, like, how to prepare for a stakeholder meeting with a German leadership team. And it gave me advice that was generic, like, be confident, tell a story, use visuals.

speaker: Sofia
text: And it suggested I open with a personal anecdote. And I was like, hmm, in my company, leadership does not want personal anecdotes. They want numbers.

speaker: Sofia
text: So it felt wrong.

speaker: Anna
text: Anything else?

speaker: Sofia
text: Another time it suggested salary ranges that were, I think, unrealistic. It was like, you can earn X, and I was like, I do not know if that is true in Hamburg for my experience. So I did not trust it.

speaker: Sofia
text: But it still gave me, like, negotiation phrases. That part was useful.

speaker: Anna
text: That sounds like effective but not trusted.

speaker: Sofia
text: Exactly. Like I take the structure and the wording, but I do not trust the facts.

speaker: Anna
text: You mentioned Cursor and vibe coding. How does that connect to your work, and maybe also your confidence?

speaker: Sofia
text: Oh yes. So I am kind of obsessed. I use Cursor to build small agents, like, um, scripts that help me at work.

speaker: Sofia
text: For example, I built an agent that drafts SQL queries from a question. Like, I write, I need conversion by channel by week, excluding returns, and it drafts a query. I still review, but it saves time.

speaker: Anna
text: What else?

speaker: Sofia
text: I built a reporting narrative generator. So, every Monday I have to send a summary of campaign performance. I created a template where the agent reads the metrics from a CSV and writes a first draft narrative, like, this week ROAS increased due to X, but CAC rose in Y segment, recommended action is Z.

speaker: Sofia
text: It is not perfect, but it gives me a starting point.

speaker: Anna
text: Interesting. Any agents for meetings?

speaker: Sofia
text: Yes. I have a meeting prep checklist agent. I paste the meeting title and attendees, and it generates, like, what do they care about, what questions might they ask, what risks, what one slide summary.

speaker: Sofia
text: And also I made a stakeholder FAQ generator. It creates a list of likely objections, like, is this statistically significant, what about seasonality, what about attribution. That helps my anxiety because I feel prepared.

speaker: Anna
text: Does it reduce anxiety in presentations?

speaker: Sofia
text: A bit. It gives me confidence because I have answers ready. But also it can make me over prepare.

speaker: Sofia
text: Like, I have 20 possible questions and then I am more stressed.

speaker: Anna
text: You also said you believe many problems can be solved with AI.

speaker: Sofia
text: Yes, I kind of do. Like, not emotions, but a lot of work problems, planning problems, writing problems. I love building agents.

speaker: Sofia
text: It makes me feel powerful, like I can create my own support system.

speaker: Anna
text: And privacy, how do you think about that?

speaker: Sofia
text: Eehm. I understand it matters. Like GDPR, and company data, and personal data.

speaker: Sofia
text: But honestly, sometimes I ignore it because it is easier. Like, I try not to paste sensitive data, but I probably do more than I should. It is like, I know it is important, but I also want speed.

speaker: Sofia
text: And then I laugh it off like, okay, Sofia, you will go to jail. Hahahah. But yeah, I know it is not ideal.

speaker: Anna
text: So there is awareness, but convenience wins?

speaker: Sofia
text: Aha 6) Human vs AI comparison via specific tasks

speaker: Anna
text: I want to compare human mentoring and AI support through specific tasks. Let’s take a few common career support tasks. First, clarifying options.

speaker: Anna
text: If you feel stuck and you need to map options, who or what do you prefer?

speaker: Sofia
text: AI first. Because it is fast and non judgemental. I can dump everything, like, I am confused, I hate presenting, I like analysis, and it will not react like, what is wrong with you.It just structures.

speaker: Anna
text: And then?

speaker: Sofia
text: Then human, to validate. Like my friend or my mom, or ideally a mentor who is consistent.

speaker: Anna
text: Second task, making a high stakes decision, like applying internally or asking for a role change. Who do you rely on?

speaker: Sofia
text: Human more. Because I need reassurance and also context. Like, my friend knows my company culture.

speaker: Sofia
text: AI does not.

speaker: Anna
text: Third task, preparing for stakeholder presentations. Who helps more?

speaker: Sofia
text: This one is mixed. AI helps with structure, like the storyline, and anticipating questions. But a human helps with delivery, like confidence, tone, and what is realistic in the room.

speaker: Anna
text: What about practical tasks like CV rewriting or drafting messages?

speaker: Sofia
text: AI is very effective there. It can rewrite, it can produce versions. But I do not fully trust it because it can sound too perfect, too American.

speaker: Sofia
text: So I edit. Also I sometimes ask the German mentor style person, like, is this wording okay. She is effective for that even if I do not trust her emotionally.

speaker: Anna
text: So you use both, depending on the task.

speaker: Sofia
text: Yes. AI for speed and drafts. Humans for context and emotional safety.

speaker: Sofia
text: 7) Trust–effectiveness link

speaker: Anna
text: Now I want to explore the link between trust and effectiveness. In your experience, how does trust affect whether something is effective?

speaker: Sofia
text: Trust is like, um, permission. If I trust a mentor, I tell the real story. Like, I say, I am scared, I feel stupid, I do not understand the meeting dynamics.

speaker: Sofia
text: And then they can help. If I do not trust, I only talk about safe topics, like CV. Then it is less effective.

speaker: Anna
text: And for AI?

speaker: Sofia
text: For AI, trust is different. I do not need emotional trust. I need to trust accuracy and that it is not misleading me.

speaker: Sofia
text: If I do not trust it, I still might use it for structure, but I will not follow advice blindly.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you give an example where you trusted but it was not effective?

speaker: Sofia
text: Yes, the first mentor in the women-in-tech programme. I trusted her as a person. I felt warmth.

speaker: Sofia
text: But it became not effective because she was not reliable, and advice stayed vague, like, be confident, you can do it, and then no follow up. So I felt good but nothing changed.

speaker: Anna
text: And effective but not trusted?

speaker: Sofia
text: AI sometimes. Like the negotiation phrases. Or the plan for internal move.

speaker: Sofia
text: It was effective because it gave me steps. But I did not trust that it understood Germany or my company. So I double checked with humans.

speaker: Sofia
text: Another example is the second mentor, the German one. She was effective with concrete tasks, but I did not trust her enough to share the deeper anxiety.

speaker: Anna
text: You also mentioned human support that was effective despite low trust, like university career services.

speaker: Sofia
text: Yes. They helped with German CV format. I did not trust them as, like, knowing my life, but they were effective for that task.

speaker: Anna
text: When you think about perceived effectiveness, how do you define it for yourself?

speaker: Sofia
text: If it leads to action and better outcomes. Like, I feel clearer, I do the next step, I perform better in meetings, I get better feedback from my manager, or I get interview callbacks. Also confidence.

speaker: Sofia
text: Like, if I can present and not panic, that is effectiveness.

speaker: Anna
text: Does trust always lead to effectiveness in your opinion?

speaker: Sofia
text: Not always. I mean , trust can make me feel better but not change behaviour. Like, emotional comfort without structure is not enough.

speaker: Sofia
text: And effectiveness can happen without full trust, like a useful template. But for deep career decisions, trust is necessary, because I need to share real things. 8) Preferences and hybrid model reaction (including micro-poll ratings)

speaker: Anna
text: I want to do a quick micro poll, just short. On a scale from 0 to 10, where 0 is no trust at all and 10 is complete trust, how would you rate your trust in human coaches or mentors, in general, for your career situation?

speaker: Sofia
text: Um. I would say 7. Because I believe humans can understand.

speaker: Sofia
text: But I also had inconsistency. So not 9.

speaker: Anna
text: What drives that 7?

speaker: Sofia
text: Warmth, feeling seen, credibility, like they know the path. Also accountability. But I deduct points because reliability is not guaranteed and sometimes advice is generic.

speaker: Anna
text: Same scale, trust in AI tools for career support?

speaker: Sofia
text: Maybe 5.5. Hahaha. Is half allowed?

speaker: Anna
text: Totally fine. Why 5.5?

speaker: Sofia
text: Speed, structure, low judgement, repeatability. I can ask again and again. But questionable accuracy and context.

speaker: Sofia
text: And sometimes it sounds too confident and I get suspicious.

speaker: Anna
text: Now perceived effectiveness. Same 0 to 10. Effectiveness of human mentoring or coaching for your situation.

speaker: Sofia
text: I would say 6. Because when it works, it is amazing. But I had inconsistency.

speaker: Sofia
text: And also sometimes humans are supportive but vague.

speaker: Anna
text: And effectiveness of AI tools for your situation?

speaker: Sofia
text: I would say 7. Which is funny because trust is lower. But effectiveness is higher for some tasks.

speaker: Anna
text: That is interesting. Why 7?

speaker: Sofia
text: Because it helps me move when I am stuck. It gives me drafts, plans, options. It reduces overwhelm.

speaker: Sofia
text: But I still validate with humans.

speaker: Anna
text: That separation is exactly what I want to understand. Now imagine a hybrid model. For example, you have an AI that helps you clarify options, prepare messages, and build a plan.

speaker: Anna
text: And then you have a human mentor or coach who steps in for key decisions, emotional support, and accountability. How does that sound?

speaker: Sofia
text: That sounds ideal. Like, AI as the always available assistant, and human as the real anchor.

speaker: Anna
text: What would make you adopt it?

speaker: Sofia
text: Reliability of the human part. Like consistent mentor. Also clear boundaries.

speaker: Sofia
text: Like, when does AI handle and when does human handle. And transparency about privacy. Even though I laugh it off, I still want to know.

speaker: Sofia
text: Like, what happens to my data. If it is clear, I feel safer.

speaker: Anna
text: What would make you hesitate?

speaker: Sofia
text: If it feels like AI is replacing the human, like I cannot access a person when I need. Or if the human is too expensive or too unavailable. Also if the AI gives wrong assumptions and pushes me in a direction that does not fit me.

speaker: Anna
text: In a hybrid model, what tasks would you assign to AI, and what tasks to a human?

speaker: Sofia
text: AI: brainstorming options, structuring my thoughts, drafting messages, CV versions, interview prep questions, meeting prep checklist, stakeholder FAQ, like all that. Human: role strategy, reading company politics, helping me with confidence and presentation delivery, and accountability, like, did you actually do the thing.

speaker: Anna
text: When you say accountability, what would that look like?

speaker: Sofia
text: Like, if I say, I will talk to my manager next week, the human asks me, did you do it, what happened, what do you need now. AI can remind me, but it does not feel the same.

speaker: Anna
text: Why not?

speaker: Sofia
text: Because I do not want to disappoint a real person. AI does not care. 9) Closing

speaker: Anna
text: We are almost at the end. Is there anything important about trust or effectiveness in career support that we did not cover?

speaker: Sofia
text: Maybe one thing. I think I am optimistic about AI. I genuinely think we can solve many problems with AI, especially work problems.

speaker: Sofia
text: Like I love building agents. But for career, it is not only logic. It is identity.

speaker: Sofia
text: It is fear. And then I need a human to say, you are not crazy, you are allowed to want this. AI cannot really give that, even if it tries.

speaker: Anna
text: That is helpful. If you could design the perfect support for someone like you in Hamburg in e-commerce analytics, what would it look like?

speaker: Sofia
text: It would be like, AI gives me a structure and helps me prepare. And then a mentor who understands both data and business, and who is consistent, and who helps me practice presentations. Like maybe role play.

speaker: Sofia
text: And also understands I am not native in German, so gives me language tips without making me feel stupid.

speaker: Anna
text: Last question. If you think back to your stakeholder anxiety, what would be one small improvement that would change a lot for you?

speaker: Sofia
text: Practice with someone safe. Like rehearsing the narrative. And having a clear, simple recommendation.

speaker: Sofia
text: Like not trying to be perfect. If I can say, here is the insight, here is the impact, here is what we do, then I feel more in control.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you, Sofia. That was very insightful. After I stop recording, if you think of anything else you want to add, you can message me.

speaker: Sofia
text: Thank you. It was actually nice to talk. I feel

speaker: Anna
text: Hi Jonas. Thanks for joining. Before we start, do I have your permission to record?

speaker: Anna
text: Everything is anonymous, you can skip any question, and you can stop anytime.

speaker: Jonas
text: Yeah, um, yes. You can record. That is fine.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you. Just to double check, you are comfortable that this is for a master thesis study about trust and perceived effectiveness in AI-based versus human career coaching, and we keep it pseudonymized.

speaker: Jonas
text: Yes. As long as it is really anonymized, I am okay.

speaker: Anna
text: It will be. If any detail feels too identifying, tell me and we can rephrase. Also, are there any topics you would prefer not to discuss?

speaker: Jonas
text: Eehm. I think I do not want to go into very detailed security stuff. I had one incident and it made me kind of, yeah, paranoid.

speaker: Jonas
text: But I can talk about it in general.

speaker: Anna
text: Perfect. We will keep it high level. And just so you know, I will ask about both human support and AI tools, but you decide what you want to share.

speaker: Jonas
text: Okay.

speaker: Anna
text: Great. Let us start with a bit of context. 2)  Participant context and career situation

speaker: Anna
text: Where are you currently in your career, and what career decisions or questions are you facing, or recently faced?

speaker: Jonas
text: Okay. So I am Jonas, I am 28, and I work as a backend developer in a fintech scale-up here in Cologne. I studied Computer Science, Bachelor, also in NRW.

speaker: Jonas
text: I have, um, around five and a half years experience full-time, if you count internships it is more, but yeah. And the big question for me right now is, like, what is next. Because I am technically strong, that is my thing, and I like building systems, I like clean code, architecture, performance, reliability.

speaker: Jonas
text: But in our company there is this expectation that at some point you either go into a lead role or you kind of stay forever in the same level. And I do not want to stagnate.

speaker: Anna
text: When you say lead role, what does that mean in your company?

speaker: Jonas
text: That is already part of the problem. It is not super clear. We have titles like Senior Engineer, Staff Engineer, Team Lead, Engineering Manager.

speaker: Jonas
text: But the boundaries are fuzzy. Sometimes Team Lead is also writing a lot of code, sometimes it is basically a mini-manager who does Jira and meetings. And that is my fear.

speaker: Anna
text: What is the fear exactly?

speaker: Jonas
text: I fear becoming a manager with an office job, you know. Like, no creativity. Just meetings, status updates, people problems.

speaker: Jonas
text: And I do not mean that in a disrespectful way, but I enjoy craft. I enjoy building. If I imagine my week is all meetings and, like, spreadsheets and performance reviews, I feel, um, trapped.

speaker: Jonas
text: I need creativity. I like solving problems, designing things. Even debugging can feel creative, in a weird way.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you give me an example of when that fear shows up in daily work?

speaker: Jonas
text: Yes. Like, we have these planning meetings, refinement, retro, sync with product, sync with compliance, and then leadership sync. And sometimes I look at my Team Lead, and he is in meetings all day.

speaker: Jonas
text: And then he maybe reviews a PR at night. And he is stressed. And when I see that, I think, if this is the path, I do not want it.

speaker: Jonas
text: I do not want to be the person who cannot open an IDE during the day.

speaker: Anna
text: And what is the decision you faced in the last six to twelve months related to this?

speaker: Jonas
text: So in the last, um, maybe eight months, I had an offer from another company, not fintech, more like e-commerce infrastructure. They wanted me as Senior Backend Engineer with more ownership. And I seriously considered leaving.

speaker: Jonas
text: Because in our scale-up it is intense, and there is a lot of ambiguity. But then I decided to stay, because I negotiated internally to get more scope. Like, more ownership of a core service, and also a clearer path to some leadership that is more technical.

speaker: Jonas
text: That was the decision.

speaker: Anna
text: What made it difficult?

speaker: Jonas
text: Uncertainty. Like, what is better. In a scale-up, growth is fast, you learn a lot, but also you can burn out.

speaker: Jonas
text: And in fintech, the stakes are high. Production incidents are scary. Compliance, audits, security, it is not just, oh we deploy and see.

speaker: Jonas
text: It can be, if we mess up, there are real consequences. So the question was, do I stay in the intense environment but maybe grow faster, or do I go somewhere calmer. And also, I was not sure if I am actually good for leadership, or if I just like the idea of it.And there was money too, obviously.

speaker: Anna
text: What kind of support did you feel you needed at that time?

speaker: Jonas
text: I needed someone to help me see the options clearly and not just emotionally. Like, to reflect, okay, what do you want, what are your values, what is realistic. And also very practical, like negotiation.

speaker: Jonas
text: I am not naturally a negotiator. I can argue about architecture, but not about salary.

speaker: Anna
text: That is a common split. Before we go into support, can you describe your current work setup a bit. Team, domain, maybe tech stack.

speaker: Jonas
text: Sure. We are a fintech in payments. Like, we provide payment processing for small and mid businesses.

speaker: Jonas
text: There is also some lending products, but my area is payments and settlement. Backend stack is mostly Kotlin and Java, Spring Boot, some older services in Java 8, we are migrating slowly. We use Kafka for events, Postgres, Redis.

speaker: Jonas
text: Some things in AWS, but we are moving parts to a more controlled environment because of compliance. Observability is decent, we have Grafana, Prometheus, logging, alerts. And team setup, we have squads, like cross-functional with product and design.

speaker: Jonas
text: My squad is backend heavy because payments are complex.

speaker: Anna
text: And how is it in Cologne, work-wise. Hybrid, office, tech community?

speaker: Jonas
text: We are hybrid. Office in Cologne, but many people are remote, also Berlin, Munich, even some in Spain. Cologne tech scene is smaller than Berlin, but there are meetups.

speaker: Jonas
text: I go sometimes to a Kotlin meetup or general backend meetups. Fintech is there, also insurtech, but it is not like London. Still, you know people.

speaker: Jonas
text: Sometimes you meet someone and they are like, oh I know your company, you had that incident.

speaker: Anna
text: You mentioned production incidents. Is that part of the leadership pressure?

speaker: Jonas
text: Yes. Because when things break, someone needs to coordinate, decide, communicate. And that is leadership.

speaker: Jonas
text: And it is stressful. But also, that can be meaningful, like you feel responsible. So there is attraction and fear.

speaker: Jonas
text: 3) Career support in general

speaker: Anna
text: When you need career support, who or what do you usually turn to?

speaker: Jonas
text: First, friends in tech. Like, peers. We talk.

speaker: Jonas
text: Sometimes my girlfriend, but she is not in tech, so it is more emotional support. Then sometimes seniors at work, if I trust them. I do not really use official career coaching.

speaker: Jonas
text: I never went to a paid career coach. And I do not use AI for career stuff. For work, yes.

speaker: Jonas
text: For career, no.

speaker: Anna
text: What has actually helped, and what felt unhelpful or frustrating?

speaker: Jonas
text: Helpful is when someone understands the context. Like fintech, scale-up, German market, salary ranges, and also company politics. Unhelpful is generic advice like, just be confident, just apply, just network.

speaker: Jonas
text: Like, thanks. I know. But how.

speaker: Jonas
text: Also sometimes people project their own path onto you. Like, they became manager so they think you must. But maybe I do not.

speaker: Anna
text: So you prefer practical and context-aware support.

speaker: Jonas
text: Exactly. And also honesty. If someone tells me, yeah you would be a great manager, but they do not really know me, that feels like empty motivation.

speaker: Anna
text: Do you use any resources, like blogs, books, forums?

speaker: Jonas
text: Some. I read about engineering career ladders. Staff Engineer path, that stuff.

speaker: Jonas
text: There is a book, Staff Engineer, and also blogs from big tech. But then I think, okay, that is Google, not a German fintech. So it helps, but limited.

speaker: Anna
text: What about internal resources, like HR, performance frameworks?

speaker: Jonas
text: We have a career ladder doc, but it is, um, aspirational. It says, as Team Lead you do mentoring, planning, stakeholder management. As Staff Engineer you do cross-team architecture.

speaker: Jonas
text: But in practice, it is messy. So it gives vocabulary, but not a clear plan. 4) Human coaching: experience and trust

speaker: Anna
text: You mentioned that you had informal mentoring from a senior engineer. Can you tell me about that experience?

speaker: Jonas
text: Yes. So, in my previous team, we had a senior engineer, I will call him Markus, not real name. He was, like, very calm, very solid.

speaker: Jonas
text: He had been in fintech before, also in a bank. And we started talking because I was struggling with scope. I was doing a lot of on-call, a lot of incidents, and also feature work.

speaker: Jonas
text: And I felt I was drowning. So I asked him, how do you handle this, and how do you position yourself.

speaker: Anna
text: Was it formal mentoring, or just informal?

speaker: Jonas
text: Informal. Like, coffee chats. Sometimes after a retro, we would stay 15 minutes.

speaker: Jonas
text: Sometimes we booked 30 minutes. It was not like a program.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you describe one specific episode where this mentoring built trust for you?

speaker: Jonas
text: Yes. There was a moment when I got my performance review, and I was told, you are doing great technically, but you need to show more leadership. And I was like, what does that mean.

speaker: Jonas
text: And also, my salary increase was lower than I expected. So I was angry, but also unsure if I am being unrealistic. I talked to Markus, and he did not just hype me.

speaker: Jonas
text: He asked very concrete questions. Like, what exactly did they say, what did you deliver, what is the market rate, what is your leverage. And he also shared his own numbers, like his salary range, which is kind of sensitive.

speaker: Jonas
text: That was a big trust moment, because he took a risk for me.

speaker: Anna
text: What did he do, behavior-wise, that made you trust him?

speaker: Jonas
text: He was honest and not ego-driven. He did not try to be the hero. He also said, I do not know everything, but here is what I would do.

speaker: Jonas
text: And he listened. He did not jump to solutions. Also confidentiality.

speaker: Jonas
text: He explicitly said, this stays between us, I will not talk to your manager. That matters. Because in a scale-up, gossip travels fast.

speaker: Anna
text: What advice did he give you in that salary and scope situation?

speaker: Jonas
text: He gave me a plan. First, separate emotions from facts. Second, write down my impact.

speaker: Jonas
text: Like, not just I wrote code, but I reduced incident frequency, improved latency, mentored juniors, improved test coverage. Third, decide what I want. Do I want more money, or more scope, or both.

speaker: Jonas
text: Fourth, schedule a meeting with my manager, not in a reactive way, but prepared. And he helped me with wording. Like, how to say, I want to grow into a lead path, and for that I need ownership, and compensation aligned with market.

speaker: Anna
text: And what changed afterwards?

speaker: Jonas
text: I negotiated. I got a better raise, not huge, but meaningful. And more important, we adjusted my role scope.

speaker: Jonas
text: I became the owner of a service, settlement reconciliation, which is critical. And they also reduced my on-call rotation frequency. So I got more time for deep work.

speaker: Jonas
text: That was a tangible outcome. And mentally, I felt more confident. Like, I can advocate for myself.

speaker: Anna
text: So that mentoring felt effective.

speaker: Jonas
text: Yes, for that task, very effective.

speaker: Anna
text: Were there any moments where you trusted him but it was not effective?

speaker: Jonas
text: Yes. He is very technical, and sometimes when I ask about, like, people leadership or stakeholder stuff, his advice becomes generic. Like, just communicate more, build relationships.

speaker: Jonas
text: He is not bad, but it is not detailed. So I trust him as a person and as an engineer, but not everything he says is actionable for me.

speaker: Anna
text: That is interesting. So trust and effectiveness are related but not the same.

speaker: Jonas
text: Exactly. I can respect someone and still not get what I need.

speaker: Anna
text: What are, for you, the main drivers of trust for a human coach or mentor?

speaker: Jonas
text: Competence, but competence in my context. Like, understands fintech constraints, understands German work culture, understands scale-up chaos. Honesty.

speaker: Jonas
text: If they are unsure, they say it. Confidentiality. If I share career fears, I need it to stay safe.

speaker: Jonas
text: Consistent follow-up. Like, if we talk and they remember next time, that shows they care. And also, not ego-driven.

speaker: Jonas
text: Some seniors love to talk and show how smart they are. That kills trust for me.

speaker: Anna
text: And what makes someone untrustworthy?

speaker: Jonas
text: If they are political. If they use mentoring to recruit you to their agenda. Or if they promise things.

speaker: Jonas
text: Like, do this and you will get promoted. Nobody can promise that. Or if they share other people’s private info, because then I think they will share mine too.

speaker: Anna
text: How did you feel during those mentoring conversations, emotionally?

speaker: Jonas
text: Safer. Like, less alone. In German I would say, erleichtert.

speaker: Jonas
text: Because you realize, okay, it is not just me. Also, it gave structure. In a scale-up, everything is urgent.

speaker: Jonas
text: Mentoring gave me a step back. 5) AI tools: experience and trust

speaker: Anna
text: Now shifting to AI tools. What is your experience with AI tools, and how do you use them?

speaker: Jonas
text: I use AI a lot for coding. Like, daily. Not because I blindly trust it, but because it speeds things up.

speaker: Jonas
text: I use it for unit tests, integration test scaffolding, refactoring suggestions, generating boilerplate, sometimes explaining an unfamiliar library. Also for code review, like, can you spot potential issues. I also use it to draft documentation.

speaker: Anna
text: Which kinds of tools, in general terms? Like integrated in IDE or web-based?

speaker: Jonas
text: Both. In IDE, like a coding assistant. Also sometimes a chat interface.

speaker: Jonas
text: But I am careful. For work code, I do not paste sensitive stuff. We have policies.

speaker: Jonas
text: And personally, because of my privacy thing, I try to limit what I share.

speaker: Anna
text: We will get to privacy. Before that, can you give me a moment where AI really helped you on a technical task?

speaker: Jonas
text: Yes. Recently we had a performance issue in a Kafka consumer. Under load, we had spikes, and the consumer lag went crazy.

speaker: Jonas
text: I suspected some blocking call. I asked the AI to help me reason about a certain pattern in Kotlin coroutines, like where blocking might happen if you mix coroutine context with a legacy library. It suggested a few things, and one of them was correct: we had a hidden blocking call in a mapping function that did synchronous network calls.

speaker: Jonas
text: I had overlooked it. So it helped me look in the right place. Then I fixed it by moving that call to an async pipeline and adding caching.

speaker: Jonas
text: That reduced lag significantly.

speaker: Anna
text: So it was not just code generation, but also diagnosis.

speaker: Jonas
text: Exactly. Like a second brain, but not always right.

speaker: Anna
text: And can you share a moment when AI failed or was risky?

speaker: Jonas
text: Many. Hahaha. One example: I asked for a refactor of a piece of code that handles money amounts, like decimals, currency.

speaker: Jonas
text: It suggested using float. And I was like, no. That is dangerous.

speaker: Jonas
text: Another time it hallucinated an API that does not exist. Like, it confidently said, use this method, and it was fake. That is the problem.

speaker: Jonas
text: It can look correct but be wrong. In fintech, that is scary. Also security.

speaker: Jonas
text: It sometimes suggests patterns that are not safe, like logging too much, or ignoring validation.

speaker: Anna
text: How do you handle that risk?

speaker: Jonas
text: Verification. I treat it like a junior developer with confidence. I check documentation.

speaker: Jonas
text: I run tests. I reason myself. It is helpful for speed, but I do not outsource judgment.

speaker: Anna
text: How would you describe your trust in AI tools in technical contexts?

speaker: Jonas
text: Conditional. I trust it for ideas, for drafts, for boilerplate. I do not trust it for correctness without verification.

speaker: Jonas
text: And I definitely do not trust it for sensitive data.

speaker: Anna
text: You said you avoid using AI for career topics. Why?

speaker: Jonas
text: Two reasons. One is privacy. Career topics are personal.

speaker: Jonas
text: The second is, I have this feeling it reinforces what you already believe. Like confirmation bias. If I ask, should I become a team lead, it will give me a nice answer that fits my question framing.

speaker: Jonas
text: And if I am in a mood, I might just select the parts that comfort me. It is like a mirror. And I do not want that.

speaker: Jonas
text: I want friction, sometimes. I want someone to challenge me.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you give a concrete example where you noticed that effect?

speaker: Jonas
text: Yes. I tried once. Just once.

speaker: Jonas
text: I asked something like, I am afraid management will kill my creativity, how can I grow without becoming a manager. And it gave me a very well-written answer, like, you can become Staff Engineer, you can mentor, you can do architecture. And it felt good.

speaker: Jonas
text: But then I realized, it just validated my fear. It did not ask, maybe your picture of management is wrong, maybe there is creative leadership. It could have, but it did not.

speaker: Jonas
text: And I did not push it. I just took the comforting answer. That is exactly the risk.

speaker: Jonas
text: It is too agreeable if you do not structure it.

speaker: Anna
text: So it can be soothing, but maybe not corrective.

speaker: Jonas
text: Yes. And for career decisions, I need something that reduces self-delusion, not increases it.

speaker: Anna
text: That is a strong statement. Let us talk about the privacy concern you mentioned earlier. You said you had a past incident where your email was compromised.

speaker: Jonas
text: Yes.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you describe it at a high level, what happened and how it changed your behavior?

speaker: Jonas
text: High level. So, a few years ago, I noticed weird login notifications. Like, password reset emails I did not request.

speaker: Jonas
text: Then I realized my email account had been accessed. And because email is the key to everything, they tried to reset other accounts too. Some passwords were reused, which is stupid, I know, and so some accounts were accessed.

speaker: Jonas
text: It was not catastrophic, but it was invasive. I felt, um, violated. Like, someone is in your digital home.

speaker: Anna
text: That sounds intense. What did you do afterwards?

speaker: Jonas
text: I changed everything. Password manager, unique passwords, 2FA everywhere, also a hardware key for important accounts. I stopped trusting cloud services blindly.

speaker: Jonas
text: I started thinking in threat models, like, what happens if this is leaked. And I became very cautious about sharing personal info in tools that store data. That includes AI tools.

speaker: Jonas
text: Because I do not fully know where the prompts go, who can access, how long it is stored. Even if they say it is private, I am cautious.

speaker: Anna
text: So your trust drivers for AI include data boundaries.

speaker: Jonas
text: Yes. If an AI tool is local, like running on my machine, I feel more trust. If it is cloud, I assume it is stored somewhere.

speaker: Jonas
text: Also, verifiability. Like, can I see sources, can I see reasoning. And clear policies.

speaker: Anna
text: Do you use any local AI tools?

speaker: Jonas
text: A bit. For experimenting. Not super powerful compared to cloud, but for some tasks, yes.

speaker: Jonas
text: And for work, we have approved tools, but still, I am cautious. 6)  Human vs AI comparison via specific tasks

speaker: Anna
text: Now I want to compare human and AI via specific career-related tasks. I will name a task, and you tell me which you would prefer, and why. Does that work?

speaker: Jonas
text: Yes.

speaker: Anna
text: Task one is clarifying options. Like, you are unsure whether to pursue Staff Engineer, Team Lead, or change company. Who would you go to?

speaker: Jonas
text: Human. Because I need questions back. I need someone to explore my assumptions.

speaker: Jonas
text: AI can list options, but I can also Google that. Human can say, okay, but what do you actually want, and why. And they can notice contradictions.

speaker: Anna
text: What if the human does not know fintech?

speaker: Jonas
text: Then less useful. Context matters. But still, a good human can facilitate reflection.

speaker: Anna
text: Task two: planning concrete next steps for a lead path, like what skills, what projects, what timeline.

speaker: Jonas
text: This is mixed. AI could help structure a plan, like a checklist. But I would want a human to validate it in my company context.

speaker: Jonas
text: Because in a scale-up, formal checklists are sometimes fake. So I would use AI for a draft, but then human for reality check.

speaker: Anna
text: Task three: negotiating salary and role scope.

speaker: Jonas
text: Human, definitely. Because negotiation is social. I need to practice, role-play, get feedback on tone.

speaker: Jonas
text: Also, a human can share market knowledge. AI can give generic tips, but it cannot tell me what my manager is likely to react to.

speaker: Anna
text: Task four: CV rewriting or LinkedIn polishing.

speaker: Jonas
text: AI, actually. For that, it is fine. Because it is not deeply personal, and it is pattern-based.

speaker: Jonas
text: But I would still not paste everything. I would anonymize. AI can generate bullet points and wording.

speaker: Jonas
text: Human can also help, but AI is faster.

speaker: Anna
text: Task five: making a high-stakes decision when you are emotionally stressed, like you are burnt out and thinking of quitting.

speaker: Jonas
text: Human. Because I need emotional containment. AI cannot really do that.

speaker: Jonas
text: It can write empathetic text, but I do not feel it. And I do not want to share that level of vulnerability with a system I do not trust.

speaker: Anna
text: What about task six: technical career growth, like becoming a better engineer, learning architecture.

speaker: Jonas
text: Here AI is effective. Like, for technical learning, it is great. But again, verify.

speaker: Jonas
text: It can explain patterns, show examples. For that, I trust it more.

speaker: Anna
text: So there is a split between technical and personal.

speaker: Jonas
text: Yes. For me, AI is a tool for technical tasks. For career identity, leadership, values, I prefer human.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you think of a situation where AI was effective for you but you still did not fully trust it?

speaker: Jonas
text: Yes. Like the performance debugging I mentioned. It helped.

speaker: Jonas
text: It was effective. But I still do not trust it as a system with my sensitive info. So effectiveness in one domain does not automatically create trust in another.

speaker: Anna
text: And the opposite, trusted but not effective, you mentioned with Markus and generic advice.

speaker: Jonas
text: Exactly. I trust Markus. But he cannot always give me the detailed leadership model I need.

speaker: Jonas
text: 7) Trust–effectiveness link

speaker: Anna
text: Now I want to explore the link between trust and effectiveness in your experience. When you think about human mentoring, how does trust affect whether it is effective?

speaker: Jonas
text: Trust is like the entry ticket. If I do not trust the person, I will not share the real thing. I will talk about safe topics, like how to improve my CV, but not the deeper fears.

speaker: Jonas
text: And without the deeper stuff, advice is shallow. So trust enables depth. And depth is often where effectiveness comes from.

speaker: Anna
text: What does depth mean for you in this context?

speaker: Jonas
text: Depth is like, why do I fear management. Is it because I saw a bad example. Is it because I fear losing identity.

speaker: Jonas
text: Is it because I do not want responsibility. These are uncomfortable. If I trust the mentor, I can say, I am scared.

speaker: Jonas
text: If I do not trust, I will say, I am considering career options, which is a polite lie.

speaker: Anna
text: And with AI, how does trust connect to effectiveness?

speaker: Jonas
text: Different. With AI, trust is more about, can I rely on output and can I control my data. For technical tasks, I can get effectiveness without emotional trust, because I can verify.

speaker: Jonas
text: For career tasks, if I do not trust privacy, I will not even use it. So it cannot be effective because it is not used. Or I will sanitize so much that it becomes generic, and then it is not effective anyway.

speaker: Anna
text: So trust can be a prerequisite for use.

speaker: Jonas
text: Yes. Especially in personal domains.

speaker: Anna
text: What are your indicators that support was effective, whether human or AI?

speaker: Jonas
text: Clarity. Like, I know what I want to do next. Concrete next steps.

speaker: Jonas
text: Like, I will take ownership of project X, I will mentor someone, I will talk to my manager with these points. Also confidence. Not fake confidence, but grounded.

speaker: Jonas
text: And results, like my negotiation outcome. Also skill growth, like I learn how to communicate better.

speaker: Anna
text: Do you think trust can ever be too high, like overtrust, leading to bad outcomes?

speaker: Jonas
text: Yes. If you trust a mentor too much, you can take their path as yours. Especially if they are charismatic.

speaker: Jonas
text: That is risky. And with AI, overtrust is super risky because it can hallucinate. So I think appropriate trust is key, not just more trust.

speaker: Anna
text: Interesting. In your case, you described skepticism and verification.

speaker: Jonas
text: Yes. I am not a trusting person with systems. With humans, I can trust, but it takes time.

speaker: Anna
text: If you imagine an ideal support for your team lead path question, what would it look like?

speaker: Jonas
text: It would be someone who has seen different models. Like technical lead, staff engineer, engineering manager. And they can describe daily life, not just title.

speaker: Jonas
text: Like, what do you do on a Tuesday. How much code. How much people.

speaker: Jonas
text: And they can help me experiment, like take a temporary leadership responsibility without fully committing. And they can challenge my assumptions about creativity. 8) Preferences and hybrid model reaction (plus micro-poll ratings)

speaker: Anna
text: Now I will ask you for some quick ratings, 0 to 10. It is not a test, just to structure the conversation. And I will ask you to explain.

speaker: Anna
text: Is that okay?

speaker: Jonas
text: Yes.

speaker: Anna
text: First, current trust in human coaches or mentors for career topics, 0 to 10.

speaker: Jonas
text: I would say, um, 7.

speaker: Anna
text: Why 7, not higher or lower?

speaker: Jonas
text: Because with the right person, I trust quite a lot. Like Markus, I would say 8 or 9. But in general, I do not automatically trust a coach.

speaker: Jonas
text: There is a whole market of coaches, and I do not know their incentives. And also, some people are just not good. So overall, 7.

speaker: Anna
text: Second, current trust in AI tools, 0 to 10.

speaker: Jonas
text: Overall trust, like as a system, maybe 4.

speaker: Anna
text: What drives the 4?

speaker: Jonas
text: Privacy concerns and hallucinations. Also, I do not know boundaries. For coding assistance, I trust specific outputs after checking, but the system trust is low.

speaker: Anna
text: Third, perceived effectiveness of human coaching or mentoring for your situation, 0 to 10.

speaker: Jonas
text: For my situation, maybe 6.

speaker: Anna
text: Why 6?

speaker: Jonas
text: Because it depends on finding the right person. When it works, it is very effective, like my negotiation. But it is not always available.

speaker: Jonas
text: People are busy. And it can be generic. So I cannot assume it will solve my team lead question.

speaker: Jonas
text: But it can help.

speaker: Anna
text: Fourth, perceived effectiveness of AI tools for your situation, 0 to 10.

speaker: Jonas
text: For career situation, like leadership path, maybe 3. For technical growth, it is like 8. But you ask for my situation career-wise, so 3.

speaker: Anna
text: What makes it 3, not zero?

speaker: Jonas
text: Because it can still help with structured planning, CV, phrasing, brainstorming lists. But I avoid it mostly, so the impact is limited.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you. Now, I want to describe a hypothetical hybrid model. Imagine a career support platform where AI helps you prepare, like clarifying goals, drafting questions, structuring options, and then you have sessions with a human mentor for deeper discussion and decisions.

speaker: Anna
text: After the session, AI helps with follow-up plans and reminders. What is your reaction?

speaker: Jonas
text: That sounds, um, actually reasonable. Because AI as preparation and follow-up is less risky. The human part is where trust and emotional depth happens.

speaker: Jonas
text: But the key is privacy and boundaries. Like, what data does the AI see. If it sees my full story, I am not comfortable.

speaker: Jonas
text: If I can control what I input, maybe.

speaker: Anna
text: What would you need to trust such a hybrid model?

speaker: Jonas
text: Clear data boundaries. Like, ideally, AI runs locally or you have strong guarantees. And transparency.

speaker: Jonas
text: Also, I would want the human to be independent, not like sales. And I would want to choose what the AI stores. Like, delete button.

speaker: Jonas
text: And explainability, at least some. Like, why it suggests something.

speaker: Anna
text: And what would make it feel effective?

speaker: Jonas
text: If the human mentor is good and context-aware, and the AI helps reduce admin work. Like, I do not want to spend my mentor time writing lists. I want to talk.

speaker: Jonas
text: If AI can organize my thoughts, that is effective. Also, if it helps me do micro-experiments, like tasks to try leadership in small steps.

speaker: Anna
text: Do you have any concerns about a hybrid model?

speaker: Jonas
text: Yes. That it becomes worse of both. Like, AI collects data, human is limited.

speaker: Jonas
text: Or the human relies on AI too much and stops thinking. Or I get a generic plan again. Also, there is a risk of false confidence.

speaker: Jonas
text: If the AI writes a beautiful plan, I might think it is reality, but in a scale-up, reality changes weekly.

speaker: Anna
text: So you want adaptability.

speaker: Jonas
text: Yes. And also, I want creativity preserved. Like, leadership that still allows building things.

speaker: Jonas
text: If the hybrid model pushes me toward a pure manager role, I would reject it.

speaker: Anna
text: How would you define good leadership, in practice, that would still feel creative?

speaker: Jonas
text: Good question.I think good leadership in engineering can be creative if it is about shaping systems and people growth. Like, you design the environment. You mentor.

speaker: Jonas
text: You make decisions under uncertainty. That can be creative. But the fear is that it becomes bureaucracy, like just managing Jira tickets.

speaker: Jonas
text: So good leadership is not just meetings, but direction. Technical direction and also culture.

speaker: Anna
text: In your company, what does leadership look like right now?

speaker: Jonas
text: It is mixed. We have some leads who are like technical leaders. They still code, they do architecture, they mentor, they push quality.

speaker: Jonas
text: And we have some who are, um, more like project managers. They coordinate, but they do not have technical depth. In a fintech, that can be dangerous, because decisions have security implications.

speaker: Jonas
text: So the good ones, they combine technical competence with communication.

speaker: Anna
text: Do you see a path to become that kind of lead?

speaker: Jonas
text: Maybe. But it is not clearly supported. That is why I am thinking a lot.

speaker: Jonas
text: Like, do I push internally to become Staff Engineer, which is more technical leadership, or do I try Team Lead but set boundaries, like I still code. Or do I leave to a company with a better defined ladder.

speaker: Anna
text: If you could ask one question to an ideal mentor, what would it be?

speaker: Jonas
text: I would ask, what does your week look like and do you still feel creative. And what did you sacrifice. Because I think every path has sacrifice.

speaker: Anna
text: That is very honest. Earlier you said you want friction, someone to challenge you. Do you think AI could be designed to challenge you instead of confirming?

speaker: Jonas
text: In theory, yes. Like, if it is instructed to argue both sides, or to ask hard questions. But I am not sure I would believe it.

speaker: Jonas
text: Because it is still a system. With a human, the challenge feels more real. Like, they see you and they push you.

speaker: Jonas
text: AI pushing me feels like text.

speaker: Anna
text: So the relational element matters.

speaker: Jonas
text: Yes. And accountability. If I tell Markus, I will do this, next time he asks.

speaker: Jonas
text: AI can remind me, but it is not the same social pressure.

speaker: Anna
text: Do you ever feel judged by humans, and does that reduce trust?

speaker: Jonas
text: Yes. That is another thing. If a mentor is judgemental, I shut down.

speaker: Jonas
text: Like, if they say, why are you afraid, just do it. Then trust drops. Markus was not like that.

speaker: Jonas
text: He was calm.

speaker: Anna
text: And with AI, do you feel judged?

speaker: Jonas
text: No, but I feel observed. Hahaha. Like, the system is watching.

speaker: Jonas
text: Not emotionally, but data-wise.

speaker: Anna
text: That is a good distinction.

speaker: Jonas
text: Yeah. 9) Closing

speaker: Anna
text: We are near the end. Is there anything you expected me to ask but I did not?

speaker: Jonas
text: Maybe, um, about how I choose tools. Like, I am not anti-AI. I like it for work.

speaker: Jonas
text: But for career, I want to keep it human. At least for now. And I think many engineers are like that.

speaker: Jonas
text: We use AI as productivity, but not for life decisions.

speaker: Anna
text: That is very helpful. If you had one recommendation for someone building career AI tools, what would it be?

speaker: Jonas
text: Respect privacy by design. Not as marketing. And make it less agreeable.

speaker: Jonas
text: Make it challenge you, like a good mentor. And be honest about limitations. If it is uncertain, say it.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you. Last check, are you still comfortable with the recording and use for anonymized research?

speaker: Jonas
text: Yes.

speaker: Anna
text: Great. Thanks Jonas. I will stop the recording now.

speaker: Jonas
text: Okay. Bye.

speaker: Anna
text: Bye.

speaker: Anna
text: Hi Alina, can you hear me well?

speaker: Alina
text: Yes, hi Anna. I can hear you. Can you hear me?

speaker: Anna
text: Yes, perfectly. Thanks for joining. Before we start, I want to confirm consent.

speaker: Anna
text: Do I have your permission to record this interview? The recording is only for transcription, everything will be anonymised, and you can skip any question.

speaker: Alina
text: Yes, you can record. That is okay.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you. And just to check, are there any topics you would prefer not to discuss today?

speaker: Alina
text: Eehm. Maybe, like, very specific details about my employer, like the name or internal processes. But in general, we can talk about the work.

speaker: Anna
text: Absolutely. We will keep it at a general level, and if something feels too specific, just say stop or we can rephrase. Also, if I ask something and you are not comfortable, you can pass.

speaker: Alina
text: Okay, yes.

speaker: Anna
text: Great. One more thing, because we will talk about AI tools and coaching, I might ask you to give quick ratings from 0 to 10 at some point. It is not a test, just a way to structure the discussion.

speaker: Alina
text: Okay. Sounds fine.

speaker: Anna
text: Perfect. Then we can start. Can you briefly introduce yourself, just in terms of your current situation?

speaker: Alina
text: Sure. 2) Participant context and career situation

speaker: Anna
text: Where are you currently in your career, and what career decisions or questions are you facing right now, or recently faced?

speaker: Alina
text: Um, so I am 29, I live in Frankfurt, I moved here from Ukraine four and a half years ago. I work in a bank, in a compliance team. And my situation is, like, stable.

speaker: Alina
text: I have a stable contract, stable life, I have my apartment, I have friends here. But I feel, eehm, bored. Like, it is not crisis, it is not burnout.

speaker: Alina
text: It is more like, I wake up and I know exactly what I will do. And it is fine, but it is not, how to say, meaningful. So my career question is how to pivot from compliance into ESG or sustainability reporting, maybe ESG risk, something like that.

speaker: Alina
text: I am trying to understand how realistic it is, and what steps actually make sense in Germany.

speaker: Anna
text: When you say bored, what does that look like in your day-to-day? Like, what is missing?

speaker: Alina
text: It is difficult because the job is important, like compliance is important, but it feels very, um, procedural. Like, checklists, documentation, approvals. A lot of writing memos, following internal policies, and being very careful.

speaker: Alina
text: And I like careful. I studied law originally, so I am okay with details. But I feel disconnected from impact.

speaker: Alina
text: It is more about preventing risk for the bank, which is logical, but it is not like building something or contributing to, I do not know, society. It is a bit dramatic, but you asked what is missing. It is meaning and growth.

speaker: Alina
text: Growth also because compliance can be a bit, how to say, narrow. You can become senior, you can become team lead, but the tasks stay similar.

speaker: Anna
text: What is your current role, like broadly? What do you actually do in the compliance team?

speaker: Alina
text: I work in a team that supports business lines, like corporate clients and sometimes investment products, but not trading. We do compliance advisory. So we review certain cases, we answer questions from stakeholders, we check if communications are okay, we support audits, we coordinate with risk and legal.

speaker: Alina
text: A big part is documentation. Like, everything must be documented, why we approved something, what was the basis. There are internal controls, four-eyes principle, sometimes escalations.

speaker: Alina
text: And there is always the idea that regulators can ask later. So you need to be able to show the trail.

speaker: Anna
text: What is the biggest career decision you made in the last 6 to 12 months?

speaker: Alina
text: Hahaha. The biggest one is that I decided to stay in my bank for now instead of switching to another bank or consulting. Because I had this moment where I thought, okay, maybe the boredom is because I am in the wrong company, not the wrong field.

speaker: Alina
text: So I interviewed a bit, like not a lot, but I talked to recruiters and did two interviews for a compliance role in another institution. And then I realised it is the same, just different logo. So I decided, okay, if I want change, it needs to be a direction change, not just a company change.

speaker: Anna
text: What made that decision difficult?

speaker: Alina
text: Eehm, security. Germany is expensive, Frankfurt also. And I am not German, so stability matters.

speaker: Alina
text: Also my residency situation is stable now, but I still think about it. Like, I have a residence permit tied to employment. I am on a skilled worker path, and I can apply for permanent residency soon, but I need stable employment and language level.

speaker: Alina
text: So part of the decision is, do not do something too risky until I have that. And also the bank environment, it is very conservative. If you move around too much, people ask questions, like, why?

speaker: Alina
text: And I am not sure if this is in my head, but yeah.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you share a bit more about your move to Germany and the residency context, as much as you feel comfortable?

speaker: Alina
text: Sure. I moved in 2021. It was, eehm, partly personal, partly professional.

speaker: Alina
text: I had a partner then, in Germany. It did not work out long term, but the move was already done. Also I wanted a more international career, and in Ukraine I studied law, but the job market in law is, how to say, very local.

speaker: Alina
text: Germany felt like a place where I could restart. I first came with a job seeker plan, but then I got an offer in a financial services company, not my current bank. And later I moved to the bank, because Frankfurt has a lot of these roles and I wanted to be closer to regulation and more structured career path.

speaker: Anna
text: What is your German level now?

speaker: Alina
text: Officially B2, but in reality, like, I can work in English in my team. Our internal documents are German, but many meetings are English. However, to move internally, sometimes they want German.

speaker: Alina
text: And in compliance, German is important because you write policies, you communicate with local stakeholders. So I use German daily, but I still feel insecure. Like, I can do it, but it costs energy.

speaker: Anna
text: And what triggered your interest in ESG or sustainability reporting specifically?

speaker: Alina
text: There was one moment, actually. We had an internal project about new regulatory expectations, and one of the topics was ESG risk integration. Not the deep technical part, but the fact that regulators expect banks to consider climate risk, transition risk, reputational risk.

speaker: Alina
text: And there was a presentation, and I remember thinking, finally, something that connects regulation with real world outcomes. Like, if a bank finances something, it matters. And also, I started reading more about EU regulation, like CSRD, EU taxonomy, SFDR.

speaker: Alina
text: And it felt like a field that is new enough that I can enter, but still serious, still compliance-adjacent. It is not like I want to become, I do not know, a marketing person. It is still structured, but with more meaning.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you tell me about one specific episode at work where you felt bored or disconnected?

speaker: Alina
text: Yes. It was, um, a case where we had to review a client communication. It was a standard letter, like informing about fee changes.

speaker: Alina
text: And we went back and forth for days because of wording. Like, one sentence about risks had to be in a specific order, and we had to ensure the German was perfect. And I get why.

speaker: Alina
text: But after the third iteration, I thought, this is my life? And it was not intellectually challenging, it was just cautious. And then I compared it with the ESG topics where there are open questions, like how to interpret requirements, how to build reporting processes, how to coordinate data across departments.

speaker: Alina
text: That felt more like building.

speaker: Anna
text: What have you tried already to move toward ESG or sustainability reporting?

speaker: Alina
text: A few things. I did a short online course, like a certificate, not university, more like a professional training about CSRD basics and sustainability reporting. I also joined a couple of webinars from Big4, because they do a lot in this area.

speaker: Alina
text: And I started networking a bit on LinkedIn, like following ESG professionals, reading posts, and I had two informational calls with people. One was in sustainability consulting, one was in a bank ESG risk function. And internally, I asked HR about internal mobility, like what options exist.

speaker: Alina
text: But the internal move is tricky because ESG roles are limited and sometimes they prefer people already in risk management, or they want German C1, or they want someone who already worked with data and reporting.

speaker: Anna
text: What feels like the biggest friction right now in the pivot?

speaker: Alina
text: Credibility. Like, how do I translate my compliance skills into ESG narrative? I can say I know regulation, I can work with stakeholders, I can document.

speaker: Alina
text: But ESG reporting also needs understanding of metrics, data, frameworks. And I do not have real project examples yet. So I feel like, eehm, I am in this loop where you need experience to get experience.

speaker: Alina
text: And also, politics. In the bank, if you want to move, your manager has to support you. And my manager is nice, but of course, they do not want to lose a trained person.

speaker: Alina
text: So I feel I need to be careful how I communicate.

speaker: Anna
text: What constraints do you have outside of work? Like personal constraints that affect your options.

speaker: Alina
text: I cannot take a big pay cut. I support my family sometimes. Not like full support, but I help.

speaker: Alina
text: Also, I do not want to move to another city now. Frankfurt is my base, I built my life. And I need time for German.

speaker: Alina
text: Also, I am a bit tired of instability. When I moved, it was a lot of change. Now I want growth, but not chaos.

speaker: Alina
text: I mean, no wait, let me rephrase. I want change, but in a controlled way. 3) Career support in general

speaker: Anna
text: When you need career support, who or what do you usually turn to?

speaker: Alina
text: Mostly friends. I have a friend who is also in financial services, and we talk. I also talk to my sister, but she is not in Germany, so she supports emotionally.

speaker: Alina
text: And online resources, like reading, LinkedIn. And then AI tools, I use them for drafting and understanding texts. But for career decisions, I still prefer humans.

speaker: Alina
text: Because there is, um, fear. Like, if I say wrong thing, or if I make wrong move, it affects my residency, my stability. So I want a human reflection.

speaker: Anna
text: What has actually helped, and what felt unhelpful?

speaker: Alina
text: Helpful is when someone challenges me a bit, but realistically. Like, my friend says, okay, you say you want ESG, but what exactly? In a bank it can be different.

speaker: Alina
text: And she asked me to list roles: ESG compliance, sustainability reporting, ESG risk. That helped. Unhelpful is generic motivation, like follow your passion.

speaker: Alina
text: Because passion does not pay rent. Also, some online advice is very US-centric, like just network and you will get a job. In Germany, networking is helpful but it is not magic.

speaker: Alina
text: And also, I noticed that many career coaches speak very generally, they do not understand regulated environments.

speaker: Anna
text: What kind of support did you feel you needed most in the last months?

speaker: Alina
text: A roadmap. Like, steps. Not only emotional reassurance.

speaker: Alina
text: Steps like, what skills are missing, how to get them, which internal stakeholders to speak to, how to present my story. And also confidence. Because I doubt if I am, how to say, allowed to pivot.

speaker: Alina
text: Like, I am an immigrant, I already changed field once, from law to compliance. And now I want another change. So I need both structure and emotional grounding.

speaker: Alina
text: 4) Human coaching: experience and trust

speaker: Anna
text: You mentioned you tried a coach once. Can you tell me about that experience? How did you find the coach?

speaker: Alina
