text: Yes. It was last year, like maybe spring. I found her through a recommendation from a friend in Frankfurt.

speaker: Alina
text: She is a career coach, but also she had worked in HR in a financial institution before. That sounded good. We had, I think, three sessions.

speaker: Alina
text: First was like getting to know me, second and third were more about my situation.

speaker: Anna
text: What made you decide to try coaching at that point?

speaker: Alina
text: I was feeling stuck. Like, I was complaining to friends, and I realised they cannot solve it. And I was also feeling anxious, like, is my boredom ungrateful?

speaker: Alina
text: Because the job is stable. So I wanted a neutral person. Also, in Ukraine, coaching is becoming popular, and I thought, okay, maybe it can help.

speaker: Anna
text: What were the sessions like, practically? Like Zoom, in person, what did you do?

speaker: Alina
text: It was Zoom. She sent me a short questionnaire before, like values, goals. In the session, she asked many questions.

speaker: Alina
text: It was very, um, reflective. Like, what do you want, what is your ideal day, what energises you. She was warm.

speaker: Alina
text: She listened. She repeated back things. There was a lot of space for emotions.

speaker: Alina
text: I cried once. Not like dramatic, but I was overwhelmed.

speaker: Anna
text: What created trust for you in that coaching experience?

speaker: Alina
text: Confidentiality. She explained that everything stays between us, and she had a professional vibe. Like, she did not push me to buy ten sessions.

speaker: Alina
text: She was also empathetic, but not pity. She validated that boredom can be a sign that you outgrow a role. Also, she understood the bank culture a bit.

speaker: Alina
text: Not deeply, but enough to know that compliance is sensitive and that internal moves are political. That made me feel she is not naive.

speaker: Anna
text: Were there any moments where you felt, okay, I can really open up?

speaker: Alina
text: Yes. In the second session, I told her about my fear of being seen as unstable. Like, in Germany, I sometimes feel I have to be perfect.

speaker: Alina
text: Like, be grateful, be stable, do not complain. And she said something like, it is okay to want more, and it does not mean you are ungrateful. And she also asked about my identity, like, who are you beyond your job.

speaker: Alina
text: That was emotional, but it felt safe.

speaker: Anna
text: And what did you hope to get from coaching, specifically?

speaker: Alina
text: Action. Like, I wanted to leave with a plan. Maybe not full plan, but at least clear steps.

speaker: Alina
text: Like, which roles to target, how to position myself, what courses matter, how to approach internal stakeholders. I expected some of that because she had HR background.

speaker: Anna
text: Did you get that?

speaker: Alina
text: Not really.I got emotional relief. I felt lighter. I felt less alone.

speaker: Alina
text: And I had some clarity on values, like I care about impact and learning. But when it came to market steps, it was vague. She said, explore, talk to people, update your LinkedIn.

speaker: Alina
text: But I was like, okay, how? Who? Where?

speaker: Alina
text: What is a realistic ESG entry role? Should I do a certificate like GRI? Should I learn data?

speaker: Alina
text: Should I go to consulting? She did not have concrete answers. And she also did not give frameworks, like a networking map.

speaker: Alina
text: It was more, trust the process.

speaker: Anna
text: So in your experience, it was trusted but not effective in the way you needed?

speaker: Alina
text: Yes, exactly. I trusted her as a person. I felt safe.

speaker: Alina
text: But effectiveness, for my situation, was limited. Because my problem is partly emotional, but also very practical, like German job market, regulatory field, internal politics.

speaker: Anna
text: What would have made it more effective?

speaker: Alina
text: Industry-specific competence. Like, if she knew ESG roles in banks, or at least knew how to research them with me. Also structure.

speaker: Alina
text: Like, give me homework that is not only journaling, but tasks like identify ten target roles, identify five people to talk to, draft a pivot story, revise CV for ESG, do interview practice. And also maybe accountability, like check progress.

speaker: Anna
text: Was there anything that reduced trust in that coaching, even if you felt safe overall?

speaker: Alina
text: Eehm, not reduced trust, but I noticed that sometimes she used very confident statements without evidence, like, you will find something if you follow your values. And I was like, maybe, but the market is hard. So I started to separate emotional truth from market truth.

speaker: Alina
text: But I did not think she had bad intentions.

speaker: Anna
text: If you think about trust drivers for a human coach in general, what are the main ones for you?

speaker: Alina
text: Confidentiality, like clear boundaries. Empathy, but professional. Competence in my context, like understanding regulated environments, immigration context, German market.

speaker: Alina
text: Structure, like a process, not random talking. And feeling seen, like the coach remembers details and connects patterns. Also realism.

speaker: Alina
text: Like, do not just motivate me, but tell me what is hard and how to approach it.

speaker: Anna
text: And what are your indicators that human coaching is effective?

speaker: Alina
text: Clarity and steps. Like, I leave with decisions. Also, real market signals, like interviews or feedback from people in the field.

speaker: Alina
text: And confidence, but grounded confidence, not just hype. Also reduced anxiety, because I feel in control. 5) AI tools: experience and trust

speaker: Anna
text: You also mentioned you use AI tools. Can you tell me what you use them for and how often?

speaker: Alina
text: I use AI almost daily, but not always. Mostly for drafting German texts. Like emails to stakeholders, summaries, sometimes policy wording, but I am careful.

speaker: Alina
text: Also for understanding regulations, like if I read a long document and I need to understand the structure, definitions, or differences between terms. I use it like a study buddy.

speaker: Anna
text: Which kind of tool is it? Like a chatbot interface?

speaker: Alina
text: Yes, like a conversational tool. I do not want to say the brand, but it is basically a chatbot. Sometimes I also use internal tools, like translation software, but the AI chat is the main one.

speaker: Anna
text: What makes you cautious, you mentioned confidentiality?

speaker: Alina
text: Yes. Banking compliance is very sensitive. You cannot put client info, you cannot put internal cases.

speaker: Alina
text: Even internal policies, sometimes you should not share externally. So I never paste confidential details. I anonymise.

speaker: Alina
text: I write like, imagine a bank has scenario X, what is the general principle. Or I ask it to improve German style without context.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you give a concrete example of how you use it for German drafting?

speaker: Alina
text: Sure. For example, I need to write an email in German to a business stakeholder about a compliance requirement. My German is okay, but corporate German is, how to say, heavy.

speaker: Alina
text: Like, sehr geehrte Damen und Herren, but also not too formal, and you need this passive voice, and you need to sound firm but polite. So I write a draft in simple German, then I ask the AI to rewrite in professional corporate German tone. It gives me options.

speaker: Alina
text: I then adjust because sometimes it is too much, too long, too fluffy. But it helps.

speaker: Anna
text: And for regulations, what kind of questions?

speaker: Alina
text: Like, explain the difference between two concepts. Or summarise a regulatory text into bullet points. Or give me a structure for a memo.

speaker: Alina
text: Sometimes I ask, what are typical compliance controls for topic X. Not specific to my bank, but general. Or I ask it to translate a paragraph and explain terms.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you describe one moment where AI helped a lot?

speaker: Alina
text: Yes. There was a time we had to write a short internal note about a regulatory update. The source was in German, but the audience was mixed, some colleagues prefer English.

speaker: Alina
text: I needed to summarise quickly. I asked AI to help me structure the memo: background, key changes, impact, next steps. It gave a clean structure.

speaker: Alina
text: Then I filled in with my content. It saved time. Also, it helped me find the right German phrases, like angemessen, unverzüglich, solche words that appear often.

speaker: Anna
text: And one moment where AI failed or felt risky?

speaker: Alina
text: It failed when I asked about interpretation of a regulation. Like, I asked about a specific requirement, and it answered very confidently, like, you must do X. And I thought, okay, but is this true?

speaker: Alina
text: I checked the source, and it was more nuanced. It was not exactly wrong, but it oversimplified. And in compliance, oversimplification is dangerous.

speaker: Alina
text: Also, hallucination risk. Sometimes it invents an article number or a reference. And if you trust it, you can make mistakes.

speaker: Anna
text: How did that affect your trust?

speaker: Alina
text: It made me trust it conditionally. Like, I trust it for language and structure, but not for final interpretation. I always verify.

speaker: Alina
text: So it can be effective, but not fully trusted.

speaker: Anna
text: If you think about trust drivers for AI tools, what are they for you?

speaker: Alina
text: Usefulness, like it actually helps. Consistency. If it gives good drafts.

speaker: Alina
text: Also transparency about limitations. I like when it says, check sources. But sometimes it does not.

speaker: Alina
text: And privacy. Like, I do not want my data stored. So I keep it generic.

speaker: Alina
text: And accuracy, especially with regulatory topics.

speaker: Anna
text: And effectiveness indicators for AI in your situation?

speaker: Alina
text: Speed. Clarity. Better language.

speaker: Alina
text: Better structure. Less mental load. It helps me operate in German corporate environment.

speaker: Alina
text: It also reduces anxiety because I feel I can draft something and not sound stupid. But effectiveness is limited for deep career decisions, because it does not know my full context, and I do not want to share sensitive details. 6) Human vs AI comparison via specific tasks

speaker: Anna
text: I want to compare human coaching and AI via specific tasks. I will name a few typical career support tasks, and you tell me which one you would prefer and why. Is that okay?

speaker: Alina
text: Yes.

speaker: Anna
text: First task: clarifying options. Like, what roles exist, what pathways exist.

speaker: Alina
text: AI is good for brainstorming options. Like, list roles in ESG in banking, list skills. It can give a broad map.

speaker: Alina
text: But I would prefer a human to refine it for Germany and for my profile. Because AI can list everything, but it does not tell you what is realistic. And also, a human can ask me questions to narrow.

speaker: Anna
text: Second task: deciding between options. Like, choosing whether to pivot now or later, internal move or external.

speaker: Alina
text: Human. Because it involves risk, emotions, and also my residency context. I do not want to put that in AI.

speaker: Alina
text: And a human can sense fear, and also challenge me. AI can be too neutral, like here are pros and cons, but it does not help me commit.

speaker: Anna
text: Third task: planning concrete steps. Like a 3-month plan or 6-month plan.

speaker: Alina
text: This is interesting. AI can help structure a plan, like a template. But a human is better for accountability and realism.

speaker: Alina
text: So maybe hybrid. Like AI drafts the plan, human reviews and adjusts, and then human holds me accountable.

speaker: Anna
text: Fourth task: CV positioning and LinkedIn profile, specifically for an ESG pivot.

speaker: Alina
text: AI is helpful for wording, especially in German. Like translating my compliance experience into sustainability language. But again, a human with market knowledge is needed to tell me what recruiters want, what keywords matter, what achievements to highlight.

speaker: Alina
text: So also hybrid.

speaker: Anna
text: Fifth task: networking strategy. Like who to talk to, how to approach.

speaker: Alina
text: Human, because of nuance. In Germany, networking is not like, hey, can I pick your brain. It can feel awkward.

speaker: Alina
text: A human can help with scripts and with cultural tone. AI can write a message, but it might sound unnatural or too American. Though you can prompt it, but still.

speaker: Anna
text: Sixth task: interview practice.

speaker: Alina
text: Human. Because you need feedback on how you come across. AI can simulate questions, but it cannot fully read me.

speaker: Alina
text: Also, in compliance and ESG, there is a lot of nuance, and a human can see if I am convincing.

speaker: Anna
text: Seventh task: emotional support, like anxiety, self-doubt.

speaker: Alina
text: Human. Always. AI feels, um, empty for that.

speaker: Alina
text: It can say supportive things, but it is not the same as feeling seen.

speaker: Anna
text: And what about understanding regulations for a new field like CSRD or taxonomy?

speaker: Alina
text: AI as a starting point, but verified. And also human, like training or expert, because you need correct interpretation. For learning, AI is good.

speaker: Alina
text: For decision-making, no. 7) Trust–effectiveness link

speaker: Anna
text: Now I want to explore the link between trust and effectiveness in your experience. When you think about human coaching, how does trust affect whether it is effective?

speaker: Alina
text: Trust is like the gate. If I do not trust the coach, I will not share the real constraints. Like my fear about residency, or my financial obligations, or my insecurity about German.

speaker: Alina
text: And then the coach can only give generic advice. So trust enables depth. And depth makes it effective.

speaker: Alina
text: Also, if I trust the coach, I will actually do the homework. If I think the coach is not competent, I will ignore it.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you connect that to your coaching episode? How did trust and effectiveness interact there?

speaker: Alina
text: Yes. I trusted her, so I shared emotions and fears. That was effective for emotional relief.

speaker: Alina
text: But because she lacked market competence, the coaching was not effective for steps. So trust alone was not enough. It was trusted but not effective for the practical part.

speaker: Alina
text: I would say, trust enabled the emotional work, but effectiveness for career outcomes needed competence and structure.

speaker: Anna
text: And for AI tools, how does trust affect effectiveness?

speaker: Alina
text: I use AI even when I do not fully trust it. Like, I know it can be wrong, but it is still effective for drafting. So that is, how you said, effective but not fully trusted.

speaker: Alina
text: I trust it as a tool, not as an authority. I trust it to generate text options, not to decide. And because trust is partial, I always verify.

speaker: Alina
text: That verification step reduces risk but also takes time. So the effectiveness is limited by trust, but not zero.

speaker: Anna
text: So in your words, trust and effectiveness are separable?

speaker: Alina
text: Yes. For humans, trust is more connected because if you do not trust, you do not open up, and then nothing works. For AI, you can use it pragmatically without trust, because it is like a calculator, but with words.

speaker: Alina
text: But you still need some trust to rely on it without checking.

speaker: Anna
text: If you think about a situation where you would not use AI because trust is too low, what would that be?

speaker: Alina
text: Anything confidential. Like a real compliance case with client details. Or something that could be used against me.

speaker: Alina
text: Like discussing internal politics or naming people. I do not want that anywhere. So for sensitive discussions, I prefer human, because confidentiality is clearer.

speaker: Alina
text: Though even with humans, you need to trust them.

speaker: Anna
text: And what about effectiveness. What would make you say, this support was effective?

speaker: Alina
text: If I make progress. Like I have a clear target role, I take steps, I get interviews, I build credibility. Or even if I do not get interviews yet, I have real market feedback from informational calls.

speaker: Alina
text: And I feel less anxious because I know what I am doing. 8) Preferences and hybrid model reaction

speaker: Anna
text: I want to ask you about a hybrid model. Imagine a career support service where AI helps you prepare, like clarify options, draft documents, track steps, and then a human expert steps in for sensitive discussions, decisions, and accountability. What is your reaction?

speaker: Alina
text: That sounds ideal, actually. Because AI can do the heavy lifting for drafts and structure. And humans can do the judgment and emotional part.

speaker: Alina
text: Also it reduces cost maybe, because you do not need many human sessions for basic things. But the key is, the human must be competent in my domain. Like, an ESG person or someone who knows banking and Germany.

speaker: Anna
text: What would make you trust such a hybrid model?

speaker: Alina
text: Clear boundaries. Like, what data goes to AI, what stays private. Maybe an option to keep everything local, but that is technical.

speaker: Alina
text: Also transparency: who are the human experts, what is their background. And a process. Like, step 1 AI intake, step 2 human session, step 3 AI follow-up tasks, step 4 check-in.

speaker: Alina
text: That would make me feel safe. And also confidentiality policies, like GDPR, data handling. In Germany, people care.

speaker: Anna
text: What would make you not trust it?

speaker: Alina
text: If it feels like marketing. Like, we have AI and it will change your life. Or if the human is too generic.

speaker: Alina
text: Or if the AI gives advice that feels wrong but confident. And if they push me to share too much personal data.

speaker: Anna
text: What tasks would you want AI to lead, and what tasks would you want the human to lead?

speaker: Alina
text: AI leads drafting, translation, structuring, brainstorming. Human leads decisions, career narrative, networking strategy with cultural nuance, interview practice, and emotional support. Also, like, helping me interpret market signals.

speaker: Alina
text: AI can list roles, but human can say, for you, this role is realistic if you do X.

speaker: Anna
text: Let us do the micro-poll ratings now. I will ask four ratings from 0 to 10, and I would like you to explain each briefly. First, your current trust in human career coaches, in general, for your situation.

speaker: Anna
text: 0 is no trust, 10 is full trust.

speaker: Alina
text: I would say 7.

speaker: Anna
text: Why 7?

speaker: Alina
text: Because humans can be empathetic and confidential, and they can adapt. But I do not fully trust because many coaches are not competent in my niche. So I trust humans as humans, but I need to check their expertise.

speaker: Anna
text: Second, your trust in AI tools for your career-related needs. 0 to 10.

speaker: Alina
text: Maybe 5.

speaker: Anna
text: Why 5?

speaker: Alina
text: Because I trust it for drafting and structure, but not for deep advice. Also confidentiality concerns. And accuracy issues.

speaker: Alina
text: So it is useful, but trust is limited.

speaker: Anna
text: Third, perceived effectiveness of human coaching for your situation. 0 to 10.

speaker: Alina
text: For my situation, I would say 4.

speaker: Anna
text: What makes it 4?

speaker: Alina
text: My experience was emotionally helpful, but not actionable. So effectiveness for my actual goal, pivot to ESG, was low. Maybe if I find the right coach, it can be higher.

speaker: Alina
text: But based on what I saw, it is not very effective.

speaker: Anna
text: Fourth, perceived effectiveness of AI tools for your situation.

speaker: Alina
text: That is higher. I would say 7.

speaker: Anna
text: Why 7?

speaker: Alina
text: Because it helps me daily with German, with structuring, with learning. It makes me more productive and confident in communication. It does not solve my career pivot alone, but it supports me in practical tasks.

speaker: Anna
text: Interesting. So you have higher effectiveness for AI than for the human coaching you experienced, but lower trust.

speaker: Alina
text: Yes, exactly. That is the paradox.

speaker: Anna
text: If you imagine the ideal support for your ESG pivot, what would it look like in, say, three months?

speaker: Alina
text: I would have a clear target role. Like, I decide, okay, I aim for sustainability reporting under CSRD in a bank, or ESG risk. And I have a plan: courses, internal project involvement, maybe a small internal task force, networking calls.

speaker: Alina
text: I would also have my CV updated with an ESG narrative. And maybe I would have at least one interview or at least two strong informational calls that lead to opportunities. And I would feel less like, I am dreaming, and more like, I am executing.

speaker: Anna
text: What would be the first step you want help with right now?

speaker: Alina
text: Narrowing the target. Because ESG is broad. I need help to choose the path that matches my compliance background.

speaker: Alina
text: And then I need help to create credibility, like projects or certifications. And also, German. I know it is not sexy, but it matters.

speaker: Anna
text: When you think about hybrid, would you want the human to be a coach, like reflective, or more like a mentor, like insider?

speaker: Alina
text: More like insider. I think coaching style is nice, but I already have self-awareness. I need someone who knows the field, who can say, in Frankfurt, in banks, this is how ESG roles look, these are the hiring channels, these are the skills.

speaker: Alina
text: Also, someone who can tell me honestly if my story makes sense.

speaker: Anna
text: And how should AI be positioned in that model, so that you are comfortable?

speaker: Alina
text: As assistant, not as authority. Like, it helps you prepare for the human session, it helps you draft, it tracks tasks. But it should not pretend it knows better than the human.

speaker: Alina
text: Also it should have clear disclaimers, like verify sources, but in a calm way. And you should be able to choose what you share. 9) Closing

speaker: Anna
text: We are coming to the end. Is there anything important about your experience with human coaching or AI tools for career support that we did not cover, that you think matters?

speaker: Alina
text: Maybe one thing. In regulated environments, trust is already part of the culture. Like, we are trained to be cautious.

speaker: Alina
text: So when people say, just use AI, it is not that simple. It is not only fear, it is professional responsibility. So for me, AI is helpful, but I always have this compliance brain saying, check, verify, do not share.

speaker: Alina
text: And with humans, trust is also not automatic. You need someone who understands that mindset, otherwise they think you are just anxious.

speaker: Anna
text: That is very helpful. If you could give one advice to a designer of a career support service for people like you, what would it be?

speaker: Alina
text: Make it specific. Like, do not say career coaching for everyone. Make pathways for regulated professions, for immigrants, for Germany-specific context.

speaker: Alina
text: And combine practical steps with emotional support. Because we are not robots. Even in compliance, there is emotion.

speaker: Alina
text: We just hide it.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you. Last check, do you have any questions for me about the research or the interview?

speaker: Alina
text: Not really. I am curious what you find. But no questions now.

speaker: Anna
text: Great. Thanks again for your time and for being open. I will stop the recording now.

speaker: Alina
text: Thank you, Anna. Bye.

speaker: Anna
text: Bye.

speaker: Anna
text: Hi Pierre, can you hear me well?

speaker: Pierre
text: Yes, I can hear you. Can you hear me?

speaker: Anna
text: Yes, perfectly. Thanks for joining. Before we start, do I have your permission to record?

speaker: Anna
text: Everything will be anonymised, and you can skip any question.

speaker: Pierre
text: Yes, you can record. That is fine.

speaker: Anna
text: Great, thank you. And just to check, are there any topics you prefer not to discuss today?

speaker: Pierre
text: Um, no, I think it is okay. Maybe no very specific company secrets, like supplier names, but career stuff is fine.

speaker: Anna
text: Of course. We will keep it at a general level. Also, if at any point you want to pause, just tell me.

speaker: Pierre
text: Okay.

speaker: Anna
text: Cool. Then we can start with a bit of context about you and your current situation. 2.

speaker: Anna
text: Participant context and career situation

speaker: Anna
text: Where are you currently in your career, and what career decisions or questions are you facing right now?

speaker: Pierre
text: Eehm, so I am Pierre, I am 27. I am from France, from Lyon originally, and I moved to Stuttgart two years ago. I did a Master in Industrial Design.

speaker: Pierre
text: After that I worked one year in France, in a small studio, and then I got this job in Germany in a hardware company. It is like, not a startup, it is more established. Mid size but very German in the way it works.

speaker: Pierre
text: I am in product design, but also I coordinate with suppliers. So my role is half craft, half, like, coordination and industrialisation things.

speaker: Anna
text: When you say hardware company, what kind of products are you working on?

speaker: Pierre
text: We do components for mobility and also some industrial devices. Not full cars, but parts that go into systems. For example, housings, interface elements, sometimes a complete device like a charging module.

speaker: Pierre
text: It is very, how to say, manufacturing heavy. Lots of tolerances, testing, certifications, and supplier chain.

speaker: Anna
text: And what is the career dilemma you are facing at the moment?

speaker: Pierre
text: The big dilemma is, do I stay in this corporate style environment and grow slowly, or do I switch to a startup. And if I switch, what startup, what role. Like should I be product designer in a startup, or should I go more into product management, or like design engineering.

speaker: Pierre
text: And also I have this fear, like, if I go to a startup, it looks cool now, but later, does it look serious. Does it give credibility for, like, a long career, especially in Germany where people like stability.

speaker: Anna
text: What has made this dilemma urgent for you now, as opposed to one year ago?

speaker: Pierre
text: Um, good question. I think it is the slowness. I enjoy the craft and the design work, like sketching, CAD, making prototypes, even small details like surface finish, textures, how a knob feels.

speaker: Pierre
text: I love this. But the process is very slow. So I feel blocked.

speaker: Pierre
text: And then I see friends in startups who ship things faster, they have more ownership. And I also feel my learning is not as fast now as I want.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you give me a concrete example of the slowness, like a story that really shows it?

speaker: Pierre
text: Yes. I have one story that is very typical. We had a new revision of a housing for a module.

speaker: Pierre
text: It was not a huge change, it was like a small change for a connector position, but it impacts the injection mold. So we had to go through internal approvals, then purchasing, then quality, then the supplier. The supplier says, okay, change request, we need a new insert.

speaker: Pierre
text: Then purchasing wants three quotes. Then quality wants a risk assessment. Then there is a meeting, and in the meeting everyone says the same thing, but nobody decides.

speaker: Anna
text: Mm.

speaker: Pierre
text: So it took, I think, maybe ten weeks just to approve a change that in a smaller environment would be, like, okay, we do it, we adjust, we test. And the funniest part is, at the end, we still had a mistake because the requirements document was not updated properly. So we lost ten weeks and still had an issue.

speaker: Pierre
text: And I remember sitting there like, why am I spending my time on chasing signatures.

speaker: Anna
text: What did that do to your motivation?

speaker: Pierre
text: It makes me feel, um, like I am not a designer but a process manager. And I do not hate it, I understand it is needed in hardware, because you cannot just change like in software. But the amount of bureaucracy is too much.

speaker: Pierre
text: And also Stuttgart is very automotive culture. Like everything is planned, conservative, risk avoidance. Sometimes it is good, but it can kill creativity.

speaker: Anna
text: Where do you feel you are strongest right now in your role?

speaker: Pierre
text: I think I am strong in concept development and also in translating between design and engineering. Like I can talk to engineers, I can understand constraints, and then still keep a design intent. And with suppliers, I can communicate, like, what is the key parameter, what is the must-have, what can be flexible.

speaker: Pierre
text: So I am not only aesthetic.

speaker: Anna
text: And what feels hardest?

speaker: Pierre
text: The politics and the waiting. And also, eehm, the feeling that my career path is not clear. Like in Germany, there is a clear ladder for engineers sometimes.

speaker: Pierre
text: For designers in hardware, it is less clear. You can become senior designer, but then what. And because I am not German, I also feel I need to prove credibility.

speaker: Anna
text: How is your German now?

speaker: Pierre
text: It is okay for work, like B1, maybe low B2. I can do meetings, but sometimes I miss nuance. When people speak Swabian, forget it.

speaker: Pierre
text: I can do small talk, but when it is conflict or negotiation, English is easier for me. But in this region, German is important, especially in supplier discussions.

speaker: Anna
text: You mentioned status and credibility. Can you say more about what status means for you in this decision?

speaker: Pierre
text: Um, yes. It is a bit stupid maybe, but, like, the name of the company on your CV. In France also, but in Germany maybe more, people look at it.

speaker: Pierre
text: If you are in a known industrial company, it signals stability. If you are in a startup, people ask, is it serious, did you really do something, or is it chaos.

speaker: Anna
text: Is that coming from your own view, or from other people, like family, peers, LinkedIn?

speaker: Pierre
text: All of it. My family, they are like, you moved to Germany, good job, stable, good salary, why you want to risk. And then on LinkedIn, you see people move to startups and it looks modern, but you also see people come back and say, it failed.

speaker: Pierre
text: And I am like, if I move now, in two years, will I be able to come back to corporate if I want. Or will they see me as unstable.

speaker: Anna
text: What would success look like for you, if things go well?

speaker: Pierre
text: Success is, I am doing meaningful product work, shipping real things, not just PowerPoints. And I have a clear story. Like, I can explain why I did this path.

speaker: Pierre
text: And I feel my skills grow. Also, I want to be in a place where decisions are made faster, but still with quality. And maybe long term, I could lead a design team, or be a product lead for hardware, like owning a product line.

speaker: Anna
text: What is the biggest career decision you have made in the last six to twelve months?

speaker: Pierre
text: The biggest decision was, I started actively exploring startups. Not only thinking, but actually doing something. I joined events in Stuttgart, I talked to people, I started a side project to update my portfolio.

speaker: Pierre
text: And I also had a conversation internally about rotation, like maybe moving to a more innovation focused team. But that one, hmm, it did not really move.

speaker: Anna
text: What made it difficult to decide?

speaker: Pierre
text: Uncertainty. Like, what is the right startup, what is the right role. Also salary risk.

speaker: Pierre
text: Stuttgart is expensive. And visas are not an issue because I am EU, but still, stability matters. And then fear of making a wrong move and losing credibility.

speaker: Anna
text: What kind of support did you feel you needed while making that decision?

speaker: Pierre
text: I needed someone who understands design careers in hardware, and understands Germany. And someone who can be honest, like tell me, Pierre, your portfolio is good but you need this, or your story is weak here. I needed structure, like steps, not only motivation.

speaker: Pierre
text: 3. Career support in general

speaker: Anna
text: When you need career support, who or what do you usually turn to?

speaker: Pierre
text: Um, I talk with friends, mostly designers. Some are in Berlin, some in Munich, some in Paris. I also talk with one colleague at work, but carefully, because you do not want to look like you want to leave.

speaker: Pierre
text: I also look at online resources, like articles, videos, and sometimes I use AI tools for certain tasks. Not really for self reflection, more for brainstorming.

speaker: Anna
text: What has actually helped you in the past, and what felt unhelpful?

speaker: Pierre
text: Helpful is when people give specific feedback. Like, not, follow your passion, but, your portfolio needs more manufacturing constraints, show how you work with suppliers, show DFM. Also helpful is when someone challenges your assumptions.

speaker: Pierre
text: Unhelpful is general advice, like, just apply everywhere, or just go to Berlin, like it is simple. And also unhelpful is when people project their own fear. Like family says, startup is dangerous, but they do not know the ecosystem.

speaker: Anna
text: In Stuttgart specifically, do you feel there are support structures or networks that matter?

speaker: Pierre
text: Yes, there are meetups, but it is different from Berlin. Stuttgart has this manufacturing gravity, like automotive suppliers, hardware culture. There are accelerators, there are innovation hubs, but it is still connected to big companies.

speaker: Pierre
text: Even startups often work with corporates. So the culture is more B2B, more industrial. That affects the kind of roles.

speaker: Anna
text: How do you approach networking there?

speaker: Pierre
text: Slowly. In France I am more direct. Here, people want to know you over time.

speaker: Pierre
text: I go to events, I talk, but I also follow up on LinkedIn, like, danke for the conversation, and then maybe coffee. It is slow but it works.

speaker: Anna
text: Any professional services, like formal career coaching, university career center, anything like that?

speaker: Pierre
text: I did not do paid career coaching. But I had mentoring through an accelerator program, like a program connected to innovation, where they match mentors. That was the closest to coaching, and it was very helpful.

speaker: Anna
text: We will go into that. Before that, one more question. When you think about career support, what do you wish existed, like an ideal support?

speaker: Pierre
text: Something that combines honest human feedback with structured tools. Like, you can prepare with tools, gather options, but then a human helps you with nuance, and with the story. And also accountability, because I procrastinate sometimes.

speaker: Anna
text: Okay. Let us move into your mentoring experience. 4.

speaker: Anna
text: Human coaching: experience and trust

speaker: Anna
text: Tell me about the mentoring you had through the accelerator program. What was the situation and what did you work on?

speaker: Pierre
text: So, about one year ago, I joined an accelerator style program, not as a founder, more like as a participant in an innovation track. It was connected to hardware and mobility. They offered mentoring.

speaker: Pierre
text: I was matched with a mentor who had worked in product development, like design and product strategy, in Germany and also internationally. He was older, maybe in his 40s, and very direct.

speaker: Anna
text: How many sessions did you have?

speaker: Pierre
text: Three sessions over, like, two months. And some messages in between.

speaker: Anna
text: What made it work for you?

speaker: Pierre
text: The honesty. Like, first session, I showed my portfolio, and he said, eehm, your work is good, but your story is too safe. You show nice renders, but you do not show what you own.

speaker: Pierre
text: And he asked me, what do you want, like really. And I started with corporate polite answers, like, I want to grow, I want impact. And he interrupted and said, no, what do you want, specifically.

speaker: Pierre
text: And I was like, okay, I want to design products that ship, and I want to be in a faster environment. And he said, then your current narrative does not match.

speaker: Anna
text: That sounds quite confronting. How did you experience that?

speaker: Pierre
text: At first, I was defensive. I was like, who is he to judge. But then, I felt he was not attacking me, he was just precise.

speaker: Pierre
text: And he had credibility, because he knew the industry. He talked about supplier lead times, manufacturing gates, he understood. So I trusted him.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you recall a vivid moment, something he said that felt especially honest or helpful?

speaker: Pierre
text: Yes. There was a moment where I said, I want to go to a startup but I am afraid it looks bad later. And he said, you are mixing fear and strategy.

speaker: Pierre
text: He said, prestige is not a plan. And I was like, ouch. But he explained.

speaker: Pierre
text: He said, you need to define what skills you want, what story you want, and then choose environments that build it. Prestige will come from coherence, not from logos. He said something like, if you go to a small company and you can explain your impact, it is stronger than being a small person in a big logo.

speaker: Anna
text: What did that change for you after the session?

speaker: Pierre
text: I started to redesign my portfolio. Not redesign like visuals, but content. I added one case study that shows supplier coordination.

speaker: Pierre
text: Like, I show the iterations, the constraints, the decisions. I also started writing short explanations of trade offs. And I also changed how I talk about my role.

speaker: Pierre
text: Before I was like, industrial designer. Now I say, industrial designer in hardware with supplier coordination and production readiness.

speaker: Anna
text: Did you take any action beyond portfolio changes?

speaker: Pierre
text: Yes. He told me to have one informational interview per week with someone in a startup environment, but in hardware, not software. So I did that for maybe six weeks.

speaker: Pierre
text: And it helped. I talked to someone in an e-mobility startup, someone in a medical device startup, someone in a robotics company. And I learned, roles are very different.

speaker: Anna
text: What did you learn about roles that mattered to your decision?

speaker: Pierre
text: That startup product designer can mean many things. Sometimes it is mostly CAD and prototypes, very hands-on. Sometimes it is UX and interfaces, more digital.

speaker: Pierre
text: Sometimes it is a mix with product management. So I realized I need to be careful. I do not want to become only a graphic person.

speaker: Pierre
text: I want to stay close to physical product.

speaker: Anna
text: What were the main drivers of trust for you with this mentor?

speaker: Pierre
text: Competence, first. He understood my context, hardware, Germany. Second, honest feedback, like he did not just comfort me.

speaker: Pierre
text: Third, confidentiality. He made it clear he is not connected to my company, and what we talk stays there. Fourth, he saw me as a person.

speaker: Pierre
text: He asked about my move to Germany, language, family pressure. And also structure. He gave tasks, like do this by next time, and we review.

speaker: Anna
text: Was there anything that reduced trust at any point?

speaker: Pierre
text: Not really. Maybe sometimes he was too fast. Like he assumes you can just do things.

speaker: Pierre
text: But overall, trust was high.

speaker: Anna
text: Did you ever have an experience where you trusted someone, but it was not effective?

speaker: Pierre
text: Yes. A colleague at work, he is very kind, very supportive. He says, Pierre, you are talented, you should go for internal promotion.

speaker: Pierre
text: He listened, he cared, so I trust him emotionally. But it was not effective because his advice was like, wait, be patient, it will come. And maybe it is true in corporate, but it did not give me steps.

speaker: Pierre
text: It kept me in the same loop. So I trusted him, but it did not change anything.

speaker: Anna
text: That distinction is helpful. When you think of effectiveness for the mentoring, how would you define it? What were your indicators?

speaker: Pierre
text: Effectiveness is, after sessions, I had clearer targets. Like I could say, okay, I want hardware startup in mobility or medical, not just any startup. And I had concrete actions: update portfolio, do informational interviews, prepare a story.

speaker: Pierre
text: Also I felt more confidence because I had a plan. So effectiveness is clarity plus action plus confidence.

speaker: Anna
text: Did mentoring influence your actual decisions, like did you apply somewhere?

speaker: Pierre
text: I have not signed anything, but I did start applying. Like, I applied to two roles, and I got one first interview. It did not go further, but it was a good test.

speaker: Pierre
text: And I changed how I present myself, thanks to the mentor.

speaker: Anna
text: What happened in that interview, if you can share at a high level?

speaker: Pierre
text: It was a robotics startup. They asked, why you leave corporate. Before I would say, I want faster pace.

speaker: Pierre
text: Now I said, I want higher ownership and shorter feedback loops, and I have experience bringing design to production, which is valuable in hardware. And they reacted well. They said, okay, you understand constraints.

speaker: Pierre
text: So that was a result.

speaker: Anna
text: Sounds like the mentor influenced both your materials and your narrative.

speaker: Pierre
text: Yes. 5. AI tools: experience and trust

speaker: Anna
text: Let us talk about AI tools. What have you used, and in what situations related to your career or work?

speaker: Pierre
text: I use AI mostly for ideation prompts and naming concepts. Like, if we have a new module and we want internal concept names, or if I am brainstorming themes for a design direction. Sometimes also for writing, like to clean up an email in English or German.

speaker: Pierre
text: But not so much for self reflection. Because I feel it flattens nuance.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you walk me through a concrete moment where AI helped you a lot?

speaker: Pierre
text: Yes. We had a workshop where we needed to propose three concept directions for a new device. It was like an industrial device that also has a user interface, like a small screen, buttons, indicator lights.

speaker: Pierre
text: And the brief was confusing. Many stakeholders, marketing, engineering, sales. Everyone wants different things.

speaker: Anna
text: That sounds familiar to me

speaker: Pierre
text: Yes. So I used AI to generate, like, categories. I gave constraints: industrial environment, gloves, dust, need readability, and also brand values.

speaker: Pierre
text: And I asked, propose concept themes with adjectives and quick rationale. It gave me like, rugged clarity, calm precision, modular honesty, things like that. Some were generic, but some helped me create a structure.

speaker: Pierre
text: Then I took the best ones and made sketches. So it helped me go from chaos to a frame.

speaker: Anna
text: So it was more like a structuring and variation tool.

speaker: Pierre
text: Exactly. Speed and variation.

speaker: Anna
text: And naming concepts?

speaker: Pierre
text: Yes, naming is funny. We need internal names sometimes for prototypes. AI is good for that.

speaker: Pierre
text: Like you say, give me names inspired by Swabian engineering and simplicity, and it gives you lists. Some are ridiculous, but some work. And it saves time.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you think of a moment where AI did not help, or even made it worse?

speaker: Pierre
text: Yes. I tried to use it for career reflection once. I wrote a long prompt about my dilemma, corporate vs startup, fear of prestige, Stuttgart culture.

speaker: Pierre
text: And it responded with very generic advice, like, consider your values, make a pros and cons list, network, follow your passion. And I was like, yes, I know. It felt like a blog post.

speaker: Pierre
text: It did not catch the nuance, like the specific signaling in German hardware.

speaker: Anna
text: What nuance did you feel was missing?

speaker: Pierre
text: The cultural nuance. Like in Stuttgart, startups are often connected to corporates. So it is not like Berlin.

speaker: Pierre
text: Also the design nuance, like in hardware, you cannot just iterate weekly. And also personal nuance, like my identity as a French person here, language, credibility. AI makes it smooth, but too smooth.

speaker: Anna
text: How would you describe your trust in AI tools for these different tasks?

speaker: Pierre
text: I trust AI for speed and for brainstorming, like generating options. But I do not trust its taste. Like in design, taste matters.

speaker: Pierre
text: AI suggestions can be same-y, like average. And I do not trust it for high stakes decisions, because it does not know the real constraints, and it can be confidently wrong.

speaker: Anna
text: Do you have concerns about privacy or data when using AI?

speaker: Pierre
text: Yes, a bit. At work, we are careful. We do not put confidential details.

speaker: Pierre
text: For personal career, I also do not want to put too much personal detail. But my main issue is not privacy, it is quality and nuance.

speaker: Anna
text: Did you ever use AI for job applications, like CV wording?

speaker: Pierre
text: A little bit. I used it to rewrite bullet points, like make it more concise. That was helpful.

speaker: Pierre
text: But I had to correct, because it sometimes makes claims too strong. Like it says, led cross functional teams, and I am like, no, I collaborated, I did not lead.

speaker: Anna
text: That is an interesting trust boundary.

speaker: Pierre
text: Yes, it tends to exaggerate.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you think of an example where AI was effective for you, but you did not fully trust it?

speaker: Pierre
text: Yes. The naming example. We needed a name for a concept, internal only, but it mattered for the presentation because it frames perception.

speaker: Pierre
text: AI gave a name that actually worked, it fit the concept. We used it. It was effective.

speaker: Pierre
text: But I did not fully trust it because it felt shallow, like it did not understand the deeper design intent, it just combined words.

speaker: Anna
text: That fits the idea of effective but not fully trusted.

speaker: Pierre
text: Exactly.

speaker: Anna
text: And the opposite, trusted but not effective, you already mentioned your colleague.

speaker: Pierre
text: Yes. 6. Human vs AI comparison via specific tasks

speaker: Anna
text: I want to compare human mentoring and AI tools through specific tasks. I will name a task, and you tell me what you would prefer and why. First task: clarifying career options.

speaker: Anna
text: Like, what roles, what industries, what paths.

speaker: Pierre
text: For clarifying options, I would start with AI, because it is fast. Like, give me a map of roles in hardware startups, differences between industrial designer, mechanical design engineer, product manager, design strategist, whatever. It can give a good first overview.

speaker: Pierre
text: But then, I would want a human to validate and contextualize. Because AI can list roles, but it cannot tell you how it really looks in Stuttgart, or in a specific company.

speaker: Anna
text: Second task: making a decision, like corporate vs startup.

speaker: Pierre
text: Human. Because that is not only information, it is identity and fear. A human can challenge you, and also read between lines.

speaker: Pierre
text: AI cannot see when I am rationalizing. A mentor can say, you are using prestige as an excuse, or you are avoiding risk. AI is polite, it does not confront you in the same way.

speaker: Anna
text: Third task: building a concrete plan for the next six weeks.

speaker: Pierre
text: Hmm. Hybrid. AI can help structure, like a checklist: update portfolio, target list, networking, interviews, timeline.

speaker: Pierre
text: But a human can prioritise. Like, Pierre, stop perfecting visuals, focus on story. And a human can hold you accountable.

speaker: Anna
text: Fourth task: rewriting your CV and cover letter.

speaker: Pierre
text: AI can help with language, especially in English or German. But I would not trust it fully. I would do AI draft, then human review, maybe a mentor or friend.

speaker: Pierre
text: Because AI can make it generic, like everyone.

speaker: Anna
text: Fifth task: portfolio critique.

speaker: Pierre
text: Human, definitely. Portfolio is taste, narrative, what to show, what not. AI can give general tips, but not a deep critique.

speaker: Pierre
text: A mentor who has hired designers is best.

speaker: Anna
text: Sixth task: ideation for a side project, like a portfolio piece.

speaker: Pierre
text: AI is very useful for ideation prompts, because it can push you out of your default. Like, propose project themes combining sustainability, mobility, circular design, whatever. But then I choose and shape it.

speaker: Pierre
text: So AI for sparks, human for meaning.

speaker: Anna
text: If you had to summarise, what is AI good at, and what is it bad at, for you?

speaker: Pierre
text: AI is good at speed, variation, structure, language cleaning. Bad at nuance, taste, context, and emotional truth. And also it can be too generic, like it averages.

speaker: Anna
text: And humans?

speaker: Pierre
text: Humans are good at seeing you, being honest, context, and credibility. But humans are slow, expensive, sometimes biased, sometimes inconsistent. And some humans are nice but not useful.

speaker: Anna
text: Aha, thank you 7. Trust–effectiveness link

speaker: Anna
text: Now I want to explore the link between trust and effectiveness in your experience. When you think about human mentoring, how does trust affect whether it is effective?

speaker: Pierre
text: Trust is like the entry ticket. If I do not trust the mentor, I will not share the real fears, like the prestige anxiety, family pressure, or that I feel stuck. Then the mentor can only give surface advice, like improve your CV.

speaker: Pierre
text: So trust enables depth. And depth makes it effective.

speaker: Anna
text: What creates that trust, specifically?

speaker: Pierre
text: For humans, it is competence and honesty. Competence means they know the domain, like hardware careers, not just general coaching. Honesty means they tell you what you need to hear, not what you want.

speaker: Pierre
text: Also confidentiality. And feeling seen, like they remember details, they understand my context. And structure, like there is a process.

speaker: Anna
text: Does trust always lead to effectiveness?

speaker: Pierre
text: Not always. Like with my colleague, I trust him, but his advice was not actionable. So trust is necessary, but not sufficient.

speaker: Pierre
text: You can trust someone and still not get results.

speaker: Anna
text: And can you have effectiveness without trust?

speaker: Pierre
text: Yes, like AI naming. Or even with humans, maybe a recruiter gives you a tip that works, but you do not trust their motives, because they want to place you. Still, the tip can be useful.

speaker: Pierre
text: So effectiveness can happen without full trust, but it is limited.

speaker: Anna
text: How does trust affect your willingness to act on advice?

speaker: Pierre
text: If I trust, I act more. Because I believe the advice fits me. If I do not trust, I might still use it, but I treat it like input, not guidance.

speaker: Pierre
text: Like, I take it, but I do not commit.

speaker: Anna
text: And for AI, how does trust relate to effectiveness?

speaker: Pierre
text: For AI, trust is more like, do I believe it is accurate for this task. If I trust it for brainstorming, it is effective because I use it. But for self reflection, I do not trust it, so I do not use it, so it is not effective.

speaker: Pierre
text: Also, if it gives generic answers, trust goes down quickly.

speaker: Anna
text: That makes sense. Do you notice any pattern where AI becomes more trusted over time?

speaker: Pierre
text: Slightly, for specific tasks. Like, I learned what prompts work. So I trust it more in a narrow scope.

speaker: Pierre
text: But not as a partner. More like a tool.

speaker: Anna
text: If you imagine an AI tool designed specifically for career coaching, would that change trust?

speaker: Pierre
text: Maybe, if it is more specialized, like it knows the German market, roles, and it is transparent. But still, I would want a human for big decisions. 8.

speaker: Pierre
text: Preferences and hybrid model reaction

speaker: Anna
text: I want to include a short micro-poll, just quick ratings from 0 to 10. 0 means no trust at all, 10 means complete trust. First: your current trust in human coaches or mentors for career topics.

speaker: Anna
text: What number comes to mind?

speaker: Pierre
text: For human mentors, I would say 8.

speaker: Anna
text: Why 8, not 10?

speaker: Pierre
text: Because it depends on the person. My mentor was great, but not everyone is. Some coaches are generic or too motivational.

speaker: Pierre
text: So I trust humans if they have competence and honesty. But I do not trust the category automatically.

speaker: Anna
text: Second: trust in AI tools for career related topics.

speaker: Pierre
text: Maybe 4.

speaker: Anna
text: Why 4?

speaker: Pierre
text: Because I trust AI for certain tasks, like brainstorming or language, but not for decisions. And I do not trust nuance. So overall, moderate low.

speaker: Anna
text: Third: perceived effectiveness of human mentoring for your situation right now, 0 to 10.

speaker: Pierre
text: Effectiveness, I would say 7.

speaker: Anna
text: Why 7?

speaker: Pierre
text: Because my mentoring helped, it gave me actions and clarity. But it was limited time, three sessions. And it does not remove the structural reality, like corporate slowness or market uncertainty.

speaker: Pierre
text: So it was effective, but not a magic solution.

speaker: Anna
text: Fourth: perceived effectiveness of AI tools for your situation right now.

speaker: Pierre
text: For my situation, maybe 5.

speaker: Anna
text: Tell me more.

speaker: Pierre
text: AI is useful as a support tool. It helps me create options, structure, write better. That is effective in small ways.

speaker: Pierre
text: But for the main dilemma, it is not deeply helpful. So it is in the middle.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you. Now, let us talk about preferences. If you could design an ideal support setup for yourself, would you choose human only, AI only, or hybrid?

speaker: Pierre
text: Hybrid.

speaker: Anna
text: What would hybrid look like for you, concretely?

speaker: Pierre
text: I would want AI first for preparation. Like, I input my background, my constraints, and it helps me map options, prepare questions, generate drafts for CV, maybe even propose a plan. Then I want a human mentor to review, challenge, and adapt it to me.

speaker: Pierre
text: And then maybe AI for follow up, like reminders, templates, and tracking progress. Like, okay, you said you will do one informational interview this week, here is a message draft, here is a checklist. That would be great.

speaker: Anna
text: What would you not want AI to do in that hybrid model?

speaker: Pierre
text: I do not want AI to pretend empathy. Like, I hate when it says, I understand how you feel, but it does not. It feels fake.

speaker: Pierre
text: I would prefer it to be transparent, like, I am a tool, here are options. Also I do not want AI to make big recommendations like, quit your job. That feels dangerous.

speaker: Anna
text: What would you want the human to do that AI cannot?

speaker: Pierre
text: The human should do the deep conversation, the confrontation, the nuance, the reading between lines. Also taste and portfolio critique. And also credibility.

speaker: Pierre
text: Like if a mentor tells me, in Stuttgart hardware, this move makes sense, I believe it more.

speaker: Anna
text: Are there any situations where you would prefer AI over a human, even if a human is available?

speaker: Pierre
text: Yes. For quick tasks. Like I need a cover letter draft at midnight.

speaker: Pierre
text: Or I want to brainstorm side project ideas quickly. Or I do not want to bother a human with small questions. Also sometimes with a human, I feel judged.

speaker: Pierre
text: With AI, you can ask stupid questions.

speaker: Anna
text: Interesting. So psychological safety can be higher with AI sometimes?

speaker: Pierre
text: For small things, yes. Because it is not a person. But for big things, I want a person.

speaker: Anna
text: And when would you prefer human only, no AI?

speaker: Pierre
text: When it is about identity, like what kind of life I want, what kind of work environment. Also when I feel emotional, like fear. AI responses feel flat.

speaker: Pierre
text: A human can respond to emotion.

speaker: Anna
text: You said earlier you worry about startup credibility later. If a mentor says, this startup is good, it will not hurt your CV, would that reduce your anxiety?

speaker: Pierre
text: Yes, because it gives me an external validation. But I also know mentors can be biased. So I would want multiple signals.

speaker: Pierre
text: Still, it helps.

speaker: Anna
text: In your ideal hybrid, how would trust be built?

speaker: Pierre
text: For the human, through competence and honesty. For AI, through consistency and transparency. Like, it shows where information comes from, it admits limits, it does not hallucinate.

speaker: Pierre
text: And maybe it can show examples of people with similar profiles, anonymized, like paths. That would increase trust.

speaker: Anna
text: And how would you know it is effective?

speaker: Pierre
text: If I get clearer targets, like I can name three roles and three types of companies. If I improve my portfolio and get interviews. If I feel less stuck.

speaker: Pierre
text: If I can take actions weekly. And if I feel my story is coherent. 9.

speaker: Pierre
text: Closing

speaker: Anna
text: Before we close, is there anything important about your experience with human mentoring or AI tools for career support that we did not cover?

speaker: Pierre
text: Maybe one thing. In hardware, the stakes are different. Like, mistakes cost money and time.

speaker: Pierre
text: So career advice also needs to respect that. AI tools often feel like software mindset. But hardware is slower, and that is okay.

speaker: Pierre
text: So for me, the right support is not to say, move fast and break things. It is more like, move with intention.

speaker: Anna
text: That is a really clear point. Anything else?

speaker: Pierre
text: Also Stuttgart is special. It is not the most sexy startup city, but there are good companies. The path can be hybrid too.

speaker: Pierre
text: Like corporate innovation teams, or startups connected to corporates. So I am exploring that.

speaker: Anna
text: Great. Thank you, Pierre. Last check, are you still comfortable with everything we discussed being used anonymously for research?

speaker: Pierre
text: Yes, totally.

speaker: Anna
text: Perfect. Thanks again for your time. I will stop the recording now.

speaker: Anna
text: Hi Noura, can you hear me well?

speaker: Noura
text: Yes, I can hear you. Can you hear me?

speaker: Anna
text: Yes, perfectly. Thanks for joining. Before we start, I want to check consent.

speaker: Anna
text: Is it okay if I record this interview? The recording is only for transcription. Everything will be anonymised, and you can skip any question.

speaker: Noura
text: Yes, that is okay. You can record.

speaker: Anna
text: Great. And just to remind you, if anything feels uncomfortable, you can say pass, or we can pause. Any topics you would prefer not to discuss?

speaker: Noura
text: Eehm, no, I think it is fine. Maybe not too many details about my company name, but otherwise okay.

speaker: Anna
text: Absolutely. We will keep it general. Could you also confirm your age and that you are based in Germany?

speaker: Noura
text: Yes. I am 23, and I live in Düsseldorf.

speaker: Anna
text: Perfect. Then we can start.

speaker: Anna
text: To begin, where are you currently in your career, and what career decisions or questions are you facing, or recently faced?

speaker: Noura
text: Okay. Um, so I am finishing my Ausbildung, and at the same time I do part-time studies, business administration. It is one of those dual-ish paths, but not the classic duales Studium, it is more like, Ausbildung in the company and then evening classes, weekend classes.

speaker: Noura
text: So it is a lot. I work as HR coordinator in a mid-size company here in Düsseldorf. We are like, not a startup, more like, established, maybe around 700 employees in Germany, and then also some international locations.

speaker: Anna
text: And your Ausbildung is in which occupation?

speaker: Noura
text: It is Kauffrau für Büromanagement, but I am placed in HR. So my official apprenticeship title is office management, but practically I am in HR operations. I chose it because I wanted something stable and also because my grades after school were okay, but I was not sure yet what I want to do long-term.

speaker: Noura
text: And the company offered me HR placement, so I was like, yes, this is interesting.

speaker: Anna
text: What does your current day-to-day look like in that HR coordinator role?

speaker: Noura
text: Eehm. A lot of scheduling. Like, interviews, onboarding appointments, Betriebsarzt appointments, trainings, and also contracts.

speaker: Noura
text: Not writing the whole contract alone, but preparing templates, checking if all documents are there, sending them to the manager for signature, tracking if the person returns it. And HR system stuff, like data entry in our HRIS, updating addresses, adding working hours, sick leave notes, Urlaub, all that. Plus many emails.

speaker: Noura
text: Stakeholders write to HR like, can you please urgently do this, and everything is always urgent. Also I support onboarding days. Like the first day, I prepare the welcome package, access badge, laptop request, and I coordinate with IT.

speaker: Noura
text: And then sometimes I help with training logistics, like booking rooms or Teams links, sending reminders.

speaker: Anna
text: That sounds like a lot of operational pressure.

speaker: Noura
text: Yes. And because I am still Ausbildung, people sometimes treat me like, you are just assisting, but then they still expect perfect accuracy. Like, if one number is wrong in a contract, it is a big problem.

speaker: Noura
text: And it is stressful because I am also studying. So I do work full-time, then I have two evenings of lectures, and sometimes Saturday. And then I try to also learn extra things because I want to move into people analytics or learning and development.

speaker: Noura
text: So it is like, three jobs.

speaker: Anna
text: You mentioned people analytics and learning and development. What drew you to those directions?

speaker: Noura
text: Um. People analytics first, because I noticed in HR there is so much talking and opinions. Like, managers say, oh we have too much sick leave because young people are lazy.

speaker: Noura
text: And I am like, maybe it is the shift schedule, maybe it is workload, maybe it is leadership. And I like the idea that you can look at data and make a better argument. Also I like Excel.

speaker: Noura
text: I know it is nerdy, but I like building tables, making it clean, seeing patterns. And L and D, I am also interested because I like helping people learn, but I am insecure about facilitation. Like if I stand in front and teach, I get nervous.

speaker: Noura
text: So L and D is attractive, but also scary. People analytics feels like, I can build credibility through numbers. But then I also feel like, do I really have the skills?

speaker: Anna
text: When you say you feel insecure about skills, what is the main insecurity?

speaker: Noura
text: That I lack real expertise or credibility. Like, I am HR coordinator, but I am not HR Business Partner. I do not do strategy.

speaker: Noura
text: I do not sit in leadership meetings. So sometimes when I think, oh I want to do people analytics, I am like, who am I to say anything? I do not even have access to all the data because of Datenschutz and because I am junior.

speaker: Noura
text: And then I see people on LinkedIn with titles like People Analytics Manager, and they have masters, they have statistics, they have Python, and I am like, I am just doing onboarding and contracts. So I feel behind.

speaker: Anna
text: What has been the most significant career decision in the last six to twelve months?

speaker: Noura
text: Hmm. The biggest one was deciding to not just stay in HR admin, but to actively ask for a project in analytics. Like, in summer, I had a moment where I was like, okay, I can finish Ausbildung and then just continue as HR admin, and it is stable.

speaker: Noura
text: My parents would like that, stable job, good company. But I felt like, if I do not move now, I will be stuck. So I asked my HR manager if I can support a project about turnover and onboarding quality.

speaker: Noura
text: It was not full people analytics, but it included some data. Like, we looked at how many people leave within the first six months, in which departments, and we tried to identify patterns.

speaker: Anna
text: How did it feel to ask for that?

speaker: Noura
text: Scary. Because I thought they will think I am annoying or I am overstepping. And also I was afraid they will ask me questions and I cannot answer.

speaker: Noura
text: But actually she reacted okay. She said, yes, we can try, but keep it small and make sure it does not affect your operational tasks. So I did it on top.

speaker: Noura
text: That is the story of my life.

speaker: Anna
text: What made the decision difficult?

speaker: Noura
text: Uncertainty. Like, is it realistic to go into people analytics without a full university degree first? And also fear of mistakes.

speaker: Noura
text: If I do a report and it is wrong, it will be embarrassing. And pressure because of studies. And also sometimes family expectations, not heavy, but like, they want me to finish something and have security.

speaker: Noura
text: My parents are from Syria, they came to Germany, they worked hard. So stability is important. They are proud that I have Ausbildung and I study, like, this is very German path, very respectable.

speaker: Noura
text: But when I say I want to do something like analytics, they are like, okay, but what job is that exactly? They want a clear label.

speaker: Anna
text: And what are you aiming for in the next six to twelve months?

speaker: Noura
text: Finish Ausbildung, for sure. It ends in summer. And then I will continue my part-time studies, maybe I have like, one and a half years left.

speaker: Noura
text: In the company, I want either a junior role with some development, like junior HR specialist with analytics tasks, or maybe I apply externally for a People Analytics Assistant role, something like that. But I am not sure. I also want to do at least one certification.

speaker: Noura
text: I was thinking either Power BI or basic SQL. Because I already use Excel, but I want to upgrade.

speaker: Anna
text: So the main questions are, stay internal versus apply outside, and which focus, people analytics versus L and D?

speaker: Noura
text: Yes. Exactly. And also, how to be taken seriously.

speaker: Noura
text: 3) Career support in general

speaker: Anna
text: When you need career support, who or what do you usually turn to?

speaker: Noura
text: Eehm. Friends a little bit, but my friends are also in Ausbildung or studies, so they are also confused. My family gives emotional support, like, they say you can do it, but they do not know HR market.

speaker: Noura
text: At work, I sometimes ask one colleague, she is like HR generalist, she is friendly. But I also do not want to bother her too much. Online resources, yes.

speaker: Noura
text: Like blogs, YouTube, sometimes German resources like Karrierebibel, but it can be very generic. And then LinkedIn, I tried outreach to mentors. Mixed results.

speaker: Noura
text: And AI tools, I use them a lot. Mainly for structuring learning plans and preparing interview answers. And also journaling with AI when I am stressed.

speaker: Noura
text: It feels non-judgmental. I can say anything without worrying about social acceptance.

speaker: Anna
text: When you think about what has actually helped, and what has been unhelpful, what comes to mind?

speaker: Noura
text: Helpful is when it is concrete. Like, someone says, do this next, and explains why. Unhelpful is when it is motivational, like, believe in yourself, and then nothing else.

speaker: Noura
text: Or when people judge. Like, if someone says, why did you not do university directly, why Ausbildung, like they imply it is less. That makes me shut down.

speaker: Anna
text: In your support sources, do you see any patterns about what you trust?

speaker: Noura
text: I trust when someone understands my context. Like, Germany context, Ausbildung, part-time studies. If someone is like, just do a master abroad, I am like, okay, but that is not helpful for me.

speaker: Noura
text: And I trust when they do not talk down to me. 4) Human coaching: experience and trust

speaker: Anna
text: Let us talk about the human side first. You mentioned LinkedIn outreach to mentors. Can you walk me through what you did and what happened?

speaker: Noura
text: Sure. Um, I started last year, around October, I think. I was seeing many posts about mentoring, and I felt like, okay, I do not have a network.

speaker: Noura
text: So I searched for people analytics roles in Germany. I filtered by Düsseldorf, Köln, sometimes Berlin because many roles are there. And then I looked for people who maybe also did Ausbildung or who wrote about non-traditional paths.

speaker: Noura
text: Then I wrote messages like, hi, I am Noura, I work in HR, I am doing Ausbildung plus part-time studies, I am interested in people analytics, could I ask you two questions or could we have a short call.

speaker: Anna
text: How many did you reach out to, roughly?

speaker: Noura
text: Maybe like, 20? Over time. Not all in one day.

speaker: Noura
text: Sometimes I wrote three, then I waited. Many did not reply.

speaker: Anna
text: Let us start with a positive interaction. Can you describe one contact that felt helpful and trustworthy?

speaker: Noura
text: Yes. There was one woman, she worked as People Analytics Specialist in a big retail company. Based in Köln.

speaker: Noura
text: She replied after two days, which already felt like, wow. She said, yes, I can do a 20-minute call, but please send me your questions first, so we can focus. That felt professional.

speaker: Noura
text: And also she wrote in German, but with a friendly tone, like, klar, machen wir.

speaker: Anna
text: What happened in the call?

speaker: Noura
text: We had a Teams call. I was nervous. She started with, tell me your story.

speaker: Noura
text: And I explained, Ausbildung, HR coordinator, part-time studies. And I said I feel not credible. And she said, listen, this path is not a weakness.

speaker: Noura
text: In Germany, Ausbildung is valued. And HR operations gives you understanding of processes and data quality, which is crucial for analytics. She made it sound like, you already have something relevant.

speaker: Anna
text: That sounds validating. What made it feel trustworthy beyond validation?

speaker: Noura
text: She was specific. She asked what HR system we use, what kind of data I touch, like, time tracking, absences, onboarding, recruitment pipeline. Then she said, okay, based on this, your first analytics projects can be descriptive, like dashboards for onboarding and turnover.

speaker: Noura
text: She explained data access challenges. She said, in Germany, Datenschutz is big, so you need to learn how to phrase questions. Like not, give me individual data, but aggregated patterns, and always ask, what decision will this support.

speaker: Noura
text: That was super practical.

speaker: Anna
text: Did she give you concrete next steps?

speaker: Noura
text: Yes. She said, for the next three months, pick one tool and go deep. For example, Power BI plus basic SQL.

speaker: Noura
text: She even suggested a learning order: first understand data tables and joins in SQL, then practice with sample HR datasets, then build dashboards. She also said to do a small internal project and document it, like a mini portfolio. And she offered to review my plan in one month by message.

speaker: Noura
text: That follow-up offer made me trust her more, because it was consistent.

speaker: Anna
text: What changed for you after that interaction?

speaker: Noura
text: I felt calmer. Like, okay, there is a path. And I asked my manager for that turnover project partly because of this call.

speaker: Noura
text: Also I started learning SQL basics. I used AI to make a plan, but her advice gave the direction. She also told me which skills are actually used day-to-day, not just trendy.

speaker: Noura
text: Like, she said, do not panic about Python at the beginning. Excel, SQL, Power BI, and communication is enough for entry.

speaker: Anna
text: Great. Now let us talk about a frustrating interaction.

speaker: Noura
text: Yes, there was one guy. He was like Head of People Analytics something. Very impressive profile.

speaker: Noura
text: I wrote him a message, and he replied like, sure, send your CV, I can give feedback. I was excited. I sent it.

speaker: Noura
text: Then he wrote back, very short, like, your profile is weak, you need a university degree, and HR admin is not real HR. It was harsh. And he said, also you should do internships in analytics, otherwise no chance.

speaker: Anna
text: How did that land with you?

speaker: Noura
text: Bad. I cried a bit. Not like, dramatic, but I felt ashamed.

speaker: Noura
text: Because it confirmed my fear. And the tone felt judging. He did not ask questions.

speaker: Noura
text: He did not understand that I am already working full-time. He just compared me to a standard path. Also he never answered again after that.

speaker: Noura
text: Like, he dropped the bomb and disappeared.

speaker: Anna
text: That is a strong example. What did it do to your willingness to seek human mentoring?

speaker: Noura
text: It made me hesitant. I was like, okay, maybe I should not ask people. It felt like, if I am not already perfect, they will judge.

speaker: Noura
text: And also, ghosting is common. Some people say, yes, let us schedule, then they never send times. Or they reply with generic lines like, keep learning, network more, and that is it.

speaker: Noura
text: That feels like, not effective.

speaker: Anna
text: When you think about trust drivers for humans, based on these experiences, what stands out?

speaker: Noura
text: For humans, trust is about feeling safe. Like, I can share insecurity without being laughed at. Confidentiality also, like, I do not want my colleagues to know I am planning to leave.

speaker: Noura
text: With a LinkedIn mentor, it is weird, because you do not know them. But still, you want discretion. Empathy, but also being taken seriously.

speaker: Noura
text: Practical knowledge, like understanding Germany HR market, privacy rules, what skills matter. And consistency, like if they say they will follow up, they do.

speaker: Anna
text: And what about distrust drivers?

speaker: Noura
text: Judgment, obvious. Also when they are too vague. Or when they push their own agenda, like, they want to sell coaching or courses.

speaker: Noura
text: And also mismatch, like they are in Berlin startup world and they cannot relate to Düsseldorf corporate HR.

speaker: Anna
text: You mentioned earlier that sometimes someone can be kind but not helpful. Do you have an example?

speaker: Noura
text: Yes. There was a woman, she was super kind. She wrote long messages like, you are doing great, you are strong, I believe in you.

speaker: Noura
text: Very sweet. But when I asked, okay, how do I move into people analytics, she said, just follow your passion, apply and it will happen. That was trusted in a way, because she was safe and kind.

speaker: Noura
text: But it was not effective. I ended the chat feeling warm, but still lost.

speaker: Anna
text: That is a clear trusted but not effective example.

speaker: Noura
text: Yes, exactly. 5) AI tools: experience and trust

speaker: Anna
text: Let us shift to AI tools. You said you have experience using AI for learning plans and interview answers, and also for journaling when stressed. Can you describe how you use it in practice?

speaker: Noura
text: Sure. I use, um, like conversational AI tools, mostly ChatGPT. Sometimes also the one in Microsoft, but mostly ChatGPT.

speaker: Noura
text: I use it in English, sometimes in German. My English is okay, especially for work topics. German is my everyday language, but for structured stuff, I sometimes prefer English because the output feels more direct.

speaker: Noura
text: Arabic I speak with my family, but I do not use it for career stuff.

speaker: Anna
text: And what are the typical tasks you use AI for?

speaker: Noura
text: Learning plan: like, I say, I have 6 hours per week, I want to learn SQL and Power BI, I have HR background, make me a 8-week plan with topics and small exercises. Or I say, explain joins like I am beginner, and give me practice questions. Also for interviews: I paste a job description and my CV, and ask for possible interview questions and STAR answers.

speaker: Noura
text: Then I practice. And journaling: when I am stressed, I write like, I feel overwhelmed, I feel stupid, I feel like I am failing. And it responds in a calm way.

speaker: Noura
