text: It asks me questions. It is non-judgmental. That is the key.

speaker: Noura
text: I can say anything without worrying about social acceptance. If I tell my friend, I feel stupid, they might say, no you are not, stop. But with AI, I can be messy.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you describe a specific stress moment where you used AI journaling, and what it did for you emotionally?

speaker: Noura
text: Yes. There was a day in November. I had work, and then lecture, and then I got an email from a manager saying, why is the contract wrong, this is unacceptable.

speaker: Noura
text: And it was a small mistake in start date format, but he wrote very angry. I felt my stomach drop. And then after lecture, I came home at like 22:30, and I was shaking.

speaker: Noura
text: I was like, I cannot do this, I am not good enough. So I opened AI chat and wrote everything. Like, I am overwhelmed, I make mistakes, people think I am incompetent, I want to quit.

speaker: Noura
text: And it responded like, it reflected my feelings, and it said, this is a stressful environment, mistakes happen, and it asked me to separate facts from interpretations. It asked, what exactly happened, what is the evidence that you are incompetent, what would you say to a friend. It felt like guided journaling.

speaker: Anna
text: And what changed after that?

speaker: Noura
text: I felt relief. Like, I could breathe. It made me calmer.

speaker: Noura
text: Not magically happy, but calmer. And then it helped me write a professional reply to the manager. Like, short, acknowledging the correction, and then I fixed it.

speaker: Noura
text: So it was emotional regulation plus practical.

speaker: Anna
text: When you think about trust in AI, what makes you trust it, and what makes you not trust it?

speaker: Noura
text: Trust drivers for AI: it is always available. It is non-judgmental. It helps structure.

speaker: Noura
text: It can break down a big thing into steps. It also does not get tired of my questions. For example, joins, I ask five times, it still answers.

speaker: Noura
text: But trust issues: accuracy varies. Sometimes it is too confident. Like it says something and it sounds right, but it is not.

speaker: Noura
text: And privacy uncertainty exists. I do not paste very sensitive company data. I do not put names or internal numbers.

speaker: Noura
text: But still, you wonder, where does it go.

speaker: Anna
text: Do you have an example of a moment AI helped with a learning plan, something concrete?

speaker: Noura
text: Yes. In December, I wanted to learn SQL, but I was overwhelmed by all resources. I asked AI: I am HR coordinator, I want people analytics, I have basic Excel, no coding, 6 hours per week, make me a plan.

speaker: Noura
text: It gave me weekly topics: week one, select statements, filtering, sorting. Week two, group by and aggregates. Week three, joins.

speaker: Noura
text: Week four, subqueries. Then it suggested small HR examples, like, employee table, absence table. That made it feel relevant.

speaker: Noura
text: Then I followed it and I created a small fake dataset in Excel, and I practiced queries. It gave me exercises like, find departments with highest turnover. That was fun.

speaker: Noura
text: It also suggested to track progress and do mini projects. So I built a small dashboard in Power BI with a sample dataset. That gave me confidence.

speaker: Anna
text: And a moment AI did not help?

speaker: Noura
text: Many. One moment: I asked for a plan, and it was generic. Like, learn statistics, learn Python, learn machine learning, build portfolio, network, apply.

speaker: Noura
text: It was like, everything. And I was like, okay, this is not realistic. Another moment: I asked about German HR data privacy rules, like what is allowed for analytics, and it gave a confident answer that sounded like legal advice.

speaker: Noura
text: And I was like, hmm, I am not sure. It did not mention Betriebsrat involvement properly. So I realized, okay, this can be wrong.

speaker: Noura
text: It can also make assumptions. Like it assumes you can access data easily, but in my company, access is restricted.

speaker: Anna
text: So effective sometimes, but you double-check.

speaker: Noura
text: Yes. It can be effective but not fully trusted. Like, it gives useful structure, but I verify.

speaker: Noura
text: 6) Human vs AI comparison via specific tasks

speaker: Anna
text: I want to compare human versus AI through specific tasks. Let us take CV and interview preparation first. For that, what feels more useful, human support or AI?

speaker: Noura
text: AI is more useful for speed. Like, I can paste my CV and job description and get questions, and it gives me drafts. It also helps me phrase things in a more professional way, especially in English.

speaker: Noura
text: But I do not fully trust it, because sometimes it exaggerates. It adds skills I do not have. So I have to correct.

speaker: Noura
text: Human is useful for realism. Like, the mentor from Köln told me, do not try to be everything, focus on what is credible. That is human judgment.

speaker: Noura
text: But I do not always have access to humans. So AI wins for availability.

speaker: Anna
text: How about deciding between people analytics and L and D? Which helps more?

speaker: Noura
text: For deep decision, human helps more, if the human is good. Because they can ask questions, they can understand values, and they can challenge gently. AI can ask questions too, but it sometimes feels scripted.

speaker: Noura
text: Still, AI is good for exploring. Like, I can say, give me pros and cons, give me day-to-day tasks, give me possible entry roles. That is helpful.

speaker: Anna
text: And for learning plans?

speaker: Noura
text: AI is very effective for learning plans. It is like a personal tutor. But sometimes it is too broad.

speaker: Noura
text: Human can also help, but most humans will not sit and build a weekly plan with you. So AI is better.

speaker: Anna
text: For emotional support, like stress and confidence?

speaker: Noura
text: This is interesting. AI journaling is surprisingly good for immediate calming, because it is non-judgmental. Human support is deeper, but also risky.

speaker: Noura
text: Like, with humans, you worry about being judged. With AI, you can say anything. But then human can give real empathy, like tone, facial expression, and also you know they are a person.

speaker: Noura
text: AI empathy feels like, simulated. Still, it works on me sometimes.

speaker: Anna
text: For navigating workplace politics or stakeholder issues?

speaker: Noura
text: Human is better, because they know context. AI can give templates, like how to write an email, how to set boundaries. But humans can say, in Germany, with Betriebsrat, you must consider this.

speaker: Noura
text: AI can miss nuance.

speaker: Anna
text: Do you feel you trust humans more overall, or AI more overall?

speaker: Noura
text: Hmm. Overall I trust humans more for high-stakes decisions, but I trust AI more for private messy thoughts. Because humans can judge.

speaker: Noura
text: 7) Trust–effectiveness link (including micro-poll ratings)

speaker: Anna
text: Now I want to explore the link between trust and effectiveness in your experience. When you think about human support, like mentors or coaches, how does trust affect whether it is effective?

speaker: Noura
text: Trust is like, the door. If I trust, I share the real problem. Like I can say, I feel not credible, I am afraid.

speaker: Noura
text: If I do not trust, I will just ask surface questions, like, what course should I do. Then the advice is surface. So trust enables depth, and depth makes it effective.

speaker: Anna
text: And if you do not trust, what happens?

speaker: Noura
text: I filter myself. I try to look strong. Then I do not get help with the real thing.

speaker: Noura
text: So it is less effective.

speaker: Anna
text: How about AI? How does trust affect effectiveness there?

speaker: Noura
text: With AI, if I do not trust accuracy, I do not follow the advice. I might still use it as brainstorming. Like, it can be effective as a mirror, even if I do not trust it as truth.

speaker: Noura
text: But if it makes a wrong assumption, it can confuse me. So trust in AI is more like, trust in reliability and boundaries. If I know it is good for structuring, then it is effective for that.

speaker: Noura
text: If I mistakenly trust it for legal topics, it can be harmful. So I keep it in its lane.

speaker: Anna
text: That is a nice way to put it, keep it in its lane. I would like to include a quick micro-poll. I will ask for ratings from 0 to 10.

speaker: Anna
text: 0 means no trust at all, 10 means complete trust. First, your current trust in human coaches or mentors for career support, generally. What number comes to mind?

speaker: Noura
text: Um. Maybe 6.

speaker: Anna
text: Why 6?

speaker: Noura
text: Because I had one good experience, which raises it. But many people ghost or judge, or give generic advice. So I cannot say 8 or 9.

speaker: Noura
text: But it is not 2, because humans can be very helpful if the match is right. So 6.

speaker: Anna
text: Next, your trust in AI tools for career-related support, 0 to 10.

speaker: Noura
text: I would say 7.

speaker: Anna
text: Interesting, slightly higher. Why 7?

speaker: Noura
text: Because it is consistent in being available and non-judgmental. And for structuring and interview prep, it is usually helpful. But I do not give it 9 because accuracy varies and privacy is uncertain.

speaker: Noura
text: So 7.

speaker: Anna
text: Now perceived effectiveness. For your situation specifically, how effective has human support been, 0 to 10?

speaker: Noura
text: Hmm. Maybe 5.

speaker: Anna
text: Why 5?

speaker: Noura
text: Because the good mentor gave me direction, but overall, I did not get ongoing support. And some interactions made me feel worse. So the net effect is medium.

speaker: Noura
text: If I had a good coach consistently, it could be higher.

speaker: Anna
text: And perceived effectiveness of AI tools for your situation, 0 to 10?

speaker: Noura
text: I would say 8.

speaker: Anna
text: Why 8?

speaker: Noura
text: Because I actually use it weekly, and it gives me concrete things: learning plan, practice, interview answers, email drafts, journaling. It reduces stress. It helps me make progress.

speaker: Noura
text: But I keep one point off because sometimes it is wrong or too generic, and I need to double-check.

speaker: Anna
text: Great. Thank you. You already gave one example of trusted but not effective, the kind mentor with vague advice.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you give an example of effective but not fully trusted, besides the legal topic?

speaker: Noura
text: Yes. Interview answers. AI can generate very strong answers, like perfect STAR stories.

speaker: Noura
text: It is effective as a template. But I do not fully trust it, because it can make me sound like someone else. And sometimes it adds metrics that I cannot prove.

speaker: Noura
text: So it is useful, but I have to edit. So it is effective, but not trusted as final truth.

speaker: Anna
text: That makes sense. 8) Preferences and hybrid model reaction

speaker: Anna
text: Now imagine a hybrid model where AI supports you for preparation, reflection, and structuring, and then a human mentor or coach steps in for key decisions, context, and accountability. How does that sound to you?

speaker: Noura
text: Honestly, that sounds ideal. Because I want the speed and privacy of AI, but I also want human validation and reality check. Especially for credibility questions.

speaker: Noura
text: Like, am I on the right track, am I overselling, is this realistic in Germany.

speaker: Anna
text: What would you want the AI part to do, and what would you want the human part to do?

speaker: Noura
text: AI part: learning plan, practice questions, explain concepts, help me draft applications, help me reflect when stressed, help me prepare for interviews. Also help me organize options, like list roles, required skills, timeline. Human part: feedback on my plan, like, is it too ambitious, is it missing something.

speaker: Noura
text: Also help me with identity and confidence, but in a real way. And networking guidance. Like, in Düsseldorf HR market, which companies have people analytics teams, how to approach them.

speaker: Noura
text: And also accountability, like, check in with me, did you do the plan, adjust.

speaker: Anna
text: What would make you trust a human in such a hybrid model?

speaker: Noura
text: Feeling safe, confidentiality, empathy, being taken seriously, practical knowledge, and consistency. And also transparency about their background. Like, are they really experienced in people analytics or L and D, or are they general career coach who knows nothing about HR.

speaker: Noura
text: I want someone who understands HR.

speaker: Anna
text: And what would make you trust the AI part more?

speaker: Noura
text: Clear boundaries and transparency, like what it is good at and what not. Also privacy clarity. And maybe sources.

speaker: Noura
text: Like, if it says, in Germany, HR analytics often requires this, and it links to something credible, that would help. Also if it remembers my context correctly. Sometimes it forgets, and then it gives advice that does not fit.

speaker: Anna
text: How do you feel about the idea that AI could match you to a human mentor based on your goals and preferences?

speaker: Noura
text: That would be great, because LinkedIn outreach is random. You do not know who will reply, and you cannot see if they are actually supportive. If there was matching, like, you can choose someone with a similar path, or someone who is not judgmental, that would help trust.

speaker: Anna
text: What are your concerns about a hybrid model?

speaker: Noura
text: Cost. Because I am early career, I do not have money for expensive coaching. Also quality control.

speaker: Noura
text: Like, how do you ensure the human is good and not just motivational. And time. If the human is not responsive, it ruins it.

speaker: Noura
text: Also data privacy: if AI collects my information and shares it with a human, I would want control. Like, I want to decide what is shared.

speaker: Anna
text: If you could design the ideal experience, how would it work?

speaker: Noura
text: I would start with AI onboarding, like I explain my situation, my constraints, Ausbildung, part-time studies, Düsseldorf, HR coordinator, goals. Then AI suggests a few paths and learning plan. Then it suggests three mentors that fit.

speaker: Noura
text: I choose one. Then I have a short call with the mentor, like 30 minutes, to validate plan and set goals. Then AI supports me weekly with tasks.

speaker: Noura
text: Then every month, a human check-in, like, adjust and reflect. That would be perfect.

speaker: Anna
text: Would you prefer the human check-ins to be video, or chat, or voice?

speaker: Noura
text: Video, at least sometimes. Because trust builds with seeing the person. But sometimes chat is okay for quick questions.

speaker: Noura
text: A mix.

speaker: Anna
text: If you had to choose only one, only AI or only human, which would you pick right now?

speaker: Noura
text: Right now, only AI. Because I actually have access and it helps me. Human is too uncertain.

speaker: Noura
text: But ideally, hybrid.

speaker: Anna
text: That is very clear. 9. Closing

speaker: Anna
text: Before we end, is there anything important about your experience with career support, trust, or effectiveness that we did not cover?

speaker: Noura
text: Maybe one thing. Um. In Germany, there is this feeling of career ladder and titles.

speaker: Noura
text: Like, people want you to have the correct degree for the correct job. And that makes me insecure. So any support that understands that, and helps me translate my path into credible story, that is what I need.

speaker: Noura
text: AI helps me write the story. Human helps me believe it.

speaker: Anna
text: That is a strong closing point. If you think about the next month, what is one concrete step you want to take?

speaker: Noura
text: Finish my SQL basics module, like, consistent. And also maybe ask at work if I can get access to some aggregated data for another small analysis, like training participation. Something small.

speaker: Anna
text: Great. Thank you, Noura. I will stop the recording now.

speaker: Anna
text: And thank you again for sharing, especially the difficult parts.

speaker: Anna
text: I am glad. Have a good evening.

speaker: Noura
text: You too. Bye.

speaker: Anna
text: Hi Slava. Thanks for joining. Before we start, do I have your permission to record?

speaker: Anna
text: Everything is anonymous, you can skip any question, and you can stop at any time.

speaker: Slava
text: Yes, you have my permission. Recording is okay. And thanks for saying I can skip.

speaker: Slava
text: That helps already. Um.

speaker: Anna
text: Good. Just to confirm, we will use a pseudonym and remove any identifying details like company name or exact people. If I ask something that feels too sensitive, just tell me and we move on.

speaker: Anna
text: Any topics you prefer not to discuss today?

speaker: Slava
text: Maybe, eehm, nothing super specific. I just do not want to talk about like exact incident names, like safety incidents with names, because it gets tricky. But general, yes, we can talk.

speaker: Anna
text: Perfect. We will keep it general. And I might interrupt lightly to clarify, but I will try not to lead you.

speaker: Anna
text: Ready?

speaker: Slava
text: Yes. Ready. 2) Participant context and career situation

speaker: Anna
text: To start, where are you currently in your career, and what career decisions or questions are you facing right now?

speaker: Slava
text: Okay. So, I am 30. I am from Poland originally.

speaker: Slava
text: I moved to Germany eight years ago, first to Dresden actually, and then Leipzig. Now I am in Leipzig since, I think, six years. I work in logistics operations for a big retail chain.

speaker: Slava
text: Like, everyone knows it, but I will not say the name. It is large, nationwide. I work in a distribution center that supplies stores in the region.

speaker: Slava
text: And my role now is operations manager, like a logistics operations manager. I manage multiple shifts, multiple areas, like inbound, outbound, picking, also some returns. It is, um, high pressure.

speaker: Slava
text: My main question right now is: do I continue in operations and go up, like senior operations, site lead path, or do I try to move into consulting or strategy, like internal strategy team or external consulting. And it sounds, like, clean when I say it, but emotionally it is not clean at all.

speaker: Anna
text: What makes it not clean emotionally?

speaker: Slava
text: Because operations is my identity now. I am good at it. I have a reputation.

speaker: Slava
text: Like, if you ask people, they say Slava delivers. And I do. But I am also close to burnout.

speaker: Slava
text: And I can feel it. And the idea of consulting is like, maybe more intellectual, maybe more control, maybe more future options. But also it is like fantasy and reality mixed.

speaker: Slava
text: So I am in this tension.

speaker: Anna
text: When did this tension become sharp for you? Was there a trigger moment?

speaker: Slava
text: Yes. In the last, maybe, nine months. It got really sharp in, I would say, spring and summer.

speaker: Slava
text: Because we had, like, a reorganization. And we also had higher sick leave. Krankenstand was crazy.

speaker: Slava
text: And we had pressure from headquarters because costs. Also, service level had to stay high. So basically the same output with less people and less overtime.

speaker: Slava
text: That is always the joke, right.

speaker: Anna
text: You mentioned you are close to burnout. How do you notice it in yourself?

speaker: Slava
text: Sleep. First sleep. I wake up at 3:40 or 4:10 and my brain is already running.

speaker: Slava
text: Like I open eyes and it is already a shift plan in my head. Or it is like, what if the sorter stops, what if the last mile carrier rejects volume, what if we miss the cut-off. And then I cannot fall asleep again.

speaker: Slava
text: Then irritability. I snap. Not always at people, but like internally I am angry.

speaker: Slava
text: Also with my partner I am less patient. Small things annoy me, like the dishwasher not loaded correctly. It is stupid.

speaker: Anna
text: Oh

speaker: Slava
text: And then constant firefighting. Even when I am not at work, I check my phone. There are WhatsApp messages and Teams messages.

speaker: Slava
text: I try not to, but I do. Weekend messages. I have this feeling like I am always responsible.

speaker: Slava
text: Like a weight.

speaker: Slava
text: Also physical. I have shoulder tension, headaches, and I started to get like stomach issues. Not dramatic but you feel it.

speaker: Slava
text: My partner says, you are not present. You are there but not there.

speaker: Anna
text: That sounds heavy. In the last 6 to 12 months, what was the biggest career decision you made?

speaker: Slava
text: The biggest decision was whether to accept a promotion to take over another area, like a bigger scope. It was like, okay, you become responsible for outbound plus last mile coordination, not only warehouse outbound. That means more stakeholders, more stress, but also more visibility.

speaker: Slava
text: And I said yes. And now I am like, why did I say yes. But also, I learned a lot.

speaker: Anna
text: What made that decision difficult at the time?

speaker: Slava
text: I felt like if I say no, it means I am not ambitious. And I have this thing, maybe from Poland, like, you come to Germany, you want to prove yourself. You want to show you are not the immigrant guy who is lucky to have a job.

speaker: Slava
text: You know. So I said yes. Also, money.

speaker: Slava
text: It was not huge, but it was something. And status. And also, I had a good relationship with my boss.

speaker: Slava
text: He was like, I believe in you. So I did not want to disappoint. But the difficult part was I already felt tired.

speaker: Slava
text: Like, I already felt, okay, I am at 80 percent capacity. And then I took 120 percent scope. That is not smart.

speaker: Anna
text: What kind of support did you feel you needed during that decision?

speaker: Slava
text: Someone to help me think with distance. Like, is this good for you, not only for career. And also someone who understands operations, because many people just say, take the promotion, it is good.

speaker: Slava
text: But they do not understand what it means, like shift calls at night, escalation, works council topics, staffing chaos.

speaker: Anna
text: When you say you did not have that person, does that relate to mentoring or coaching experiences?

speaker: Slava
text: Yes.

speaker: Anna
text: When you need career support, who or what do you usually turn to?

speaker: Slava
text: Eehm. Usually, long walks. That is my main.

speaker: Slava
text: I walk along the canal, Karl-Heine-Kanal, or in Auwald. I just walk, like one hour, two hours, sometimes more. And I think.

speaker: Slava
text: It is like processing. Second, I talk to my partner. She is German, from Saxony, and she is in healthcare, like not HR.

speaker: Slava
text: But she is good at listening. And she tells me when I am making stupid assumptions.And she helps me calm down.

speaker: Anna
text: Anything else?

speaker: Slava
text: I use AI tools, a lot, but more for planning, scenario analysis, writing. Not for self reflection. I do not like to tell a chat my feelings.

speaker: Slava
text: It feels, I do not know, sterile.

speaker: Slava
text: Also friends. But friends are not really helpful for career strategy because they are either in similar stress or they just say, it will be fine. Which is supportive but not helpful.

speaker: Slava
text: I mean, no wait, let me rephrase. Friends help emotionally, but not with clarity.

speaker: Anna
text: Do you use any formal career services, like university services, networks, professional coaching?

speaker: Slava
text: Not now. I used to, like, early on I had one mentor. That was the only structured thing.

speaker: Slava
text: After that, nothing structured. I sometimes watch videos, podcasts, like consulting content, or operations leadership content. But it is not like a person.

speaker: Anna
text: What has actually helped in the past, and what felt unhelpful or frustrating?

speaker: Slava
text: Helped: my early mentor, and also some managers who gave direct feedback. Like, German directness sometimes is painful, but it can be helpful. Unhelpful like, find your passion.

speaker: Slava
text: Or, just apply. Or, work life balance is important. Like, ja, danke.

speaker: Slava
text: That does not solve anything. Also, sometimes HR internal programs are more like checkbox. They say you can move internally, but then there is no real path.

speaker: Anna
text: If you think about the kind of support you wish you had now, what is missing?

speaker: Slava
text: A mentor who understands business roles and also understands psychology. Like someone with psychologist background who works in HR, or a full time career mentor who has business context. Because I need both.

speaker: Slava
text: I need someone who can help me regulate, like, stress, emotions, and also someone who can say, okay, consulting is like this, strategy is like this, your skills transfer like this, here is a plan. And I do not know where to find that. 4) Human coaching: experience and trust

speaker: Anna
text: You mentioned one powerful mentoring relationship early in your career. Can you tell me that story? How did you meet, what made it powerful?

speaker: Slava
text: Yes. It was when I moved to Germany. I started in warehouse, like entry level.

speaker: Slava
text: I was doing picking, then I became team lead. I was hungry, like, I wanted to learn everything. I was also insecure because my German was not good.

speaker: Slava
text: I had like B1, maybe B2, but in logistics slang it is different. My mentor was a manager in the site, not my direct boss, but like one level above. He noticed me because I was always asking questions, and also I was doing like small improvements.

speaker: Slava
text: Like I made a simple Excel to track some errors and root causes. Nothing crazy. But he saw it.

speaker: Slava
text: He invited me for coffee. And at first I thought, okay, I am in trouble. Because in warehouse, if a manager calls you, it is usually not good.

speaker: Slava
text: But he said, no, I just see potential.We met every two weeks. Sometimes in the canteen, sometimes outside. He would ask me, what do you want, what do you struggle with.

speaker: Slava
text: And he was very direct. He said, you are fast and smart, but you are also, how to say, too eager to please. And he said, you need to learn boundaries, and you need to learn stakeholder management, not just doing work.

speaker: Anna
text: What did he do that created trust for you?

speaker: Slava
text: First, confidentiality. He explicitly said, what we talk stays here, unless you want me to escalate something. That was big for me.

speaker: Slava
text: Because I was afraid to look weak.Second, he understood the context. He knew operations. He knew the pressure.

speaker: Slava
text: He knew KPIs. So when I said, I feel overwhelmed, he did not say, take a vacation. He said, okay, what is the load, what can be delegated, what is system problem.

speaker: Slava
text: Also he challenged me. Not only empathy. He would say, you complain but you also create your own chaos.

speaker: Slava
text: And it was true. He made me see patterns. Also, he remembered details.

speaker: Slava
text: Like, next time he asked, how was your night shift, what happened with that supervisor. Feeling seen. That is trust for me.

speaker: Anna
text: Do you remember a specific moment or feedback that stayed with you?

speaker: Slava
text: Yes. There was one moment, I had a conflict with a German supervisor. He thought I was too pushy, too direct.

speaker: Slava
text: I thought he was lazy. It was messy. I came to mentor and I was like, he does not respect me because I am Polish.

speaker: Slava
text: I was angry. And my mentor listened. Then he said, okay, maybe.

speaker: Slava
text: But also maybe you are communicating like in Poland, more like, do it now, and in Germany, people want more context, more agreement. Especially with works council culture. He said, if you want respect, you need to speak in their logic.

speaker: Slava
text: Use facts, use process, not emotion. And he taught me how to have that conversation. He even role played with me, like, what to say, how to say.

speaker: Slava
text: And after I did it, the relationship improved. It was not perfect, but it was better. And I learned something: trust is not only being nice, it is being helpful in a concrete way.

speaker: Anna
text: What changed in your career after that mentoring relationship?

speaker: Slava
text: A lot. I got moved to a better role. I became shift manager earlier than I would.

speaker: Slava
text: And I also got confidence. Like, I started to feel I belong. And also I learned to think bigger, not only day to day.

speaker: Anna
text: And then you said after that, nothing structured. What happened?

speaker: Slava
text: He left the company. He moved to another city. And after that, the culture changed.

speaker: Slava
text: New leadership. And I also moved to Leipzig. In Leipzig, I had good bosses but no one like that.

speaker: Slava
text: Also I became more senior, so people assume you do not need help. But actually you need more.

speaker: Anna
text: Today, when you think of having a mentor or coach, what would you expect? And what would make you trust them?

speaker: Slava
text: I would expect structure. Like, not just random talks. A process.

speaker: Slava
text: Maybe goals. Accountability. Trust drivers for human: confidentiality, feeling seen, empathy plus challenge, and industry understanding.

speaker: Slava
text: Also not judging burnout. If someone is like, you are weak, then no. I need someone who can say, burnout risk is real, but also, you have choices.

speaker: Slava
text: And I want someone who understands Germany context. Like, works councils, Betriebsrat, sick leave norms, and also internal mobility. Because sometimes advice from US content is like, just quit.

speaker: Slava
text: That is not realistic.

speaker: Anna
text: Have you ever had a human support that you trusted, but it was not effective?

speaker: Slava
text: Yes. My partner, sometimes. I trust her fully.

speaker: Slava
text: She is very supportive. But if I ask, should I move to consulting, she cannot answer. She can help me calm down, but she cannot give steps.

speaker: Slava
text: So I trust, but not effective for that specific task. And also friends. They are loyal, but they do not move me forward.

speaker: Anna
text: That distinction is helpful. Anything else you want to add about what you do not want in a human coach?

speaker: Slava
text: I do not want someone who is too soft and just validates. I also do not want someone who is like a guru. I want practical.

speaker: Slava
text: And I want someone who can handle complexity. And I want boundaries, like, what they can do, what they cannot do. 5) AI tools: experience and trust

speaker: Anna
text: Let us shift to AI tools. You said you use AI heavily for planning, scenario analysis, and writing reports. Can you walk me through how you actually use it in your work?

speaker: Slava
text: Yes. So I use AI almost daily. For example, peak season planning.

speaker: Slava
text: We have like Easter peak, summer peak, and then Christmas, Black Friday, all that. We need to forecast volume, staffing, overtime, temp agency. I take historical data, like shipments, order lines, pick rate, absenteeism.

speaker: Slava
text: I put it in my own spreadsheets. Then I use AI to help me think through scenarios. Like, if volume increases 12 percent, and sick leave stays at 8 percent, what staffing do I need to maintain OTIF.

speaker: Slava
text: Or if we cannot get enough temps, what levers do we have. AI helps me structure options and risks. Also risk logs.

speaker: Slava
text: Like, we do weekly risk register. AI helps me write it cleaner, more executive language. Because operations people write messy.

speaker: Slava
text: I am included. And report writing. Every week I send an update to regional director.

speaker: Slava
text: It must be crisp. AI helps with rewriting, making it more structured, less emotional. Also incident postmortems.

speaker: Slava
text: When a sorter breaks and we miss cut-off, we do a postmortem. AI helps me create a template: timeline, root cause, corrective actions, preventive actions.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you give one moment where AI helped a lot?

speaker: Slava
text: Yes. Last year, like October, we had a problem with last mile carrier capacity. They suddenly reduced trucks due to driver shortage.

speaker: Slava
text: And we had store deliveries at risk. My boss asked me to prepare an escalation message to headquarters and also propose mitigation plan, within like two hours. I had all the messy notes.

speaker: Slava
text: I used AI to structure it: situation, impact, options, recommendation, request. It produced a very clear message. I still edited, but it saved me, honestly.

speaker: Slava
text: And the tone was better than my angry tone. Also it suggested a mitigation I did not think: shifting some volume to alternative cross-dock in the region, even if cost is higher, for only two weeks. We did something similar.

speaker: Slava
text: So it helped.

speaker: Anna
text: And one moment where AI failed, or felt risky?

speaker: Slava
text: Yes. Two things. First, hallucinated numbers.

speaker: Slava
text: I once asked it to summarize a dataset and I gave it like a table. And it confidently said, absenteeism decreased by 3 percent, but actually it increased. It misunderstood.

speaker: Slava
text: And if I would copy paste that, I would look stupid. So I learned: never trust numbers unless I verify. Also confidentiality and senses.

speaker: Slava
text: We have works council topics, like shift patterns, overtime, performance. If I put too much detail into AI, it is risky. Also HR sensitivity.

speaker: Slava
text: For example, I wanted to write a note about a supervisor performance issue. AI suggested language that was too direct, like, terminate or replace. In Germany, you cannot just say that.

speaker: Slava
text: Also it can create legal issues. So I do not use AI for personal HR cases. I keep it for general structure and anonymized.

speaker: Anna
text: So when you talk about trust in AI, what drives it for you?

speaker: Slava
text: Speed, structure, low effort. It is always available. Also it is consistent.

speaker: Slava
text: And it does not judge. Like, if I ask stupid question, it does not laugh. But emotional safety is limited.

speaker: Slava
text: And nuance is limited. Also, it can be overconfident. So trust is conditional.

speaker: Slava
text: I trust it to help me draft, structure, brainstorm. I do not trust it as final truth.

speaker: Anna
text: You said you do not use AI for self reflection. Can you explain why? What do long walks and partner talks give you instead?

speaker: Slava
text: Yes. AI feels like talking into a mirror that answers. But it is not a human.

speaker: Slava
text: For self reflection, I need silence. I need my body to calm down. When I walk, my nervous system goes down.

speaker: Slava
text: I breathe. I notice things. I remember what actually matters.

speaker: Slava
text: And with my partner, I get real feedback. She can see my face. She can say, you are lying to yourself.

speaker: Slava
text: AI cannot do that in the same way. Also, there is intimacy. Like, I can be weak.

speaker: Slava
text: I do not want to be weak with a tool. Even if it is safe, it feels weird. Also I do not want to create habit of outsourcing my feelings.

speaker: Slava
text: I want to process them myself. Maybe it is old school. 6.

speaker: Slava
text: Human vs AI comparison via specific tasks

speaker: Anna
text: I want to compare human and AI via concrete tasks. I will name a task and you tell me which you would prefer and why. First: writing a report for senior leadership about weekly performance and risks.

speaker: Slava
text: AI first. Because it can structure fast. I still verify.

speaker: Slava
text: But AI is effective there. Human mentor would be slower, and also they would not be in my inbox at 23:00. AI is.

speaker: Anna
text: Second: scenario planning for peak season staffing and capacity.

speaker: Slava
text: AI plus me. Like, AI helps generate scenarios, but I need domain knowledge. A human could help if they have operations background, but it is rare.

speaker: Slava
text: Most coaches do not know picking rate and cut-off times. So AI is more practical.

speaker: Anna
text: Third: deciding whether to move from operations into consulting or strategy.

speaker: Slava
text: Human. 100 percent. AI can give pros and cons, but it cannot feel my situation.

speaker: Slava
text: It cannot challenge my avoidance. It cannot hold me accountable.

speaker: Anna
text: Fourth: preparing a CV and cover letter for consulting roles.

speaker: Slava
text: AI for drafting and structure, human for positioning. Like, AI can make it pretty, but human mentor can say, this is the story, this is credible, this is what consulting wants. AI can guess, but it is generic.

speaker: Anna
text: Fifth: practicing an interview, especially case interview style.

speaker: Slava
text: Hybrid. AI for practice questions and feedback quick. Human for real pressure, like, interrupting, probing, seeing if I am confident.

speaker: Slava
text: Also human can tell if I sound like operations guy who is hiding insecurity.

speaker: Anna
text: Sixth: managing your burnout risk and boundaries at work.

speaker: Slava
text: Human. Because I need empathy plus challenge. AI can suggest time management tips, but it will not handle the messy reality, like my boss calling, or works council conflict, or guilt.

speaker: Slava
text: Human can.

speaker: Anna
text: Is there any area where you feel AI is effective even if you do not fully trust it?

speaker: Slava
text: Yes. Report writing. Sometimes it produces a very strong narrative.

speaker: Slava
text: It sounds confident, like consultant language. It is effective. But I do not fully trust it.

speaker: Slava
text: I verify every claim. So it is like, effective output, but trust is partial. I rely on it as a tool, not as authority.

speaker: Anna
text: And is there any area where you trust a human but they might not be effective?

speaker: Slava
text: Yes, like I said, supportive people who listen but do not give steps. Also, some managers who are nice but they do not have time. They say, yeah, you can move internally, and then nothing happens.

speaker: Slava
text: I trust they mean well, but it is not effective. 7) Trust–effectiveness link

speaker: Anna
text: Now I want to explore the link between trust and effectiveness in your experience. When you think about human mentoring or coaching, how does trust affect whether it is effective?

speaker: Slava
text: Trust is like entry ticket. If I do not trust, I will not say the real thing. I will say the safe version.

speaker: Slava
text: Like, I am busy. Not like, I am scared, or I feel trapped, or I fantasize about leaving because I hate this. If I do not trust, then the coach works on surface.When I trusted my mentor early on, I told him, I feel like outsider, I feel angry, I feel insecure.

speaker: Slava
text: And then he could help. So trust enables depth. Depth enables effectiveness.

speaker: Anna
text: What are your indicators that mentoring or coaching is effective for you?

speaker: Slava
text: Concrete steps. Not only feelings. Like, after a session, I want a plan: this week do X, next week do Y.

speaker: Slava
text: Also reduced overwhelm. Like, I feel lighter, I can breathe. Better decisions.

speaker: Slava
text: Like, I stop looping in my head and I choose. Also energy. If coaching is effective, I have more energy, not less.

speaker: Slava
text: And for transition, effectiveness would mean: credible plan to move, maybe applications sent, interviews, or at least informational interviews. Not only dreaming.

speaker: Anna
text: And how does trust affect effectiveness with AI tools for you?

speaker: Slava
text: Different. With AI, trust is more like reliability. If I see it makes mistakes, I trust less, so I verify more.

speaker: Slava
text: Effectiveness can still be high because it saves time, but trust changes how I use it. Also if I do not trust it with confidentiality, I will not put sensitive info. So it limits usefulness.

speaker: Slava
text: For example, I cannot ask it, how to handle this specific works council conflict, because I cannot share details. So trust boundaries reduce effectiveness.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you name the main trust drivers for AI in your case, and the main trust drivers for humans, clearly separated?

speaker: Slava
text: Okay. For humans feeling seen, confidentiality, empathy plus challenge, industry understanding, no judgment about burnout, and structured accountability. Like, they keep me on track.

speaker: Slava
text: For AI speed, structure, low effort, availability. Also it is consistent. But trust is limited by overconfidence, hallucinations, and confidentiality risks.

speaker: Slava
text: And lack of emotional nuance.

speaker: Anna
text: And effectiveness indicators, also separated, for your situation?

speaker: Slava
text: Human effectiveness would be: clarity on direction, concrete transition plan, better boundaries, less burnout, and progress like interviews.AI effectiveness is: better planning, faster writing, clearer reports, scenario options, and reducing cognitive load in operations tasks. 8) Preferences and hybrid model reaction (with micro-poll ratings)

speaker: Anna
text: I want to include a short micro-poll, just to structure the comparison. I will ask four ratings from 0 to 10, and I want you to explain briefly. First: your current trust in human coaches or mentors for career topics, 0 to 10.

speaker: Slava
text: Um. I would say 7 out of 10. Because I had one very good mentor, so I know it can be great.

speaker: Slava
text: But I also know many coaches are generic. And I worry about people who do not understand operations. So I am open, but not blindly.

speaker: Anna
text: What would move it from 7 to 9?

speaker: Slava
text: Clear proof of understanding my context, like retail logistics, KPIs, shift reality. And confidentiality. And also if they have psychologist background, because then I feel they can handle stress topics without making it weird.

speaker: Anna
text: Second rating: trust in AI tools for career related or work related support, 0 to 10.

speaker: Slava
text: For work tasks, like planning and reports, trust is 6. For career guidance, trust is lower, maybe 4 or 5. But overall if you force me one number, I say 6 out of 10.

speaker: Anna
text: Why 6?

speaker: Slava
text: Because it is useful and often correct in structure. But I have seen mistakes. And the confidence is dangerous.

speaker: Slava
text: Also privacy. So I trust it as assistant, not as expert.

speaker: Anna
text: Third rating: perceived effectiveness of human mentoring or coaching for your current situation, 0 to 10.

speaker: Slava
text: If I had the right person, it could be 9. But in reality, given I do not have it now, I would say 7. Like, I believe it is effective, but access is the problem.

speaker: Anna
text: What makes you believe it could be 9 with the right person?

speaker: Slava
text: Because of my early mentor. I saw how one person can change your trajectory. Also because my problem is not only technical.

speaker: Slava
text: It is identity and stress and choices. Humans are better for that.

speaker: Anna
text: Fourth rating: perceived effectiveness of AI tools for your current situation, 0 to 10.

speaker: Slava
text: For my operations tasks, 8. For the transition question, maybe 5. Overall, if one number, I say 7.

speaker: Anna
text: So trust in AI is 6, effectiveness is 7. Trust in humans is 7, effectiveness is 7, with potential higher. Is that fair?

speaker: Slava
text: Yes. That is fair. AI is like, effective worker.

speaker: Slava
text: Human is like, potential deeper shift.

speaker: Anna
text: Now I will describe a hybrid model very briefly, and you tell me your reaction. Imagine a career support service where AI helps you prepare, structure your thoughts, draft CV and messages, and track tasks between sessions. Then you have sessions with a human mentor who is matched to you based on background and style, and they focus on deeper decision making, accountability, and emotional regulation.

speaker: Anna
text: How does that land for you?

speaker: Slava
text: Honestly, that is exactly what I want. Because I already use AI for prep. But I do not have the human part.

speaker: Slava
text: The matching is key. Like, I do not want random coach. I want someone who understands business roles, maybe consulting, maybe HR, and ideally psychology background.

speaker: Slava
text: Because if I am close to burnout, I need someone who can spot patterns, like perfectionism, guilt, over responsibility. Also I like the idea AI tracks tasks. Because I am good at work tasks, but for my own career I procrastinate.

speaker: Slava
text: So if AI says, hey, you said you will message two people on LinkedIn, did you do it, it could help. But it must not be creepy. It must feel like tool, not surveillance.

speaker: Anna
text: What would make it feel creepy?

speaker: Slava
text: If it collects too much. If it stores sensitive personal notes. Also if it is not transparent.

speaker: Slava
text: Like, who sees what. If the human mentor can see my AI conversations, I need control. Because sometimes I might write things I do not want to share.

speaker: Anna
text: How would you prefer the division of labor between AI and human in such a model?

speaker: Slava
text: Preparation, brainstorming, structure, drafts, reminders, maybe practice questions.For human decision sessions, value clarification, burnout boundaries, and reality check about consulting. Like, consulting is not vacation. Also human should help with network strategy.

speaker: Slava
text: Like, who to talk to, how to position my story.

speaker: Anna
text: You said earlier you do not know where to find that kind of mentor. What have you tried so far?

speaker: Slava
text: I tried LinkedIn. But it is noisy. Everyone is like coach.

speaker: Slava
text: Hard to tell quality. I also looked at internal programs, but they are more leadership training, not career transition. I asked one colleague who moved to consulting.

speaker: Slava
text: He gave me tips, but it was one conversation. Not ongoing. I also considered paying for coaching, but I do not know how to choose.

speaker: Slava
text: Like, I fear spending money and getting generic advice.

speaker: Anna
text: What signals would you look for to evaluate a mentor or coach?

speaker: Slava
text: Case examples. Like, have they helped people transition from ops to consulting. Also their questions.

speaker: Slava
text: If first call they ask deep questions, not selling. Also if they can explain their method. Like, how they work.

speaker: Slava
text: And if they can talk about confidentiality clearly. Also vibe. Like, do I feel safe and also challenged.

speaker: Slava
text: Not only friendly. 9) Closing

speaker: Anna
text: We are close to the end. If you imagine yourself six months from now, what would be a good outcome, realistically?

speaker: Slava
text: Realistic good outcome: I have a clear plan. Either I commit to operations but with boundaries, maybe internal move to less firefighting role, like process improvement, continuous improvement. Or I commit to consulting path and I have already done like, five informational interviews and maybe applied to some roles.

speaker: Slava
text: Also I would like to feel healthier. Like, sleep better. Not checking phone every weekend.

speaker: Slava
text: That would be success.

speaker: Anna
text: If you could give advice to someone designing career support, based on your experience, what would you emphasize?

speaker: Slava
text: Do not underestimate burnout and emotional load in operations. People think it is just logistics. But it is people, safety, pressure, and you feel responsible.

speaker: Slava
text: Also, do not make advice generic. People need context. And give structure, like steps, not only inspiration.

speaker: Slava
text: And for AI, be transparent about limits and privacy. Otherwise people will not trust with important topics.

speaker: Anna
text: Anything you wish I asked but did not?

speaker: Slava
text: Maybe about consulting fantasy. Like, I know it is also pressure, travel, long hours. But I still want it because it feels like growth.

speaker: Slava
text: I guess that is enough.

speaker: Anna
text: We can end on that. Thank you, Slava. Your examples were very concrete and helpful.

speaker: Anna
text: I will stop the recording now.

speaker: Slava
text: Thank you. It was good to know you. Okay i

speaker: Anna
text: Hi Silvia, can you hear me well?

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes.

speaker: Anna
text: Yes, perfectly. Thanks for joining. Before we start, do I have your permission to record this call for my research?

speaker: Anna
text: Everything is anonymised, and you can skip any question.

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes, you can record. That is fine.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you. And just to repeat, you can pause, stop, or skip anything. No consequences.

speaker: Anna
text: Are there any topics you would prefer not to discuss?

speaker: Silvia
text: Mmm. Not really. Maybe like, very personal family stuff.

speaker: Silvia
text: But career is fine. If I feel uncomfortable, I will tell you.

speaker: Anna
text: Great. And I will use a pseudonym and remove any identifying details. Cool.

speaker: Anna
text: So I will start with some context questions and then we will go into human coaching and AI tools. Ready?

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes, ready.

speaker: Anna
text: Nice. So first, could you introduce yourself briefly, like age, where you are based, what you do?

speaker: Silvia
text: Sure. I am Silvia, 25. I am Italian.

speaker: Silvia
text: I have been living in Berlin for three years now. I did a Master’s in International Relations. And I work in a climate-tech startup, in partnerships and sales, like business development.

speaker: Anna
text: Great, thank you. And just to ground it, you are currently in Berlin, right?

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes. Neukolln.

speaker: Anna
text: Ok.

speaker: Silvia
text: Like, not the cool part, more the chaotic part.

speaker: Anna
text: Understood.

speaker: Silvia
text: Berlin is always chaotic anyway.

speaker: Anna
text: True when i was there it was exactly like that. Ok, then let us move to your career situation. 2) Participant context and career situation

speaker: Anna
text: Where are you currently in your career, and what career decisions or questions are you facing, or recently faced?

speaker: Silvia
text: Eehm, so I think I am at this point where I am not a junior anymore, but I also do not feel like a real professional, you know. I have, like, two years of work experience in Berlin, and before that some internships. In my current job I started as like partnerships associate, and now I am like BD manager, but in a startup that title means nothing.

speaker: Silvia
text: It means you do everything.

speaker: Anna
text: Mm.

speaker: Silvia
text: And my main question is, I need to sharpen my positioning. Like, what am I, actually. Am I BD, am I product, am I operations.

speaker: Silvia
text: Because in our company, the lines are super blurred. And I feel ambitious, I want to grow, but I also feel insecure because I am not technical enough. And climate-tech is very technical, or at least it can be.

speaker: Silvia
text: So I am trying to figure out where I can be strongest.

speaker: Anna
text: When you say sharpen your positioning, what does that mean for you, concretely?

speaker: Silvia
text: Like, if I need to apply somewhere, or if I want to ask for a different scope internally, I need to say, ok, I am a BD person. Or, no, I am more like product-ish. Or, I am like ops, I make things work.

speaker: Silvia
text: And right now my story is too broad. It is like, I do sales, I do partnerships, I do marketing sometimes, I do a bit of customer success, and then I join product calls and talk about features.

speaker: Anna
text: Mm. So it is not clear what the core is.

speaker: Silvia
text: Exactly. And it sounds nice, but it also sounds like, she is random. Like, she is not deep.

speaker: Anna
text: And what triggered that question recently? Was there a specific moment?

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes. There was like a re-org moment. In December, our founders decided we should focus on enterprise accounts, longer sales cycles, more consultative selling.

speaker: Silvia
text: We are in carbon accounting software, for supply chain emissions, mostly Scope 3. So it is complex. And they said, ok, Silvia, you will own partnerships for DACH and also start leading enterprise outreach for, like, industrial clients.

speaker: Anna
text: That is a big shift.

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes. And it was exciting, because it is like, wow, they trust me. But it also was scary because I was like, I do not speak German perfectly, and also enterprise means you need credibility.

speaker: Silvia
text: Like, you talk to sustainability managers, procurement, sometimes CFO. And then the product is technical, you need to explain methodologies, data integration, APIs, ERP systems. And I was like, hmm, ok, am I the right person.

speaker: Anna
text: What happened that made you feel not technical enough?

speaker: Silvia
text: There is one moment I remember. We had a customer demo with a logistics company. The head of sustainability asked about how we map emission factors and how we deal with missing supplier data.

speaker: Silvia
text: And then someone from their IT joined and asked about integration with SAP and data security, like where the data is hosted, encryption, access rights.

speaker: Anna
text: Mm.

speaker: Silvia
text: And I tried to answer, but I was not sure. I gave like a high-level answer, and then our engineer jumped in, and he was super precise. Like, yes, we use this, we do that, we have a certain architecture.

speaker: Silvia
text: And the vibe changed, you know. It was like, ok, the technical guy is the credible one. And I felt like, I am just the person doing the talking.

speaker: Anna
text: That sounds uncomfortable.

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes. And then after the call, the founder told me, you did well, but you need to be more confident. And I was like, yes, but confidence comes from knowledge.

speaker: Silvia
text: It is not just like, be confident.

speaker: Anna
text: Mm. So your insecurity is tied to competence, not just mindset.

speaker: Silvia
text: Exactly. And also, I think I compare myself to people in Berlin who are like, product managers, ex-consultants, or people from TU Munich, you know, very technical. And I am International Relations.

speaker: Silvia
text: Sometimes I feel like, what am I doing here.

speaker: Anna
text: How do you measure ambition for yourself?

speaker: Silvia
text: Eehm. Good question. I measure it like, I want to have more impact and also more responsibility.

speaker: Silvia
text: I want to lead projects, maybe lead a team. I want to be in rooms where decisions happen. And I also want to earn more, honestly.

speaker: Silvia
text: Berlin is expensive now.

speaker: Anna
text: Sure.

speaker: Silvia
text: And I want to stay in climate-tech because it matters, like, it is not just selling random software. But I also do not want to become like this, how to say, performance machine, where I am always optimizing, always chasing titles.

speaker: Anna
text: So there is tension between ambition and authenticity.

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes. Exactly. Like, I want to win, but I also want to feel like myself.

speaker: Anna
text: And in terms of your situation in Germany, do you have any visa constraints, or is it straightforward?

speaker: Silvia
text: I am EU, so it is straightforward. That is one privilege. I do not have Blue Card stress.

speaker: Silvia
text: But I have like, life stress. Berlin stress.

speaker: Anna
text: Understood. And your German level?

speaker: Silvia
text: I think B1, maybe low B2 in reading. Speaking is the problem. In meetings I can do some German, but for enterprise sales, it is tough.

speaker: Silvia
text: Sometimes I switch to English, and then the German person switches too, but you feel like, hmm, maybe I am losing something.

speaker: Anna
text: Ok. Thanks. That is helpfut.

speaker: Anna
text: Let us talk about where you get career support in general. 3) Career support in general

speaker: Anna
text: When you need career support, who or what do you usually turn to?

speaker: Silvia
text: Eehm. Friends first. Like other internationals in Berlin, people working in startups.

speaker: Silvia
text: Also some Italian friends, because they understand my background. Then sometimes my boyfriend, but he is in tech, so he gives a technical perspective.

speaker: Anna
text: Mm.

speaker: Silvia
text: And I also use online resources. Like newsletters, podcasts, LinkedIn posts. Sometimes I talk to people in my network, like informational chats.

speaker: Silvia
text: Berlin is very network-y, you can just DM someone and say, coffee.

speaker: Anna
text: Does that work for you?

speaker: Silvia
text: Sometimes yes. Sometimes it is superficial. Like, people give advice but they do not know your context.

speaker: Silvia
text: So you get very generic things. But the network effect is real. If you meet one person, they introduce you to another, and then you see patterns.

speaker: Anna
text: Any formal services, like university career services or mentors?

speaker: Silvia
text: Not university, because my Master was in Italy and I did not really use career services. In Berlin, I did group coaching, like a program for women in startups. It was paid, but not super expensive.

speaker: Anna
text: Ok.

speaker: Silvia
text: And I sometimes use AI tools. Like ChatGPT. Mostly for work, not for like, should I change my job.

speaker: Silvia
text: More for outreach messages, market research summaries, like competitor mapping.

speaker: Anna
text: What has actually helped you, and what felt unhelpful or frustrating?

speaker: Silvia
text: Helped: talking to peers. Like people one or two steps ahead. They say, this is normal, you are not crazy, and also they share very practical things, like, how they position their role, how they negotiate salary, scripts for difficult conversations.

speaker: Silvia
text: That is super helpful.

speaker: Anna
text: And unhelpful?

speaker: Silvia
text: When advice is too generic. Like, follow your passion. Or be confident.

speaker: Silvia
text: Or, build your personal brand. And you are like, ok, but what do I do on Monday.

speaker: Anna
text: Mm. Thank you. Let us talk about your experience with human coaching, specifically the group coaching you mentioned.

speaker: Anna
text: 4) Human coaching: experience and trust

speaker: Anna
text: Can you describe that group coaching experience? What was it, and what did it look like in practice?

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes. It was like an eight-week program, once a week, two hours. Zoom.

speaker: Silvia
text: There were maybe twelve women, mostly in startups, roles like marketing, BD, product, operations. The coach was a woman, German, maybe in her 40s, with like coaching certification.

speaker: Anna
text: And what was the goal of the program?

speaker: Silvia
text: It was career clarity and confidence. Like positioning, boundaries, leadership presence. And also peer accountability.

speaker: Silvia
text: We had like homework, journaling prompts, and then we shared in the group.

speaker: Anna
text: What did you like about it?

speaker: Silvia
text: The peer effect. One hundred percent. Like, hearing other women say they feel impostor syndrome, they feel not technical enough, they feel behind.

speaker: Silvia
text: It normalised my feelings. And also, peers had examples. Like one woman was in a climate-tech scaleup, and she explained how BD works there, how they work with product.

speaker: Silvia
text: It was like, wow, ok, there are options.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you share a specific moment where peers helped you?

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes. There was a session on self-advocacy. I shared that our founders want me to do enterprise outreach, but I feel insecure.

speaker: Silvia
text: And I said, I do not know how to ask for support without sounding weak. And then two peers jumped in. One said, you can frame it as, to deliver better results, you need access to technical knowledge, so you propose a weekly session with an engineer to learn the product deeper.

speaker: Silvia
text: And another said, you can ask for a clearer role definition, like, what is success in three months.

speaker: Anna
text: That sounds practical.

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes. And then they even gave me wording. Like, I mean, no wait, let me rephrase.

speaker: Silvia
text: They gave me a script. Like, in German and English. One person said, you can say, I want to take full ownership, and to do that I need these resources.

speaker: Silvia
text: It is not weakness, it is professionalism.

speaker: Anna
text: And did you use that?

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes. I actually did. The next week I spoke with the founder.

speaker: Silvia
text: I said, I want to own enterprise, but I need a technical buddy. And now I have a weekly session with our solutions engineer. It is like thirty minutes.

speaker: Silvia
text: That came from peers, not from the coach.

speaker: Anna
text: Interesting. So the outcome was a concrete change at work.

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes. Exactly.

speaker: Anna
text: And how did the coach contribute?

speaker: Silvia
text: Eehm. She facilitated. She created a safe space.

speaker: Silvia
text: She had some frameworks, like values, strengths, vision. But sometimes it felt generic. Like, she would say, ok, write down your values, and then align your career.

speaker: Silvia
text: And I was like, yes, that is true, but it is also like, ok, I have values, now what.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you remember a moment where the coach felt generic or secondary?

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes. There was one session where I said, I am unsure if I should move toward product or stay in BD. And she said, maybe you can do an ikigai exercise, like what you love, what you are good at, what the world needs, what you can be paid for.

speaker: Anna
text: Mm.

speaker: Silvia
text: And I was like, ok, yes, but that is like, the internet. And she did not really ask deep questions. It was like, ok, do the exercise, and you will know.

speaker: Silvia
text: But I did the exercise and I still did not know, because I like many things.

speaker: Anna
text: So it was nice but not specific.

speaker: Silvia
text: Exactly. She was kind. She was trustworthy in the sense she was respectful and confidential.

speaker: Silvia
text: But not effective in that moment, because she did not get into my concrete context, like climate-tech BD, technical insecurity, Berlin startup reality.

speaker: Anna
text: That is helpful. You are already distinguishing trust and effectiveness.

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes. Trust was high in terms of safety, but effectiveness was medium.

speaker: Anna
text: Let us unpack trust in human coaching for you. What makes a human coach or a group setting trustworthy?

speaker: Silvia
text: For humans, trust is like, do I feel seen, not judged. Emotional safety. Confidentiality.

speaker: Silvia
text: Also, lived experience matters. Like, if someone has been in a similar role, BD in a technical company, then I trust more. And peer credibility, like hearing from peers who actually do the thing.

speaker: Silvia
text: That was huge.

speaker: Anna
text: So peers were like a credibility source.

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes. Because they do not pretend. They say, I did this, it worked, or it did not.

speaker: Silvia
text: And you believe it because it is messy.

speaker: Anna
text: Anything that reduces trust in human coaching?

speaker: Silvia
text: If it feels like they have a one-size-fits-all method. Or if they push you to conclusions. Or if they do not remember what you said before.

speaker: Silvia
text: Like if I share something vulnerable and next time they forget, I feel like, ok, I am just another client.

speaker: Anna
text: In group coaching, did you worry about confidentiality?

speaker: Silvia
text: A bit, yes. Because you do not know people. But we had rules, like what is said here stays here.

speaker: Silvia
text: And it felt ok. I did not share super sensitive details like salary numbers. But I shared enough.

speaker: Anna
text: And did you feel seen in that group?

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes, by peers. The coach was ok, but peers really saw me. They said, oh, you always downplay your competence.

speaker: Silvia
text: Or, you are always translating technical stuff into human language, that is a skill. And I was like, oh, that is true.

speaker: Anna
text: That is interesting. So trust drivers can come from different actors in a group setting.

speaker: Silvia
text: Exactly.

speaker: Anna
text: Ok. Before we move to AI, I want to capture one more concrete episode. Biggest career decision in the last six to twelve months.

speaker: Anna
text: What was it?

speaker: Silvia
text: Hmm. I think it was whether to stay in this startup or take a role in a bigger climate-tech company, like a scaleup, where the role is more defined. I got approached by a recruiter in September.

speaker: Silvia
text: It was a partnerships role, but more like account management, less chaotic.

speaker: Anna
text: And what made it difficult?

speaker: Silvia
text: The uncertainty. In Berlin startups, you can grow fast, but you can also burn out. In a bigger company, you learn processes, but you might get stuck.

speaker: Silvia
text: And I also felt like, if I leave now, I am running away from my technical insecurity instead of solving it.

speaker: Anna
text: What did you decide?

speaker: Silvia
text: I stayed. And then the re-org happened, so now it is like, ok, you wanted growth, here it is.

speaker: Anna
text: That is how it goes.

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes.

speaker: Anna
text: Ok. Now let us shift to AI tools. 5) AI tools: experience and trust

speaker: Anna
text: You said you use AI mainly for work, like outreach messages and market research summaries. Can you walk me through how you actually use it?

speaker: Silvia
text: Sure. For outreach, I do cold emails and LinkedIn messages, mostly. Our product is carbon accounting for supply chains.

speaker: Silvia
text: We target sustainability managers, procurement, sometimes operations. And each persona cares about different things.

speaker: Anna
text: Mm.

speaker: Silvia
text: So I use AI to draft an initial message, then I customise. I might say, ok, write a LinkedIn message to a head of sustainability in manufacturing, mention recent EU regulations, like CSRD, and connect to Scope 3 reporting, and be friendly but not too salesy.

speaker: Anna
text: And then you edit.

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes. I always edit, because otherwise it is too generic, too enthusiastic, like, hope you are doing great, and I am like, no, Germans do not do that.

speaker: Anna
text: Fair.

speaker: Silvia
text: And also, I feed it context. Like, I paste their company description, or I summarise their latest sustainability report, and I ask for a message that references something specific. It saves time.

speaker: Anna
text: Any follow-up sequences?

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes. Like, I ask it to propose a three-step follow-up sequence. For example, first message is value proposition, second is a short case study, third is a question.

speaker: Silvia
text: It helps structure.

speaker: Anna
text: And market research summaries?

speaker: Silvia
text: That is also huge. Like, I say, summarise the carbon accounting software landscape in Europe, main competitors, positioning, typical pricing models, and key decision criteria for buyers. Then it gives me a map.

speaker: Silvia
text: But I have to be careful because it sometimes invents things.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you give an example of when it invented things?

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes. It once said a competitor had a partnership with a big consulting firm. And I was like, wow, that is important.

speaker: Silvia
text: Then I searched and it was not true. It was like hallucination. That was a trust hit.

speaker: Anna
text: How did you notice it was wrong?

speaker: Silvia
text: Because I knew the competitor a bit. And also it cited like, sources, but when I checked, the sources were not real. And then I was like, ok, I cannot rely on it for factual market intelligence unless I verify.

speaker: Anna
text: So you have a verification habit.

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes. For market facts, yes. For message drafts, less risky.

speaker: Anna
text: Ok. Tell me about a moment AI helped a lot.

speaker: Silvia
text: One moment was when we were launching a new feature: supplier engagement module. We needed to explain it in a simple way to prospects. I asked AI to help craft a value proposition for three personas: sustainability lead, procurement, and IT.

speaker: Silvia
text: It gave me different angles. For procurement, it focused on supplier compliance and risk. For IT, it focused on integration and data governance.

speaker: Silvia
text: That helped me create a better outreach. And we had better reply rates that week, like, not crazy, but noticeable. I think because messages were more relevant.

speaker: Anna
text: So effectiveness there was in speed and structure and persona adaptation.

speaker: Silvia
text: Exactly. And also, it helps with language. Like, I am Italian, my English is good, but sometimes I want a crisp sentence, and it helps.

speaker: Anna
text: And a moment where AI did not help, apart from hallucinated facts.

speaker: Silvia
text: There was a moment where I asked it to help me position myself. Like, I tried once. I said, I am in climate-tech BD, I am not sure if I am more BD or product.

speaker: Silvia
text: Help me decide.

speaker: Anna
text: And what happened?

speaker: Silvia
text: It gave me a very structured answer. Like, here are pros and cons, here is a decision matrix, here are steps. And it felt impressive, like, wow.

speaker: Silvia
text: But I also felt like, it is pushing me into optimization mode. Like, choose the best option, maximise. And I was like, but I do not want to optimise.

speaker: Silvia
text: I want to know what I actually want.

speaker: Anna
text: Mm.

speaker: Silvia
text: And then I felt anxious. Because it was like, ok, do these ten steps, build a portfolio, talk to five people, do a SWOT. And I was like, oh my god, more tasks.

speaker: Anna
text: So it increased the pressure.

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes. And also it did not know me. It did not ask about my values in a deep way.

speaker: Silvia
text: It was like, do a values exercise, which is again generic. So I stopped. For personal decisions, I avoid AI.

speaker: Silvia
text: Because I fear it will push me into being a productivity robot, not a human.

speaker: Anna
text: That is an important boundary.

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes. I use it for external-facing tasks. Messages, summaries.

speaker: Silvia
text: But not for, who am I.

speaker: Anna
text: You also mentioned that wanting question, like what you truly want, feels more suitable for a psychologist or coach, or something you figure out yourself.

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes. Exactly. Because wanting is emotional, messy.

speaker: Silvia
text: AI is too clean. It gives you an answer, but maybe it is not your answer. It is like, it can be effective in output, but not authentic.

speaker: Anna
text: That is a good phrase. Effective output but not authentic.

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes.

speaker: Anna
text: Let us talk specifically about trust in AI. What drives trust for you, and what reduces it?

speaker: Silvia
text: Trust drivers: speed. It is always there. Structure.

speaker: Silvia
text: It can take messy information and create a clean outline. And for outreach, it can generate variants fast, which feels like, ok, I can iterate.

speaker: Anna
text: And what reduces trust?

speaker: Silvia
text: When it invents facts. When it sounds too confident. Also privacy, but for me less, because I do not put very sensitive things.

speaker: Silvia
text: But still, I do not put internal numbers. And the other thing is, it can lead to sameness. Like, if everyone uses it, everyone writes the same messages.

speaker: Anna
text: So you fear losing uniqueness.

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes. And losing my voice. That is like an emotional trust issue.

speaker: Silvia
text: Like, can I trust it to represent me.

speaker: Anna
text: That is a different trust dimension than factual accuracy.

speaker: Silvia
text: Exactly.

speaker: Anna
text: Ok. Now I want to compare human and AI via specific tasks. But before that, we will embed some micro-poll ratings.

speaker: Anna
text: It will be quick. Is that ok?

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes. 6) Human vs AI comparison via specific tasks

speaker: Anna
text: I will ask you to rate from 0 to 10, where 0 is no trust at all and 10 is complete trust. First: your trust in human career coaches, based on your experience, including the group coaching nuance.

speaker: Silvia
text: Hmm. I would say, maybe 7.

speaker: Anna
text: 7. Why 7, not higher or lower?

speaker: Silvia
text: Higher because I can feel safe, like confidentiality, being heard. And in group coaching, peers add credibility. Lower because the coach can be generic, and also, I have not had like one-on-one coaching with someone who really knows my domain.

speaker: Silvia
text: If I had a coach who did climate-tech BD, maybe it would be 9.

speaker: Anna
text: Ok. Next your trust in AI tools for career-related support, 0 to 10.

speaker: Silvia
text: For career-related, like decisions, I would say 4. For work tasks, maybe 8, but you asked career support, so 4.

speaker: Anna
text: 4. What drives that?

speaker: Silvia
text: I trust it to generate structure and drafts, but I do not trust it with my identity questions. And I do not trust it with facts unless I verify. So overall, 4.

speaker: Anna
text: Next: perceived effectiveness of human coaching for your situation, 0 to 10.

speaker: Silvia
text: Hmm. Maybe 6.

speaker: Anna
text: Why 6?

speaker: Silvia
text: Because it helped through peers, accountability, and I made a concrete change at work. But the coach itself was not super effective. And group coaching is not personalised.

speaker: Silvia
text: So 6.

speaker: Anna
text: And perceived effectiveness of AI tools for your situation, 0 to 10.

speaker: Silvia
text: For my situation, I think 7. But again, not for personal decisions, more for tasks. So maybe 7.

speaker: Anna
text: Interesting. So AI effectiveness higher than AI trust.

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes. Because it can produce a strong message, like objectively effective, but I might not trust it emotionally. Or I feel it is not me.

speaker: Anna
text: That is exactly the distinction we are exploring. Ok, thanks. Now we will go deeper with tasks.

speaker: Anna
text: I will name a task and you tell me which you prefer, human or AI, and why.

speaker: Silvia
text: Ok.

speaker: Anna
text: Task one: drafting outreach messages to prospects. Human coach, peer, or AI?

speaker: Silvia
text: AI. Definitely AI.

speaker: Anna
text: Why?

speaker: Silvia
text: Speed. And you can do variants. And it is not emotionally risky.

speaker: Silvia
text: If AI gives me a bad message, I just change it. Also, a human coach would be too slow and expensive for that.

speaker: Anna
text: And what would make AI more trustworthy for outreach?

speaker: Silvia
text: If I can control the tone. Like, prompt it with my style and constraints. And if it does not make wrong assumptions about the prospect.

speaker: Silvia
text: Sometimes it assumes they care about something they do not.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you give a concrete example?

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes. I once asked it to write a message to a procurement lead. It said, you are probably under pressure to comply with CSRD.

speaker: Silvia
text: But procurement is not directly responsible. So it was like, slightly wrong. Then the message feels off.

speaker: Anna
text: Ok. Task two: summarising a market or competitor landscape.

speaker: Silvia
text: AI, but with verification. Like, I use it as a starting point, but then I check.

speaker: Anna
text: What do you check?

speaker: Silvia
text: Competitor names, features, pricing, partnerships, any claims. I cross-check with websites, news, sometimes G2 reviews.

speaker: Anna
text: Task three: preparing for a difficult conversation with your founder about your scope, like BD vs product vs operations.

speaker: Silvia
text: Hmm. That is more human. Or peers.

speaker: Anna
text: Why?

speaker: Silvia
text: Because it is emotional and political. AI can give me scripts, but it cannot read the room. Peers can tell you, watch out, the founder will react like this, or the culture is like that.

speaker: Anna
text: Does AI help at all there?

speaker: Silvia
text: Maybe for structuring my points. Like, ok, list what I want, list what I offer, list what support I need. But I do not want it to tell me what I should want.

speaker: Anna
text: Task four: clarifying what you want long term, like the wanting question.

speaker: Silvia
text: Human. Or myself.

speaker: Anna
text: What kind of human, specifically? Coach, therapist, mentor, friend?

speaker: Silvia
text: Eehm. I think a coach or therapist. Coach for career structure, therapist for deeper patterns.

speaker: Silvia
text: Friends also help, but they are biased. A coach at least is neutral. But the coach needs to be good.

speaker: Anna
text: What is good?

speaker: Silvia
text: Someone who asks real questions, not frameworks. Someone who can hold silence. And who can challenge me gently.

speaker: Silvia
text: And ideally someone who understands startup roles.

speaker: Anna
text: Ok. Task five: building confidence in technical meetings.

speaker: Silvia
text: That is tricky. I think human plus practice. AI can help me learn concepts, like explain what Scope 3 is, or explain what an API is, but confidence comes from using it.

speaker: Anna
text: So AI can support learning.

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes. Like, I ask it, explain SAP integration like I am five. That helps.

speaker: Silvia
text: But then in a meeting, you need to speak.

speaker: Anna
text: Task six: writing a personal narrative for LinkedIn or for interviews, like your positioning.

speaker: Silvia
text: Hmm. Hybrid. AI can help with drafts and structure.

speaker: Silvia
