text: Human can help with authenticity and truth.

speaker: Anna
text: That is a good segue into trust and effectiveness. Let us go there. 7) Trust–effectiveness link

speaker: Anna
text: When you think about your experiences, how does trust affect whether support is effective, for humans and for AI?

speaker: Silvia
text: For humans, trust is like the condition for depth. If I trust the coach, I share the real insecurity. Like, I say, I feel stupid in technical meetings.

speaker: Silvia
text: If I do not trust, I will say something superficial, like, I want to grow. Then the coaching is superficial, and effectiveness is low.

speaker: Anna
text: Mm.

speaker: Silvia
text: And in the group, trust was created by rules and by seeing others be vulnerable. Then I felt, ok, I can share. That made it effective because peers gave real advice.

speaker: Anna
text: So trust enabled effectiveness.

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes, for humans. For AI, it is different. Trust is not needed for it to produce an effective output.

speaker: Silvia
text: Like, it can write a strong message even if I do not trust it. But then, whether it is effective for me depends on whether I use it and whether it aligns with me.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you give an example of effective but not trusted?

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes. I had one outreach message it generated that was really good. Very crisp, very relevant, and it got a reply.

speaker: Silvia
text: But I felt weird, like, is this my voice. It felt slightly manipulative, like too polished. And I was like, ok, it works, but I do not trust it to represent my values.

speaker: Silvia
text: So it was effective in outcome, but not trusted.

speaker: Anna
text: That is very clear. And the other direction: trusted but not effective.

speaker: Silvia
text: That is the coach moment. She was nice, safe, I trusted her as a person, but her advice was generic. Like, do ikigai.

speaker: Silvia
text: So I trusted her, but it did not move me.

speaker: Anna
text: If you think about effectiveness indicators for you, what counts as effective support?

speaker: Silvia
text: Clearer narrative. Like, I can say what I do and why it matters. Confidence in meetings.

speaker: Silvia
text: Concrete experiments, like trying a project with product, or setting boundaries with founders. Better outreach results, like reply rate, meeting booked. Clearer boundaries, like what I will not do.

speaker: Silvia
text: And reduced anxiety. Like, sleeping better.

speaker: Anna
text: And how do trust and effectiveness interact in your day-to-day?

speaker: Silvia
text: With AI, I use it because it is effective for tasks, even if trust is partial. With humans, if trust is not there, I do not use it, so effectiveness cannot happen. So trust is like a gate for humans.

speaker: Silvia
text: For AI, trust is like a filter, not a gate.

speaker: Anna
text: Oh wow.

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes. Because I can still use AI pragmatically, like a tool, without trusting it emotionally. But for a coach, you cannot.

speaker: Anna
text: Ok. If you look at your earlier ratings, human trust 7, human effectiveness 6, AI trust 4, AI effectiveness 7. Does that pattern make sense to you now?

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes. It makes sense. Because humans are more trustworthy emotionally, but not always effective practically.

speaker: Silvia
text: AI is effective practically, but not trustworthy for identity.

speaker: Anna
text: In your opinion, what would increase trust in AI for career decisions?

speaker: Silvia
text: Hmm. That is hard. Maybe if it had boundaries, like it clearly says, I am not here to tell you what to want.

speaker: Silvia
text: I can help you explore options. Also, if it asked better questions, not just give answers. And if it was more transparent, like, why it suggests something.

speaker: Anna
text: So a more Socratic approach.

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes. And maybe if it was integrated with a human, so you do not feel alone with it.

speaker: Anna
text: Ok. That brings us to preferences and hybrid models. 8) Preferences and hybrid model reaction

speaker: Anna
text: Imagine a hybrid model: AI helps you prepare, structure, draft, and explore options, and then a human coach or mentor steps in for high-stakes decisions, values, and accountability. How does that sound to you?

speaker: Silvia
text: That sounds good. That is like, the ideal.

speaker: Anna
text: What feels good about it?

speaker: Silvia
text: Because it matches how I already behave. I use AI for fast tasks and structure. Then I go to peers for real talk.

speaker: Silvia
text: If a platform made that seamless, it would reduce friction.

speaker: Anna
text: What would make you sceptical?

speaker: Silvia
text: If it is not clear when AI stops and human starts. Like, if they pretend AI is a coach. That would annoy me.

speaker: Silvia
text: Also, privacy. If my AI chat is shared with a human without my control, I would not like that. And also, I fear the hybrid could still push me into optimization.

speaker: Silvia
text: Like, you do AI exercises, you get tasks, you become like, more productive, but not necessarily happier.

speaker: Anna
text: So you want it to support choice, not optimisation.

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes. Choice and clarity. Not hustle.

speaker: Anna
text: If you could design your ideal hybrid journey for your current question, BD vs product vs ops, what would it look like?

speaker: Silvia
text: Eehm. First, AI helps me map the roles. Like, what does BD look like in climate-tech, what does product look like, what does ops look like, day-to-day, success metrics, typical career paths.

speaker: Anna
text: Ok.

speaker: Silvia
text: Then AI helps me list my experiences and translate them into skills. Like, I already do some product discovery because I talk to customers, I translate feedback to engineers. That could be product.

speaker: Silvia
text: Or I coordinate partnerships, that is ops.

speaker: Anna
text: Mm.

speaker: Silvia
text: Then, with a human, I would talk about what I enjoy, what drains me, what I want to become. And also, the human can challenge my insecurity, like, are you really not technical enough, or are you just comparing yourself.

speaker: Anna
text: Would you prefer one-on-one or group?

speaker: Silvia
text: For this, one-on-one. Group is good for normalising, but for a decision, I want personal attention.

speaker: Anna
text: What kind of person would you trust most as a human in that hybrid?

speaker: Silvia
text: Someone who did BD or product in a technical startup. Ideally climate-tech, but at least B2B SaaS. And someone who understands Berlin culture, like ambiguity.

speaker: Silvia
text: And someone who does not judge my background. Like, International Relations is not a weakness.

speaker: Anna
text: And how would you want AI positioned in that model? As a tool, as a coach, as a copilot?

speaker: Silvia
text: Tool or copilot. Not coach. Coach implies emotional guidance.

speaker: Silvia
text: Copilot is like, you still fly the plane.

speaker: Anna
text: Nice. Any concerns about reliance, like overusing AI?

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes. I can see myself going into a loop. Like, prompt, refine, prompt, refine.

speaker: Silvia
text: It feels productive, but you are not deciding. So the system should maybe limit it or encourage reflection.

speaker: Anna
text: Encourage reflection how?

speaker: Silvia
text: Like, after giving options, ask, which one feels energising. Or, what do you fear. But not in a fake way.

speaker: Silvia
text: And maybe it should say, stop now and talk to a human.

speaker: Anna
text: So nudges.

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes. But not too paternalistic. Berlin people hate being told what to do.

speaker: Anna
text: Fair.

speaker: Silvia
text: We are all like, do not control me. But also, please help me.

speaker: Anna
text: That is very Berlin.

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes.

speaker: Anna
text: If you think about trust in a hybrid model, what are the key trust conditions?

speaker: Silvia
text: For AI part: transparency, boundaries, no hallucinations, and control over my data. For human part: confidentiality, being seen, and domain credibility. And also, a clear explanation of how the human is chosen, like matching logic.

speaker: Silvia
text: If it is random, I would not trust.

speaker: Anna
text: Ok. If you had to summarise your preference in one sentence, what would it be?

speaker: Silvia
text: AI for execution and structure, humans for meaning and courage.

speaker: Anna
text: Meaning and courage. Woah.

speaker: Silvia
text: Because decisions need courage. And courage comes from feeling supported, not from a perfect spreadsheet.

speaker: Anna
text: Mm. Ok. We are close to closing.

speaker: Anna
text: I will ask a couple of final questions. 9) Closing

speaker: Anna
text: Looking forward, what is one concrete next step you want to take in the next month regarding your positioning question?

speaker: Silvia
text: I want to do a small experiment. Like, I want to take ownership of a product-related project. We have a feature request pipeline, and I want to lead one initiative from customer insight to shipping, with product and engineering.

speaker: Silvia
text: Just one.

speaker: Anna
text: That would give you information.

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes. It will show if I like product work, or if I hate it. And also, it will increase my technical confidence because I will work closer with engineers.

speaker: Anna
text: What support do you need to do that?

speaker: Silvia
text: Time and permission. And someone to mentor me, like the product lead. And I need to manage my own anxiety, like, not thinking I am stupid.

speaker: Anna
text: If you had a good coaching support, human or hybrid, what would success look like after, say, three months?

speaker: Silvia
text: I would have a clear narrative: I am a BD person with product mindset, or I am transitioning to product, or I am ops. And I would feel calmer. Like, ok, I am not behind.

speaker: Silvia
text: I am on a path. And I would feel more confident in technical meetings, like I can ask questions without shame.

speaker: Anna
text: Anything else you want to add that we did not cover?

speaker: Silvia
text: Maybe one thing. In climate-tech, there is also this moral pressure. Like, you want to do good, and sometimes you feel guilty if you focus on career and money.

speaker: Silvia
text: And coaching that ignores that feels incomplete. AI also ignores that. It is like, optimise your career.

speaker: Silvia
text: But in climate-tech, you also want alignment with values.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you. So the value layer matters.

speaker: Silvia
text: Yes. Because otherwise you can become cynical. And then you leave climate-tech.

speaker: Anna
text: Ok. Thank you, Silvia. That was very good to talk to you.

speaker: Anna
text: I will stop the recording now. Thanks again for your time.

speaker: Silvia
text: Thank you. It was actually nice to talk. And good luck with your thesis.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you so much. Bye.

speaker: Silvia
text: Ciao.

speaker: Anna
text: Hi Mihir. Thanks for joining. Before we start, do I have your permission to record?

speaker: Anna
text: Everything is anonymous, and you can skip any question.

speaker: Mihir
text: Hi Anna. Yes, you can record. That is okay.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you. And just to confirm, you are comfortable with this being used for a research thesis, anonymized, no real names, no company names?

speaker: Mihir
text: Yes, that is fine. I will also try not to mention my company name.

speaker: Anna
text: Perfect. If anything slips out, I will remove it in transcription. One more thing, if at any point you want to pause or stop, just tell me.

speaker: Anna
text: Okay?

speaker: Mihir
text: Okay.

speaker: Anna
text: Great. We will talk about your experiences with career support from humans and from AI tools, and how you think about trust and effectiveness. No right or wrong answers.

speaker: Anna
text: I will ask a main question, and sometimes follow up. Ready?

speaker: Mihir
text: Yes, ready. A bit nervous, but ready.

speaker: Anna
text: Totally fine. We can go step by step. 2) Participant context and career situation

speaker: Anna
text: To start, where are you currently in your career, and what career decisions or questions are you facing right now?

speaker: Mihir
text: Um, okay. So I am 26. I am from India.

speaker: Mihir
text: I have been in Germany for, like, two and a half years now. I am based in Munich. I am doing my Master’s in Electrical Engineering, but with a track in embedded systems and robotics, like more software plus hardware.

speaker: Mihir
text: I am also working as a working student in a startup.

speaker: Anna
text: Mm. And when you say career decisions or questions, what is the biggest one for you right now?

speaker: Mihir
text: The biggest is, what role do I actually want and can I get in Germany. Because I feel I am doing many things. At the startup I do embedded stuff, some firmware, sometimes testing, sometimes a bit of data logging and like Python scripts.

speaker: Mihir
text: But I do not know if I should aim for embedded software engineer, or robotics engineer, or maybe something like systems engineer. And then also the whole German job market has these titles, like Entwicklungsingenieur, Softwareentwickler, Systemingenieur, and they all sound similar but then requirements are different. So, eehm, I am confused.

speaker: Anna
text: When did that confusion become more intense? Was there a moment in the last months?

speaker: Mihir
text: Yes. Actually last summer, like around June or July 2025, I had to decide about my thesis topic and also whether to extend my working student contract. My startup wanted me to stay, but it is a bit, how to say, unclear.

speaker: Mihir
text: Like I learn a lot, but I do not know if it is the right brand for my CV. And then my university supervisor was like, pick a thesis that matches your target job. And then I was like, but I do not know the target job.

speaker: Mihir
text: So it became a loop.

speaker: Anna
text: A loop, yes. What did you decide in the end?

speaker: Mihir
text: In the end, I chose a thesis topic that is kind of in the middle. It is about real-time sensor data processing on microcontrollers, with some edge AI concepts, but not too heavy. My thinking was, okay, embedded plus some ML buzzword helps.

speaker: Mihir
text: But then I also feel, maybe I am doing it for the job market, not because I love it. And then I feel guilty. It is a lot.

speaker: Anna
text: When you say you feel guilty, can you say more? Guilty about what?

speaker: Mihir
text: Guilty because I feel I am not having a clear passion. Like in India, also with my family, it is like you choose a track and you become that. Here I see people very focused.

speaker: Mihir
text: Like, my classmates, some are like, I am robotics, I do ROS2, I build robots, that is it. Some are like, I am power electronics, I do SiC, that is it. And I am like, I can do many things but I cannot say one sentence what I am.

speaker: Mihir
text: And then on LinkedIn everyone is like, I joined this company as full-time, I got Blue Card, I bought a car, whatever. And I am still studying. And I am 26.

speaker: Mihir
text: And in my head it is like, bro, what are you doing. It makes me very low sometimes.

speaker: Anna
text: Thanks for sharing that. When you feel low, what does that look like day to day?

speaker: Mihir
text: Um. I sleep late because I overthink. Then in the morning I am tired.

speaker: Mihir
text: I still go to work because I have to. And then I do okay at work, because tasks are clear. But when it is about future, like applying, planning, then I freeze.

speaker: Mihir
text: And sometimes I just scroll job ads and then I get more stressed. Or I compare salaries. Or I watch videos like, how to get a job in Germany as international student.

speaker: Mihir
text: And then it is too much. It is not like I cannot function, but it feels heavy. Like a constant pressure.

speaker: Anna
text: That pressure, is it mainly about time, money, visa, or identity, or all of it?

speaker: Mihir
text: All. Money because Munich is expensive. I share a WG.

speaker: Mihir
text: Rent is crazy. Visa because I have student visa. I know after graduation I can get job-seeker, and then Blue Card path, but it still feels like a ticking thing.

speaker: Mihir
text: Also identity because I feel, I came here to build something. I wanted a proper career. And I am still not there.

speaker: Anna
text: What is your German level right now?

speaker: Mihir
text: Like B2 maybe. I can do daily things. I can speak in supermarket, Bürgerbüro, but job interviews in German, no.

speaker: Mihir
text: And job ads are sometimes in German. Or mixed. So I use AI to translate and explain.

speaker: Mihir
text: That is a big part.

speaker: Anna
text: We will go deeper into that later. Before that, tell me a bit about your working student role. What kind of startup is it, and what do you actually do there?

speaker: Mihir
text: Okay. It is a small startup, maybe 25 people. They build a hardware product for industrial monitoring.

speaker: Mihir
text: Like sensors plus edge device. I am in the engineering team. My tasks, for example, one month I worked on firmware for a microcontroller to handle SPI communication with a sensor.

speaker: Mihir
text: Then we had issues with timing, so I had to debug with logic analyzer. Then I also wrote a small Python tool to parse logs and produce graphs, like check packet loss. Sometimes I also support QA by writing test scripts.

speaker: Mihir
text: So it is many hats.

speaker: Anna
text: And how do you feel about that?

speaker: Mihir
text: Mixed. On one side, I love that I learn. Like it is hands-on.

speaker: Mihir
text: It is not like only theory. On the other side, when I try to write my CV, it becomes messy. Because the job ad wants, like, embedded C, RTOS, communication protocols, but also wants requirements engineering, or wants safety standards, or wants AUTOSAR.

speaker: Mihir
text: And I am like, I did a bit of everything, but not deep in those. And then I think, am I behind.

speaker: Anna
text: You said you sometimes use AI for confidence-building, like am I behind. Is that connected to this?

speaker: Mihir
text: Yes. Very connected. Because when I see job ads, I feel not enough.

speaker: Mihir
text: And then I ask AI, like, if I have these skills, is it normal, am I behind, what can I do in 3 months. Sometimes it helps, sometimes it makes it worse.

speaker: Anna
text: Okay. We will come back. One last thing in this section.

speaker: Anna
text: What kind of plan do you imagine would calm you? If you picture an ideal structured plan, what is in it?

speaker: Mihir
text: Hmm. Like a timeline. Like, okay, next 8 weeks, do this project, update CV, apply to 10 roles per week, practice interviews twice a week, learn German one hour per day.

speaker: Mihir
text: And also milestones, like by March, have one strong portfolio project, by April, have 5 interviews, by May, finish thesis. Something like that. And also decision points, like if embedded roles are not working, then pivot to data engineering or something.

speaker: Mihir
text: But with logic, not just random.

speaker: Anna
text: Aha. Got it. 3) Career support in general

speaker: Anna
text: When you need career support, who or what do you usually turn to?

speaker: Mihir
text: First, my friends. Mostly Indian friends also in Munich. We are all like in the same boat.

speaker: Mihir
text: And sometimes German classmates. But with Germans I feel, they are kind, but they do not fully understand visa pressure, you know. Then I also talk to my girlfriend in India, on video call.

speaker: Mihir
text: She is supportive, but she cannot help with Germany specifics. And then I use online resources, like YouTube, LinkedIn posts, sometimes Reddit, but it is too much noise. And I use AI tools, like ChatGPT, also sometimes Gemini, but mostly ChatGPT.

speaker: Anna
text: Any university career services?

speaker: Mihir
text: I tried one workshop at university. It was okay, like basic, how to structure CV, what is Anschreiben, things like that. But it was very general.

speaker: Mihir
text: And also mostly in German. So I felt, okay, nice, but not enough.

speaker: Anna
text: What has actually helped you, and what felt unhelpful or frustrating?

speaker: Mihir
text: Helpful is when someone tells me concrete reality. Like, in Germany they like this format, like this evidence, they ask this in interviews, like they want projects. Also helpful is when someone reads my CV and says, this is confusing, cut this.

speaker: Mihir
text: Unhelpful is generic motivation. Like, keep going, you will be fine. Because I know they mean well, but it does not reduce my uncertainty.

speaker: Mihir
text: It is like a band-aid.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you give me an example of high support but not effective? Like someone you trust, but it did not help?

speaker: Mihir
text: Yes. My close friend here, he is like my brother. He listens.

speaker: Mihir
text: He tells me, you are smart, you will get job, do not worry. And I trust him, like emotionally. But after talking, I still do not know what to do next.

speaker: Mihir
text: So I feel supported, but not effective. And then sometimes I feel worse because I wasted time talking instead of doing. But also, I need that sometimes.

speaker: Mihir
text: So it is complicated.

speaker: Anna
text: That is really clear. Supportive but not directional.

speaker: Mihir
text: Yes, exactly.

speaker: Anna
text: And in terms of paid support, have you ever tried a paid career coach?

speaker: Mihir
text: No. I have not. I thought about it, but I have no idea where to find the right one.

speaker: Mihir
text: And I also worry about money and scams. Like, there are many coaches on Instagram or LinkedIn. Everyone is a coach.

speaker: Mihir
text: How to know who is legit. And also, I feel I need it urgently, but I do not know how to choose.

speaker: Anna
text: When you say urgently, what makes it urgent right now?

speaker: Mihir
text: Because I feel time is running. I am 26, still student. I moved from role to role.

speaker: Mihir
text: In India I did internship, then I worked one year, then I came to Germany, then I did working student. So it feels like I am always junior. I want to finally start a real career, like a full-time role with a plan.

speaker: Mihir
text: And also visa and money. So I feel urgency.

speaker: Anna
text: Okay. 4) Human coaching: experience and trust

speaker: Anna
text: You mentioned you had a mentor via a student association. Can you tell me about that experience? How did you meet, and what was the context?

speaker: Mihir
text: Yes. So there is a student association in Munich, like for international students in engineering. They have mentorship program.

speaker: Mihir
text: I joined because a friend told me. It was like, you fill a form, they match you with a mentor. My mentor was an Indian guy, but he has been in Germany for, like, 10 years.

speaker: Mihir
text: He works at a big automotive supplier as embedded engineer. So he knows the system.

speaker: Anna
text: How did the first meeting go?

speaker: Mihir
text: We met in a cafe near Sendlinger Tor. It was very Munich. He was like, okay, tell me your story.

speaker: Mihir
text: And I started talking, very messy. Like, I did this, then that, then Germany. And he listened.

speaker: Mihir
text: And then he asked very structured questions. Like, what do you want, what are your constraints, what do you enjoy, what are your strengths. And then he also explained how hiring works in Germany.

speaker: Mihir
text: That was the big value.

speaker: Anna
text: What did he explain that was new for you?

speaker: Mihir
text: Many things. Like, he said in Germany, HR screens first, they look for keywords, but also they look for stability. They do not like too chaotic story.

speaker: Mihir
text: He said, your CV must show a narrative. He also explained that for embedded roles, you need to show you worked close to hardware, not only Python. And he explained Blue Card basics.

speaker: Mihir
text: Like, he said do not panic, but you need a salary threshold and a degree. He said also, in interviews they will ask about your projects in detail, and they want you to explain your decisions, not just list tools.

speaker: Anna
text: Do you remember a specific moment in that conversation that changed something for you?

speaker: Mihir
text: Yes. He looked at my CV and he said, your CV is like a shopping list. He said, you wrote everything you touched, but you did not write what you achieved.

speaker: Mihir
text: And he took one bullet, like I wrote, implemented firmware in C. He said, no, write, implemented firmware module for sensor communication, reduced latency, improved stability, something like that. And then he asked me, did it improve anything?

speaker: Mihir
text: And I was like, I do not know, it just worked. And he said, go back, measure, or at least describe impact. That was like, okay, German style.

speaker: Mihir
text: Evidence.

speaker: Anna
text: What made you trust him?

speaker: Mihir
text: Hmm. Competence, first. He clearly knew the market.

speaker: Mihir
text: He used German terms, like he talked about Tarif, about Betriebsrat, about what working student means, like Werkstudent, and he understood. Second, he was honest. He did not sugarcoat.

speaker: Mihir
text: He said, Munich is competitive, do not apply randomly. Third, he understood international student constraints. He knew visa, language anxiety.

speaker: Mihir
text: And also he was respectful. Like, he did not judge me for being confused. So I felt safe.

speaker: Anna
text: Did you feel confidentiality with him? Like you could share things?

speaker: Mihir
text: Yes, because it was one-on-one and he also said, whatever we discuss stays here. It was informal but he said it. So I felt okay to say I am stressed.

speaker: Anna
text: After that mentor meeting, what changed in your behavior?

speaker: Mihir
text: I changed my CV format. I made it one page, more focused. I made sections like projects, skills, and I removed many random things.

speaker: Mihir
text: I also started tracking applications in a spreadsheet, like he suggested. And I started preparing for interviews by doing STAR method. He told me about that.

speaker: Mihir
text: So I had more structure.

speaker: Anna
text: Did it solve the confusion about which role fits you?

speaker: Mihir
text: Not fully. It helped me understand the process. But role identity is still open.

speaker: Mihir
text: He gave some suggestions, like, based on my interest, embedded software is good, but he also said, do not chase buzzwords. But I still feel uncertain.

speaker: Anna
text: That is interesting. So high trust, and useful, but not fully effective for the deeper question.

speaker: Mihir
text: Yes. Exactly. Because he was one person, and also he has his own bias.

speaker: Mihir
text: He is in automotive. He thinks embedded is the best. Maybe he is right, but maybe not for me.

speaker: Anna
text: If you imagine a paid career coach, what would you expect from them that your mentor did not provide?

speaker: Mihir
text: I expect more systematic. Like not only one meeting. I want a process.

speaker: Mihir
text: Like first, assess my strengths, values, constraints. Then explore roles. Then choose direction.

speaker: Mihir
text: Then make plan, with weekly check-ins. And accountability. And also someone who knows the German market but also can understand international student reality.

speaker: Mihir
text: And also, I want them to push me, not only comfort me. Like, you said you will apply to 10 jobs, did you do it. But in a kind way.

speaker: Anna
text: What would make you trust a paid coach?

speaker: Mihir
text: Hmm. Proof of competence, like their background. Maybe they worked in hiring or in industry.

speaker: Mihir
text: Also testimonials, but that can be fake. Maybe if they understand my context quickly, like they ask good questions. Also transparency, like what they can and cannot do.

speaker: Mihir
text: And confidentiality. And also, realistic guidance. Like not, you will get job in 2 weeks.

speaker: Mihir
text: That would make me distrust.

speaker: Anna
text: Have you had any interactions with someone who claimed to be a coach, and it felt off?

speaker: Mihir
text: Yes, on LinkedIn. Someone messaged, like, I can help you get job in Germany, pay me 500 euros, I will rewrite your CV. It felt like spam.

speaker: Mihir
text: He did not ask anything about me. So I ignored.

speaker: Anna
text: So for you, trust is tied to personalization and realism.

speaker: Mihir
text: Yes.

speaker: Anna
text: Okay. 5) AI tools: experience and trust

speaker: Anna
text: Now let us talk about AI tools. You said you use AI for learning, debugging, and explaining German job ads. Can you tell me about the first time you used AI for a career-related thing?

speaker: Mihir
text: I think first time was in 2023, when I came to Germany. I was applying for working student roles. I saw job ads in German.

speaker: Mihir
text: Like, they had many words I did not understand. Like, Kenntnisse in, Erfahrung mit, wünschenswert, Vorteil, and all these. So I copied the job ad into ChatGPT and I asked, explain this in English and tell me what are must-have and nice-to-have.

speaker: Mihir
text: And it gave me a structured breakdown. That was very helpful.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you give me a vivid example, like a specific job ad or requirement where it helped you decode expectations?

speaker: Mihir
text: Yes. There was one job ad for Embedded Software Working Student. It said something like, Erfahrung in hardwarenaher Programmierung, Kenntnisse in Echtzeitbetriebssystemen, gute Deutschkenntnisse wünschenswert, and then it had like, CAN, LIN, SPI, I2C.

speaker: Mihir
text: I was like, okay, I know SPI, I2C, a bit of CAN from university, but not deep. And German part made me panic. So AI explained, hardwarenah means close to hardware, real-time OS is like FreeRTOS, and wünschenswert means desirable but not mandatory.

speaker: Mihir
text: It also told me, highlight SPI and I2C projects, and for German, mention that you are learning and comfortable in English. That reduced stress.

speaker: Anna
text: So speed and translation reduced anxiety.

speaker: Mihir
text: Yes, because it made it clear. Like, okay, I do not need to be perfect German. At least for working student, maybe English okay.

speaker: Anna
text: What about using AI for learning and debugging in your technical work?

speaker: Mihir
text: That is daily. Like, I am working with C on microcontrollers. Sometimes there is a bug, like a pointer issue, or timing issue.

speaker: Mihir
text: I paste a simplified code snippet, and ask, what could cause this behavior. It gives ideas. Or for Python scripts, it helps me fix errors fast.

speaker: Mihir
text: Also for concepts, like interrupts, DMA, concurrency, it explains in simple terms. I use it like a tutor. And I trust it more there, because I can test the output.

speaker: Mihir
text: If it says something wrong, I will see.

speaker: Anna
text: So you can verify.

speaker: Mihir
text: Yes. In career advice, it is harder to verify.

speaker: Anna
text: You also mentioned you sometimes use AI for confidence-building, like am I behind. Can you describe a moment when you did that?

speaker: Mihir
text: Yes. One night, I was scrolling LinkedIn. I saw someone from my university, same age, got a full-time role at a big company.

speaker: Mihir
text: And then I felt like, I am failing. So I opened AI and I wrote like, I am 26, still studying, is it too late, am I behind compared to others in Germany. And AI replied like, no, everyone has different path, it is normal, you have international experience, do not compare.

speaker: Mihir
text: It felt good for 5 minutes. But then it felt generic. Like a fortune cookie.

speaker: Anna
text: Did it help in any practical way?

speaker: Mihir
text: Not really. It calmed me, but not grounded. Then I asked, okay, give me a plan.

speaker: Mihir
text: And it gave a plan, but it was too optimistic. Like, apply to 50 jobs per week, build two projects, learn German to B2 in 2 months. And then I felt worse because it was unrealistic.

speaker: Mihir
text: So sometimes AI increases anxiety.

speaker: Anna
text: That is a really concrete example. What do you think made that plan feel untrustworthy?

speaker: Mihir
text: Because it did not consider my actual time. I have thesis, work, cooking, life. It was like, just do everything.

speaker: Mihir
text: Also, it did not ask me questions first. It assumed. And it gave too many options.

speaker: Mihir
text: Like, you can be embedded, you can be data, you can be product, you can do PhD. And I was like, no, I need fewer options, not more.

speaker: Anna
text: So for trust in AI, speed and availability are positives, but accuracy and fit to your context are concerns.

speaker: Mihir
text: Yes.

speaker: Anna
text: Are there moments where you do not trust AI, but you still use it because it is useful?

speaker: Mihir
text: Yes. For example, CV templates. Sometimes I ask AI to rewrite a bullet point.

speaker: Mihir
text: I do not fully trust it because it can exaggerate or use fake metrics. But it still gives a good structure. Like it transforms boring sentence into impact format.

speaker: Mihir
text: Then I edit. So low trust but still useful.

speaker: Anna
text: That is a good separation. You do not fully trust the content, but you trust the format help.

speaker: Mihir
text: Exactly.

speaker: Anna
text: What are your trust drivers for AI specifically? If you list them.

speaker: Mihir
text: Speed. Availability at night. Ability to explain and translate.

speaker: Mihir
text: Also, it is non-judgmental. Like, I can ask stupid questions. And it can structure information.

speaker: Mihir
text: Like it can turn a mess into bullets.

speaker: Anna
text: And what reduces trust?

speaker: Mihir
text: Hallucinations. Like sometimes it says things with confidence that are wrong. Also generic advice.

speaker: Mihir
text: Also privacy, like if I paste my CV with personal data. I try to remove, but still. And also emotional flattening.

speaker: Mihir
text: Like it responds like a bot, even if it is trying to be nice. It does not feel like real understanding.

speaker: Anna
text: When you say hallucinations, have you caught a specific one?

speaker: Mihir
text: Yes. One time I asked about Blue Card requirements. It gave salary threshold numbers, but they were inconsistent.

speaker: Mihir
text: Like one message said one number, then later another. Then I checked other sources and it was confusing. So I realized I cannot rely on it for legal stuff.

speaker: Mihir
text: I can use it to understand concept, but not exact.

speaker: Anna
text: Okay. 6) Human vs AI comparison via specific tasks

speaker: Anna
text: Now I want to compare human support and AI support through specific tasks. I will name a task, and you tell me what you would prefer and why. First task clarifying career options, like what roles exist and which fits you.

speaker: Mihir
text: For options, I use AI first. Because it can list many roles and explain. Like, difference between embedded engineer and firmware engineer and systems engineer.

speaker: Mihir
text: That is helpful. But then I need a human to narrow down based on me. Because AI can list, but it does not know my personality.

speaker: Mihir
text: A human can ask, what do you enjoy, do you like working alone, do you like debugging, do you like customers, and then guide.

speaker: Anna
text: Second task making a decision, like choosing a direction for the next year.

speaker: Mihir
text: Human. Because decision is emotional and also has risk. I want someone to challenge me and also understand my constraints.

speaker: Mihir
text: AI can give pros and cons, but it feels like a spreadsheet. Human can see my fear and maybe call it out.

speaker: Anna
text: Third task: planning concrete next steps, like a weekly plan, checklists, milestones.

speaker: Mihir
text: This is interesting. I think AI can draft a plan fast. Like, it can give a template, weekly schedule, application pipeline.

speaker: Mihir
text: But I need human to make it realistic and hold me accountable. Because AI will not check if I did it. Also human can adjust based on real life.

speaker: Anna
text: Fourth task rewriting CV and cover letters.

speaker: Mihir
text: AI is strong for language and structure. But human is better for truth and positioning. Like, AI can make it sound good, but sometimes too generic.

speaker: Mihir
text: A human who knows German hiring can say, this is not credible, or this story is confusing. Also mentor can say, do not write this because Germans interpret it differently.

speaker: Anna
text: Fifth task preparing for interviews.

speaker: Mihir
text: Both. AI can simulate questions, like give me typical embedded interview questions, and I can practice. It can also help me structure answers.

speaker: Mihir
text: Human is better for feedback on my communication, like how I sound, my confidence, and also the cultural part. Like in Germany they want concise answers, not too much self-promotion but also not too shy. A human can tell me.

speaker: Anna
text: Sixth task emotional support, like when you feel behind.

speaker: Mihir
text: Human. Even if it is not effective in plan, it is real. AI can give reassurance, but it feels hollow.

speaker: Mihir
text: But also, sometimes I do not want to burden friends, so I use AI for venting. It is like, okay, at least something. But not the same.

speaker: Anna
text: That is very nuanced. You are using both, but for different functions.

speaker: Mihir
text: Yes. And also because human costs money and time. AI is free and instant.

speaker: Mihir
text: That matters.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you describe a specific episode where AI helped you in a technical or career task more than a human could at that moment?

speaker: Mihir
text: Yes. At work, we had a bug in firmware. It was like, sometimes sensor read fails.

speaker: Mihir
text: My colleague was busy. I asked AI, and it suggested that I should check if the chip select timing is correct and if there is a race condition with interrupt. It gave me a checklist.

speaker: Mihir
text: I tested, and actually there was an interrupt that was messing the timing. So AI helped me faster than waiting for colleague. That felt very effective.

speaker: Mihir
text: And trust was okay because I verified.

speaker: Anna
text: And a specific episode where a human helped more than AI?

speaker: Mihir
text: The mentor meeting, definitely. Because he understood my whole context. He told me realistic steps.

speaker: Mihir
text: And also he gave me confidence grounded in experience. Like, he said, I have seen many people like you, it works, but you must focus. That felt different than AI saying, you can do anything.

speaker: Anna
text: And an episode where AI increased anxiety?

speaker: Mihir
text: The night with the plan. Also sometimes when I ask, what is best career for me, it gives too many options and I spiral. It is like opening 20 tabs.

speaker: Anna
text: And an episode where a human was kind but not effective?

speaker: Mihir
text: My friend I mentioned. Also my mom. She is like, beta, do not worry, everything will be fine, just study.

speaker: Mihir
text: In Hindi she says, sabbbbbb jhe. It is sweet. But it does not help with Germany job market.

speaker: Mihir
text: 7) Trust–effectiveness link

speaker: Anna
text: Now I want to explore the link between trust and effectiveness in your experience. When you think about human mentoring or coaching, how does trust affect whether it is effective?

speaker: Mihir
text: Trust is like, it decides how honest I can be. If I do not trust, I will only show the nice story. Like, I will say, I am fine, I just want CV tips.

speaker: Mihir
text: But the real issue is, I am scared and confused. If I trust, I can say, I feel behind, I do not know my direction, I am panicking. Then the person can help with the real problem.

speaker: Mihir
text: Also, if I trust their competence, I will follow their advice. If I doubt, I will not act. So trust affects action.

speaker: Anna
text: What are the main drivers of trust for you in a human mentor or coach?

speaker: Mihir
text: Competence, like they know German hiring, they know engineering roles. Empathy, but not pity. Understanding international constraints, like visa, language, working student.

speaker: Mihir
text: Confidentiality. Structure, like they have a process, not random talking. And also feeling seen, like they remember details, they connect patterns.

speaker: Mihir
text: Like, if I say, I always avoid applying, they notice avoidance and help.

speaker: Anna
text: And for AI, how does trust affect effectiveness?

speaker: Mihir
text: For AI, trust is more like, do I believe the information is correct and relevant. If I trust it is accurate, it is effective. If I suspect it is hallucinating, I will double-check and then it is less effective because it adds work.

speaker: Mihir
text: But sometimes even if I do not trust fully, it can still be effective as a tool, like templates. So effectiveness can happen with partial trust. But for deep decisions, low trust means I will not rely on it.

speaker: Mihir
text: I will only use it as a brainstorming tool.

speaker: Anna
text: You just said something important. Sometimes low trust, still useful. Can you explain that with one more example?

speaker: Mihir
text: Yes. Cover letters in German. My German is not enough.

speaker: Mihir
text: So I ask AI to draft an Anschreiben. I do not trust the exact wording because it can sound too formal or weird. But it gives me a base.

speaker: Mihir
text: Then I edit with my friend who knows German better. So I use it despite low trust.

speaker: Anna
text: And opposite direction, high trust but not effective. We talked about supportive friends. Is there any case where you trusted a mentor or human, but it did not lead to results?

speaker: Mihir
text: Hmm. Actually yes. After my mentor meeting, I felt high trust.

speaker: Mihir
text: But I did not follow everything. Like, he told me to apply regularly and track. I did for two weeks, then thesis got heavy, I stopped.

speaker: Mihir
text: So effectiveness was limited not because his advice was bad, but because I did not implement. And also because he was not there to follow up. So trust was high, but outcome not fully.

speaker: Anna
text: So there is also an accountability component.

speaker: Mihir
text: Yes. Trust alone is not enough. I need structure and accountability.

speaker: Mihir
text: That is why I think a paid coach could help, if they do weekly check-ins.

speaker: Anna
text: If we separate trust and effectiveness, how do you personally define effectiveness in career support? What are your indicators?

speaker: Mihir
text: Effectiveness is when after the support, I have clarity and next steps. Like, I know what role I am targeting, what companies, what skills to highlight. Also my applications become stronger, like more interviews.

speaker: Mihir
text: Interview performance improves, like I answer better. And also reduced overwhelm. Like I feel calm because I know what to do.

speaker: Mihir
text: And confidence grounded in evidence, like not just feeling good, but actually seeing progress.

speaker: Anna
text: You mentioned reduced overwhelm. What reduces overwhelm for you concretely?

speaker: Mihir
text: Checklists. Like, today do this. And also having fewer decisions.

speaker: Mihir
text: If someone says, for next month, focus only on embedded roles, do not also apply to data. That reduces overwhelm. And also a timeline.

speaker: Mihir
text: If I see, okay, thesis ends May, apply from March, interview April, then I feel less panic.

speaker: Anna
text: Great. 8) Preferences and hybrid model reaction

speaker: Anna
text: I want to embed a quick micro-poll now. I will ask you to rate from 0 to 10. Zero means no trust or not effective at all, ten means fully trust or extremely effective.

speaker: Anna
text: And then you explain. Okay?

speaker: Mihir
text: Okay.

speaker: Anna
text: First, trust in human coaches or mentors for career guidance. What number?

speaker: Mihir
text: I would say 7.5. Maybe 8 if it is a good mentor like mine.

speaker: Anna
text: Why 7.5 or 8, not higher?

speaker: Mihir
text: Because humans can be biased, or they can not understand my niche. Also, some coaches can be scammy. So I trust conditionally.

speaker: Mihir
text: But when I find a good one, I trust a lot.

speaker: Anna
text: Second, trust in AI tools for career guidance. What number?

speaker: Mihir
text: For career guidance, maybe 6. For technical learning, higher, like 8. But for career, 6.

speaker: Anna
text: Why 6?

speaker: Mihir
text: Because it is helpful and fast, but accuracy and context is uncertain. And it can give generic advice. So I trust it as an assistant, not as authority.

speaker: Anna
text: Third, perceived effectiveness of human support for your situation right now.

speaker: Mihir
text: Effectiveness, I think 7. Because mentor helped, but I need more continuous support. If I had a coach, maybe it could be 9, but I have not tried.

speaker: Mihir
text: So based on my experience, 7.

speaker: Anna
text: And perceived effectiveness of AI tools for your situation right now.

speaker: Mihir
text: Hmm. Maybe 6.5. It helps a lot in small tasks, like translating job ads, drafting, learning.

speaker: Mihir
text: But for the big picture, it does not solve.

speaker: Anna
text: Great. Thanks. Now, I will describe a hybrid model briefly.

speaker: Anna
text: Imagine a service where AI helps you explore options, translate job ads, draft CV bullets, and create a structured weekly plan. Then a human coach steps in for deeper sessions: choosing a direction, reviewing your story, practicing interviews, and accountability check-ins. How does that sound?

speaker: Mihir
text: That sounds like exactly what I need. Because AI can do the fast work, and human can do the deeper work. Also it could reduce cost, because human time is expensive.

speaker: Mihir
text: So if AI does preparation, human session is more focused. That sounds good.

speaker: Anna
text: What would you need to trust such a hybrid model?

speaker: Mihir
text: Transparency. Like, what does AI do, what does human do. And data privacy, like who sees my data.

speaker: Mihir
text: Also quality of the human coach, like matching. Because if I get wrong coach, then it fails. And also boundaries, like AI should not give legal advice about visa with exact numbers, but it can explain concepts.

speaker: Mihir
text: So clear boundaries.

speaker: Anna
text: Matching is a big one. What would make you feel the matching is good?

speaker: Mihir
text: If the coach understands international student path and engineering. Like, not a general life coach. Also maybe someone who worked in Germany hiring.

speaker: Mihir
text: And also personality fit. Like, I want structured, not too fluffy. I want someone who gives plan.

speaker: Mihir
text: So if the system asks me questions and matches based on that, I would trust more.

speaker: Anna
text: And what would make you suspicious or reduce trust in a hybrid model?

speaker: Mihir
text: If it feels like marketing, like promises too much. Or if the AI outputs are clearly generic. Or if they hide that AI is used.

speaker: Mihir
text: I prefer honesty. Also if they push me to buy more sessions. Like upsell.

speaker: Mihir
text: That would reduce trust.

speaker: Anna
text: If you had to choose today, for the next two months, what would your ideal support mix be?

speaker: Mihir
text: I think, AI daily for small tasks, like job ads, learning, drafting. And then a human coach maybe every week or every two weeks for direction and accountability. And maybe one mentor in industry for real insight.

speaker: Mihir
text: Like, if I can talk to someone at a company I target. That would be ideal.

speaker: Anna
text: And if we go deeper, what would you want the coach to deliver by the end of those two months, as concrete outputs?

speaker: Mihir
text: Output one: clear role direction, like embedded software engineer focusing on industrial or automotive or robotics. Output two: CV and LinkedIn story aligned. Output three: portfolio project with documentation.

speaker: Mihir
text: Output four: interview prep plan and practice sessions. Output five: application pipeline system. And maybe German learning plan for job context, like key phrases.

speaker: Anna
text: Oh wow. That is very structured.

speaker: Mihir
text: Yes. Because structure calms me.

speaker: Anna
text: Mee too. When you imagine having that structure, what changes emotionally?

speaker: Mihir
text: I feel less like I am floating. Like, right now I feel like I am swimming with no shore. If I have a plan, I can breathe.

speaker: Mihir
text: Even if plan is hard, at least it is clear. Then I feel, okay, I am not wasting time. Then I can sleep better.

speaker: Anna
text: That is a strong image. Swimming with no shore.

speaker: Mihir
text: Yes. It is like that.

speaker: Anna
text: One last thing in this section. You said you are not against career coaches and you feel you need one urgently, but you have no idea where to find the right one. What would make it easier to find the right one?

speaker: Mihir
text: A place where coaches are vetted. Like, not random. Also where I can see, okay, this coach knows engineering, knows international students, knows Germany hiring.

speaker: Mihir
text: And reviews that are real. And maybe a first short call to check fit. And clear pricing.

speaker: Mihir
text: Because hidden pricing is suspicious.

speaker: Anna
text: Great. 9) Closing

speaker: Anna
text: We are coming to the end. I want to check if there is anything important we did not cover about your experiences with human support, AI tools, trust, or effectiveness.

speaker: Mihir
text: No.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you, Mihir. That was very helpful and very clear. I will stop recording now.

speaker: Anna
text: Any final questions for me?

speaker: Mihir
text: No questions. Thank you. It was actually nice to talk.

speaker: Anna
text: Thanks. Take care.

speaker: Mihir
text: You too.

speaker: Anna
text: Hi Katharina. Thanks for joining. Before we start, do I have your permission to record this interview for research purposes?

speaker: Anna
text: Everything will be anonymised, and you can skip any question.

speaker: Katharina
text: Yes, you have my permission to record. And thank you for saying I can skip. That already feels, um, safer.

speaker: Anna
text: Great. And are you comfortable doing this mostly in English, with occasional German words if that feels more natural?

speaker: Katharina
text: Yes, totally. I work in English anyway. And sometimes I just say Gehalt or Jahresgespraech because it is faster.

speaker: Anna
text: Perfect. Just to set expectations, the interview is about your experience with career support, including human coaching and AI tools, and especially how you think about trust and perceived effectiveness. There are no right or wrong answers.

speaker: Anna
text: If something feels too personal, we can move on. Does that work?

speaker: Katharina
text: Yes. I will try to be honest. Sometimes I notice I start to sound like I am presenting.

speaker: Katharina
text: So if I do that, tell me.

speaker: Anna
text: That is helpful. I may ask you to slow down or give an example, but I will not push you to share anything you do not want to. Could you start by introducing yourself briefly and what you do?

speaker: Katharina
text: Sure. I am Katharina, 28, born in Germany, and I live in Hamburg. I work as a product marketing specialist at a B2B software company.

speaker: Katharina
text: We are SaaS. We sell a platform that helps mid-market companies manage procurement workflows and supplier onboarding. So it is, like, supply chain and operations focused, not shiny consumer stuff.

speaker: Katharina
text: My role is product marketing, so positioning, messaging, launches, sales enablement, customer stories, sometimes competitive analysis, and internal stakeholder management, which is basically half the job.

speaker: Anna
text: Great thank you. Let us start with your current career situation. 2) Participant context and career situation

speaker: Anna
text: Where are you currently in your career, and what career decisions or questions are you facing, or recently faced?

speaker: Katharina
text: Um, I would say I am at this point where I am good at my job, and people trust me operationally, but I feel stuck. Like a plateau. The workload is high, I am involved in everything, but the path forward is unclear.

speaker: Katharina
text: I am not sure if I should aim for a PMM Lead track, like leading a small team or owning a bigger portfolio, or if I should pivot into product management. And then, connected to that, I avoided addressing a salary mismatch for too long. So my questions are: what is my next role, and how do I advocate for myself without burning bridges.

speaker: Anna
text: When you say you feel stuck, what does that look like day to day?

speaker: Katharina
text: It looks like this constant sprint mode. We have releases every two weeks, but real launches are more like monthly, and then bigger themes quarterly. And it is always messy because product changes scope late, sales wants certainty early, and marketing wants a clean story.

speaker: Katharina
text: I am in the middle. I do messaging docs, I build decks, I do training sessions, I write release notes that are actually product announcements, I coordinate with customer success for webinars, I chase people for approvals, I negotiate claims with legal, and I am also supposed to do research like win-loss and persona updates. There is never a quiet week.

speaker: Katharina
text: And because there is so much to do, I feel like I cannot step back and think strategically about my own career. I keep telling myself, later.

speaker: Anna
text: What was the most significant decision in the last 6 to 12 months?

speaker: Katharina
text: Investing in coaching. Like paying real money and committing time. That was the biggest decision because it meant I am admitting I cannot just power through.

speaker: Katharina
text: And it also meant I committed to two uncomfortable things: actually addressing salary, and exploring roles beyond my current company, including product roles. Before that, I was talking about it, but not doing it.

speaker: Anna
text: What made it difficult to make that decision?

speaker: Katharina
text: A few things. One is I am used to solving problems alone. Another is I was worried it would be a waste of money, like some fluffy advice.

speaker: Katharina
text: And also, time. Because the workload is high, so scheduling five sessions feels like another project. And honestly, I had a bit of shame.

speaker: Katharina
text: Like, why do I need help for something adults should figure out. But then I was also not sleeping well, and I had this feeling of, if I do not change something now, I will just slowly become bitter.

speaker: Anna
text: When did you notice the plateau? Was there a moment, or was it gradual?

speaker: Katharina
text: It was gradual. But there were two moments. One was a performance review cycle where my manager said, you are doing great, you are reliable, everyone likes working with you.

speaker: Katharina
text: And I was happy for five minutes, but then I realised, there is no concrete plan. No clear next step. Just more work.

speaker: Katharina
text: The second moment was when a new product manager joined and I was basically onboarding them on messaging and customer context, and they had a higher salary than me, which I found out indirectly. And I was like, wait. I am doing senior work, but I am paid like an earlier-career specialist.

speaker: Anna
text: That brings us to salary mismatch. Could you describe what you mean by mismatch, and how you avoided addressing it?

speaker: Katharina
text: So, I joined three years ago at 52k base. At the time I thought it was okay. Hamburg is expensive, but I was also coming from a smaller marketing job, and I was just happy to get into B2B SaaS.

speaker: Katharina
text: Over time my scope grew a lot. I was owning launches for two product areas: supplier onboarding and approval workflows. I also started mentoring a working student, I built the competitive battlecards, and I was running monthly enablement sessions.

speaker: Katharina
text: But my salary increases were small and very standard. Like 3 percent, then later a small bump when my title changed to specialist. But the market moved.

speaker: Katharina
text: Recruiters started reaching out with ranges like 65 to 75 for PMM roles. And then I compared with peers. Not exact, because Germany is weird about salary conversations, but I had enough signals that I was below the band for my impact.

speaker: Anna
text: And how did you avoid addressing it?

speaker: Katharina
text: By telling myself stories. Like, now is not the right time. The company is investing, budgets are tight.

speaker: Katharina
text: Or, there are salary bands, so nothing can change. Or, I should first prove myself in this one more launch. There is always a next milestone.

speaker: Katharina
text: Also, I told myself, if I ask, I will be seen as difficult. Like the annoying person who makes things about money. And I did not want that identity.

speaker: Anna
text: Under those stories, what was the fear?

speaker: Katharina
text: Fear of rejection. Fear of being told no, and then having to face what that means. Because if they say no, then either I accept it and feel undervalued, or I have to consider leaving, which is also scary because changing jobs is energy, interviews, uncertainty.

speaker: Katharina
text: And I was already tired. So avoidance felt like self-protection.

speaker: Anna
text: What kind of support did you feel you needed at that point?

speaker: Katharina
text: Structure and accountability. And also someone who can hold the emotional part without making it therapy. Like, I did not need to talk about my childhood.

speaker: Katharina
text: I needed to talk about why I avoid money conversations and how to still do them. And I needed someone who knows the German corporate context, like salary bands, how performance reviews work, what is realistic in a negotiation.

speaker: Anna
text: What was your work background before this role?

speaker: Katharina
text: I did a Bachelor in business administration, and during that I had internships in marketing, mostly B2B. Then I worked two years in a smaller company in Hamburg, like a services company, doing marketing generalist work. Then I moved into SaaS.

speaker: Katharina
text: So in total I have around five to six years of work experience if you count internships, but three years in this specific PMM type role.

speaker: Anna
text: And in your current company, what is the structure like? Is it a startup, scaleup, corporate?

speaker: Katharina
text: It is like a scaleup. Around 250 people. Headquarters in Hamburg, but we have offices in Berlin and Munich too.

speaker: Katharina
text: Product and engineering are mostly Hamburg and Berlin. We sell to mid-market, and the sales cycle is longer, like three to six months. So PMM is heavy on enablement and proof points.

speaker: Anna
text: Okay. Let us talk about career support in general. 3) Career support in general

speaker: Anna
text: When you need career support, who or what do you usually turn to?

speaker: Katharina
text: Usually friends first. Some friends from university, some friends in tech. Then sometimes colleagues I trust, like one product manager who is very straightforward.

speaker: Katharina
text: I also read stuff online, like PMM career ladders and salary reports, but those can be generic. And I have used AI tools lightly, mainly for writing, like CV bullets or interview question lists.

speaker: Anna
text: What has actually helped, and what felt unhelpful or frustrating?

speaker: Katharina
text: Helpful is when someone gives structure and also asks uncomfortable questions. Like, what do you actually want, and what are you avoiding. And also, someone who understands the context.

speaker: Katharina
text: Like B2B, cross-functional politics, German salary norms. Unhelpful is generic encouragement. Like, you are great, you deserve more.

speaker: Katharina
text: It feels good, but it does not change behaviour.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you give an example of trusted but not effective support?

speaker: Katharina
text: Yes. My best friend from university. I trust her completely.

speaker: Katharina
text: She is kind, she listens. But she works in public sector communications. Her advice is shaped by that environment.

speaker: Katharina
text: She told me, just wait for the next review, they will recognise you, and do not push too much. And I felt emotionally supported, but it was not effective. It kept me passive.

speaker: Katharina
text: She did not challenge my avoidance because she hates conflict too. So it was trust without effectiveness.

speaker: Anna
text: And the opposite, effective but not trusted?

speaker: Katharina
text: AI is the obvious one. It can give me a pretty good template for a negotiation email or a structured interview answer. That is effective for that narrow task.

speaker: Katharina
text: But I do not trust it with sensitive context, like exact salary numbers or internal politics. So I do not share the real inputs, which means it cannot help with the deeper part.

speaker: Anna
text: If you think about your company environment, do people talk openly about career development?

speaker: Katharina
text: They say the right things. Like, we care about growth, we have frameworks. But in reality, it is mostly driven by business needs.

speaker: Katharina
text: Promotions happen when a team needs it or when someone threatens to leave. That is my cynical view. There are also good managers, but there is a lot of ambiguity.

speaker: Anna
text: What did you try before coaching to address the plateau?

speaker: Katharina
text: I tried working harder, honestly. Taking more ownership. I also tried asking my manager for a growth plan, but it stayed vague.

speaker: Katharina
text: Like, keep doing what you are doing, take more strategic initiatives. But no concrete milestones. I also tried doing informational chats internally with product managers, but those were informal and I did not follow through.

speaker: Katharina
text: And I read a lot of content about product management versus product marketing, but reading does not make decisions.

speaker: Anna
text: Okay. Let us move into your human coaching experience. 4) Human coaching: experience and trust

speaker: Anna
text: You mentioned a structured five-session coaching package with a certified coach. Can you describe what it was, how you found it, and what made you commit?

speaker: Katharina
text: Yes. I found the coach through a recommendation from a colleague, actually. She said the coach is certified and also used to working with people in tech.

speaker: Katharina
text: I checked her website, which looked serious, not too salesy. The package was five sessions, each 75 minutes. Three were online on Zoom, one was in-person in Hamburg, and the last one was online.

speaker: Katharina
text: There was also email support between sessions, like accountability check-ins. I committed because I realised I was spending energy avoiding decisions. And the cost, ironically, made it real.

speaker: Katharina
text: Like, if I pay, I will show up.

speaker: Anna
text: What was the cost range, if you feel comfortable sharing?

speaker: Katharina
text: It was around 1,100 euros for the package. So not cheap. I hesitated.

speaker: Katharina
text: But then I thought, I spend money on other things that do not change my life. And this might.

speaker: Anna
text: Tell me about the first session. What happened, and what was the early trust moment for you?

speaker: Katharina
text: The first session was very structured, which I loved. She started with confidentiality boundaries explicitly. She said, everything you share stays here, and she explained the only exceptions, like if there is a serious risk situation, but for career topics it is confidential.

speaker: Katharina
text: She also asked me what I need to feel safe in coaching. That surprised me. No one in work asked me that.

speaker: Katharina
text: And she outlined her process transparently. She said, we will clarify your situation, define a goal, identify blockers, build a plan, and practise the key conversations. It felt like a process, not a vibe.

speaker: Anna
text: When she asked what you need to feel safe, what did you answer?

speaker: Katharina
text: I said, I need confidentiality, obviously, and I need clear structure. And I said, I need challenge without shame. Like, you can confront me, but do not make me feel stupid.

speaker: Katharina
text: And she repeated it back, like, challenge without shaming, got it. And then she said, if at any point you feel shame in the room, tell me, because shame blocks learning. That was like, wow.

speaker: Katharina
text: That made me trust her quickly.

speaker: Anna
text: How else did trust form early?

speaker: Katharina
text: Competence. She understood the German corporate context. Like, she asked about salary bands, job levels, performance review cadence.

speaker: Katharina
text: She knew how managers talk here. And she did not jump into advice immediately. She asked questions first.

speaker: Katharina
text: That made me feel she is not projecting. Also, she was consistent. She ended the session with clear homework and clear next steps.

speaker: Katharina
text: That reliability builds trust for me.

speaker: Anna
text: What were your trust drivers for a human coach, if you list them out?

speaker: Katharina
text: Confidentiality, structure, competence in my market, empathy, challenge, consistency, and being seen. Like remembering details, catching patterns, not just listening passively.

speaker: Anna
text: Did you have any doubts about her early on?

speaker: Katharina
text: A little. I was worried it would be too psychological and not practical. Because I am a practical person.

speaker: Katharina
text: But she balanced it. She would explore the emotional blockers and then translate into action. That is what made it work.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you describe a moment where she challenged you without shaming, and it changed your behaviour?

speaker: Katharina
text: Yes. In session two, I was talking about salary in a very analytical way. I was describing benchmarks, role scope, market ranges.

speaker: Katharina
text: And she stopped me and said, you are speaking like a consultant. Where are you in this story. What are you actually afraid of.

speaker: Katharina
text: I got quiet. I felt exposed. But her tone was calm, not accusing.

speaker: Katharina
text: And then she said, I am not asking to judge you, I am asking because fear is driving your actions more than data. And I admitted, I am afraid they will say no and then I will feel small, and I will have to decide whether to leave. That admission changed the work.

speaker: Katharina
text: After that, we did not pretend it is just a rational negotiation. We worked on the fear response too.

speaker: Anna
text: What was it like to say that out loud?

speaker: Katharina
text: It was uncomfortable. I felt like, oh my god, I am 28 and I am scared of a conversation. But also relieving.

speaker: Katharina
text: Because it was the truth. And once it was spoken, it felt less like this shadow that controls everything.

speaker: Anna
text: How did it change your behaviour after that session?

speaker: Katharina
text: It shifted me from endless preparation to action. Because before, I would say, I need more data, more proof. After that, I realised, no amount of data will remove fear.

speaker: Katharina
text: So we practised the conversation and planned timing. Also, I started noticing avoidance in other areas. Like I avoid asking product for clarity because I do not want conflict.

speaker: Katharina
text: And I started being more direct.

speaker: Anna
text: You mentioned concrete outcomes: a target role list, negotiation script, two mock interviews, and a six-week plan with weekly accountability. Could you walk me through each outcome and what it looked like?

speaker: Katharina
text: Sure. We basically treated it like a mini project.

speaker: Katharina
text: Outcome one: target role list. We defined two tracks. Track A was product marketing path, aiming for Senior PMM or PMM Lead.

speaker: Katharina
text: Track B was product management, but realistically associate PM roles, because I do not have direct PM ownership. For each track, we created a list of companies and roles, including salary ranges, location constraints, and what skills I need. It was a spreadsheet.

speaker: Katharina
text: Very German.

speaker: Katharina
text: Outcome two: negotiation script. We built a structure for the salary conversation: opening, rationale, ask, silence, handling objections, next steps. We wrote example lines, and we practised saying them out loud without softening.

speaker: Katharina
text: Outcome three: two mock interviews. One mock interview was tailored to a PMM lead style role. The other was tailored to an associate PM role, with product case questions and prioritisation.

speaker: Katharina
text: We recorded them, and I reviewed my answers.

speaker: Katharina
text: Outcome four: six-week plan with weekly accountability. She created weekly themes and tasks, and I had to send a Friday update. It was simple but it worked.

speaker: Anna
text: Let us go deeper into the target role list. What did you actually put on it?

speaker: Katharina
text: We listed about, um, 18 roles total. For PMM, we listed companies like mid-size SaaS in Hamburg, Berlin remote-friendly companies, and a few larger ones with PMM teams. I avoided mega corporations because I do not want pure politics.

speaker: Katharina
text: For product, we listed associate PM roles in B2B platforms, because my domain knowledge is supply chain and procurement. We also listed internal options like moving into a product operations type role, or taking ownership of a roadmap area informally. But we were honest that internal pivots are slow.

speaker: Anna
text: What criteria did you use to decide what is a good role?

speaker: Katharina
text: We used criteria like: learning curve, autonomy, manager quality, workload realism, and salary. Also how cross-functional the role is. I like cross-functional, but I want healthier boundaries.

speaker: Katharina
text: And location, because I live in Hamburg and I do not want to relocate. I could do occasional travel, but not moving.

speaker: Anna
text: What did you learn from comparing PMM lead versus product management?

speaker: Katharina
text: I learned that my desire for product management is partly a desire for more influence, and partly an escape fantasy. Like, if I become PM, then I will be respected and paid more, and my work will be more strategic. But that is not automatically true.

speaker: Katharina
text: Product can be just as chaotic. And PMM lead path is more realistic short-term because I already have strength there. The coach helped me see that I can also negotiate influence within PMM, like owning strategy, not just execution.

speaker: Anna
text: Now negotiation script. Can you share one or two example lines you practised, without quoting them as a script, just describing them?

speaker: Katharina
text: Yes. We practised starting with a calm frame, like saying I want to discuss compensation aligned with my scope and market benchmarks. Then stating my target number clearly, like targeting 65k base, based on comparable PMM roles in Hamburg.

speaker: Katharina
text: And then anchoring it in impact, like the launches I owned, enablement outcomes, adoption metrics. And we practised a line for salary band objections, like asking what band my role is mapped to and what is required to move within it or to the next level. That line was powerful because it shifts from personal pleading to process.

speaker: Anna
text: How did you practise? Was it just repeating, or role-play?

speaker: Katharina
text: Role-play. She played my manager, and she pushed back. Like, she said, budget is tight, or we can revisit later, or you are doing great but.

speaker: Katharina
text: And I had to respond without collapsing. We also practised silence. She literally made me sit in silence after stating the number.

speaker: Katharina
text: That was hard because I fill silence with explanations.

speaker: Anna
text: What was your default pattern in those role-plays?

speaker: Katharina
text: Over-explaining and apologising. Like, I would say, if possible, or I know it is a lot, or I understand. And she stopped me.

speaker: Katharina
text: She said, you can be polite without shrinking. That was a key learning.

speaker: Anna
text: Tell me about the actual salary conversation in real life. What happened?

speaker: Katharina
text: Okay. So I scheduled a meeting with my manager, framed as development and compensation alignment. I did it after a successful launch, not during a crisis week.

speaker: Katharina
text: The meeting was 45 minutes. I started with a summary of my scope changes over the last year, like owning two product areas, enablement, mentoring. Then I said I want to align my compensation with that scope and the market.

speaker: Katharina
text: I stated the target number, 65k base. My manager did not react dramatically. He said, thank you for being direct, and he asked me what data I used.

speaker: Katharina
text: I shared two sources, like recruiter ranges and an internal level mapping we have.

speaker: Anna
text: How did he respond regarding bands?

speaker: Katharina
text: He said there are salary bands and my current salary is within the band for my level, but near the lower end. He also said moving to 65k might require a level change, like senior specialist. He suggested a step approach: an immediate adjustment plus a plan for level change in the next cycle.

speaker: Katharina
text: And he asked if I would be open to taking on a more strategic initiative, like owning messaging for a new module and mentoring a junior person formally.

speaker: Anna
text: How did you feel in that moment?

speaker: Katharina
text: Relief, because he did not reject me. Also a bit annoyed, because it felt like, of course I am already doing more, but now it is formalised. But I stayed calm.

speaker: Katharina
text: The coach helped me not take it personally. We agreed on next steps: he would talk to HR and come back in two weeks. And we scheduled a follow-up.

speaker: Anna
text: And what was the outcome?

speaker: Katharina
text: The outcome was, I got an increase to 58k immediately, effective next month. And we set a target for moving to senior specialist by the next review, with a band that would put me around 62 to 64, depending on performance and budget. So I did not get 65 right away.

speaker: Katharina
text: But it was a meaningful correction. Also, the conversation itself was a huge win, because I stopped avoiding it. And now I have a documented plan.

speaker: Anna
text: That sounds realistic. How did you interpret that result emotionally?

speaker: Katharina
text: Mixed. Part of me was like, finally. Part of me was like, I should have asked earlier.

speaker: Katharina
text: And part of me was like, maybe I should still explore external options because internal movement is slow. The coach helped me hold that complexity without spiralling.

speaker: Anna
text: Let us talk about the mock interviews. What happened in the first mock interview? What questions were hardest?

speaker: Katharina
text: In the first mock interview for PMM lead, she asked questions like: describe a launch that did not go well, how do you measure PMM impact, how do you handle conflict between product and sales, and tell me about a time you influenced stakeholders without authority. Those were hard because I have examples, but I would ramble. I would go into details about stakeholder drama and forget to state results.

speaker: Katharina
text: Also, I realised I under-sell my impact because I say we, not I.

speaker: Anna
text: And what improved after the second mock interview?

speaker: Katharina
text: After the second, I was more structured. I used a simple structure: context, action, result, learning. I also got better at naming metrics.

speaker: Katharina
text: Like, for a launch, I mentioned adoption rate, sales cycle influence, demo conversion, or enablement completion. Even if metrics are imperfect, stating them shows you think about outcomes. And I stopped apologising in my answers.

speaker: Katharina
text: That was big.

speaker: Anna
text: For the associate PM mock interview, what was challenging?

speaker: Katharina
text: Prioritisation. She asked a case like: you have three feature requests, sales wants A, customers complain about B, engineering wants C, how do you decide. And I could reason, but I felt insecure because I do not own a roadmap now.

speaker: Katharina
text: We reframed my PMM experience as relevant because I have customer insight, competitive context, and cross-functional coordination. I learned to speak in trade-offs, not just messaging.

speaker: Anna
text: Now the six-week plan. Can you describe what you actually did week by week, not just the plan on paper?

speaker: Katharina
text: Yes. Week 1, I gathered data and wrote a baseline. I collected job descriptions, salary ranges from recruiter conversations, and I mapped my current responsibilities.

speaker: Katharina
text: I also tracked my time for one week to see where I actually spend time.

speaker: Katharina
text: Week 2, I did role exploration. I had two informational chats. One with a PMM Lead in a Berlin SaaS company, and one with an associate PM in Hamburg.

speaker: Katharina
text: I also talked to an internal PM about what skills I would need. Week 3, I updated my CV and LinkedIn. I rewrote bullets to focus on impact, like improved enablement adoption, reduced sales cycle confusion, and led messaging for two modules.

speaker: Katharina
text: I also created a small portfolio doc with two launch case studies, one successful, one messy, showing what I learned.

speaker: Anna
text: Oh wow and next.

speaker: Katharina
text: Week 4, negotiation prep. This was the hardest week because we had a big release and there was chaos. I missed one accountability update because I was exhausted.

speaker: Katharina
text: But then I recovered. I practised the salary script twice, once with the coach and once alone. I also wrote down my fear responses, like if they say no, what do I do.

speaker: Katharina
text: Then week 5, execution. I had the salary conversation with my manager. And I submitted three applications, two PMM roles and one associate PM.

speaker: Katharina
text: I also reached out to a recruiter contact.

speaker: Katharina
