text: And week 6, iteration. I reviewed what worked, adjusted my plan, and kept tracking metrics. I also had the follow-up salary meeting.

speaker: Katharina
text: And I did one more interview prep session because I got a screening call.

speaker: Anna
text: You mentioned weekly accountability. What did that look like, concretely?

speaker: Katharina
text: Every Friday by 6 pm, I sent a short update email or message. Five bullet points: what I did, what I avoided, what I learned, what is next, and what support I need. The coach replied with one or two questions.

speaker: Katharina
text: Sometimes she just asked, what is the smallest next action you can do in 15 minutes. That question is annoying but effective. It breaks the procrastination.

speaker: Anna
text: Did you ever feel resistance to the accountability?

speaker: Katharina
text: Yes. Sometimes I felt like, I am already overloaded, now I have homework. And sometimes I felt childish, like I need someone to check on me.

speaker: Katharina
text: But then I noticed it works. And the tone was not policing. It was supportive, but firm.

speaker: Anna
text: This is a good moment to ask about micro-poll ratings. I will ask four quick ratings, 0 to 10, and I want your reasoning. First: trust in human coaches, in general.

speaker: Katharina
text: In general, I would say 7 out of 10.

speaker: Anna
text: Why 7?

speaker: Katharina
text: Because I believe humans can create real relational safety and challenge. But quality varies a lot. Some coaches are too fluffy or too generic.

speaker: Katharina
text: And trust depends on competence and boundaries. So I trust the potential, but not automatically the person.

speaker: Anna
text: Second rating: trust in AI tools for career support.

speaker: Katharina
text: 4 out of 10.

speaker: Anna
text: Why 4?

speaker: Katharina
text: Because I trust it for low-stakes tasks like rewriting text or generating a checklist. I do not trust it for sensitive context or high-stakes decisions. Also, I do not fully trust privacy, and I do not trust that it understands my specific situation.

speaker: Katharina
text: It can sound confident while being generic.

speaker: Anna
text: Third rating: perceived effectiveness of human coaching for your situation.

speaker: Katharina
text: 8 out of 10.

speaker: Anna
text: Why 8 and not higher?

speaker: Katharina
text: Because it created concrete outcomes and behaviour change, but it did not solve everything. I still have workload constraints. And some uncertainty remains about whether I pivot to product.

speaker: Katharina
text: Coaching helped me act and reduce avoidance, but it is not magic.

speaker: Anna
text: Fourth rating: perceived effectiveness of AI tools for your situation.

speaker: Katharina
text: 5 out of 10.

speaker: Anna
text: Why slightly higher than trust?

speaker: Katharina
text: Because effectiveness for me includes speed and output. AI can create a useful output even if I do not trust it deeply, because I do not share sensitive inputs. So it is effective in narrow tasks, like templates, bullet rewriting, interview question lists.

speaker: Katharina
text: But it is not effective for deep behaviour change.

speaker: Anna
text: Great. Let us continue with AI tools in more detail. 5) AI tools: experience and trust

speaker: Anna
text: What AI tools have you used, and for what career-related tasks?

speaker: Katharina
text: Mostly ChatGPT. I also tried one CV tool that claims it optimises for ATS, but it was not great. With ChatGPT, I used it to rewrite CV bullets, like turning my messy sentence into an impact bullet.

speaker: Katharina
text: I also used it to brainstorm interview questions for PMM roles and to draft a follow-up email after an interview. And one time I asked it for a negotiation script structure.

speaker: Anna
text: What did you like about it?

speaker: Katharina
text: Speed and structure. Like, if I am staring at a blank page, it gives me something to react to. It also helps me reduce perfectionism because I can iterate faster.

speaker: Katharina
text: And it does not judge. If I ask a basic question, it does not roll its eyes.

speaker: Anna
text: And what did you dislike or distrust?

speaker: Katharina
text: Lack of context and relational safety. It cannot sense when I am avoiding. It cannot hold discomfort.

speaker: Katharina
text: It also does not know my company culture. And I do not want to type in sensitive details like internal politics or exact salaries. So I self-censor.

speaker: Katharina
text: That limits usefulness.

speaker: Anna
text: Do you think trust in AI could increase for you, and under what conditions?

speaker: Katharina
text: Maybe, if there were very clear data boundaries and if it was transparent about uncertainty. Like, if it says, I am not sure, here are options, rather than sounding confident. And if it could remember context safely, but that is also scary.

speaker: Katharina
text: Because remembering context means storing data. So I am conflicted.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you describe a specific moment when AI was effective for you, even if you did not fully trust it?

speaker: Katharina
text: Yes. The negotiation email template. I wanted to request a meeting with my manager without making it sound like a threat.

speaker: Katharina
text: AI suggested a calm structure: frame it as development and compensation alignment, propose a time, and mention you want to prepare and share context. That was effective. But I did not include my salary number or detailed frustrations.

speaker: Katharina
text: I kept it generic.

speaker: Anna
text: And a moment when AI output was not effective?

speaker: Katharina
text: When I asked for salary benchmarks in Hamburg for PMM. It gave ranges that felt too broad and not grounded. And it sounded very certain.

speaker: Katharina
text: That made me cautious. I then used actual salary reports and recruiter conversations instead. So it reminded me: AI can be wrong in a confident tone.

speaker: Anna
text: How do you define trust for AI, compared to trust for humans?

speaker: Katharina
text: For AI, trust is more like reliability and predictability. Does it give a coherent structure, does it not hallucinate too much, does it respect boundaries. For humans, trust includes emotional safety, confidentiality, and being seen.

speaker: Katharina
text: It is more relational. AI cannot do that in the same way.

speaker: Anna
text: And how do you define effectiveness, separately?

speaker: Katharina
text: Effectiveness is: did it help me move forward. Did it create clarity, action, measurable outcomes, confidence, reduced avoidance. For AI, effectiveness might be faster drafting.

speaker: Katharina
text: For human coaching, effectiveness is behaviour change, like actually having the salary conversation.

speaker: Anna
text: You said earlier that coaching felt like a psychologist for career questions. Could you expand on that in relation to AI?

speaker: Katharina
text: Yes. The coach noticed patterns. Like when I intellectualise or when I avoid.

speaker: Katharina
text: And she could challenge me gently. That is psychological. AI can reflect language patterns a bit, but it does not feel like a real mirror.

speaker: Katharina
text: And also, I do not want AI to be my therapist. That feels wrong. I want it to be a tool.

speaker: Katharina
text: 6) Human vs AI comparison via specific tasks

speaker: Anna
text: I want to compare human coaching and AI via specific tasks. I will list tasks and ask which one you prefer, and why. Task one: clarifying options and direction, like PMM lead versus product management.

speaker: Katharina
text: Human. Because direction is tied to values and fears. AI can list pros and cons, but it cannot ask the right uncomfortable question in a human way.

speaker: Katharina
text: My coach could say, you say you want product, but are you escaping something. That question mattered.

speaker: Anna
text: Would you use AI at all for that task?

speaker: Katharina
text: As a support tool. Like generating a competency matrix: what skills PMM lead needs, what skills associate PM needs. Or drafting questions to ask in informational interviews.

speaker: Katharina
text: That is great. But the decision-making and meaning part, human.

speaker: Anna
text: Task two: planning concrete steps and maintaining momentum.

speaker: Katharina
text: Hybrid. AI can generate templates and reminders, but human accountability was what made me actually do it. I do not feel accountable to AI.

speaker: Katharina
text: I can ignore notifications. With a human, I felt, I committed, and she will notice.

speaker: Anna
text: Task three: CV and application writing.

speaker: Katharina
text: AI is good for wording. Human is good for narrative. So again hybrid.

speaker: Katharina
text: AI can rewrite bullets, but a human can help me choose what story to tell. Like, am I positioning myself as PMM lead, or as a pivot to product. That is strategy.

speaker: Anna
text: Task four: interview preparation.

speaker: Katharina
text: Both. AI can generate question lists and help structure answers. Human can simulate pressure and give feedback on my presence and confidence.

speaker: Katharina
text: My coach caught things like I shrink my voice when talking about money or impact. AI would not catch that.

speaker: Anna
text: Task five: salary negotiation.

speaker: Katharina
text: Human. Because it is emotional. I needed role-play and someone to push back realistically.

speaker: Katharina
text: AI can give scripts, but I would not share the real fear, and I would not practise the awkward parts. And the awkward parts are the point.

speaker: Anna
text: You already gave examples of trusted but not effective and effective but not trusted. I want to make sure we capture those clearly. Could you restate one example of trusted but not effective, and one example of effective but not trusted?

speaker: Katharina
text: Trusted but not effective: my university friend. I trust her fully, but her advice was generic and kept me passive. Effective but not trusted: AI negotiation template.

speaker: Katharina
text: It produced a useful structure, but I did not trust it with sensitive context, so it stayed shallow.

speaker: Anna
text: Do you have an example where you trusted a human coach but something was not effective, at least in a small way?

speaker: Katharina
text: Hmm. Yes. Sometimes I trusted her process, but a specific exercise did not land.

speaker: Katharina
text: Like she asked me to visualise an ideal day in five years. I found it too abstract. I trust her, but that exercise did not directly help.

speaker: Katharina
text: We moved on quickly. So trust does not guarantee every tool is effective. But overall it was.

speaker: Anna
text: And do you have an example where AI was effective but you felt it was not safe or you would not rely on it?

speaker: Katharina
text: Yes. When I asked for possible interview answers about conflict management, it gave a nice structure. But I would not copy it directly because it can sound generic and not truthful.

speaker: Katharina
text: And I would not want to reveal my real internal conflicts to it. So I used it as a base, but not as a truth source.

speaker: Anna
text: In your B2B PMM reality, what are the biggest tensions you manage between stakeholders?

speaker: Katharina
text: Product wants to ship, and they hate marketing language. Sales wants clear claims and competitive differentiation. Customer success wants stability and fewer surprises.

speaker: Katharina
text: Marketing wants consistency across channels. And leadership wants results. PMM is always negotiating priorities.

speaker: Katharina
text: Like, product says, we cannot commit to dates, and sales says, we need dates. I end up translating. That translation work is not always visible, but it is critical.

speaker: Anna
text: How does that context affect what you want from coaching?

speaker: Katharina
text: I needed someone who understands that my stress is not just workload, it is relational complexity. I am constantly managing expectations. Coaching helped me set boundaries, like saying no to last-minute requests, and also helped me frame my impact in that messy environment.

speaker: Katharina
text: 7) Trust–effectiveness link

speaker: Anna
text: Now I want to focus directly on the link between trust and perceived effectiveness. In your experience, how does trust affect whether coaching is effective?

speaker: Katharina
text: For me, trust is the gateway. If I trust the coach, I admit the real thing I am avoiding. And that real thing drives behaviour change.

speaker: Katharina
text: Without trust, I stay on the surface. Like, help me write a better CV. With trust, I can say, I am terrified of being rejected, and I feel guilty asking for money.

speaker: Katharina
text: That changed what we worked on. And because we worked on the real blocker, the coaching became effective.

speaker: Anna
text: You said trust formed early because of confidentiality boundaries, transparent process, and challenge without shame. Can you describe that early trust moment in more detail, like what she said or did, and what you felt?

speaker: Katharina
text: In the first session, she explained confidentiality very clearly, and she asked me what safety means for me. That alone was huge. Then she said something like, we will go at a pace that is challenging but not overwhelming, and you are in control.

speaker: Katharina
text: She also set boundaries for herself, like she is not my friend, she is my coach, and the container is the session. That professionalism felt safe. I felt, okay, this is not gossip, this is not judgement, this is work.

speaker: Anna
text: How did that trust translate into actions or outcomes?

speaker: Katharina
text: Because I trusted her, I did the homework. I sent the Friday updates. I practised the script even when it felt cringe.

speaker: Katharina
text: And I admitted when I avoided something. Like week 4, when I missed the update, I told her I felt ashamed. If I did not trust her, I would have disappeared.

speaker: Katharina
text: That continuity created momentum, which created outcomes.

speaker: Anna
text: Let us go back to salary avoidance. What story did you tell yourself, and what fear was underneath?

speaker: Katharina
text: The story was: it is not the right time, budgets are tight, salary bands mean it is fixed, I should just be grateful and prove myself more. Underneath was fear of hearing no and feeling undervalued. And fear of having to choose, stay or leave.

speaker: Katharina
text: And also fear of being seen as greedy or difficult.

speaker: Anna
text: What triggered the shift from avoidance to action?

speaker: Katharina
text: Two things. One was external validation: recruiter ranges and seeing that my market value is higher. That made it concrete.

speaker: Katharina
text: The second was the coach asking me to name the fear. Once I named it, I could not hide behind spreadsheets. It became a behavioural issue, not a data issue.

speaker: Anna
text: You said coaching is high-impact when it includes structure plus relational safety. Could you explain what each part contributed?

speaker: Katharina
text: Structure gave me a path and reduced overwhelm. It turned vague anxiety into weekly steps. Relational safety allowed me to be honest about what I avoid.

speaker: Katharina
text: Without safety, structure becomes a checklist I can fake. Without structure, safety becomes a nice conversation that does not change my life. The combination is what made it high-impact.

speaker: Anna
text: You also said it feels like a psychologist for career questions, not therapy. How does that fit into trust and effectiveness?

speaker: Katharina
text: It fits because psychological insight is needed for behaviour change. But it needs boundaries. Therapy can go into family dynamics and deeper trauma.

speaker: Katharina
text: Coaching stayed focused: workplace patterns, decision-making, communication. That boundary made me trust it, because I did not feel it would spiral into something too heavy. And that focus made it effective, because we stayed on actions.

speaker: Anna
text: You now track outcomes. How does tracking connect to trust and effectiveness?

speaker: Katharina
text: Tracking makes effectiveness visible. Otherwise it is just feelings. I track applications sent, interviews, salary conversation milestones.

speaker: Katharina
text: I also track a weekly avoidance score, like did I do the hard thing. Seeing numbers motivates me. And it also reduces shame.

speaker: Katharina
text: Like, if I did not apply this week, I can see why, maybe workload. It becomes data. That is something my coach modelled.

speaker: Katharina
text: So trust enabled me to be honest, and then tracking made progress measurable.

speaker: Anna
text: Could you give me the specific metrics you track and how often?

speaker: Katharina
text: Weekly, I track: number of applications submitted, number of networking reach-outs, number of interview invites, and number of interview prep sessions. For salary, I track: meeting scheduled, meeting done, follow-up scheduled, decision received. And I track my mood, like 1 to 5, and sleep quality, because career stress affects my mental stability.

speaker: Katharina
text: It is simple, not a full mental health app. Just awareness.

speaker: Anna
text: How has tracking affected your motivation?

speaker: Katharina
text: It helps me not catastrophise. Like, if I feel stuck, I can look and see, actually I had two interviews this month. Or I made one salary conversation happen.

speaker: Katharina
text: That builds confidence. It also shows me when I am avoiding. If a week is empty, I can ask, what happened.

speaker: Katharina
text: And then I can adjust.

speaker: Anna
text: If trust is the gateway, what would happen if trust was low with a coach?

speaker: Katharina
text: I would perform. I would talk about safe topics. I would not admit fear.

speaker: Katharina
text: And then the coaching would be less effective, because it would stay at surface tactics. It might still help a bit, but not the high-impact kind.

speaker: Anna
text: And with AI, you described a different pattern. How does the trust-effectiveness link look there?

speaker: Katharina
text: It is more transactional. AI can be effective without deep trust because I keep it in a safe zone. I do not share sensitive stuff, so it cannot help with that, but it can still help with drafting.

speaker: Katharina
text: So trust limits the scope. And because the scope is limited, effectiveness is limited too. That is basically the relationship.

speaker: Katharina
text: 8) Preferences and hybrid model reaction

speaker: Anna
text: Imagine a hybrid model where AI supports preparation and follow-up, like structuring goals, drafting documents, and tracking tasks, and a human coach focuses on deeper conversations, accountability, and high-stakes moments. What is your reaction?

speaker: Katharina
text: That sounds ideal. Because AI can reduce admin and make things efficient. I do not need a human to rewrite a bullet point ten times.

speaker: Katharina
text: But I need a human to challenge avoidance and to role-play difficult conversations. And I need accountability from a person. I can ignore an app, but I do not want to ignore a human I respect.

speaker: Anna
text: What would make you trust a hybrid model?

speaker: Katharina
text: Clear boundaries. Like, what data is stored, what is shared with the coach, what stays private. Also, transparency about what AI does and does not do.

speaker: Katharina
text: If AI is positioned as advice, that is risky. If it is positioned as structure and drafting support, okay. And the human needs to own the ethical part and the nuance.

speaker: Anna
text: Where would you prefer AI to lead, and where would you prefer the human to lead?

speaker: Katharina
text: AI can lead in templates, tracking, reminders, and generating question lists. Human should lead in values clarification, identity questions, emotional blockers, negotiation practice, conflict handling, and interpreting context. Also, anything involving risk, like leaving a job or confronting a manager.

speaker: Anna
text: If you had to design your ideal career support experience, what would it look like in practice?

speaker: Katharina
text: It would start with two human sessions to clarify direction and blockers. Then an AI tool would help me set up a plan and track tasks. Then weekly, a short human check-in for accountability and reflection.

speaker: Katharina
text: And AI would help in between with drafting and prep. Also, I would want the human coach to be trained and certified, not just a random influencer. And I would want the whole thing to feel professional, not like motivational content.

speaker: Anna
text: What concerns would you have about a hybrid approach?

speaker: Katharina
text: Misalignment. Like if AI suggests something that conflicts with the coach, I would be confused. Also privacy.

speaker: Katharina
text: And the risk that AI makes it feel too transactional, losing the relational safety. If the system pushes me to input sensitive feelings into a tool, I would resist. I want my emotions to be held by a human, not by a chatbot.

speaker: Anna
text: If you think about your own timeline, would AI have helped you more at the beginning or later?

speaker: Katharina
text: Later. At the beginning, I needed relational safety to admit what I was avoiding. AI could not give me that.

speaker: Katharina
text: Once I had momentum, AI could support maintaining it.

speaker: Anna
text: You mentioned mental stability and career satisfaction. How do you connect that to seeking help?

speaker: Katharina
text: People spend most of their time at work. If work is constantly stressful and you feel stuck, it leaks into everything. For me, I noticed I was irritable, I slept badly, I avoided social plans because I was tired.

speaker: Katharina
text: Coaching helped me feel more stable because I had a plan and I took action. That reduced the background anxiety. So seeking help is not weakness.

speaker: Katharina
text: It is, um, maintenance. Like mental hygiene. And I want to be careful because it is not therapy, but it still affects mental stability.

speaker: Anna
text: That is clear. Let us close soon, but I want to make sure we captured the specific concrete episodes the study needs. I will ask a few targeted questions.

speaker: Anna
text: First, the early trust moment. You described confidentiality and process. Was there a specific moment you remember thinking, okay I can trust this person?

speaker: Katharina
text: Yes. It was when she said, tell me what you need to feel safe, and then she repeated it back without judgement. And then when I said, I am ashamed about the salary topic, she did not reassure me in a fake way.

speaker: Katharina
text: She said, shame is common here, and we will work with it. That made me feel normal, not broken.

speaker: Anna
text: Second, the challenge without shaming moment. You described her calling out that you were speaking like a consultant. Did that feel risky?

speaker: Katharina
text: Yes, but in a good way. It felt like she sees through my defence. But her tone was respectful, not mocking.

speaker: Katharina
text: If she had laughed or pushed too hard, I would have shut down. Instead, I felt invited.

speaker: Anna
text: Third, negotiation script practice. Besides stating the number, what was the hardest part?

speaker: Katharina
text: Silence and handling pushback. Like when my manager says, budgets are tight. My instinct is to retreat.

speaker: Katharina
text: Practising responses helped, like asking for process clarity, asking what would be required, agreeing on a timeline. Also, not taking it personally.

speaker: Anna
text: Fourth, mock interviews. What question made you stumble the most, and what changed?

speaker: Katharina
text: The question about measuring PMM impact. I started talking about assets, like decks and webinars. Then she stopped me and said, those are outputs, what are outcomes.

speaker: Katharina
text: That changed my framing. After practice, I could talk about adoption, pipeline influence, and reduced sales confusion.

speaker: Anna
text: Fifth, the six-week plan. What did the weekly accountability feel like emotionally? Motivation, pressure, both?

speaker: Katharina
text: Both. Motivation because I wanted to report progress. Pressure sometimes, but it was healthy pressure.

speaker: Katharina
text: It kept me honest. Also, the coach did not punish me when I failed. She used it as information.

speaker: Katharina
text: That reduced fear.

speaker: Anna
text: Great. I think we have it. Let us move to closing.

speaker: Anna
text: 9) Closing

speaker: Anna
text: Is there anything else you want to add about trust and perceived effectiveness, maybe something people misunderstand?

speaker: Katharina
text: No, not really.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you. Final check are you comfortable with the topics we covered today and the level of detail?

speaker: Katharina
text: Yes. It is anonymous I mean.

speaker: Anna
text: Great. Then I will stop the recording here. Thank you for your time, Katharina.

speaker: Katharina
text: Thank you. It was.

speaker: Anna
text: Hi Amir, thanks for making the time today. How are you?

speaker: Amir
text: Hi Anna. I am good, eehm, a bit tired because I had a lab meeting this morning, but yeah, good.

speaker: Anna
text: Makes sense. Before we start, I want to confirm consent. Do I have your permission to record this interview?

speaker: Anna
text: Everything is anonymized, and you can skip any question at any time.

speaker: Amir
text: Yes, you can record. That is okay.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you. And just checking, are there any topics you would prefer not to discuss today?

speaker: Amir
text: Um, I think it is fine. Maybe nothing super personal, like family details. But career stuff, identity stuff, that is okay.

speaker: Anna
text: Absolutely. We will stay within what feels comfortable. If anything feels too personal, just tell me and we move on.

speaker: Amir
text: Cool.

speaker: Anna
text: Great. Let us begin. 2) Participant context and career situation

speaker: Anna
text: To start, where are you currently in your career, and what career decisions or questions are you facing right now, or recently faced?

speaker: Amir
text: Okay. So, I am 24, I am from Iran, and I have been in Germany four years now. I am based in Cologne, in Köln.

speaker: Amir
text: I am finishing my Master in Human-Computer Interaction. It is like, eehm, between computer science and psychology, you know. My current situation is I am writing my thesis and also working part-time as a working student in UX research.

speaker: Anna
text: What kind of company is it?

speaker: Amir
text: It is a SaaS company, B2B, like a platform for internal workflows, kind of. Not like a sexy consumer app. But interesting problems.

speaker: Amir
text: The team is small. There is one lead UX researcher and then me and one UX designer, and product managers, engineers, you know. I do mostly research ops and some interviews and surveys.

speaker: Anna
text: And what is the biggest career decision you have faced in the last six to twelve months?

speaker: Amir
text: The biggest one was probably choosing my thesis scope and also, like, choosing what kind of first full-time role I should optimize for. Because the thesis topic can lock you in a bit, at least in your narrative. Like if I do something very academic, then I can say I want research track, PhD, blah blah.

speaker: Amir
text: But if I do something more applied, then it is easier to say I want product research. And then there is the visa thing. I am on a student residence permit now.

speaker: Amir
text: I need the job after graduation. So the decision is not purely what I like, it is also what is feasible.

speaker: Anna
text: What made that difficult?

speaker: Amir
text: Um. Multiple constraints. First, the job market right now is weird.

speaker: Amir
text: Like, internships and working student roles are still okay, but junior full-time roles in UX research are not so many. Especially if you need visa sponsorship, you know. Second, language.

speaker: Amir
text: My German is okay for daily life, like I can handle Bürgeramt, I can order food, I can do small talk. But in professional settings, research interviews in German, that is hard. So I ask myself, do I focus on English-speaking roles, or do I push German fast.

speaker: Amir
text: And third, identity, like, what kind of life I want. Stability or autonomy. Like I enjoy structured work, but also I hate feeling stuck.

speaker: Anna
text: When you say identity, what does that mean for you in this context?

speaker: Amir
text: It is like, who am I trying to become in the next two years. Like, do I want to be a very serious researcher, publish papers, conferences, CHI, that world. Or do I want to be more product, shipping, fast feedback loops.

speaker: Amir
text: And then there is the immigrant lens, like, do I want to stay in Germany long term, apply for Blue Card later, or do I keep the option to move, maybe Netherlands, maybe Canada, I do not know. It is not like I can just pick a vibe. There are consequences.

speaker: Anna
text: What kind of support did you feel you needed while making those decisions?

speaker: Amir
text: I needed, um, two things. One is clarity. Like not motivational talk, but clarity.

speaker: Amir
text: And the second is emotional regulation. Because I can think a lot. I overthink.

speaker: Amir
text: I can build a whole decision tree and still feel anxious. So I needed someone or something that can help me name what I am actually afraid of, and then structure it.

speaker: Anna
text: That is helpful. And your thesis, what is it on right now?

speaker: Amir
text: So, my thesis is on how people use AI tools for reflective practices in work contexts. Like, not purely productivity, but reflective thinking, learning from experience. It is like, I studied journaling, reflection prompts, and then how AI changes the affordances.

speaker: Amir
text: I am doing interviews with early-career people actually. So it is meta.

speaker: Anna
text: That is quite aligned with your own habits then.

speaker: Amir
text: Yes, exactly. That is also why it was hard, because it is personally relevant and I can bias myself. So I had to be careful.

speaker: Anna
text: We will come back to that when we talk about AI tools. Before that, tell me a bit about your background. What did you study before the Master?

speaker: Amir
text: In Iran I did undergrad in industrial engineering, but I focused on systems design and some programming. Then I came to Germany, I did a bridge year, language, and then I started the HCI Master. I also did some student projects in interaction design, usability testing, and like, one project with Deutsche Bahn data, but more conceptual.

speaker: Anna
text: And student life in Cologne, how is it for you?

speaker: Amir
text: Cologne is good. It is open, people are friendly compared to some other cities. There is like, this vibe, more relaxed.

speaker: Amir
text: People say, Köln ist ein Dorf, you see the same people. For me, student life is also like working student life. Because I work 20 hours.

speaker: Amir
text: So it is not like partying all the time. But I have routines, like I go to a cafe near Zülpicher Platz, I study, I meet friends. It is okay.

speaker: Amir
text: 3. Career support in general

speaker: Anna
text: When you need career support, who or what do you usually turn to?

speaker: Amir
text: Um. First, I use AI tools a lot, but not for CV mainly. More for reflection.

speaker: Amir
text: Second, I talk with two friends. One is also international, from Turkey, doing data science. Another is German, doing product management.

speaker: Amir
text: We do like, reality checks for each other. And third, sometimes I talk to my supervisor at university, but that is more academic direction.

speaker: Anna
text: What kind of support do you get from your workplace?

speaker: Amir
text: From work, not official. There is no mentoring program. But my lead researcher is supportive.

speaker: Amir
text: She gives feedback, like, how to frame my impact, how to communicate. But she is busy. And also I do not want to be too needy.

speaker: Amir
text: So I use her for concrete questions, like, what skills matter, what portfolios matter, how to prepare for interviews.

speaker: Anna
text: Have you used university career services in Germany?

speaker: Amir
text: Once. At the university we have career counseling, like a workshop. I attended a seminar about Bewerbungen and networking.

speaker: Amir
text: It was helpful for basics, but it was very generic. Also it was in German. I understood, but I was like, okay, this is not my main problem.

speaker: Amir
text: My problem is not how to format a CV, it is like, what am I optimizing for, and what trade-offs I accept.

speaker: Anna
text: What has actually helped you in the past, and what felt unhelpful?

speaker: Amir
text: Helpful is when someone helps me reduce the problem into something actionable. Like, you have three options, define evaluation criteria, run small experiments. Unhelpful is when people just say, follow your passion, or, everything will work out.

speaker: Amir
text: That makes me angry, honestly. Because it ignores the visa reality, and the job market reality.

speaker: Anna
text: So you value realism and structure.

speaker: Amir
text: Yes. But also I need emotional space. It is not only structure.

speaker: Amir
text: It is like, structure plus permission to be uncertain. 4. Human coaching: experience and trust

speaker: Anna
text: Have you ever tried human career coaching, like a private coach, mentor, or career counselor, in a one-to-one format?

speaker: Amir
text: I tried one session, actually. It was through a program at the university, like alumni mentoring. It was not exactly coaching, more mentoring.

speaker: Amir
text: One session, one hour.

speaker: Anna
text: What was it like?

speaker: Amir
text: It was limited. The person was nice, German, he worked in HR at a big company. He asked me about my background, and then he gave advice like, apply widely, build network, improve German.

speaker: Amir
text: It was not wrong. But it did not go deep. Also I felt I had to perform confidence.

speaker: Amir
text: Like, I had to show I am motivated, I am proactive. And maybe it is cultural, but I did not want to share my doubts, like, I am scared I will not get a job and then I have to leave. Because then I feel weak.

speaker: Anna
text: What do you think made it hard to go deeper?

speaker: Amir
text: Two things. First, lack of continuity. One session, there is no trust built.

speaker: Amir
text: Second, I did not know if he really understands my context. Like, he is German, he never had visa pressure. He can say, just take your time.

speaker: Amir
text: For me, time is not neutral. And also, I did not know what he expects. In Germany, people can be direct, but also professional.

speaker: Amir
text: I did not want to overshare.

speaker: Anna
text: When you think about trust in a human coach or mentor, what would make a human feel trustworthy for you?

speaker: Amir
text: Competence, like understanding UX research and the job market, not only general advice. And also, confidentiality, like they explicitly say, this stays here. And the vibe.

speaker: Amir
text: Like, if I feel judged, then no. If I feel they are trying to push me into a standard path, also no. And also, I need them to ask good questions, not only give advice.

speaker: Amir
text: If they only give advice, then it is like, okay, you are just a blog post.

speaker: Anna
text: And what would make a human untrustworthy?

speaker: Amir
text: If they are too confident without understanding my situation. Or if they project their own story. Like, I did this, so you should do this.

speaker: Amir
text: Also if they treat me like a problem to fix. Or if they are, um, biased. Like, I had one experience in a networking event where someone kind of assumed, because I am international, that I will take any job.

speaker: Amir
text: That makes me close.

speaker: Anna
text: If you had to put a number on it, a micro-poll, 0 to 10, where 0 is no trust at all and 10 is full trust, what is your current trust in human coaches for career topics?

speaker: Amir
text: Eehm. I would say 6.

speaker: Anna
text: And why 6?

speaker: Amir
text: Because I know humans can be very insightful and empathetic, and they can understand nuance. But for me, the access is limited, the match is uncertain, and I do not know if they understand visa constraints. So I trust the potential, not the default.

speaker: Anna
text: And perceived effectiveness, same scale 0 to 10, how effective do you think human coaching would be for your situation right now?

speaker: Amir
text: Maybe 5.

speaker: Anna
text: Why lower than trust?

speaker: Amir
text: Because even if I trust them, it may not translate to action, due to cost, time, or mismatch. Like, I can have a nice talk and feel supported, but then what. Also I think for my kind of problems, a lot is internal decision making.

speaker: Amir
text: A coach can help, but they cannot remove the constraints. So effectiveness is moderate.

speaker: Anna
text: That distinction is important. Thank you. 5.

speaker: Anna
text: AI tools: experience and trust

speaker: Anna
text: Now I want to go deeper into AI tools. You mentioned you use AI as a structured reflection partner, almost like guided journaling, three to four times per week. Can you describe what that looks like in practice?

speaker: Amir
text: Yes. So I have a routine. Usually in the evening, after work or after studying.

speaker: Amir
text: Like 20 to 40 minutes. I open the AI chat, and I start with a check-in. I literally write, current state, and then I list, energy level, mood, main concern.

speaker: Amir
text: It sounds like therapy, but it is not therapy. It is like, data plus feelings.

speaker: Anna
text: What happens after the check-in?

speaker: Amir
text: Then I paste my personal prompt. I have a template. It says something like, mirror my assumptions, list possible biases, ask me two clarifying questions, and then propose decision principles, not decisions.

speaker: Amir
text: That last part is important. I do not want it to decide for me. I want it to help me create principles.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you give an example of the prompt template, without exact wording if you prefer?

speaker: Amir
text: Yeah, roughly it is: First, restate what I said in a structured way, like bullet points. Second, identify my hidden assumptions. Third, identify cognitive biases, like loss aversion, catastrophizing, whatever.

speaker: Amir
text: Fourth, ask me questions that challenge me. Fifth, propose a framework, but keep it light, not too many. And then I ask it to propose two or three decision principles that I can reuse.

speaker: Anna
text: How did you develop that routine?

speaker: Amir
text: It evolved. At first I used AI like everyone, for quick questions. Then I noticed I am using it to think.

speaker: Amir
text: Like I can type and it reflects. And then I realized, if I want it to be consistent, I need to design the interaction. HCI mindset, you know.

speaker: Amir
text: Like, I can create an interface behavior through prompts. So I iterated. I removed parts that make it preachy, and I added parts that make it reflect uncertainty.

speaker: Anna
text: When you say you use it three to four times per week, is it scheduled or more reactive?

speaker: Amir
text: Both. I try to do it Sunday evening, like planning week. And then one or two times midweek when I feel stuck.

speaker: Amir
text: And sometimes after something triggers me, like a rejection email, or a weird meeting. Then I use it to process.

speaker: Anna
text: Walk me through a full session from start to end, including how you save outputs.

speaker: Amir
text: Okay. So, step one: I open a note on my laptop where I write a quick raw dump, like, what happened, what I feel. Step two: I paste a cleaned version to AI.

speaker: Amir
text: Step three: I ask it to mirror and find assumptions. Then it responds. I read it slowly.

speaker: Amir
text: Sometimes I feel resistance, like, no, that is not it. Then I reply with corrections. Step four: I ask it to generate principles or trade-offs.

speaker: Amir
text: Step five: I choose one principle that feels true, and I write it in my personal decision log.

speaker: Anna
text: You have a decision log.

speaker: Amir
text: Yes. In Notion. Very German of me.

speaker: Amir
text: It is like, date, topic, options, principle, next step. And I tag it, like visa, career, identity, relationships. Then, over days, I cross-check.

speaker: Amir
text: Like, if on Monday I think I want stability, and on Thursday I think I want autonomy, I compare. I ask, is this mood-driven or value-driven.

speaker: Anna
text: How do you cross-check with AI across multiple sessions?

speaker: Amir
text: I do two things. One is consistency check. I ask AI, based on what I wrote last time, what changed.

speaker: Amir
text: But I do not fully trust its memory, because it may not have the context unless I paste it. So I paste the key points. Second, I do triangulation.

speaker: Amir
text: I talk to a friend, or I write alone without AI. If the principle still holds, then I accept it.

speaker: Anna
text: What does conditional trust mean for you in this AI context?

speaker: Amir
text: It means I trust it as a thinking tool, not an authority. So I trust the process when it helps me see patterns, but I do not trust the content as truth. Like, if it says, the job market is great, I would laugh.

speaker: Amir
text: It does not know my reality. But if it says, you seem to prioritize safety but also fear stagnation, that can be true. So I trust it for mirroring and structuring, not for facts or predictions.

speaker: Anna
text: What makes it feel trustworthy in those moments?

speaker: Amir
text: Internal coherence. Like if it can restate my situation accurately. If it catches contradictions gently.

speaker: Amir
text: If it shows uncertainty, like, this could be one interpretation, not definitive. Also, if it helps name emotions without making me feel stupid. Like, it can say, it sounds like grief or fear, and I am like, yes.

speaker: Amir
text: And it does not require me to perform confidence. With humans, I often perform. With AI, I can write, I am scared, and it is fine.

speaker: Anna
text: That non-judgmental aspect seems important.

speaker: Amir
text: Very important. Because I come from a culture where you have pride, you do not show weakness too much. And also as an immigrant, you always want to appear capable.

speaker: Amir
text: The AI is like, okay, you can be messy here.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you share a vivid example of a value conflict session, like stability versus autonomy, or prestige versus learning versus visa security?

speaker: Amir
text: Yes. There was one in October. I had two opportunities.

speaker: Amir
text: One was an interview process with a big company, like a well-known German brand, maybe automotive supply chain. It was a UX research internship that could lead to a job. It would be stable and looks good.

speaker: Amir
text: The other was a smaller startup in Berlin, remote-first, doing a product I find interesting. They offered a working student role now and maybe a junior role later, but uncertain.

speaker: Anna
text: And what was the conflict?

speaker: Amir
text: The conflict was prestige and visa security versus learning and autonomy. The big company is like, you get structure, you get brand, maybe easier to justify for visa, and more stable salary. But the work might be slower, more bureaucracy, more German language, also.

speaker: Amir
text: The startup is like, fast learning, more autonomy, English, but risk. And I was stuck. I was ruminating.

speaker: Amir
text: Like, if I choose wrong, I waste time. That is catastrophic for me.

speaker: Anna
text: What did you ask the AI in that session?

speaker: Amir
text: I started with, I feel like I am optimizing three different things and they conflict. Then I used my prompt, mirror assumptions, biases. The AI mirrored and said, you assume stability equals safety, but you also assume autonomy equals identity fulfillment.

speaker: Amir
text: It listed biases like, status quo bias, because I am leaning to big company because it feels safe. Also scarcity mindset, because visa makes me fear losing options. And then it asked questions like, what does stability mean concretely, is it contract length, is it learning structure, is it social belonging.

speaker: Anna
text: What did you notice emotionally as you read that?

speaker: Amir
text: I noticed tightness. Like in my chest. Because it made it real.

speaker: Amir
text: It was not abstract anymore. I realized I am afraid of being forced to leave. And also I realized I am afraid of losing myself in bureaucracy.

speaker: Amir
text: So it is like two fears.

speaker: Anna
text: And what decision principle came out?

speaker: Amir
text: The principle was something like, in the next two years, prioritize options that increase visa safety while still giving me skill growth that is transferable. That is a compromise principle. It is not prestige.

speaker: Amir
text: It is not pure learning. It is, increase safety and transferability.

speaker: Anna
text: How did you apply that principle?

speaker: Amir
text: I used it to decide my thesis framing too. I chose a thesis that is relevant to industry, like AI-supported reflection in work contexts, but still has research rigor. So I can apply for UX research roles and also for research assistant roles.

speaker: Amir
text: And then, for the job decision, I did not fully decide only by that principle. I still talked to my friend. But it reduced my anxiety.

speaker: Anna
text: That sounds like a moment where AI truly helped.

speaker: Amir
text: Yes. It created a coherent self-narrative. Like, I am not inconsistent, I am balancing constraints.

speaker: Amir
text: It made me feel less shame. Like, I am not cowardly for wanting stability. It is rational.

speaker: Anna
text: Could you describe another moment where AI helped you take a concrete step?

speaker: Amir
text: Yes. In December I got a rejection from a company after a good interview. I was devastated.

speaker: Amir
text: I wrote to AI, I feel like I will never get a job, I am behind. Then it did something useful: it reframed it as evidence that I can pass interviews, and it helped me create a post-mortem template. Like, what went well, what could improve, what is in my control.

speaker: Amir
text: Then I did that, and I sent a message to the interviewer asking for feedback, in German. I would not do that without the emotional regulation. Because I would just hide.

speaker: Anna
text: So it reduced rumination and supported action.

speaker: Amir
text: Exactly.

speaker: Anna
text: Now, can you give me an example where AI did not help?

speaker: Amir
text: Oh yes. Many. One is when I get into over-intellectualizing.

speaker: Amir
text: Like, I ask it to generate frameworks, and then it gives me five frameworks, and then I feel more overwhelmed. It is like, I wanted clarity and I get a menu. Another is when it gives confident but shallow answers, like, you should network, you should set goals.

speaker: Amir
text: That is like, okay, thanks. And sometimes it can create false certainty. Like, it can write a very coherent narrative that feels good, but it might be too neat.

speaker: Amir
text: And that can be dangerous. Because life is messy.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you recall a specific session where it felt safe but was not effective, meaning trusted but not effective?

speaker: Amir
text: Yes. There was a session after a conflict with my team. I felt misunderstood in a meeting.

speaker: Amir
text: I used AI to vent. It mirrored my feelings very nicely, it validated, it named emotions. I felt calm.

speaker: Amir
text: So I trusted it emotionally. But then it did not produce a next step. I ended the session feeling soothed but still stuck.

speaker: Amir
text: It was like a warm blanket but no map. So trusted, yes. Effective, not really, because I did not act.

speaker: Anna
text: That is a clear distinction. Now the other direction: effective but not fully trusted. Do you have an example where the output was useful but you still did not fully trust it?

speaker: Amir
text: Yes. Sometimes it generates a decision principle that is very elegant. Like, prioritize learning velocity over brand.

speaker: Amir
text: And I am like, that sounds cool, very Silicon Valley. It can be effective in giving me a language to think, but I do not trust it because it might be biased toward certain narratives, like hustle culture. So I take the structure but I validate with my real constraints.

speaker: Amir
text: I ask, does this fit visa, finances, mental health. So it is effective as a tool, not trusted as a worldview.

speaker: Anna
text: What about privacy discomfort, does that ever show up?

speaker: Amir
text: Yes. That is another limit. Sometimes I write something and then I think, okay, where does this go.

speaker: Amir
text: Like, I am not writing illegal things, but still, it is personal. And then I get uncomfortable. So I sometimes abstract.

speaker: Amir
text: I do not write exact company name, I write my workplace. I also do not write exact numbers. And sometimes I choose to journal offline instead.

speaker: Amir
text: So the trust is conditional also because of privacy.

speaker: Anna
text: If you had to rate your trust in AI tools for these kinds of career and identity reflections, 0 to 10, what would you say?

speaker: Amir
text: I would say 8.

speaker: Anna
text: Why 8 and not 10?

speaker: Amir
text: Because there are still hallucinations and overconfidence. Also privacy. Also it can be generic.

speaker: Amir
text: But overall, for my use case, it is consistent and helpful.

speaker: Anna
text: And perceived effectiveness of AI tools for your situation, 0 to 10?

speaker: Amir
text: I would say 8 as well, maybe 8.5 but okay, 8.

speaker: Anna
text: Why?

speaker: Amir
text: Because it helps me create coherent self-narratives and decision frameworks, and it reduces anxiety. But it cannot replace real-world constraints. It also cannot network for me, it cannot sponsor visa.

speaker: Amir
text: So effectiveness is high in thinking, medium in execution.

speaker: Anna
text: You said you do not use AI mainly for CVs. Can you explain why?

speaker: Amir
text: Yes. For CVs, I can do it myself, and also I do not fully trust it to understand German job culture. Also CV is like surface.

speaker: Amir
text: My main struggle is not wording. My struggle is decision making and identity. So I use AI where it is strongest for me: structured reflection, asking questions, mirroring.

speaker: Amir
text: For CV, I prefer to ask my lead researcher or friends.

speaker: Anna
text: How does your HCI mindset shape how you interact with AI?

speaker: Amir
text: I think of it as an interface. Like, the output is influenced by my input. So I try to design prompts like affordances.

speaker: Amir
text: Like, I want it to ask me questions, so I tell it to ask. I want it to show uncertainty, so I ask it to present alternatives. Also I notice when it is leading me.

speaker: Amir
text: Like, it can subtly push a narrative. So I try to make it symmetrical, like, show me multiple interpretations, show bias, do not moralize.

speaker: Anna
text: Do you ever feel you get dependent?

speaker: Amir
text: That is a fear. Sometimes I think, if I always process with AI, will I lose my own ability. But then I see it more like training wheels.

speaker: Amir
text: It helps me learn how to structure. And sometimes I stop using it for a week to see. I can still think.

speaker: Amir
text: So I do not feel addicted, but it is a tool I like.

speaker: Anna
text: When you stop for a week, what changes?

speaker: Amir
text: I ruminate more. I talk more to friends. But friends are busy.

speaker: Amir
text: And I also feel more alone. AI is always available. That is a huge thing.

speaker: Amir
text: For international students, loneliness is real. And AI fills some gap, not socially, but cognitively and emotionally.

speaker: Anna
text: That is an important point.

speaker: Amir
text: Yes. It is like, not companionship, but containment. Like a container for thoughts.

speaker: Amir
text: 6. Human vs AI comparison via specific tasks

speaker: Anna
text: Now I want to compare human versus AI via specific career-related tasks. I will name a task, and you tell me which you would prefer and why. First task: clarifying career options, like industries or roles.

speaker: Amir
text: For clarifying options, AI is good for brainstorming and mapping. Like, it can list industries, roles, skill overlaps. But I do not trust it fully for local specifics.

speaker: Amir
text: So I use AI to generate the space, then I validate with humans or job boards. Humans are better for realistic insider knowledge, like, in Cologne this company hires, or, this role expects German. AI can be too abstract.

speaker: Anna
text: Second task: making a high-stakes decision, like choosing between offers.

speaker: Amir
text: For high-stakes, I want hybrid. AI helps structure criteria and emotions. Human helps reality check and maybe emotional support.

speaker: Amir
text: If I had a coach I trust, I would use them there. But because I do not have one, I use friends.

speaker: Anna
text: Third task: planning concrete next steps, like a job search strategy for three months.

speaker: Amir
text: AI is great for planning, like, weekly plan, track applications, build portfolio. But again, it can be generic. So I use it to propose a plan, then I edit.

speaker: Amir
text: Human can hold accountability better. AI cannot really shame you, which is good and bad. It is good because no judgment, but sometimes I need pressure.

speaker: Anna
text: Fourth task: preparing for interviews.

speaker: Amir
text: AI for mock questions and structuring answers, yes. But for vibe and cultural nuance, humans. Like in Germany, the way you talk about yourself is different.

speaker: Amir
text: AI can help, but a human recruiter or friend helps more.

speaker: Anna
text: Fifth task: dealing with anxiety or self-doubt after rejections.

speaker: Amir
text: AI, definitely. Because I can be messy, I can write at 1 am. It helps me name emotions.

speaker: Amir
text: Humans I do not want to bother always. Also humans can give you their own anxiety. AI is stable.

speaker: Anna
text: Any task where you strongly prefer human?

speaker: Amir
text: When it is about social context, like office politics, or negotiating salary, or reading between lines. AI can give advice, but humans know reality. Also when it is about belonging, like, am I welcome in this team.

speaker: Amir
text: AI cannot feel the vibe.

speaker: Anna
text: Any task where you strongly prefer AI?

speaker: Amir
text: When it is about internal conflict, identity, values. Because humans can judge, even if they do not want to. AI is safer.

speaker: Amir
text: Also it is structured. Humans can be chaotic.

speaker: Anna
text: That is a nice contrast. 7. Trust–effectiveness link

speaker: Anna
text: Now I want to explore the link between trust and effectiveness in your experience. When you think about AI tools, how does trust affect whether it is effective?

speaker: Amir
text: Trust is like, permission to use it deeply. If I do not trust it, I will not tell it the real thing. And then it will give generic advice.

speaker: Amir
text: So trust increases depth of input, which increases quality of output. Also if I trust it as a process, I will follow the steps, like check assumptions, generate principles. That makes it effective.

speaker: Anna
text: And when trust is low, what happens?

speaker: Amir
text: I become defensive. Like, it says something and I am like, no, you do not understand. Then I stop.

speaker: Amir
text: Or I use it only for shallow things. Then it is not effective for deep decisions.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you think of a moment where the AI output could have been effective but you did not trust it enough to use it?

speaker: Amir
text: Yes. When it gave me advice about negotiating a contract. It was probably good advice, like, ask for clarity, ask for written terms.

speaker: Amir
text: But I did not trust it because I felt it does not know German legal culture. So I did not act. I asked my friend instead.

speaker: Amir
text: So even if it was effective in theory, lack of trust reduced effectiveness.

speaker: Anna
text: And the other way: can trust itself make something feel effective even when the practical outcome is limited?

speaker: Amir
text: Yes. Like the warm blanket session. I trusted it emotionally, it felt safe.

speaker: Amir
text: That reduced stress, so in that sense it was effective for emotional regulation, but not effective for action. So it depends what effectiveness means. If effectiveness is less anxiety, then it was effective.

speaker: Amir
text: If effectiveness is decision, then no.

speaker: Anna
text: When you think about human coaching, how does trust affect effectiveness there?

speaker: Amir
text: Even more. Because with humans, if I do not trust, I will not share real fears. I will perform.

speaker: Amir
text: Then the coach will coach the performance, not the reality. So trust is a gate. But also, with humans, trust takes time.

speaker: Amir
text: With AI, trust is more immediate because it is non-judgmental by default, at least in feeling.

speaker: Anna
text: Interesting. What are your indicators that something is effective, either AI or human?

speaker: Amir
text: Clear decision principles. Like a sentence I can reuse later. Also a coherent self-story, like, I can explain to myself why I choose something.

speaker: Amir
text: Also concrete next steps. And less anxiety, like my body feels calmer. And better conversations with humans.

speaker: Amir
text: Like, I can talk to my lead researcher and not be chaotic, because I already structured my thoughts with AI.

speaker: Anna
text: That last point is important. Can you give an example?

speaker: Amir
text: Yes. I had a meeting with my lead researcher about my future. Before the meeting I used AI to clarify what I want to ask.

speaker: Amir
text: I wrote, I want feedback on my readiness for junior role, and what gaps. The AI helped me generate a structured agenda. Then in the meeting, I was clear.

speaker: Amir
text: She responded better. So the AI indirectly improved a human interaction.

speaker: Anna
text: So effectiveness can be downstream.

speaker: Amir
text: Exactly. It is like a scaffold. 8.

speaker: Amir
text: Preferences and hybrid model reaction

speaker: Anna
text: Now I want to ask about your preferences. If you could design an ideal support system for career decisions, what would it look like?

speaker: Amir
text: It would be hybrid. AI for preparation, reflection, and follow-up. Human for pivotal moments.

speaker: Amir
text: Like, AI helps me clarify what I feel and what I want. Then human helps with contextual advice and accountability. Then AI helps me integrate after the human session, like, what did I learn, what principle, what next steps.

speaker: Anna
text: What would you want the AI to do, specifically, in a hybrid model?

speaker: Amir
text: First, help me articulate the problem before I talk to a coach. Like, a pre-coaching intake, but intelligent. Second, help me generate questions for the coach.

speaker: Amir
text: Third, after the coach, help me translate insights into actions and principles. Also keep a memory of my principles over time, but with privacy controls.

speaker: Anna
text: And what would you want the human to do?

speaker: Amir
text: Validate reality. Like, tell me what is realistic in Germany, in UX research. Also give me emotional presence when it is heavy.

speaker: Amir
text: AI is safe but it is not real empathy. And the human can hold me accountable. Like, you said you will do this, did you do it.

speaker: Amir
text: AI can remind, but it is not the same.

speaker: Anna
text: If you heard about a platform that combines AI-guided exploration with access to human insiders or coaches, how would you react?

speaker: Amir
text: I would be interested, but I would ask, how do you match me with the human. Because trust depends on fit. If you match me with someone who does not understand international constraints, I will not trust.

speaker: Amir
text: Also I would ask, what happens to my data. And I would want the AI to be transparent about limits. Like, do not pretend to be a therapist.

speaker: Amir
text: Also, I would want pricing that makes sense for a student.

speaker: Anna
text: What would make you trust such a hybrid platform?

speaker: Amir
text: Clear boundaries. Like, what AI does, what human does. Also evidence that the insiders are real, verified.

speaker: Amir
text: And maybe some kind of quality signal, like reviews, but also not fake. And also, the platform should not push me to a path that benefits them. Like, conflict of interest.

speaker: Anna
text: If you had to choose one mode for the next six months, only AI or only human, what would you choose?

speaker: Amir
text: Only AI, honestly, because of access and my habit. But I would miss the human reality check. So I would probably build it through friends.

speaker: Anna
text: That is clear.

speaker: Amir
text: But if I had a really good coach who understands my context, then maybe only human. But that is hypothetical.

speaker: Anna
text: What is your biggest hesitation about AI in career coaching contexts?

speaker: Amir
text: Overconfidence and generic advice. And privacy. Also, if it becomes too persuasive, like it pushes a narrative, then it can manipulate.

speaker: Amir
text: I do not like that. I want autonomy.

speaker: Anna
text: And your biggest hesitation about human coaching?

speaker: Amir
text: Cost. And judgment. And mismatch.

speaker: Amir
text: And sometimes humans can be biased, consciously or not.

speaker: Anna
text: Do you think your preference will change as you become more stable, like after you get a job?

speaker: Amir
text: Yes. I think when visa pressure reduces, I may be more open to exploring identity without urgency. Then human coaching could become more valuable.

speaker: Amir
text: Right now I need speed and structure. Later I may need depth and relational support. 9.

speaker: Amir
text: Closing

speaker: Anna
text: We are coming to the end. Is there anything important about your experience with AI or human career support that we did not cover?

speaker: Amir
text: I guess no we are good.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you. And final check, are you okay with everything we discussed being used anonymously for research purposes?

speaker: Amir
text: Yes, that is fine.

speaker: Anna
text: Great. Thank you for your time, Amir. I really appreciate your openness.

speaker: Amir
text: Thanks Anna. It was interesting. Also for my thesis, it is funny.

speaker: Anna
text: Yes. Okay, I will stop the

speaker: Anna
text: Hi Laura. Thanks for joining. Before we start, do I have your permission to record?

speaker: Anna
text: Everything will be anonymised. You can skip any question, and you can stop anytime.

speaker: Laura
text: Yes, I consent. You can record.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you. Just to confirm, this is for a master thesis about trust and perceived effectiveness in AI-based career coaching versus human coaching, with early-career people in Germany. I will ask about your experiences and perceptions.

speaker: Anna
text: Any topics you prefer not to discuss?

speaker: Laura
text: Um, no, it is fine. Maybe just no very detailed numbers about my salary. But otherwise okay.

speaker: Anna
text: Perfect. We can keep it high level. And if anything feels too specific, we can move on.

speaker: Anna
text: Are you comfortable speaking mostly in English?

speaker: Laura
text: Yes. My English is fine. And sometimes I might put a German word because Frankfurt is like that.

speaker: Anna
text: Totally fine. Okay, let’s start. 2) Participant context and career situation

speaker: Anna
text: To begin, where are you currently in your career, and what career decisions or questions are you facing or recently faced?

speaker: Laura
text: Eehm. So I am 27. I am from Spain originally, and I have been in Germany for six years now.

speaker: Laura
text: I live in Frankfurt. I work in a bank as a data and finance analyst. It is a bit of a hybrid role, like I sit between finance controlling and data analytics, so I do reporting, dashboards, forecasting, and also like ad hoc analysis when stakeholders ask something last minute.

speaker: Laura
text: And the big decision I faced, like in the last six months especially, was whether I stay in finance and go deeper, like try to get promoted, or if I move to a climate mission startup, like a climate fintech or a climate analytics company, or if I apply for a Master track or even PhD track in something like sustainable finance or climate economics.

speaker: Anna
text: And when you say big decision, what made it feel high-stakes for you?

speaker: Laura
text: Um, multiple things. One is that Frankfurt banking culture is intense. Like the prestige logic is real.

speaker: Laura
text: It is like, if you leave, people assume you could not handle it or you are not ambitious. And I am an international, even if I am EU, I still feel that pressure to prove myself. Another thing is money and stability.

speaker: Laura
text: I have a good salary, I can live alone, I can save, I can travel to Spain. If I go to a startup, the pay might be lower, and also the risk is higher, like they can fail. And then the third option, academia, it is like identity.

speaker: Laura
text: I have this voice in my head, like you are smart, you should do research, you should do a PhD, you should do something meaningful and deep. But then I also know academia is stressful and uncertain. Funding, supervision, and like, you can feel very alone.

speaker: Anna
text: You mentioned you have been in Germany six years. What was your path to Frankfurt and to banking?

speaker: Laura
text: I did my Bachelor in Spain in Business Administration and Economics. In my last year I did an Erasmus in the Netherlands, and I liked the international environment. Then I applied for a Master in Germany.

speaker: Laura
text: I did a Master in Finance and Data Analytics, like a program that was half finance, half data. It was in a different city first, not Frankfurt. After that I got an internship in Frankfurt and then a full-time offer.

speaker: Laura
text: And Frankfurt is very, you know, bank-heavy. So it kind of happened.

speaker: Anna
text: What team are you in now, broadly? Like investment banking, retail, risk, something else?

speaker: Laura
text: Risk. Not the trading side. More like risk management and portfolio monitoring.

speaker: Laura
text: I work with credit risk data, and also climate risk started to appear. So I do things like stress testing data preparation, and management reporting. It is not like front office glamour, but the pressure is still high because it goes to senior management.

speaker: Laura
text: And because risk is like, no mistakes. In German they say, Fehlerkultur, but in banking it is like, no, there is no Fehlerkultur.

speaker: Anna
text: That is a vivid line. What are your day-to-day stressors in that environment?

speaker: Laura
text: Deadlines. Like, there are cycles, month-end, quarter-end, and then special requests. And you cannot say no, because the stakeholder is like a director or someone.

speaker: Laura
text: And also the culture is very, how to say, risk-averse and formal. So even if you do good work, you feel like it is never enough. And I have perfectionism.

speaker: Laura
text: So I will check things five times. And then I also sometimes feel lonely because most people are German or have their network already. My German is okay, like B2-ish, but in meetings it is often German, and then they switch to English for me, and I feel like, ugh, I am the reason the meeting is slower.

speaker: Laura
text: Even if nobody says it, you know.

speaker: Anna
text: That feeling of being the friction.

speaker: Laura
text: Exactly. And then also my family is in Spain. So if I have a hard week, it is not like I can just go for dinner with my parents.

speaker: Laura
text: I have friends, but adult life, everyone is busy. So yes. So the decision felt high-stakes because it touches money, identity, mental health, and also like my future story.

speaker: Laura
text: Like, who am I.

speaker: Anna
text: When did the decision become urgent?

speaker: Laura
text: Around September last year, so like four months ago. There was a reorg announcement. Not layoffs, but reorg.

speaker: Laura
text: And my manager basically told me, there is an opportunity to take more responsibility, but it will be more pressure. And at the same time I was getting messages on LinkedIn from climate startups because my profile had climate risk keywords. And then, um, I had this moment where I thought, if I say yes now, I lock myself in for at least two more years, because leaving after getting responsibility looks bad.

speaker: Laura
text: And I was already tired. So it became urgent. 3) Career support in general

speaker: Anna
text: When you need career support, who or what do you usually turn to?

speaker: Laura
text: Hmm. It changed. Earlier, like during my Master, I used university career services a bit, like CV review.

speaker: Laura
text: Not so much for deep career decisions. Then at the bank, I sometimes talk to colleagues, like informal mentoring. And I talk to friends, like friends in consulting, friends in tech.

speaker: Laura
text: And my sister in Spain, she is a psychologist, so she is good for emotional support, not career advice, but she helps me see patterns. And then, yes, I use AI. Like, very actively.

speaker: Laura
text: Especially in this decision period, it became a big thing.

speaker: Anna
text: When you say career support, what do you mean you need? Is it information, structure, reassurance, something else?

speaker: Laura
text: All of it. But I think the hardest part is rumination. Like I can research forever.

speaker: Laura
text: The internet gives you infinite stories. But then you still cannot decide. So support for me is, one, structure, and two, emotional containment, like someone to hold the anxiety without making it worse.

speaker: Laura
text: And three, reality checks, like what is realistic in Germany, what is realistic in Frankfurt.

speaker: Anna
text: What has actually helped you historically, and what felt unhelpful?

speaker: Laura
text: Helpful is when someone asks me good questions. Like, not advice immediately. Like, why do you want this, what are you afraid of.

speaker: Laura
text: Unhelpful is generic advice, like follow your passion. Or people projecting. Like a friend who hates corporate will say, just leave, corporate is evil.

speaker: Laura
text: And a colleague who is very corporate will say, startups are chaos, you will regret. That is unhelpful.

speaker: Anna
text: And where does AI fit into that ecosystem for you?

speaker: Laura
text: In normal times, AI is like productivity. Like help me draft an email, summarise a report, or explain something technical. But in that three-week period, it became almost like a coach.

speaker: Laura
text: Not in the emotional way, but in the decision structure way. And I did not expect that. 4) Human coaching: experience and trust

speaker: Anna
text: Let us talk about human coaching first. Have you ever had career coaching, like a professional coach, or something similar?

speaker: Laura
text: Not really professional. I had one short session with a coach that my bank offered, like an internal program, but it was more like career development talk. It was 45 minutes.

speaker: Laura
text: And she was nice, but it was very surface. And then I had informal mentoring with a senior colleague, like coffee chats. But not like a structured coaching relationship.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you tell me about that one session? What was it like?

speaker: Laura
text: It was on Teams. The coach was external but hired by the bank. She asked about my goals, and I said, I am not sure if I want to stay.

speaker: Laura
text: And she immediately tried to put it into a framework, like strengths, opportunities. Which is okay, but I felt she did not understand my context. Like Frankfurt risk teams have a very specific culture.

speaker: Laura
text: And also she did not know me, so in 45 minutes, it is hard. I left feeling, okay, she is supportive, but I still do not know what to do. So it was trusted in the sense she was kind, but it was not effective for my situation.

speaker: Anna
text: That is an important distinction. We can come back to that. What about informal mentoring?

speaker: Anna
text: Any episode that stands out?

speaker: Laura
text: Yes. I had a coffee with a director in another team, a woman, and she was very honest. She told me, if you want to move internally to a more climate-related risk team, you need sponsors, you need visibility, and you need to play the game a bit.

speaker: Laura
text: And I appreciated that because it was concrete and realistic. I trusted her competence because she knows the bank. But also, she is inside the system, so she also had bias, like she wants people to stay.

speaker: Anna
text: When you think about trust in a human coach or mentor, what drives that trust for you?

speaker: Laura
text: Competence and context understanding. Like do they understand Germany, the labour market, also cultural things. Second is confidentiality.

speaker: Laura
text: Like, if it is internal coaching, I am never 100 percent sure it is confidential. Third is empathy, but not like pity. More like, they can sit with ambiguity.

speaker: Laura
text: And also structure. Like they have a process. If it is just vibes, I do not trust it.

speaker: Anna
text: And what would make you distrust a human coach?

speaker: Laura
text: If they push their agenda. If they talk too much about themselves. If they make big claims, like I can guarantee you will find your purpose in two sessions.

speaker: Laura
text: That feels like marketing. And if they are not transparent about pricing and boundaries. Also if they judge.

speaker: Laura
text: Like, if they say, why are you so ungrateful, you have a good job. That would shut me down. 5) AI tools: experience and trust

speaker: Anna
text: Now let us go into AI tools. You already mentioned a three-week period. Can you walk me through how that started?

speaker: Laura
text: Yes. It started very practically. I had a Sunday where I could not relax.

speaker: Laura
text: I was on the couch, and I was scrolling LinkedIn and reading about climate jobs and reading about PhDs. And my brain was like a browser with 50 tabs. And I thought, okay, I need to do something structured.

speaker: Laura
text: And I opened ChatGPT. I had used it before for work, but not for life decisions. And I wrote something like, help me structure a decision between three paths: staying in banking, moving to a climate startup, or doing a Master or PhD.

speaker: Laura
text: And it responded with a framework, like criteria, scoring, scenario planning. And I was like, okay, this is actually what I need.

speaker: Anna
text: How often did you use it during those three weeks?

speaker: Laura
text: A lot. Like daily. Some days maybe one hour total, some days just ten minutes.

speaker: Laura
text: But it was consistent. It became like, after work, I open it, I dump my thoughts, and I ask it to reflect back. And I did it for three weeks intensively, then it reduced.

speaker: Anna
text: What made it feel coaching-like for you, as opposed to just a tool?

speaker: Laura
text: Two things. One, it forced me to make trade-offs explicit. Like, I could not just say, I want stability and meaning and money and learning.

speaker: Laura
text: It was like, okay, choose weights. And that was painful. And two, it mirrored my avoidance.

speaker: Laura
text: Like it would say, you are listing pros and cons but you are not stating what you value most, or you are using uncertainty as a reason to delay. And I was like, ugh, that is true. It felt like someone calling me out, but without judgement.

speaker: Laura
text: That is coaching-like.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you describe the decision model you built, in concrete terms?

speaker: Laura
text: Yes. So I defined five criteria. Learning and growth, values alignment, residency and stability, financial runway, and mental health.

speaker: Laura
text: And then I assigned weights. I did not do it alone, I did it with AI. It suggested a starting point, then I adjusted.

speaker: Anna
text: What weights did you end up with?

speaker: Laura
text: I ended with learning at 25 percent, values alignment at 25 percent, stability at 20 percent, financial runway at 15 percent, and mental health at 15 percent.

speaker: Anna
text: And what did stability mean for you specifically, given you are an EU citizen?

speaker: Laura
text: Good question. It is not visa in the strict sense. It is more like, job security, ability to pay rent, and also my long-term plan to maybe apply for German citizenship.

speaker: Laura
text: Like, I know as EU I can live here, but citizenship is still a thing I considered for identity and for like, feeling settled. Also stability is like, probation period risk. In a startup you have probation and it can end fast.

speaker: Laura
text: In a bank it is stable. In academia, it is like, contracts, stipends, very uncertain.

speaker: Anna
text: Okay. And then how did you use those criteria?

speaker: Laura
text: I built a scoring table. Like each path gets a score from 1 to 10 on each criterion, then multiplied by the weight. But the AI also pushed me to do scenarios, not just one score, because each path has multiple versions.

speaker: Anna
text: Yes, tell me please about the scenarios.

speaker: Laura
text: For staying in finance, I had three scenarios. One was stay in my current team and take that extra responsibility. Two was move internally to a climate risk related team, like within the bank, if possible.

speaker: Laura
text: Three was stay but negotiate boundaries, like less overtime, which is hard but possible. For climate startup, I had, one, join an early-stage startup with lower pay but high mission and learning. Two, join a scale-up, like Series B, more stable, but maybe more corporate already.

speaker: Laura
text: Join a climate consultancy or climate data vendor, like still mission but more stable. For academia, I had, one, do a Master in sustainable finance, like a second Master, which is expensive and time. Two, apply directly for a PhD in Germany, maybe funded.

speaker: Laura
text: Three, do part-time research while staying in the bank, which is like unrealistic but I included it.

speaker: Anna
text: And did you actually research real programs and real startups, or was it hypothetical?

speaker: Laura
