text: Both. The scenarios started abstract. Then in week two, it became concrete.

speaker: Laura
text: I started listing specific companies and specific programs. But I was careful, I did not put confidential bank information. And I also did not put full company names sometimes.

speaker: Laura
text: I would write like, climate fintech, Frankfurt, 50 people. Because privacy.

speaker: Anna
text: What were your trust drivers for AI in this process? What made you trust it enough to use it as a decision partner?

speaker: Laura
text: Structure and consistency. Like it does not get tired. It can hold the whole model and remember the weights.

speaker: Laura
text: Also the ability to mirror assumptions. Like it would say, you assume startup equals meaning, but is that always true. And forcing explicit trade-offs.

speaker: Laura
text: And no judgement. With humans, I sometimes feel judged, like, why would you leave a good job. With AI, I can say anything, even contradictions, and it just works with it.

speaker: Anna
text: And what were distrust drivers?

speaker: Laura
text: Mistakes. Sometimes it would say things with confidence that were not true, like a statistic or a program detail. So I learned to verify.

speaker: Laura
text: Also generic advice. Sometimes it would become like LinkedIn motivational. And missing context, like it cannot feel the Frankfurt culture.

speaker: Laura
text: It can approximate, but not fully. And privacy concerns. Like, where does this data go, who sees it.

speaker: Laura
text: So I never shared too personal or identifiable details. And also biased framing. Sometimes it pushes optimisation logic, like maximise learning, but humans are not spreadsheets.

speaker: Laura
text: So I had to correct.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you give an example of something that was effective but not fully trusted?

speaker: Laura
text: Yes. It suggested salary ranges for climate roles and also suggested which German cities have more climate startups. It was useful as a starting point, but I did not trust it.

speaker: Laura
text: I went to reality checks, like Glassdoor, LinkedIn, talking to people, and also job ads. So it was effective in giving me hypotheses, but trust was partial.

speaker: Anna
text: And an example of something you trusted but it was not effective?

speaker: Laura
text: Hmm. In AI? Or in general?

speaker: Anna
text: In general, either human or AI, as long as you make it explicit.

speaker: Laura
text: Human. My friend in Barcelona. I called her crying, like not crisis, but overwhelmed.

speaker: Laura
text: And she was very supportive. She told me, you are brave, you will figure it out, you deserve happiness. I trusted her emotionally.

speaker: Laura
text: It felt very good. But after the call, I still had no plan. So it was trusted but not effective for decision execution.

speaker: Anna
text: That is very clear. Now, can you describe how the AI outputs evolved over the three weeks? Like, what did you produce?

speaker: Laura
text: Week one was frameworks and criteria. Like, define values, define weights, build a scoring table. Week two was scenarios and risk analysis.

speaker: Laura
text: It asked me to list risks, and then mitigations. It also helped me draft outreach messages to people. Week three was the decision memo.

speaker: Laura
text: I wrote a one-page memo. The AI helped me structure it. It was like a real consulting deliverable, which is funny.

speaker: Anna
text: Tell me about that memo. What did it contain?

speaker: Laura
text: It had a headline decision statement at the top, like, I will move to a climate mission-driven role in the next three months, targeting scale-ups, while keeping a backup plan of internal move if offers do not materialise. Something like that. Then rationale, like values and learning and mental health.

speaker: Laura
text: Then risks, like financial risk, skill gap, identity risk, like leaving prestige. Then mitigations, like keep savings, upskill in climate data, talk to mentors, set timeline, and also like, if no offer by date, reconsider. And then next steps, like outreach list, applications, and a weekly plan.

speaker: Anna
text: And what was the final decision, in the end?

speaker: Laura
text: I chose the climate startup path. Specifically, I joined a climate risk analytics scale-up. It is not like 5 people in a garage.

speaker: Laura
text: It is around 120 people, offices in Germany, and they sell software to banks and insurers. So it is climate mission but still connected to my finance background. And I accepted an offer starting in March.

speaker: Laura
text: So yes, that is the final.

speaker: Anna
text: Congratulations. What made that the winning option compared to staying or academia?

speaker: Laura
text: The weighted model showed it clearly. Values alignment and learning were high, mental health was better, stability was okay because it is a scale-up not super early. Financial runway was lower than bank, but still acceptable.

speaker: Laura
text: And the biggest thing was, I realised I was using academia as an escape fantasy. Like, oh, if I do a PhD, I do not have to decide between corporate and mission because I can be intellectual. But the AI kept asking, what is your actual goal.

speaker: Laura
text: Do you want research, or do you want meaning. And I realised I want meaning and impact, not necessarily academia.

speaker: Anna
text: That moment sounds important. Can you describe a specific moment when AI surfaced an avoidance for you?

speaker: Laura
text: Yes. There was a prompt it asked me. I asked it to help me decide, and it said something like, what are you protecting by not deciding.

speaker: Laura
text: And I wrote, I am protecting my identity as someone who made the safe choice and the prestigious choice. If I leave, I lose the story. And then it asked, what is the cost of keeping that story.

speaker: Laura
text: And I wrote, burnout, loneliness, cynicism. And when I saw it in text, it was like, okay, I cannot unsee it. That was a real coaching moment.

speaker: Anna
text: And a moment where AI did not help?

speaker: Laura
text: Yes. Sometimes it pushed premature clarity. Like I would write, I feel scared, and it would respond with, then choose the option that maximises your weighted score.

speaker: Laura
text: And I was like, yes, but I am a human. It could not hold the fear. It can label it, but not contain it.

speaker: Laura
text: And sometimes it created false certainty. Like, you could get an offer in four weeks, just do these steps. And in reality, hiring cycles are slow.

speaker: Laura
text: So I had to ground it.

speaker: Anna
text: During those three weeks, did you also talk to humans? Or was it mostly AI?

speaker: Laura
text: I did both. But AI was like the backbone. Humans were like emotional support and reality check.

speaker: Laura
text: I talked to my sister, I talked to two friends, and I talked to one colleague who had moved from bank to fintech. And those conversations were important. Like, my sister helped me not panic.

speaker: Laura
text: My friend helped me feel less alone. And the colleague helped me with practical things like, negotiate contract, what to ask. So it was hybrid already.

speaker: Anna
text: You said you used AI intensively for three weeks. Did you use it in a specific way, like journaling, or like Q and A?

speaker: Laura
text: Both. I had sessions where I just brain-dumped. Like, here are my thoughts, reflect them back, ask me questions.

speaker: Laura
text: And then I had sessions where I asked for deliverables. Like, build a decision matrix, draft a message, draft a memo, generate scenarios. And I also used it to rehearse conversations, like with my manager.

speaker: Anna
text: Did that rehearsal actually influence what you said in real conversations?

speaker: Laura
text: Yes. I had to tell my manager that I am exploring. I did not want to say, I am leaving, too early.

speaker: Laura
text: But I wanted to set boundaries. The AI helped me phrase it in a professional way. And I did it.

speaker: Laura
text: And it reduced my anxiety because I had rehearsed.

speaker: Anna
text: That is an effectiveness indicator in itself. We will come back. 6) Human vs AI comparison via specific tasks

speaker: Anna
text: I would like to compare human and AI support via concrete tasks. I will name a task and you tell me what works better, and why, based on your experience. First task clarifying options.

speaker: Anna
text: Like, generating possible paths.

speaker: Laura
text: AI is better for breadth. It can generate many options quickly, and it does not get bored. Humans are better for filtering based on knowing you.

speaker: Laura
text: But if the human does not know you well, AI is more useful.

speaker: Anna
text: Second task making trade-offs explicit, like choosing criteria and weights.

speaker: Laura
text: AI, surprisingly. Because it forced me to write numbers. Humans sometimes avoid numbers because it feels too rational.

speaker: Laura
text: But in my case, the numbers helped me see what I actually value.

speaker: Anna
text: Third task reality check about the labour market in Germany, like what is realistic in Frankfurt, hiring cycles, cultural things.

speaker: Laura
text: Humans. Definitely humans. Because they have lived experience.

speaker: Laura
text: AI can summarise general patterns, but Frankfurt banking is very specific. Like the prestige and risk culture. Humans can tell you, yes, your manager will react like this.

speaker: Laura
text: Or, in startups, probation is like this. That was human.

speaker: Anna
text: Fourth task emotional support when you feel overwhelmed.

speaker: Laura
text: Human. No question. AI can say supportive words, but it feels like, eehm, empty.

speaker: Laura
text: Not always, but often. Human voice, human presence, it calms your nervous system.

speaker: Anna
text: Fifth task building an action plan, like timelines, outreach list, risk mitigations.

speaker: Laura
text: AI is very good. Because it can turn chaos into steps. And then humans can validate the steps.

speaker: Laura
text: So AI creates the plan, human makes it realistic and also holds you accountable.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you give an example of the outreach list you mentioned?

speaker: Laura
text: Yes. I created a list of around 18 people. Some were LinkedIn connections, some were second-degree, some were alumni.

speaker: Laura
text: I grouped them by category, like people in climate risk, people in climate fintech, people in academia. And I wrote short messages. The AI helped me draft the messages in a way that is polite in Germany.

speaker: Laura
text: Like, not too direct, not too long. And then I actually sent them.

speaker: Anna
text: How many responses did you get?

speaker: Laura
text: Maybe 10 responded. And I had 6 calls. And two of those calls directly led to interview processes.

speaker: Laura
text: So the plan was executed, not just theoretical.

speaker: Anna
text: That seems like strong perceived effectiveness.

speaker: Laura
text: Yes. It reduced rumination. Instead of thinking, I was doing.

speaker: Anna
text: Another task is  preparing for a difficult conversation, like with your manager or with HR.

speaker: Laura
text: AI again. It is like a simulator. You can practice, you can ask, what might they say, and how do I respond.

speaker: Laura
text: It gave me scripts. But I still adapted in real life.

speaker: Anna
text: And task of exploring deeper values and identity, like who you want to be.

speaker: Laura
text: This one is mixed. AI helped because it asked structured questions and reflected patterns. But humans help because they know my history and they can challenge me emotionally, like, you always do this.

speaker: Laura
text: AI can too, but it is more cognitive.

speaker: Anna
text: When you think about trust in these tasks, does your trust differ by task?

speaker: Laura
text: Yes. For emotional tasks, I do not trust AI fully. For structure tasks, I trust AI more.

speaker: Laura
text: But I trust it with conditions. Like I trust it to help me think, not to tell me the truth. If that makes sense.

speaker: Anna
text: Yes. Trust as appropriate reliance, not blind belief I agree.

speaker: Laura
text: Exactly. 7) Trust–effectiveness link

speaker: Anna
text: Now I want to explore the link between trust and effectiveness. In your experience, how does trust affect whether something is effective?

speaker: Laura
text: Um. Trust is like permission. If I trust the tool or the person, I will share the real problem, not the polite version.

speaker: Laura
text: And then the output is better. With AI, I trusted it enough to be honest about my fears and contradictions. But I also limited what I share because of privacy.

speaker: Laura
text: So trust is partial. And effectiveness was still high because for my decision, I needed structure more than deep emotional disclosure. If I needed therapy-level support, trust would be different.

speaker: Anna
text: So effectiveness can be high even with partial trust, depending on the task.

speaker: Laura
text: Yes. Exactly. For example, I did not fully trust it on facts, like salary numbers.

speaker: Laura
text: But it was still effective because it made me clearer and it pushed me to take action. So trust and effectiveness are related but not identical.

speaker: Anna
text: And what about the opposite? Can you have trust but low effectiveness?

speaker: Laura
text: Yes. Like the coaching session at the bank. I trusted she was kind.

speaker: Laura
text: I trusted she meant well. But it was not effective because it was generic and not contextual. Also sometimes friends.

speaker: Laura
text: I trust them, but they cannot give structure or they just say, you will be fine. That is emotionally nice but not effective for decision.

speaker: Anna
text: How did your trust in AI develop over the three weeks? Was it immediate or gradual?

speaker: Laura
text: Gradual. The first day, I was skeptical. I thought, it will give generic advice.

speaker: Laura
text: Then it surprised me with good questions. Then I started using it more. Then I had one hallucination moment, like it told me something about a German program that was wrong.

speaker: Laura
text: And that reduced trust. But I adapted by verifying. So trust became like calibrated.

speaker: Laura
text: Not more or less, but smarter.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you describe that hallucination moment?

speaker: Laura
text: Yes. I asked about a specific scholarship option for a Master in Germany. It gave me a confident answer about eligibility and deadlines.

speaker: Laura
text: And then I checked and it was wrong. And I felt, okay, this can mislead. In high stakes decisions, that is dangerous.

speaker: Laura
text: So I learned to not rely on it for factual details without checking.

speaker: Anna
text: So your trust drivers became, it is good for reasoning, not for authoritative facts.

speaker: Laura
text: Yes. Reasoning and structure, yes. Facts, verify.

speaker: Laura
text: And also privacy, be careful.

speaker: Anna
text: When you reflect on perceived effectiveness, what are your indicators? How did you know it was effective, not just engaging?

speaker: Laura
text: Clarity. Like, I could say, this is my priority order. I could articulate trade-offs.

speaker: Laura
text: Decision confidence. Not like 100 percent, but enough. Action plan execution.

speaker: Laura
text: Like, I actually did the outreach and interviews. Reduced rumination. Like, my mind was calmer.

speaker: Laura
text: And better conversations with humans. Because I came to them with a structured story, not chaos. That made humans more helpful too.

speaker: Anna
text: That last one is interesting. AI enabling better human conversations.

speaker: Laura
text: Yes. Because humans get tired if you are messy. Like, you call a friend and you are like, I do not know, I do not know, and after 20 minutes they are like, okay.

speaker: Laura
text: But if you say, I have three paths, here is what I value, can you help me reality-check this one risk, then the conversation is productive.

speaker: Anna
text: That is a very concrete mechanism.

speaker: Laura
text: Yes. 8) Preferences and hybrid model reaction

speaker: Anna
text: I will now ask you to do a short micro-poll, just quick ratings. On a scale from 0 to 10, where 0 is no trust at all and 10 is complete trust, how would you rate your trust in human career coaches, broadly?

speaker: Laura
text: Hmm. For human career coaches, I would say 6.5. Maybe 7.

speaker: Laura
text: Because I think humans can be very good, but I have not had enough experience to trust blindly. And also there are many coaches with different quality.

speaker: Anna
text: What drives that 6.5 or 7, and what prevents it from being higher?

speaker: Laura
text: Drives it higher is empathy, context, and accountability. Prevents it is uncertainty about competence and agenda. Like, are they actually good, or is it marketing.

speaker: Laura
text: And also cost. Like if you pay a lot, you want results, but results are not guaranteed. So trust is cautious.

speaker: Anna
text: Same scale, trust in AI tools for career support.

speaker: Laura
text: For AI, I would say 7.5. But it is weird. Because I trust it in a different way.

speaker: Laura
text: I trust its process, not its truth. So I give it 7.5 because it was consistent and helpful, but it is not like I trust it with my life.

speaker: Anna
text: What keeps it from being higher?

speaker: Laura
text: Hallucinations, privacy, and lack of real-world accountability. Like, it can say anything. There is no consequence.

speaker: Laura
text: A human coach has reputation. AI does not care. Also it can miss emotional context.

speaker: Anna
text: Now perceived effectiveness. On 0 to 10, how effective do you think human coaching would be for your specific situation, that three-path decision?

speaker: Laura
text: If it is a good coach, it could be 8. But based on my actual experience, I would rate 5.5. Because I did not have a strong human coaching relationship.

speaker: Laura
text: So in practice, it did not move the decision.

speaker: Anna
text: And perceived effectiveness of AI tools for that situation?

speaker: Laura
text: For my situation, I would say 9. Honestly. It enabled the final decision and action plan.

speaker: Laura
text: It did not just make me faster, it made me clearer.

speaker: Anna
text: What would have made it a 10?

speaker: Laura
text: If it could hold emotions better. Like, if it could help with fear without becoming generic. And if it could guarantee factual accuracy or show sources.

speaker: Laura
text: Then I would trust more and it would be even more effective.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you. That took about a minute, perfect.

speaker: Anna
text: Now, thinking about your preferences, if you could design the ideal support model for a person like you in that situation, would it be human-only, AI-only, or hybrid?

speaker: Laura
text: Hybrid. Definitely hybrid. AI for preparation, structure, and follow-up.

speaker: Laura
text: Human for emotional containment, accountability, and maybe like one or two key sessions to challenge blind spots.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you describe what hybrid would look like, concretely, like over a few weeks?

speaker: Laura
text: Yes. Week one, AI helps you map options, values, criteria. Then you meet a human coach to talk about emotional stuff and identity, like what is behind the decision.

speaker: Laura
text: Then AI helps you build scenarios and an action plan. Then a human helps you reality-check and also practice conversations. Then AI helps you with execution, like reminders, drafting outreach, tracking progress.

speaker: Laura
text: And then a final human session to integrate and reflect.

speaker: Anna
text: How do you feel about the idea of a platform that combines human mentors or coaches with AI support, like AI to structure and humans to support emotionally?

speaker: Laura
text: It makes sense. Because the problem is, humans are expensive and not always available. And sometimes you do not need a human for everything.

speaker: Laura
text: Like, I do not need to pay someone to build a matrix. But I would pay for someone to help me sit with fear and to see patterns. So hybrid is efficient.

speaker: Anna
text: What would you need to trust such a hybrid platform?

speaker: Laura
text: Transparency about what AI does and what humans do. Data protection. Like, where do my inputs go.

speaker: Laura
text: Also quality control of the human side. Like, who are these mentors, are they trained, do they have ethics. And also boundaries.

speaker: Laura
text: Like, do not pretend AI is a therapist. Be honest. If the platform is honest, I trust more.

speaker: Anna
text: What would make you hesitate?

speaker: Laura
text: If it feels like a black box. Or if it pushes me to share too much personal data. Or if the human is not good.

speaker: Laura
text: Like one bad mentor can ruin trust. Also if the AI outputs are generic, then why use it. It needs to be personalised, but that conflicts with privacy.

speaker: Laura
text: So that is a tension.

speaker: Anna
text: Yes, that trade-off. Personalisation versus privacy.

speaker: Laura
text: Exactly. And also, hmm, in Germany, people are sensitive about Datenschutz. I am Spanish, but living here, you absorb it.

speaker: Laura
text: 9) Closing

speaker: Anna
text: Before we wrap up, is there anything you wish you had known before starting that three-week decision sprint?

speaker: Laura
text: I wish I knew that clarity is not a feeling, but rather a result of action. Like, I thought I need to feel sure, then act. But actually I acted, then I felt more sure.

speaker: Laura
text: And AI helped me act. So I wish I had started earlier.

speaker: Anna
text: Any final thoughts on trust and effectiveness that you think are important?

speaker: Laura
text: No.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you, Laura. I will stop the recording now.

speaker: Anna
text: Hi Tobias, can you hear me well?

speaker: Tobias
text: Yes, I can hear you. Um, yes, loud and clear.

speaker: Anna
text: Great. Thanks for joining. Before we start, a couple of quick points.

speaker: Anna
text: This is a research interview about trust and perceived effectiveness in different kinds of career support, including human coaching and AI tools. It is voluntary. You can skip any question, and you can stop at any time.

speaker: Anna
text: I will keep your identity anonymous and use a pseudonym. With your permission, I would like to record this for transcription. Is that okay?

speaker: Tobias
text: Yes, that is okay. Recording is fine.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you. And just to double check, do you have any questions before we begin?

speaker: Tobias
text: Not really. I read the short info you sent. It is fine.

speaker: Anna
text: Perfect. I will start the recording now. Okay.

speaker: Anna
text: So, to warm up, could you introduce yourself a bit. Whatever feels relevant for your career situation right now.

speaker: Tobias
text: Sure. Eehm, I am Tobias, well, pseudonym Tobias, I guess. I am 28.

speaker: Tobias
text: I was born in Germany, grew up in Baden Wurttemberg, and I live in Stuttgart. I work as a junior mechanical engineer in a mid size automotive supplier. Um, and I would say I am at that stage where I have, like, enough experience to see how things work, but not enough seniority to really influence it.

speaker: Tobias
text: That is kind of the whole issue.

speaker: Anna
text: Mm. Thank you. And you are comfortable speaking mostly English, with some German words if needed?

speaker: Tobias
text: Yes. I will probably mix sometimes, like, the German company words. Like Zielvereinbarung and so on.

speaker: Anna
text: Totally fine. 2) Participant context and career situation

speaker: Anna
text: Let us start with your context. What exactly do you do in your job day to day, and what kind of company is it?

speaker: Tobias
text: Okay. So, we are a supplier, not Tier 1 like the huge ones, but also not a tiny workshop. Maybe, like, 800 people.

speaker: Tobias
text: We do components for thermal management and some structural parts. I am in the development department, Konstruktion, but it is not pure CAD all day. It is, like, a mix.

speaker: Tobias
text: Um, I do design changes, tolerance analysis, and also support testing. Like, if a part fails in testing or if we have a customer issue, then we do root cause analysis, and I have to coordinate with testing, materials, sometimes with suppliers.

speaker: Anna
text: So it is design, plus troubleshooting, plus coordination.

speaker: Tobias
text: Exactly. And supplier coordination is the part I did not expect so much. Because at university it is, like, oh you design a thing.

speaker: Tobias
text: In reality it is, you design a thing, but then you talk to three people, and the supplier says, we cannot do that radius, and purchasing says, cost too high, and the customer says, we need it yesterday.

speaker: Anna
text: That sounds very familiar for automotive.

speaker: Tobias
text: Yes. And Stuttgart is, you know, very automotive. Everybody either works directly for OEMs or for suppliers, or your neighbor does.

speaker: Tobias
text: So the culture is quite, um, how to say, traditional. Hierarchy, titles, people care about who studied where, what your grade was, who is Dr. Ing.

speaker: Tobias
text: There is a lot of respect for expertise, which is good. But also it can be very rigid.

speaker: Anna
text: When did you start in this role?

speaker: Tobias
text: I joined the company about two and a half years ago. Before that I did my master at Hochschule, actually in the region, and I did internships, Werkstudent, at another supplier. So I did not come completely blind.

speaker: Tobias
text: But still, first full time job, first time being part of a project for real.

speaker: Anna
text: If you think about the last 6 to 12 months, what has been the biggest career decision or turning point for you?

speaker: Tobias
text: Honestly, it was the decision to pay for a private career coach, and then to stop after the first session. And then, to replace that with, um, two things. One is using AI tools for reflection and preparation, and the other is asking a senior colleague to mentor me informally.

speaker: Tobias
text: That is the biggest shift. Because before, I thought, okay, I need a professional coach, like a structured thing. And now I am, like, skeptical, and I do it differently.

speaker: Anna
text: We will definitely go into that. Before we go there, can you describe what feeling stuck meant for you. Like, what did the recognition gap look like?

speaker: Tobias
text: Yes. So, the simple story is, I work a lot, I deliver, and I am still seen as, like, junior helper. That is the vibe.

speaker: Tobias
text: It is not that people are mean. It is more subtle. For example, in project meetings, I bring solutions, but then a senior engineer repeats it, and then it becomes the solution.

speaker: Tobias
text: Sorry, that sounds bitter, but it is true.

speaker: Anna
text: No need to filter. That is useful detail.

speaker: Tobias
text: Another thing is performance reviews. We have the annual review, Jahresgespraech, and there is this rating system. And you have Zielvereinbarung, and you get feedback like, you did a good job, keep going, but nothing concrete.

speaker: Tobias
text: I asked for more responsibility, like owning a module, or being the main contact for a subproject. And my manager said, yes, maybe next year, first prove yourself. And I was thinking, I am already proving myself for two years.

speaker: Anna
text: So, vague feedback, no clear pathway.

speaker: Tobias
text: Yes. And also compensation, like salary band. There are bands.

speaker: Tobias
text: And promotions are cautious. It is not like startups where you change title every year. Here it is, wait, wait, wait.

speaker: Tobias
text: Which is okay. But I wanted at least a development plan. Like, tell me what to do.

speaker: Tobias
text: And instead it was, be patient, and be visible. And I hate the word visible. Because it feels like politics.

speaker: Anna
text: Mm. What did you interpret as the main reason you were under recognized. Was it technical skill, communication, politics, or something else?

speaker: Tobias
text: It is a mix. Technically I am good, but maybe not, like, brilliant genius. But I think that is okay.

speaker: Tobias
text: I think the bigger issue is, I am not the loud guy. In meetings, I speak when I have something. I am not doing this, look at me.

speaker: Tobias
text: And in that culture, the loud ones are sometimes seen as more senior. Also, I do a lot of support work. Like, fixing issues, helping others, doing the unpleasant tasks.

speaker: Tobias
text: And that is important, but it is invisible. It is like, when everything works, nobody notices.

speaker: Anna
text: That is a very clear picture. In your mind, what were the options you were considering, before you booked coaching?

speaker: Tobias
text: I had three options. One, stay and just endure and hope it gets better. Two, move internally, like to testing or project management, maybe to get different visibility.

speaker: Tobias
text: Three, leave the company, maybe even leave the supplier world, or go into consulting, which everyone suggests in Stuttgart if you are ambitious. Like, oh you should do Beratung, you can earn more, and you see many projects.

speaker: Anna
text: And which of those felt attractive, and which felt wrong?

speaker: Tobias
text: Consulting felt wrong emotionally. Like, I respect it, but it is not me. I like building stuff, understanding a product deeply, improving it.

speaker: Tobias
text: The idea of, like, flying Monday to Thursday, making slides, telling others what to do, it felt like, not authentic. But I still had the thought because people kept saying it. Internal move was interesting, but also risky because then you lose technical path.

speaker: Tobias
text: Staying was safe but depressing. So I wanted clarity. 3.

speaker: Tobias
text: Career support in general

speaker: Anna
text: Before you went to private coaching, what kind of career support did you use in general. Mentors, friends, anything formal?

speaker: Tobias
text: Mostly informal. Friends from university, we talk. Sometimes my girlfriend, but she is in a different field, so it is more emotional support.

speaker: Tobias
text: I also talked to one former professor once, but it was a short call. And inside the company, there is something like mentoring program, but it is very, hm, formal, and you need approval. And I did not want to signal, like, I am unhappy.

speaker: Tobias
text: Also, you know, in German companies, people talk. Confidentiality is not always real, even if they say it.

speaker: Anna
text: That is important. So you did not use internal HR career services.

speaker: Tobias
text: Not really. HR is, in my perception, not for you, but for the company. That sounds cynical, but that is how it feels.

speaker: Tobias
text: They can help with forms, but not with, like, your personal strategy.

speaker: Anna
text: If you imagine ideal career support, what would it look like for you?

speaker: Tobias
text: I wanted someone who understands the industry context, like automotive supplier, and also understands personality differences. Like, not everyone should be extroverted sales person. I wanted a structured approach, but not a template.

speaker: Tobias
text: Like, ask me questions, understand my situation, and then help me plan. Also, I wanted confidentiality, and I wanted someone who can challenge me without shaming me.

speaker: Anna
text: Challenge without shaming. Can you unpack that?

speaker: Tobias
text: Yes. Like, it is okay if someone says, Tobias, you avoid conflict, you need to practice. That is challenge.

speaker: Tobias
text: But if someone says, Tobias, you are too sensitive, everyone feels that, just toughen up, then it feels like, you are not okay as you are. That is shame. And then I close.

speaker: Anna
text: That distinction will matter later, I think.

speaker: Tobias
text: Yes. 4)  Human coaching: experience and trust

speaker: Anna
text: Let us go into the private coaching experience. How did you find the coach, and why did you choose them?

speaker: Tobias
text: I found him on LinkedIn. He had a lot of content, like, posts about career acceleration, engineering to leadership, that kind of thing. He positioned himself as former consultant, now coach, and he had testimonials.

speaker: Tobias
text: He also had a website, very polished. I was, like, okay, he is professional. And he offered a package, like, three sessions, plus some worksheets, and support by email.

speaker: Anna
text: What made you believe he would fit you?

speaker: Tobias
text: He said he worked with engineers. And he spoke about structure, like, we build a strategy, we clarify your value proposition, we plan next steps. That sounded good.

speaker: Tobias
text: And he had this thing, like, engineers are undervalued because they do not market themselves. That hit me. I was, like, yes, that is me.

speaker: Anna
text: How much was the package, roughly?

speaker: Tobias
text: It was around, um, 900 euros for three sessions. Something like that. It felt expensive, but I told myself, okay, investment.

speaker: Anna
text: What were your expectations for session one?

speaker: Tobias
text: I expected that he would ask about my background, my job, what I want, what frustrates me. I expected, like, listening, and then maybe a framework. I also expected some empathy, not therapy, but, like, understanding.

speaker: Tobias
text: And I expected confidentiality.

speaker: Anna
text: Okay. Walk me through session one, in detail. Where were you, what was the format, what happened?

speaker: Tobias
text: It was on Zoom. I was at home, in my small office corner. I even took notes.

speaker: Tobias
text: I was nervous. He joined, he was very energetic, like, hi Tobias, great to meet you, we will make you unstoppable. That kind of vibe.

speaker: Tobias
text: And I was, like, okay, a bit much, but fine.

speaker: Anna
text: What happened next?

speaker: Tobias
text: He started with, like, a pitch. He talked for maybe ten minutes about his method. Like, I have a proven system, engineers go through these steps, and then they either move to consulting or leadership.

speaker: Tobias
text: He used those words a lot. Proven, system, method. And I was thinking, okay, but what about me.

speaker: Anna
text: Did you feel space to interrupt?

speaker: Tobias
text: Not really. He was talking fast. I tried to say, yes, I work in a supplier, and he was like, yes, yes, automotive, I know, very hierarchical, and then he continued.

speaker: Tobias
text: It felt like he already knew the story.

speaker: Anna
text: Was there a specific moment when trust dropped sharply for you?

speaker: Tobias
text: Yes. It was when I described my performance review. I said, I feel under recognized, I do a lot, and the feedback is vague, and I feel frustrated, and also I feel, like, maybe I am too quiet, but I do not want to play politics.

speaker: Tobias
text: And he said, literally, everyone feels that. Everyone thinks they are under recognized. It is not special.

speaker: Tobias
text: You need to stop complaining and start acting.

speaker: Anna
text: How did that land in your body, in that moment?

speaker: Tobias
text: My stomach dropped. Like, physically. I felt heat in my face.

speaker: Tobias
text: And my throat got tight. I remember I stopped breathing for a second.It felt like, okay, I made myself vulnerable, and he slapped it away. And then I became very careful.

speaker: Anna
text: What did you do after that in the conversation?

speaker: Tobias
text: I said, okay, yes, maybe. And I started to speak more generally. I did not share, for example, that I had some conflict with a senior colleague, or that I sometimes feel anxious before reviews.

speaker: Tobias
text: I was not going to give him that information after that.

speaker: Anna
text: So you moved from specifics to safer surface.

speaker: Tobias
text: Exactly. Psychological safety went down. I did not use those words then, but that is what it was.

speaker: Anna
text: What did he do after saying that?

speaker: Tobias
text: He went into, like, narrative. He asked, what is your long term goal. I said, I want to be a senior engineer, maybe lead small team, but also stay technical.

speaker: Tobias
text: And he said, okay, then the fastest route is consulting. Because in consulting you learn to communicate, you get visibility, you get salary, and then you can go back to industry at a higher level. He said it like it is obvious.

speaker: Anna
text: And how did you respond?

speaker: Tobias
text: I said, I am not sure consulting fits me. I like engineering. And he said, that is just fear.

speaker: Tobias
text: Engineers always say they like engineering, but what they really want is recognition and money, and consulting gives that. And then he did something that felt judgmental. He said, you are the typical introverted engineer who hides behind technical details, and you need to become more of a leader type.

speaker: Anna
text: That felt like a personality judgment.

speaker: Tobias
text: Yes. Because it was said with this, like, smile, like, I see through you. And I was thinking, you do not know me.

speaker: Tobias
text: Also, introverted is not a problem. And he used it like a diagnosis. Like, here is your defect.

speaker: Anna
text: Did you say anything back?

speaker: Tobias
text: Not really. I laughed awkwardly. Like, hahahah, maybe.

speaker: Tobias
text: But inside I was, like, no. And then I started to distrust his intentions. I thought, he wants to sell a narrative that fits his method, not my situation.

speaker: Anna
text: You used the word intentions. What did you think his intention was?

speaker: Tobias
text: It felt salesy. Like, he has a product, and the product is, push engineers to consulting or leadership branding. And I was not a person, I was a case.

speaker: Tobias
text: Like, case number 47. He even used examples, like, I had a client, mechanical engineer, moved to consulting, doubled salary. And I was, like, okay, but that is not necessarily my goal.

speaker: Tobias
text: Also, it felt like he was proud of that path, because he was consultant before. So he was biased.

speaker: Anna
text: That is very clear. Did he offer anything concrete in that session that you could take away?

speaker: Tobias
text: Yes, and that is the annoying part. He gave a framework that is actually not stupid. He said, you need to define your value proposition in three parts.

speaker: Tobias
text: Your technical skill, your business impact, and your leadership behaviors. And then you need to collect evidence for each, like projects, metrics, examples. He also suggested a structure for talking to your manager.

speaker: Tobias
text: Like, do not ask, can I get promotion. Instead, say, here is what I delivered, here is how it links to company goals, here is what I want next, and what support I need.

speaker: Anna
text: That sounds reasonable.

speaker: Tobias
text: It is reasonable. If someone I trust would say it, I would do it. But because he said it after invalidating me and labeling me, I did not want to engage.

speaker: Tobias
text: It felt like, if I follow his framework, I accept his worldview. And I did not want that.

speaker: Anna
text: That is a perfect example of separating usefulness from trust. Low trust, some usefulness, but you could not use it fully.

speaker: Tobias
text: Yes. I even received a PDF after the call, like worksheets. And I opened it once, and I felt annoyed.

speaker: Tobias
text: I closed it.

speaker: Anna
text: What happened at the end of session one? Was there a plan for session two?

speaker: Tobias
text: He proposed homework, like, fill in the value proposition, and next session we refine and maybe discuss consulting options. And he said, if you are serious, you need to commit. And I said, yes, okay, I will do it.

speaker: Tobias
text: But inside I was already out.

speaker: Anna
text: Did you communicate your discomfort to him?

speaker: Tobias
text: No. And that is also part of the problem. I did not trust him enough to say, hey, what you said hurt.

speaker: Tobias
text: I did not think it would be safe. I imagined he would say, see, you are sensitive. So I just avoided.

speaker: Anna
text: What did you do between session one and the next scheduled session?

speaker: Tobias
text: I did not do homework. I procrastinated. I felt stress when I saw the calendar invite.

speaker: Tobias
text: Like, I had this tight feeling. And then I wrote him an email, like, I need to pause for now due to workload. Something polite.

speaker: Tobias
text: He responded fast, like, okay, but remember, success requires consistency. It was like a motivational poster.

speaker: Anna
text: And you stopped attending.

speaker: Tobias
text: Yes. I did not go to session two. I lost the money basically.

speaker: Tobias
text: And that also made me angry at myself. Like, why did you do that.

speaker: Anna
text: If you look back, what are the key reasons trust ruptured so quickly?

speaker: Tobias
text: Three things. One, dismissal. Everyone feels that.

speaker: Tobias
text: It killed the feeling of being taken seriously. Two, pre made narrative. Consulting is the solution.

speaker: Tobias
text: He did not explore alternatives. Three, judgment. Labeling my personality in a negative way.

speaker: Tobias
text: And also, maybe a fourth, lack of boundaries. Like, he did not ask about confidentiality, he did not ask what I am comfortable sharing. He just assumed.

speaker: Anna
text: If we zoom out, what does trust mean for you in a human coach relationship. What are the drivers?

speaker: Tobias
text: Being listened to, actually listening, not waiting to speak. Confidentiality, like clear statement. Non judgment, like you can challenge but not shame.

speaker: Tobias
text: Adapting to context, like automotive supplier reality, not generic Silicon Valley story. Transparent process, like, today we do this, why we do it. And boundaries, like, what is coaching, what is not.

speaker: Tobias
text: Also not being too salesy. Like, if I feel I am a revenue stream, I cannot trust.

speaker: Anna
text: That is a strong list. What are distrust drivers, basically the opposite?

speaker: Tobias
text: Templates. Invalidation. Salesy vibe.

speaker: Tobias
text: Pushing consulting. Personality judgment. And also over confidence.

speaker: Tobias
text: Like, when someone says, I have the proven method, then I think, okay, you will not listen.

speaker: Anna
text: After that experience, how did it affect you emotionally or behaviorally when seeking support?

speaker: Tobias
text: I became more cautious. Like, I did not want to talk to another coach. I also became more careful at work.

speaker: Tobias
text: Because it confirmed this fear that if you share frustration, people will dismiss you. So I kept it inside more. But also, weirdly, it made me clearer about my boundaries.

speaker: Tobias
text: Like, now I know what I do not want.

speaker: Anna
text: Mm. That is an after effect that can be both negative and informative.

speaker: Tobias
text: Yes.

speaker: Anna
text: One more detail on this. You said the advice was not necessarily wrong, but distrust prevented depth and follow through. Can you give one example of something you did not tell him because of distrust, that could have mattered?

speaker: Tobias
text: Yes. I did not tell him about a specific incident. There was a project where a test failed, and I found the root cause and I proposed a change, and it solved it.

speaker: Tobias
text: But in the meeting, my manager presented it as the team, and my name was not mentioned. And I was really upset. I wanted to talk about that, because it is about recognition, and also about how to communicate.

speaker: Tobias
text: But after he dismissed me, I was not going to share that. That story would require vulnerability. And I knew he would probably say, everyone has that, just be louder.

speaker: Tobias
text: And I did not want that.

speaker: Anna
text: That makes sense. Okay. 5) AI tools: experience and trust

speaker: Anna
text: After you stopped the coaching, you mentioned you switched to a mix of AI reflection and a trusted senior colleague. Let us start with AI. What tools do you use, and for what exactly?

speaker: Tobias
text: Mostly ChatGPT. Sometimes also another tool integrated in the browser, but mainly ChatGPT. I use it in German and English.

speaker: Tobias
text: And I use it not for technical design, like not for CAD obviously, but for thinking and communication.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you describe a typical use case?

speaker: Tobias
text: The most common is preparation for conversations. Like, if I want to talk to my manager about development, I write a rough description of my situation, and I ask, help me structure this. What is a clear agenda.

speaker: Tobias
text: What are questions I can ask. How can I phrase it in a calm way. Because I tend to either be too emotional inside or too passive outside.

speaker: Tobias
text: AI helps me find a middle.

speaker: Anna
text: So it is like a rehearsal.

speaker: Tobias
text: Yes, rehearsal, and also clarity. It asks me questions sometimes if I prompt it that way. Like, what do you actually want.

speaker: Tobias
text: What are your constraints. And I answer, and then I see patterns. It is like journaling but more structured.

speaker: Anna
text: Do you use it for decision trade offs too?

speaker: Tobias
text: Yes. Like, should I stay and try internal move, or leave. I can list pros and cons.

speaker: Tobias
text: But I try not to let it decide. It is more, it helps me see the decision more clearly.

speaker: Anna
text: Do you use it for concrete documents?

speaker: Tobias
text: Sometimes. Like, drafting an email to a senior colleague, asking for advice. Or drafting a development plan.

speaker: Tobias
text: Or rewriting bullet points for my internal profile. We have internal systems, like, you need to write competencies. I hate writing that.

speaker: Tobias
text: AI helps.

speaker: Anna
text: How does trust play out for you with AI tools. Do you trust them?

speaker: Tobias
text: It is different. I trust it as a tool, not as a person. So trust means, is it useful, is it consistent, does it keep my data private, things like that.

speaker: Tobias
text: But emotionally, it cannot shame me. That is important. Like, AI does not say, you are too sensitive.

speaker: Tobias
text: Unless you prompt it badly.

speaker: Anna
text: That is an interesting point. So psychological safety is higher because there is no judgment vibe.

speaker: Tobias
text: Yes. I can type something stupid, and it will respond. It might be wrong, but it is not judging.

speaker: Tobias
text: So I am more open. But I also do not fully trust its advice, because sometimes it is generic, or it says confident things that are not correct.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you give an example where it was not correct or not helpful?

speaker: Tobias
text: It once suggested, like, in German companies you can just ask HR for promotion criteria and they will provide it. That is, in my experience, naive. HR will give you generic guidelines, but the real criteria are political.

speaker: Tobias
text: So I learned, do not take it literally. Another example, it sometimes suggests, just set boundaries and say no. But in a project context, you cannot just say no.

speaker: Tobias
text: You need a strategy. So I have to adapt.

speaker: Anna
text: So AI is supportive, but not a magic solution.

speaker: Tobias
text: Exactly. It is like a calculator for words. But you need to know what you want.

speaker: Anna
text: Do you have privacy concerns?

speaker: Tobias
text: Yes. I never put confidential company data. I never put names.

speaker: Tobias
text: I abstract. Like, I say, mid size supplier, manager, senior colleague. And I also do not paste internal documents.

speaker: Tobias
text: I keep it general. So trust is conditional.

speaker: Anna
text: How did you start using AI in this way. Was it directly after the coaching?

speaker: Tobias
text: Pretty much. I was angry and I needed to process. I did not want to talk to friends too much because I felt ashamed, like, I wasted money.

speaker: Tobias
text: So I wrote it into AI. Like, here is what happened, help me understand. And it gave me language.

speaker: Tobias
text: Like, it said, this sounds invalidating, and you experienced a trust rupture. And I was like, yes, exactly. It gave me words.

speaker: Anna
text: That language helped you make sense of it.

speaker: Tobias
text: Yes.

speaker: Anna
text: Do you ever miss the human element with AI. Like empathy, accountability?

speaker: Tobias
text: Accountability, yes. AI cannot make me do the thing. It can suggest.

speaker: Tobias
text: But if I am scared to talk to my manager, AI cannot look at me and say, okay, now do it. And empathy, it can simulate, but it is still, you know, not real. Sometimes I want someone to say, I see you, and mean it.

speaker: Tobias
text: AI cannot mean it.

speaker: Anna
text: That is a nice way to put it.

speaker: Tobias
text: But still, I prefer it over a bad coach. 6. Human vs AI comparison via specific tasks

speaker: Anna
text: I want to do a more concrete comparison. I will name a task, and you tell me whether you would prefer a human coach, AI tool, or a mix, and why. Ready?

speaker: Tobias
text: Yes.

speaker: Anna
text: Task one. Clarifying what you want from your career in the next one to two years.

speaker: Tobias
text: Mix. AI helps me list options and clarify values. Human, like a mentor, helps me reality check.

speaker: Tobias
text: Because AI can be too generic. Mentor can say, in this company, that path is possible or not.

speaker: Anna
text: Task two. Preparing for a conversation with your manager about recognition, promotion, or responsibilities.

speaker: Tobias
text: AI first, then human if available. AI helps structure and write. But a human who knows the politics is crucial.

speaker: Tobias
text: My senior colleague can tell me, do not phrase it like this, because manager will hear it as complaint. Or, mention this project because it is visible. AI cannot know that.

speaker: Anna
text: Task three. Emotional processing, like frustration, feeling undervalued.

speaker: Tobias
text: Honestly, AI is easier for the first draft, because no judgment. But a human friend or mentor is better if I trust them. The problem is, trust.

speaker: Tobias
text: With the coach, I did not trust, so it was useless. With AI, it is safer, but also shallow sometimes. So again, hybrid.

speaker: Anna
text: Task four. Understanding the career ladder and what skills matter for recognition in automotive supplier culture.

speaker: Tobias
text: Human, definitely. Someone inside or with deep industry knowledge. AI can give general ideas, but it does not know the informal parts.

speaker: Tobias
text: Like, who sponsors you, how you get on certain projects, how titles work. That is very specific.

speaker: Anna
text: Task five. Building a concrete plan with steps you actually execute.

speaker: Tobias
text: That is interesting. AI can produce a plan, but I might not execute. Human can create accountability.

speaker: Tobias
text: But again, only if I trust them. My senior colleague, because he is not selling me something, he is just helping, that creates accountability. So human mentor plus AI plan drafting.

speaker: Anna
text: Great. 7) Trust–effectiveness link

speaker: Anna
text: Now I want to explicitly talk about the link between trust and perceived effectiveness. In your story, it sounds like distrust prevented depth and follow through. Can you describe that mechanism in your own words?

speaker: Tobias
text: Yes. When I distrust the person, I do not share real information. I share a safe version.

speaker: Tobias
text: Then the advice is based on wrong or incomplete input. So even if the advice is good, it is not tailored. Also, I do not feel motivated to act on it, because acting feels like accepting their authority.

speaker: Tobias
text: And if I think their intentions are not aligned, I resist. So the effectiveness drops. Not because the advice is wrong, but because I do not engage.

speaker: Anna
text: That is very precise. If you compare that to higher trust situations, like with your senior colleague, what changes?

speaker: Tobias
text: I share more specifics. Like, I can say, I feel angry because my name was not mentioned. And he can respond with nuance, not dismiss.

speaker: Tobias
text: Then his advice fits. And because I trust him, I am willing to try. And then I get results.

speaker: Tobias
text: Like, I actually had better conversations.

speaker: Anna
text: So trust increases willingness to act, which increases perceived effectiveness.

speaker: Tobias
text: Exactly.

speaker: Anna
text: Can you give one example of something you actually executed because of AI preparation, and one example because of the senior colleague?

speaker: Tobias
text: AI example. I used AI to draft an agenda for my performance review follow up. Like, I asked my manager for a short check in, not the annual, but a mid year.

speaker: Tobias
text: I prepared three points. One, recap achievements with examples. Two, ask for criteria for the next level.

speaker: Tobias
text: Three, propose a next responsibility, like owning a small module. I wrote it in a calm, structured email. Before, I would write something messy or not write at all.

speaker: Tobias
text: I sent it. My manager agreed to a meeting. That happened.

speaker: Anna
text: And the senior colleague example?

speaker: Tobias
text: He helped me choose which achievements matter. I was listing technical details, like I improved tolerance stack. He said, nobody cares.

speaker: Tobias
text: He said, translate it to impact. Like, reduced rework, avoided delay, improved customer satisfaction. He also told me, mention the customer escalation you solved, because that is visible.

speaker: Tobias
text: And he told me how to say it without sounding arrogant. So in the meeting, I used that. And my manager reacted better.

speaker: Tobias
text: He actually said, okay, I see you want to move forward, let us define a plan.

speaker: Anna
text: That is a concrete outcome.

speaker: Tobias
text: Yes. It is not promotion yet. But it is movement.

speaker: Tobias
text: 8) Preferences and hybrid model reaction

speaker: Anna
text: You already described a hybrid approach. Can you tell me more about the senior colleague mentorship. How did that start, and what makes it trustworthy for you?

speaker: Tobias
text: He is a senior engineer, maybe 42, in a different team but close. We worked together on a project. He is respected, but he is not political in an aggressive way.

speaker: Tobias
text: He is calm. After my coaching disaster, I was venting a bit at lunch, carefully, and he said, if you want, we can talk. And I hesitated, because I did not want to appear weak.

speaker: Tobias
text: But he said, listen, everyone has this, but the difference is how you navigate. And he did not say it like dismissal. He said it with empathy, like, I had it too.

speaker: Anna
text: The same phrase, everyone has this, can be dismissal or connection, depending how it is said.

speaker: Tobias
text: Exactly. That is the point. The coach said it like, shut up.

speaker: Tobias
text: The colleague said it like, you are not alone. Big difference.

speaker: Anna
text: What are the boundaries of that mentorship?

speaker: Tobias
text: It is informal. We meet maybe once a month, sometimes just coffee. I do not dump everything.

speaker: Tobias
text: It is focused. I bring one topic. Like, how to talk to manager, how to move internally, what training is useful.

speaker: Tobias
text: He also said clearly, I cannot make decisions for you, and I cannot promise promotion. That transparency builds trust.

speaker: Anna
text: And confidentiality?

speaker: Tobias
text: I trust him more than internal programs because he is not HR. He is not reporting. But still, I am careful.

speaker: Tobias
text: I do not mention names when it is sensitive. But I think he respects it.

speaker: Anna
text: If you imagine a hybrid model, where AI helps you prepare, and then a human coach or mentor supports key decisions, how does that sound?

speaker: Tobias
text: That sounds ideal, if the human part is ethical and adaptive. Like, I would use AI to organize my thoughts, then the human would help contextualize and challenge me. Also, the human could help with accountability.

speaker: Tobias
text: But I would need to feel that the human is not pushing a template.

speaker: Anna
text: If a human coach could demonstrate clear boundaries, process, and adaptation, would your skepticism reduce?

speaker: Tobias
text: Yes, but slowly. I would probably ask more questions upfront now. Like, what is your approach, how do you handle confidentiality, how do you adapt.

speaker: Tobias
text: I would test. I am skeptical of marketing.

speaker: Anna
text: What would be a green flag in the first 10 minutes of a first session?

speaker: Tobias
text: A green flag is, they ask, what do you want from this, and they actually listen. They summarize my situation accurately. They do not jump to solution.

speaker: Tobias
text: They ask permission for sensitive topics. They explain the process, like today we map your situation, then we decide next steps. And they do not make me feel weird for being quiet.

speaker: Anna
text: And a red flag?

speaker: Tobias
text: Too much talking from their side. Too much success stories. Too much, I have the system.

speaker: Tobias
text: And any comment that labels my personality as a problem. 9) Micro-poll ratings

speaker: Anna
text: I want to do a very short micro poll, just quick numbers, and then I will ask you to explain. On a scale from 0 to 10, where 0 is not at all and 10 is fully, how much do you currently trust human career coaches in general?

speaker: Tobias
text: Right now, maybe 4.

speaker: Anna
text: 4 out of 10. What drives that number?

speaker: Tobias
text: I know there are good coaches. Friends had good experiences. So it is not zero.

speaker: Tobias
text: But my experience made me cautious. And I think the market has many people selling templates. So trust is low until proven.

speaker: Anna
text: On the same 0 to 10 scale, how much do you trust AI tools for career support?

speaker: Tobias
text: I would say 7.

speaker: Anna
text: 7. Why higher?

speaker: Tobias
text: Because the risk of judgment is lower, and it is consistent. It does not have ego. But it is not 10 because it can be wrong, and privacy is a concern.

speaker: Anna
text: Next, perceived effectiveness. For your situation specifically, how effective was the human coaching you experienced?

speaker: Tobias
text: For my situation, maybe 2.

speaker: Anna
text: 2 out of 10. What makes it that low?

speaker: Tobias
text: Because I did not continue, I did not do the work, I did not trust, so it did not change anything. The only effectiveness was, it taught me what I do not want, but that is not what I paid for.

speaker: Anna
text: And for AI tools, perceived effectiveness for your situation?

speaker: Tobias
text: I would say 6.

speaker: Anna
text: 6. What makes it a 6 and not higher?

speaker: Tobias
text: It helped me take steps, like preparing conversations. It gave me structure. But it cannot fully understand context and politics, and it cannot replace a human ally.

speaker: Tobias
text: Also, sometimes it is too generic.

speaker: Anna
text: Perfect. That is the micro poll. Thank you.

speaker: Anna
text: 10) Closing

speaker: Anna
text: We are coming to the end. Is there anything important about your experience that we did not cover, something you would want a researcher to understand?

speaker: Tobias
text: Nothing from my side.

speaker: Anna
text: Thank you.

speaker: Tobias
text: Thank you. It was actually helpful to talk about it.

speaker: Anna
text: I am glad. Have a good evening.

speaker: Tobias
text: You too. Bye.
